column1: ISFP	 I.ANCESTRY--BIRTH--BOYHOOD.My family is American
column2: and has been for generations
column3: in all itsbranches
column4: direct and collateral.Mathew Grant
column5: the founder of the branch in America
column6: of which I am adescendant
column7: reached Dorchester
column8: Massachusetts
column9: in May
column10: 1630.  In 1635 hemoved to what is now Windsor
column11: Connecticut
column12: and was the surveyor for thatcolony for more than forty years.  He was also
column13: for many years of thetime
column14: town clerk.  He was a married man when he arrived at Dorchester
column15: but his children were all born in this country.  His eldest son
column16: Samuel
column17: took lands on the east side of the Connecticut River
column18: opposite Windsor
column19: which have been held and occupied by descendants of his to this day.I am of the eighth generation from Mathew Grant
column20: and seventh fromSamuel.  Mathew Grant's first wife died a few years after theirsettlement in Windsor
column21: and he soon after married the widow Rockwell
column22: who
column23: with her first husband
column24: had been fellow-passengers with him and hisfirst wife
column25: on the ship Mary and John
column26: from Dorchester
column27: England
column28: in1630.  Mrs. Rockwell had several children by her first marriage
column29: andothers by her second.  By intermarriage
column30: two or three generations later
column31: I am descended from both the wives of Mathew Grant.In the fifth descending generation my great grandfather
column32: Noah Grant
column33: andhis younger brother
column34: Solomon
column35: held commissions in the English army
column37: in the war against the French and Indians.  Both were killed thatyear.My grandfather
column38: also named Noah
column39: was then but nine years old. At thebreaking out of the war of the Revolution
column40: after the battles of Concordand Lexington
column41: he went with a Connecticut company to join theContinental army
column42: and was present at the battle of Bunker Hill.  Heserved until the fall of Yorktown
column43: or through the entire Revolutionarywar.  He must
column44: however
column45: have been on furlough part of the time--as Ibelieve most of the soldiers of that period were--for he married inConnecticut during the war
column46: had two children
column47: and was a widower at theclose.  Soon after this he emigrated to Westmoreland County
column48: Pennsylvania
column49: and settled near the town of Greensburg in that county.He took with him the younger of his two children
column50: Peter Grant.  Theelder
column51: Solomon
column52: remained with his relatives in Connecticut until oldenough to do for himself
column53: when he emigrated to the British West Indies.Not long after his settlement in Pennsylvania
column54: my grandfather
column55: CaptainNoah Grant
column56: married a Miss Kelly
column57: and in 1799 he emigrated again
column58: thistime to Ohio
column59: and settled where the town of Deerfield now stands.  Hehad now five children
column60: including Peter
column61: a son by his first marriage.  Myfather
column62: Jesse R. Grant
column63: was the second child--oldest son
column64: by the secondmarriage.Peter Grant went early to Maysville
column65: Kentucky
column66: where he was veryprosperous
column67: married
column68: had a family of nine children
column69: and was drowned atthe mouth of the Kanawha River
column70: Virginia
column72: being at the time oneof the wealthy men of the West.My grandmother Grant died in 1805
column73: leaving seven children.  This brokeup the family.  Captain Noah Grant was not thrifty in the way of 'layingup stores on earth
column74: ' and
column75: after the death of his second wife
column76: he went
column77: with the two youngest children
column78: to live with his son Peter
column79: inMaysville.  The rest of the family found homes in the neighborhood ofDeerfield
column80: my father in the family of judge Tod
column81: the father of the lateGovernor Tod
column82: of Ohio.  His industry and independence of character weresuch
column83: that I imagine his labor compensated fully for the expense of hismaintenance.There must have been a cordiality in his welcome into the Tod family
column84: for to the day of his death he looked upon judge Tod and his wife
column85: withall the reverence he could have felt if they had been parents instead ofbenefactors.  I have often heard him speak of Mrs. Tod as the mostadmirable woman he had ever known.  He remained with the Tod family onlya few years
column86: until old enough to learn a trade.  He went first
column87: Ibelieve
column88: with his half-brother
column89: Peter Grant
column90: who
column91: though not a tannerhimself
column92: owned a tannery in Maysville
column93: Kentucky.  Here he learned histrade
column94: and in a few years returned to Deerfield and worked for
column95: andlived in the family of a Mr. Brown
column96: the father of John Brown--'whosebody lies mouldering in the grave
column97: while his soul goes marching on.'  Ihave often heard my father speak of John Brown
column98: particularly since theevents at Harper's Ferry.  Brown was a boy when they lived in the samehouse
column99: but he knew him afterwards
column100: and regarded him as a man of greatpurity of character
column101: of high moral and physical courage
column102: but a fanaticand extremist in whatever he advocated.  It was certainly the act of aninsane man to attempt the invasion of the South
column103: and the overthrow ofslavery
column104: with less than twenty men.My father set up for himself in business
column105: establishing a tannery atRavenna
column106: the county seat of Portage County.  In a few years he removedfrom Ravenna
column107: and set up the same business at Point Pleasant
column108: ClermontCounty
column109: Ohio.During the minority of my father
column110: the West afforded but poor facilitiesfor the most opulent of the youth to acquire an education
column111: and themajority were dependent
column112: almost exclusively
column113: upon their own exertionsfor whatever learning they obtained.  I have often heard him say thathis time at school was limited to six months
column114: when he was very young
column115: too young
column116: indeed
column117: to learn much
column118: or to appreciate the advantages of aneducation
column119: and to a 'quarter's schooling' afterwards
column120: probably whileliving with judge Tod.  But his thirst for education was intense.  Helearned rapidly
column121: and was a constant reader up to the day of his death inhis eightieth year.  Books were scarce in the Western Reserve during hisyouth
column122: but he read every book he could borrow in the neighborhood wherehe lived.  This scarcity gave him the early habit of studying everythinghe read
column123: so that when he got through with a book
column124: he knew everything init.  The habit continued through life.  Even after reading the dailypapers--which he never neglected--he could give all the importantinformation they contained.  He made himself an excellent Englishscholar
column125: and before he was twenty years of age was a constantcontributor to Western newspapers
column126: and was also
column127: from that time until hewas fifty years old
column128: an able debater in the societies for this purpose
column129: which were common in the West at that time.  He always took an activepart in politics
column130: but was never a candidate for office
column131: except
column132: Ibelieve
column133: that he was the first Mayor of Georgetown.  He supportedJackson for the Presidency; but he was a Whig
column134: a great admirer of HenryClay
column135: and never voted for any other democrat for high office afterJackson.My mother's family lived in Montgomery County
column136: Pennsylvania
column137: for severalgenerations.  I have little information about her ancestors.  Her familytook no interest in genealogy
column138: so that my grandfather
column139: who died when Iwas sixteen years old
column140: knew only back to his grandfather.  On the otherside
column141: my father took a great interest in the subject
column142: and in hisresearches
column143: he found that there was an entailed estate in Windsor
column144: Connecticut
column145: belonging to the family
column146: to which his nephew
column147: Lawson Grant--still living--was the heir.  He was so much interested in the subjectthat he got his nephew to empower him to act in the matter
column148: and in 1832or 1833
column149: when I was a boy ten or eleven years old
column150: he went to Windsor
column151: proved the title beyond dispute
column152: and perfected the claim of the ownersfor a consideration--three thousand dollars
column153: I think.  I remember thecircumstance well
column154: and remember
column155: too
column156: hearing him say on his return thathe found some widows living on the property
column157: who had little or nothingbeyond their homes.  From these he refused to receive any recompense.My mother's father
column158: John Simpson
column159: moved from Montgomery County
column160: Pennsylvania
column161: to Clermont County
column162: Ohio
column163: about the year 1819
column164: taking withhim his four children
column165: three daughters and one son.  My mother
column166: HannahSimpson
column167: was the third of these children
column168: and was then over twenty yearsof age.  Her oldest sister was at that time married
column169: and had severalchildren.  She still lives in Clermont County at this writing
column170: October5th
column172: and is over ninety ears of age.  Until her memory failed her
column173: a few years ago
column174: she thought the country ruined beyond recovery when theDemocratic party lost control in 1860.  Her family
column175: which was large
column176: inherited her views
column177: with the exception of one son who settled inKentucky before the war.  He was the only one of the children whoentered the volunteer service to suppress the rebellion.Her brother
column178: next of age and now past eighty-eight
column179: is also still livingin Clermont County
column180: within a few miles of the old homestead
column181: and is asactive in mind as ever.  He was a supporter of the Government during thewar
column182: and remains a firm believer
column183: that national success by theDemocratic party means irretrievable ruin.In June
column185: my father
column186: Jesse R. Grant
column187: married Hannah Simpson.  I wasborn on the 27th of April
column189: at Point Pleasant
column190: Clermont County
column191: Ohio.  In the fall of 1823 we moved to Georgetown
column192: the county seat ofBrown
column193: the adjoining county east.  This place remained my home
column194: until atthe age of seventeen
column196: I went to West Point.The schools
column197: at the time of which I write
column198: were very indifferent.  Therewere no free schools
column199: and none in which the scholars were classified.They were all supported by subscription
column200: and a single teacher--who wasoften a man or a woman incapable of teaching much
column201: even if they impartedall they knew--would have thirty or forty scholars
column202: male and female
column203: from the infant learning the A B C's up to the young lady of eighteenand the boy of twenty
column204: studying the highest branches taught--the threeR's
column205: 'Reading
column206: 'Riting
column207: 'Rithmetic.'  I never saw an algebra
column208: or othermathematical work higher than the arithmetic
column209: in Georgetown
column210: until afterI was appointed to West Point.  I then bought a work on algebra inCincinnati; but having no teacher it was Greek to me.My life in Georgetown was uneventful.  From the age of five or six untilseventeen
column211: I attended the subscription schools of the village
column212: exceptduring the winters of 1836-7 and 1838-9.  The former period was spent inMaysville
column213: Kentucky
column214: attending the school of Richardson and Rand; thelatter in Ripley
column215: Ohio
column216: at a private school.  I was not studious inhabit
column217: and probably did not make progress enough to compensate for theoutlay for board and tuition.  At all events both winters were spent ingoing over the same old arithmetic which I knew every word of before
column218: and repeating:  'A noun is the name of a thing
column219: ' which I had also heardmy Georgetown teachers repeat
column220: until I had come to believe it--but Icast no reflections upon my old teacher
column221: Richardson. He turned outbright scholars from his school
column222: many of whom have filled conspicuousplaces in the service of their States.  Two of my contemporaries there--who
column223: I believe
column224: never attended any other institution of learning--haveheld seats in Congress
column225: and one
column226: if not both
column227: other high offices; theseare Wadsworth and Brewster.My father was
column228: from my earliest recollection
column229: in comfortablecircumstances
column230: considering the times
column231: his place of residence
column232: and thecommunity in which he lived.  Mindful of his own lack of facilities foracquiring an education
column233: his greatest desire in maturer years was for theeducation of his children. Consequently
column234: as stated before
column235: I nevermissed a quarter from school from the time I was old enough to attendtill the time of leaving home.  This did not exempt me from labor.  Inmy early days
column236: every one labored more or less
column237: in the region where myyouth was spent
column238: and more in proportion to their private means.  It wasonly the very poor who were exempt.  While my father carried on themanufacture of leather and worked at the trade himself
column239: he owned andtilled considerable land.  I detested the trade
column240: preferring almost anyother labor; but I was fond of agriculture
column241: and of all employment inwhich horses were used.  We had
column242: among other lands
column243: fifty acres offorest within a mile of the village.  In the fall of the year chopperswere employed to cut enough wood to last a twelve-month.  When I wasseven or eight years of age
column244: I began hauling all the wood used in thehouse and shops.  I could not load it on the wagons
column245: of course
column246: at thattime
column247: but I could drive
column248: and the choppers would load
column249: and some one atthe house unload.  When about eleven years old
column250: I was strong enough tohold a plough.  From that age until seventeen I did all the work donewith horses
column251: such as breaking up the land
column252: furrowing
column253: ploughing corn andpotatoes
column254: bringing in the crops when harvested
column255: hauling all the wood
column256: besides tending two or three horses
column257: a cow or two
column258: and sawing wood forstoves
column259: etc.
column260: while still attending school.  For this I was compensatedby the fact that there was never any scolding or punishing by myparents; no objection to rational enjoyments
column261: such as fishing
column262: going tothe creek a mile away to swim in summer
column263: taking a horse and visiting mygrandparents in the adjoining county
column264: fifteen miles off
column265: skating on theice in winter
column266: or taking a horse and sleigh when there was snow on theground.While still quite young I had visited Cincinnati
column267: forty-five miles away
column268: several times
column269: alone; also Maysville
column270: Kentucky
column271: often
column272: and onceLouisville.  The journey to Louisville was a big one for a boy of thatday.  I had also gone once with a two-horse carriage to Chilicothe
column273: about seventy miles
column274: with a neighbor's family
column275: who were removing toToledo
column276: Ohio
column277: and returned alone; and had gone once
column278: in like manner
column279: toFlat Rock
column280: Kentucky
column281: about seventy miles away.  On this latter occasionI was fifteen years of age.  While at Flat Rock
column282: at the house of a Mr.Payne
column283: whom I was visiting with his brother
column284: a neighbor of ours inGeorgetown
column285: I saw a very fine saddle horse
column286: which I rather coveted
column287: andproposed to Mr. Payne
column288: the owner
column289: to trade him for one of the two I wasdriving.  Payne hesitated to trade with a boy
column290: but asking his brotherabout it
column291: the latter told him that it would be all right
column292: that I wasallowed to do as I pleased with the horses.  I was seventy miles fromhome
column293: with a carriage to take back
column294: and Mr. Payne said he did not knowthat his horse had ever had a collar on.  I asked to have him hitched toa farm wagon and we would soon see whether he would work.  It was soonevident that the horse had never worn harness before; but he showed noviciousness
column295: and I expressed a confidence that I could manage him.  Atrade was at once struck
column296: I receiving ten dollars difference.The next day Mr. Payne
column297: of Georgetown
column298: and I started on our return.  Wegot along very well for a few miles
column299: when we encountered a ferocious dogthat frightened the horses and made them run.  The new animal kicked atevery jump he made.  I got the horses stopped
column300: however
column301: before anydamage was done
column302: and without running into anything.  After giving them alittle rest
column303: to quiet their fears
column304: we started again.  That instant thenew horse kicked
column305: and started to run once more.  The road we were on
column306: struck the turnpike within half a mile of the point where the secondrunaway commenced
column307: and there there was an embankment twenty or more feetdeep on the opposite side of the pike.  I got the horses stopped on thevery brink of the precipice.  My new horse was terribly frightened andtrembled like an aspen; but he was not half so badly frightened as mycompanion
column308: Mr. Payne
column309: who deserted me after this last experience
column310: andtook passage on a freight wagon for Maysville.  Every time I attemptedto start
column311: my new horse would commence to kick.  I was in quite a dilemmafor a time.  Once in Maysville I could borrow a horse from an uncle wholived there; but I was more than a day's travel from that point.Finally I took out my bandanna--the style of handkerchief in universaluse then--and with this blindfolded my horse.  In this way I reachedMaysville safely the next day
column312: no doubt much to the surprise of myfriend.  Here I borrowed a horse from my uncle
column313: and the following day weproceeded on our journey.About half my school-days in Georgetown were spent at the school of JohnD. White
column314: a North Carolinian
column315: and the father of Chilton White whorepresented the district in Congress for one term during the rebellion.Mr. White was always a Democrat in politics
column316: and Chilton followed hisfather.  He had two older brothers--all three being school-mates of mineat their father's school--who did not go the same way.  The secondbrother died before the rebellion began; he was a Whig
column317: and afterwards aRepublican.  His oldest brother was a Republican and brave soldierduring the rebellion.  Chilton is reported as having told of an earlierhorse-trade of mine.  As he told the story
column318: there was a Mr. Ralstonliving within a few miles of the village
column319: who owned a colt which I verymuch wanted.  My father had offered twenty dollars for it
column320: but Ralstonwanted twenty-five.  I was so anxious to have the colt
column321: that after theowner left
column322: I begged to be allowed to take him at the price demanded.My father yielded
column323: but said twenty dollars was all the horse was worth
column324: and told me to offer that price; if it was not accepted I was to offertwenty-two and a half
column325: and if that would not get him
column326: to give thetwenty-five.  I at once mounted a horse and went for the colt.  When Igot to Mr. Ralston's house
column327: I said to him:  'Papa says I may offer youtwenty dollars for the colt
column328: but if you won't take that
column329: I am to offertwenty-two and a half
column330: and if you won't take that
column331: to give youtwenty-five.'  It would not require a Connecticut man to guess the pricefinally agreed upon.  This story is nearly true.  I certainly showedvery plainly that I had come for the colt and meant to have him.  Icould not have been over eight years old at the time.  This transactioncaused me great heart-burning. The story got out among the boys of thevillage
column332: and it was a long time before I heard the last of it.  Boysenjoy the misery of their companions
column333: at least village boys in that daydid
column334: and in later life I have found that all adults are not free fromthe peculiarity.  I kept the horse until he was four years old
column335: when hewent blind
column336: and I sold him for twenty dollars.  When I went to Maysvilleto school
column338: at the age of fourteen
column339: I recognized my colt as oneof the blind horses working on the tread-wheel of the ferry-boat.I have describes enough of my early life to give an impression of thewhole.  I did not like to work; but I did as much of it
column340: while young
column341: asgrown men can be hired to do in these days
column342: and attended school at thesame time.  I had as many privileges as any boy in the village
column343: andprobably more than most of them.  I have no recollection of ever havingbeen punished at home
column344: either by scolding or by the rod.  But at schoolthe case was different.  The rod was freely used there
column345: and I was notexempt from its influence.  I can see John D. White--the school teacher--now
column346: with his long beech switch always in his hand.  It was not alwaysthe same one
column347: either.  Switches were brought in bundles
column348: from a beechwood near the school house
column349: by the boys for whose benefit they wereintended.  Often a whole bundle would be used up in a single day.  Inever had any hard feelings against my teacher
column350: either while attendingthe school
column351: or in later years when reflecting upon my experience.  Mr.White was a kindhearted man
column352: and was much respected by the community inwhich he lived.  He only followed the universal custom of the period
column353: and that under which he had received his own education.

column1: ISFP	 II.WEST POINT--GRADUATION.In the winter of 1838-9 I was attending school at Ripley
column2: only ten milesdistant from Georgetown
column3: but spent the Christmas holidays at home.During this vacation my father received a letter from the HonorableThomas Morris
column4: then United States Senator from Ohio.  When he read it hesaid to me
column5: 'Ulysses
column6: I believe you are going to receive theappointment.'  'What appointment?'  I inquired.  'To West Point; I haveapplied for it.'  'But I won't go
column7: ' I said.  He said he thought I would
column8: AND I THOUGHT SO TOO
column9: IF HE DID.  I really had no objection to going toWest Point
column10: except that I had a very exalted idea of the acquirementsnecessary to get through.  I did not believe I possessed them
column11: and couldnot bear the idea of failing.  There had been four boys from ourvillage
column12: or its immediate neighborhood
column13: who had been graduated from WESTJoint
column14: and never a failure of any one appointed from Georgetown
column15: exceptin the case of the one whose place I was to take.  He was the son of Dr.Bailey
column16: our nearest and most intimate neighbor.  Young Bailey had beenappointed in 1837.  Finding before the January examination following
column17: that he could not pass
column18: he resigned and went to a private school
column19: andremained there until the following year
column20: when he was reappointed.Before the next examination he was dismissed.  Dr. Bailey was a proudand sensitive man
column21: and felt the failure of his son so keenly that heforbade his return home.  There were no telegraphs in those days todisseminate news rapidly
column22: no railroads west of the Alleghanies
column23: and butfew east; and above all
column24: there were no reporters prying into otherpeople's private affairs.  Consequently it did not become generallyknown that there was a vacancy at West Point from our district until Iwas appointed.  I presume Mrs. Bailey confided to my mother the factthat Bartlett had been dismissed
column25: and that the doctor had forbidden hisson's return home.The Honorable Thomas L. Hamer
column26: one of the ablest men Ohio ever produced
column27: was our member of Congress at the time
column28: and had the right of nomination.He and my father had been members of the same debating society (wherethey were generally pitted on opposite sides)
column29: and intimate personalfriends from their early manhood up to a few years before.  In politicsthey differed. Hamer was a life-long Democrat
column30: while my father was aWhig. They had a warm discussion
column31: which finally became angry--over someact of President Jackson
column32: the removal of the deposit of public moneys
column33: Ithink--after which they never spoke until after my appointment.  I knowboth of them felt badly over this estrangement
column34: and would have been gladat any time to come to a reconciliation; but neither would make theadvance.  Under these circumstances my father would not write to Hamerfor the appointment
column35: but he wrote to Thomas Morris
column36: United StatesSenator from Ohio
column37: informing him that there was a vacancy at West Pointfrom our district
column38: and that he would be glad if I could be appointed tofill it.  This letter
column39: I presume
column40: was turned over to Mr. Hamer
column41: and
column42: asthere was no other applicant
column43: he cheerfully appointed me.  This healedthe breach between the two
column44: never after reopened.Besides the argument used by my father in favor of my going to WESTJoint--that 'he thought I would go'--there was another very stronginducement.  I had always a great desire to travel.  I was already thebest travelled boy in Georgetown
column45: except the sons of one man
column46: JohnWalker
column47: who had emigrated to Texas with his family
column48: and immigrated backas soon as he could get the means to do so.  In his short stay in Texashe acquired a very different opinion of the country from what one wouldform going there now.I had been east to Wheeling
column49: Virginia
column50: and north to the Western Reserve
column51: in Ohio
column52: west to Louisville
column53: and south to Bourbon County
column54: Kentucky
column55: besides having driven or ridden pretty much over the whole countrywithin fifty miles of home.  Going to West Point would give me theopportunity of visiting the two great cities of the continent
column56: Philadelphia and New York.  This was enough.  When these places werevisited I would have been glad to have had a steamboat or railroadcollision
column57: or any other accident happen
column58: by which I might have receiveda temporary injury sufficient to make me ineligible
column59: for a time
column60: toenter the Academy.  Nothing of the kind occurred
column61: and I had to face themusic.Georgetown has a remarkable record for a western village.  It is
column62: andhas been from its earliest existence
column63: a democratic town.  There wasprobably no time during the rebellion when
column64: if the opportunity couldhave been afforded
column65: it would not have voted for Jefferson Davis forPresident of the United States
column66: over Mr. Lincoln
column67: or any otherrepresentative of his party; unless it was immediately after some ofJohn Morgan's men
column68: in his celebrated raid through Ohio
column69: spent a fewhours in the village.  The rebels helped themselves to whatever theycould find
column70: horses
column71: boots and shoes
column72: especially horses
column73: and many orderedmeals to be prepared for them by the families.  This was no doubt a farpleasanter duty for some families than it would have been to render alike service for Union soldiers.  The line between the Rebel and Unionelement in Georgetown was so marked that it led to divisions even in thechurches.  There were churches in that part of Ohio where treason waspreached regularly
column74: and where
column75: to secure membership
column76: hostility to thegovernment
column77: to the war and to the liberation of the slaves
column78: was far moreessential than a belief in the authenticity or credibility of the Bible.There were men in Georgetown who filled all the requirements formembership in these churches.Yet this far-off western village
column79: with a population
column80: including old andyoung
column81: male and female
column82: of about one thousand--about enough for theorganization of a single regiment if all had been men capable of bearingarms--furnished the Union army four general officers and one colonel
column83: West Point graduates
column84: and nine generals and field officers ofVolunteers
column85: that I can think of. Of the graduates from West Point
column86: allhad citizenship elsewhere at the breaking out of the rebellion
column87: exceptpossibly General A. V. Kautz
column88: who had remained in the army from hisgraduation.  Two of the colonels also entered the service from otherlocalities.  The other seven
column89: General McGroierty
column90: Colonels White
column91: Fyffe
column92: Loudon and Marshall
column93: Majors King and Bailey
column94: were all residents ofGeorgetown when the war broke out
column95: and all of them
column96: who were alive atthe close
column97: returned there.  Major Bailey was the cadet who had precededme at West Point.  He was killed in West Virginia
column98: in his firstengagement.  As far as I know
column99: every boy who has entered West Point fromthat village since my time has been graduated.I took passage on a steamer at Ripley
column100: Ohio
column101: for Pittsburg
column102: about themiddle of May
column103: 1839.  Western boats at that day did not make regulartrips at stated times
column104: but would stop anywhere
column105: and for any length oftime
column106: for passengers or freight.  I have myself been detained two orthree days at a place after steam was up
column107: the gang planks
column108: all but one
column109: drawn in
column110: and after the time advertised for starting had expired.  Onthis occasion we had no vexatious delays
column111: and in about three daysPittsburg was reached.  From Pittsburg I chose passage by the canal toHarrisburg
column112: rather than by the more expeditious stage.  This gave abetter opportunity of enjoying the fine scenery of Western Pennsylvania
column113: and I had rather a dread of reaching my destination at all.  At thattime the canal was much patronized by travellers
column114: and
column115: with thecomfortable packets of the period
column116: no mode of conveyance could be morepleasant
column117: when time was not an object.  From Harrisburg to Philadelphiathere was a railroad

Most of my time was spent among my oldschool-mates--these ten weeks were shorter than one week at West Point.Persons acquainted with the Academy know that the corps of cadets isdivided into four companies for the purpose of military exercises.These companies are officered from the cadets

That year my standing in the class--as shown by thenumber of demerits of the year--was about the same as it was among thesergeants

The troops were embarked on steamers and were on their way downthe Mississippi within a few days after the receipt of this order.About the time they started I obtained a leave of absence for twentydays to go to Ohio to visit my parents.  I was obliged to go to St.Louis to take a steamer for Louisville or Cincinnati

column141: or the later rebuke for wearing uniform clothes.The 3d infantry had selected camping grounds on the reservation at FortJessup
column142: about midway between the Red River and the Sabine.  Our ordersrequired us to go into camp in the same neighborhood
column143: and await furtherinstructions.  Those authorized to do so selected a place in the pinewoods

column147: and proved entitled to it. The campwas on a high
column148: sandy
column149: pine ridge
column150: with spring branches in the valley
column151: infront and rear.  The springs furnished an abundance of cool
column152: pure water
column153: and the ridge was above the flight of mosquitoes
column154: which abound in thatregion in great multitudes and of great voracity.  In the valley theyswarmed in myriads
column155: but never came to the summit of the ridge.  Theregiment occupied this camp six months before the first death occurred
column156: and that was caused by an accident.There was no intimation given that the removal of the 3d and 4thregiments of infantry to the western border of Louisiana was occasionedin any way by the prospective annexation of Texas
column157: but it was generallyunderstood that such was the case. Ostensibly we were intended toprevent filibustering into Texas
column158: but really as a menace to Mexico incase she appeared to contemplate war.  Generally the officers of thearmy were indifferent whether the annexation was consummated or not; butnot so all of them.  For myself
column159: I was bitterly opposed to the measure
column160: and to this day regard the war
column161: which resulted
column162: as one of the mostunjust ever waged by a stronger against a weaker nation.  It was aninstance of a republic following the bad example of European monarchies
column163: in not considering justice in their desire to acquire additionalterritory.  Texas was originally a state belonging to the republic ofMexico.  It extended from the Sabine River on the east to the Rio Grandeon the west
column164: and from the Gulf of Mexico on the south and east to theterritory of the United States and New Mexico--another Mexican state atthat time--on the north and west.  An empire in territory
column165: it had but avery sparse population
column166: until settled by Americans who had receivedauthority from Mexico to colonize. These colonists paid very littleattention to the supreme government
column167: and introduced slavery into thestate almost from the start
column168: though the constitution of Mexico did not
column169: nor does it now
column170: sanction that institution.  Soon they set up anindependent government of their own
column171: and war existed
column172: between Texas andMexico
column173: in name from that time until 1836
column174: when active hostilities verynearly ceased upon the capture of Santa Anna
column175: the Mexican President.Before long
column176: however
column177: the same people--who with permission of Mexico hadcolonized Texas
column178: and afterwards set up slavery there
column179: and then secededas soon as they felt strong enough to do so--offered themselves and theState to the United States
column180: and in 1845 their offer was accepted.  Theoccupation
column181: separation and annexation were
column182: from the inception of themovement to its final consummation
column183: a conspiracy to acquire territoryout of which slave states might be formed for the American Union.Even if the annexation itself could be justified
column184: the manner in whichthe subsequent war was forced upon Mexico cannot.  The fact is
column185: annexationists wanted more territory than they could possibly lay anyclaim to
column186: as part of the new acquisition. Texas
column187: as an independentState
column188: never had exercised jurisdiction over the territory between theNueces River and the Rio Grande. Mexico had never recognized theindependence of Texas
column189: and maintained that
column190: even if independent
column191: theState had no claim south of the Nueces.  I am aware that a treaty
column192: madeby the Texans with Santa Anna while he was under duress
column193: ceded all theterritory between the Nueces and the Rio Grande--
column194: but he was a prisonerof war when the treaty was made
column195: and his life was in jeopardy.  He knew
column196: too
column197: that he deserved execution at the hands of the Texans
column198: if theyshould ever capture him.  The Texans
column199: if they had taken his life
column200: wouldhave only followed the example set by Santa Anna himself a few yearsbefore
column201: when he executed the entire garrison of the Alamo and thevillagers of Goliad.In taking military possession of Texas after annexation
column202: the army ofoccupation
column203: under General Taylor
column204: was directed to occupy the disputedterritory.  The army did not stop at the Nueces and offer to negotiatefor a settlement of the boundary question
column205: but went beyond
column206: apparentlyin order to force Mexico to initiate war.  It is to the credit of theAmerican nation
column207: however
column208: that after conquering Mexico
column209: and whilepractically holding the country in our possession
column210: so that we could haveretained the whole of it
column211: or made any terms we chose
column212: we paid a roundsum for the additional territory taken; more than it was worth
column213: or waslikely to be
column214: to Mexico.  To us it was an empire and of incalculablevalue; but it might have been obtained by other means.  The Southernrebellion was largely the outgrowth of the Mexican war.  Nations
column215: likeindividuals
column216: are punished for their transgressions.  We got ourpunishment in the most sanguinary and expensive war of modern times.The 4th infantry went into camp at Salubrity in the month of May
column218: with instructions
column219: as I have said

column221: officers and men occupied ordinary tents.  As the summer heat increasedthese were covered by sheds to break the rays of the sun.  The summerwas whiled away in social enjoyments among the officers

column223: and near

Generallylieutenants were appointed to captaincies to fill vacancies in the staffcorps.  If they should reach a captaincy in the line before they arrivedat a majority in the staff

column251: and a war
