column136: which these last seemedto regard as a most unwarrantable attempt at coercion and would resistby taking a seat
column137: sometimes going so far as to lie down.  In time allwere broken in to do their duty submissively if not cheerfully
column138: butthere never was a time during the war when it was safe to let a Mexicanmule get entirely loose.  Their drivers were all teamsters by the timethey got through.I recollect one case of a mule that had worked in a team under thesaddle
column139: not only for some time at Corpus Christi
column140: where he was broken
column141: but all the way to the point opposite Matamoras
column142: then to Camargo
column143: wherehe got loose from his fastenings during the night.  He did not run awayat first
column144: but staid in the neighborhood for a day or two
column145: coming upsometimes to the feed trough even; but on the approach of the teamsterhe always got out of the way.  At last
column146: growing tired of the constanteffort to catch him
column147: he disappeared altogether.  Nothing short of aMexican with his lasso could have caught him.  Regulations would nothave warranted the expenditure of a dollar in hiring a man with a lassoto catch that mule; but they did allow the expenditure 'of the mule
column148: ' ona certificate that he had run away without any fault of thequartermaster on whose returns he was borne
column149: and also the purchase ofanother to take his place.  I am a competent witness
column150: for I wasregimental quartermaster at the time.While at Corpus Christi all the officers who had a fancy for riding kepthorses.  The animals cost but little in the first instance
column151: and whenpicketed they would get their living without any cost.  I had three notlong before the army moved
column152: but a sad accident bereft me of them all atone time.  A colored boy who gave them all the attention they got--besides looking after my tent and that of a class-mate andfellow-lieutenant and cooking for us
column153: all for about eight dollars permonth
column154: was riding one to water and leading the other two.  The ledhorses pulled him from his seat and all three ran away.  They never wereheard of afterwards.  Shortly after that some one told Captain Bliss
column155: General Taylor's Adjutant-General
column156: of my misfortune.  'Yes; I heardGrant lost five or six dollars' worth of horses the other day
column157: ' hereplied.  That was a slander; they were broken to the saddle when I gotthem and cost nearly twenty dollars.  I never suspected the colored boyof malicious intent in letting them get away
column158: because
column159: if they had notescaped
column160: he could have had one of them to ride on the long march then inprospect.

column1: ISFP	 VI.ADVANCE OF THE ARMY--CROSSING THE COLORADO--THE RIO GRANDE.At last the preparations were complete and orders were issued for theadvance to begin on the 8th of March.  General Taylor had an army of notmore than three thousand men.  One battery
column2: the siege guns and all theconvalescent troops were sent on by water to Brazos Santiago
column3: at themouth of the Rio Grande.  A guard was left back at Corpus Christi tolook after public property and to take care of those who were too sickto be removed.  The remainder of the army
column4: probably not more than twentyfive hundred men
column5: was divided into three brigades
column6: with the cavalryindependent.  Colonel Twiggs
column7: with seven companies of dragoons and abattery of light artillery
column8: moved on the 8th.  He was followed by thethree infantry brigades
column9: with a day's interval between the commands.Thus the rear brigade did not move from Corpus Christi until the 11th ofMarch.  In view of the immense bodies of men moved on the same day overnarrow roads
column10: through dense forests and across large streams
column11: in ourlate war
column12: it seems strange now that a body of less than three thousandmen should have been broken into four columns
column13: separated by a day'smarch.General Taylor was opposed to anything like plundering by the troops
column14: and in this instance
column15: I doubt not
column16: he looked upon the enemy as theaggrieved party and was not willing to injure them further than hisinstructions from Washington demanded.  His orders to the troopsenjoined scrupulous regard for the rights of all peaceable persons andthe payment of the highest price for all supplies taken for the use ofthe army.All officers of foot regiments who had horses were permitted to ridethem on the march when it did not interfere with their military duties.As already related
column17: having lost my 'five or six dollars' worth ofhorses' but a short time before I determined not to get another
column18: but tomake the journey on foot.  My company commander
column19: Captain McCall
column20: had twogood American horses
column21: of considerably more value in that country
column22: wherenative horses were cheap
column23: than they were in the States. He used onehimself and wanted the other for his servant.  He was quite anxious toknow whether I did not intend to get me another horse before the marchbegan.  I told him No; I belonged to a foot regiment.  I did notunderstand the object of his solicitude at the time
column24: but
column25: when we wereabout to start
column26: he said:  'There
column27: Grant
column28: is a horse for you.'  I foundthat he could not bear the idea of his servant riding on a long marchwhile his lieutenant went a-foot.  He had found a mustang
column29: a three-yearold colt only recently captured
column30: which had been purchased by one of thecolored servants with the regiment for the sum of three dollars.  It wasprobably the only horse at Corpus Christi that could have been purchasedjust then for any reasonable price.  Five dollars
column31: sixty-six andtwo-thirds per cent. advance
column32: induced the owner to part with themustang.  I was sorry to take him
column33: because I really felt that
column34: belongingto a foot regiment
column35: it was my duty to march with the men.  But I saw theCaptain's earnestness in the matter
column36: and accepted the horse for thetrip.  The day we started was the first time the horse had ever beenunder saddle. I had
column37: however
column38: but little difficulty in breaking him
column39: though for the first day there were frequent disagreements between us asto which way we should go
column40: and sometimes whether we should go at all.At no time during the day could I choose exactly the part of the columnI would march with; but after that
column41: I had as tractable a horse as anywith the army
column42: and there was none that stood the trip better. He neverate a mouthful of food on the journey except the grass he could pickwithin the length of his picket rope.A few days out from Corpus Christi
column43: the immense herd of wild horses thatranged at that time between the Nueces and the Rio Grande was seendirectly in advance of the head of the column and but a few miles off.It was the very band from which the horse I was riding had been capturedbut a few weeks before. The column was halted for a rest
column44: and a numberof officers
column45: myself among them
column46: rode out two or three miles to the rightto see the extent of the herd.  The country was a rolling prairie
column47: and
column48: from the higher ground
column49: the vision was obstructed only by the earth'scurvature.  As far as the eye could reach to our right
column50: the herdextended.  To the left
column51: it extended equally. There was no estimating thenumber of animals in it; I have no idea that they could all have beencorralled in the State of Rhode Island
column52: or Delaware
column53: at one time.  Ifthey had been
column54: they would have been so thick that the pasturage wouldhave given out the first day. People who saw the Southern herd ofbuffalo
column55: fifteen or twenty years ago
column56: can appreciate the  size of theTexas band of wild horses in 1846.At the point where the army struck the Little Colorado River
column57: the streamwas quite wide and of sufficient depth for navigation. The water wasbrackish and the banks were fringed with timber. Here the whole armyconcentrated before attempting to cross. The army was not accompanied bya pontoon train
column58: and at that time the troops were not instructed inbridge building.  To add to the embarrassment of the situation
column59: the armywas here
column60: for the first time
column61: threatened with opposition. Buglers
column62: concealed from our view by the brush on the opposite side
column63: sounded the'assembly
column64: ' and other military calls.  Like the wolves before spoken of
column65: they gave the impression that there was a large number of them and that
column66: if the troops were in proportion to the noise
column67: they were sufficient todevour General Taylor and his army.  There were probably but few troops
column68: and those engaged principally in watching the movements of the'invader.'  A few of our cavalry dashed in
column69: and forded and swam thestream
column70: and all opposition was soon dispersed.  I do not remember that asingle shot was fired.The troops waded the stream
column71: which was up to their necks in the deepESTJart.  Teams were crossed by attaching a long rope to the end of thewagon tongue passing it between the two swing mules and by the side ofthe leader
column72: hitching his bridle as well as the bridle of the mules inrear to it
column73: and carrying the end to men on the opposite shore.  The bankdown to the water was steep on both sides.  A rope long enough to crossthe river
column74: therefore
column75: was attached to the back axle of the wagon
column76: andmen behind would hold the rope to prevent the wagon 'beating' the mulesinto the water.  This latter rope also served the purpose of bringingthe end of the forward one back
column77: to be used over again.  The water wasdeep enough for a short distance to swim the little Mexican mules whichthe army was then using
column78: but they
column79: and the wagons
column80: were pulled throughso fast by the men at the end of the rope ahead
column81: that no time was leftthem to show their obstinacy.  In this manner the artillery andtransportation of the 'army of occupation' crossed the Colorado River.About the middle of the month of March the advance of the army reachedthe Rio Grande and went into camp near the banks of the river
column82: oppositethe city of Matamoras and almost under the guns of a small fort at thelower end of the town.  There was not at that time a single habitationfrom Corpus Christi until the Rio Grande was reached.The work of fortifying was commenced at once.  The fort was laid out bythe engineers
column83: but the work was done by the soldiers under thesupervision of their officers
column84: the chief engineer retaining generaldirections.  The Mexicans now became so incensed at our near approachthat some of their troops crossed the river above us
column85: and made it unsafefor small bodies of men to go far beyond the limits of camp.  Theycaptured two companies of dragoons
column86: commanded by Captains Thornton andHardee.  The latter figured as a general in the late war
column87: on theConfederate side
column88: and was author of the tactics first used by botharmies.  Lieutenant Theodric Porter
column89: of the 4th infantry
column90: was killedwhile out with a small detachment; and Major Cross
column91: the assistantquartermaster-general
column92: had also been killed not far from camp.There was no base of supplies nearer than Point Isabel
column93: on the coast
column94: north of the mouth of the Rio Grande and twenty-five miles away.  Theenemy
column95: if the Mexicans could be called such at this time when no war hadbeen declared
column96: hovered about in such numbers that it was not safe tosend a wagon train after supplies with any escort that could be spared.I have already said that General Taylor's whole command on the RioGrande numbered less than three thousand men.  He had
column97: however
column98: a fewmore troops at Point Isabel or Brazos Santiago.  The supplies broughtfrom Corpus Christi in wagons were running short.  Work was thereforepushed with great vigor on the defences
column99: to enable the minimum number oftroops to hold the fort.  All the men who could be employed
column100: were keptat work from early dawn until darkness closed the labors of the day.With all this the fort was not completed until the supplies grew soshort that further delay in obtaining more could not be thought of.  Bythe latter part of April the work was in a partially defensiblecondition
column101: and the 7th infantry
column102: Major Jacob Brown commanding
column103: wasmarched in to garrison it
column104: with some few pieces of artillery.  All thesupplies on hand
column105: with the exception of enough to carry the rest of thearmy to Point Isabel
column106: were left with the garrison
column107: and the march wascommenced with the remainder of the command
column108: every wagon being takenwith the army.  Early on the second day after starting the force reachedits destination
column109: without opposition from the Mexicans.  There was somedelay in getting supplies ashore from vessels at anchor in the openroadstead.

column1: ISFP	 VII.THE MEXICAN WAR--THE BATTLE OF PALO ALTO--THE BATTLE OF RESACA DE LAPALMA--ARMY OF INVASION--GENERAL TAYLOR--MOVEMENT ON CAMARGO.While General Taylor was away with the bulk of his army
column2: the littlegarrison up the river was besieged.  As we lay in our tents upon thesea-shore
column3: the artillery at the fort on the Rio Grande could bedistinctly heard.The war had begun.There were no possible means of obtaining news from the garrison
column4: andinformation from outside could not be otherwise than unfavorable.  WhatGeneral Taylor's feelings were during this suspense I do not know; butfor myself
column5: a young second-lieutenant who had never heard a hostile gunbefore
column6: I felt sorry that I had enlisted.  A great many men
column7: when theysmell battle afar off
column8: chafe to get into the fray.  When they say sothemselves they generally fail to convince their hearers that they areas anxious as they would like to make believe
column9: and as they approachdanger they become more subdued.  This rule is not universal
column10: for I haveknown a few men who were always aching for a fight when there was noenemy near
column11: who were as good as their word when the battle did come.But the number of such men is small.On the 7th of May the wagons were all loaded and General Taylor startedon his return
column12: with his army reinforced at Point Isabel
column13: but still lessthan three thousand strong
column14: to relieve the garrison on the Rio Grande.The road from Point Isabel to Matamoras is over an open
column15: rolling
column16: treeless prairie
column17: until the timber that borders the bank of the RioGrande is reached.  This river
column18: like the Mississippi
column19: flows through arich alluvial valley in the most meandering manner
column20: running towards allpoints of the compass at times within a few miles.  Formerly the riverran by Resaca de la Palma
column21: some four or five miles east of the presentchannel.  The old bed of the river at Resaca had become filled atplaces
column22: leaving a succession of little lakes.  The timber that hadformerly grown upon both banks
column23: and for a considerable distance out
column24: wasstill standing.  This timber was struck six or eight miles out from thebesieged garrison
column25: at a point known as Palo Alto--'Tall trees' or'woods.'Early in the forenoon of the 8th of May as Palo Alto was approached
column26: anarmy
column27: certainly outnumbering our little force
column28: was seen
column29: drawn up inline of battle just in front of the timber.  Their bayonets andspearheads glistened in the sunlight formidably.  The force was composedlargely of cavalry armed with lances.  Where we were the grass was tall
column30: reaching nearly to the shoulders of the men
column31: very stiff
column32: and each stockwas pointed at the top
column33: and hard and almost as sharp as adarning-needle. General Taylor halted his army before the head of columncame in range of the artillery of the Mexicans.  He then formed a lineof battle
column34: facing the enemy.  His artillery
column35: two batteries and twoeighteen-pounder iron guns
column36: drawn by oxen
column37: were placed in position atintervals along the line.  A battalion was thrown to the rear
column38: commandedby Lieutenant-Colonel Childs
column39: of the artillery
column40: as reserves.  Thesepreparations completed
column41: orders were given for a platoon of each companyto stack arms and go to a stream off to the right of the command
column42: tofill their canteens and also those of the rest of their respectivecompanies.  When the men were all back in their places in line
column43: thecommand to advance was given.  As I looked down that long line of aboutthree thousand armed men
column44: advancing towards a larger force also armed
column45: I thought what a fearful responsibility General Taylor must feel
column46: commanding such a host and so far away from friends.  The Mexicansimmediately opened fire upon us
column47: first with artillery and then withinfantry.  At first their shots did not reach us
column48: and the advance wascontinued.  As we got nearer
column49: the cannon balls commenced going throughthe ranks.  They hurt no one
column50: however
column51: during this advance
column52: because theywould strike the ground long before they reached our line
column53: andricochetted through the tall grass so slowly that the men would see themand open ranks and let them pass.  When we got to a point where theartillery could be used with effect
column54: a halt was called
column55: and the battleopened on both sides.The infantry under General Taylor was armed with flint-lock muskets
column56: andpaper cartridges charged with powder
column57: buck-shot and ball.  At thedistance of a few hundred yards a man might fire at you all day withoutyour finding it out.  The artillery was generally six-pounder brass gunsthrowing only solid shot; but General Taylor had with him three or fourtwelve-pounder howitzers throwing shell
column58: besides his eighteen-poundersbefore spoken of
column59: that had a long range.  This made a powerful armament.The Mexicans were armed about as we were so far as their infantry wasconcerned
column60: but their artillery only fired solid shot.  We had greatlythe advantage in this arm.The artillery was advanced a rod or two in front of the line
column61: and openedfire.  The infantry stood at order arms as spectators
column62: watching theeffect of our shots upon the enemy
column63: and watching his shots so as to stepout of their way.  It could be seen that the eighteen-pounders and thehowitzers did a great deal of execution.  On our side there was littleor no loss while we occupied this position.  During the battle MajorRinggold
column64: an accomplished and brave artillery officer
column65: was mortallywounded
column66: and Lieutenant Luther
column67: also of the artillery
column68: was struck.During the day several advances were made
column69: and just at dusk it becameevident that the Mexicans were falling back. We again advanced
column70: andoccupied at the close of the battle substantially the ground held by theenemy at the beginning.  In this last move there was a brisk fire uponour troops
column71: and some execution was done.  One cannon-ball passed throughour ranks
column72: not far from me.  It took off the head of an enlisted man
column73: and the under jaw of Captain Page of my regiment
column74: while the splintersfrom the musket of the killed soldier
column75: and his brains and bones
column76: knockeddown two or three others
column77: including one officer
column78: Lieutenant Wallen
column79: --hurting them more or less.  Our casualties for the day were nine killedand forty-seven wounded.At the break of day on the 9th
column80: the army under Taylor was ready to renewthe battle; but an advance showed that the enemy had entirely left ourfront during the night.  The chaparral before us was impenetrable exceptwhere there were roads or trails
column81: with occasionally clear or bare spotsof small dimensions.  A body of men penetrating it might easily beambushed.  It was better to have a few men caught in this way than thewhole army
column82: yet it was necessary that the garrison at the river shouldbe relieved.  To get to them the chaparral had to be passed.  Thus Iassume General Taylor reasoned.  He halted the army not far in advanceof the ground occupied by the Mexicans the day before
column83: and selectedCaptain C. F. Smith
column84: of the artillery
column85: and Captain McCall
column86: of mycompany
column87: to take one hundred and fifty picked men each and find wherethe enemy had gone.  This left me in command of the company
column88: an honorand responsibility I thought very great.Smith and McCall found no obstruction in the way of their advance untilthey came up to the succession of ponds
column89: before describes
column90: at Resaca.The Mexicans had passed them and formed their lines on the oppositebank.  This position they had strengthened a little by throwing up deadtrees and brush in their front
column91: and by placing artillery to cover theapproaches and open places.  Smith and McCall deployed on each side ofthe road as well as they could
column92: and engaged the enemy at long range.Word was sent back
column93: and the advance of the whole army was at oncecommenced.  As we came up we were deployed in like manner.  I was withthe right wing
column94: and led my company through the thicket wherever apenetrable place could be found
column95: taking advantage of any clear spot thatwould carry me towards the enemy.  At last I got pretty close up withoutknowing it.  The balls commenced to whistle very thick overhead
column96: cuttingthe limbs of the chaparral right and left.  We could not see the enemy
column97: so I ordered my men to lie down
column98: an order that did not have to beenforced.  We kept our position until it became evident that the enemywere not firing at us
column99: and then withdrew to find better ground toadvance upon.By this time some progress had been made on our left.  A section ofartillery had been captured by the cavalry
column100: and some prisoners had beentaken.  The Mexicans were giving way all along the line
column101: and many ofthem had
column102: no doubt
column103: left early.  I at last found a clear spaceseparating two ponds.  There seemed to be a few men in front and Icharged upon them with my company.There was no resistance
column104: and we captured a Mexican colonel
column105: who had beenwounded
column106: and a few men.  Just as I was sending them to the rear with aguard of two or three men
column107: a private came from the front bringing backone of our officers
column108: who had been badly wounded in advance of where Iwas.  The ground had been charged over before.  My exploit was equal tothat of the soldier who boasted that he had cut off the leg of one ofthe enemy.  When asked why he did not cut off his head
column109: he replied:'Some one had done that before.'  This left no doubt in my mind but thatthe battle of Resaca de la Palma would have been won
column110: just as it was
column111: ifI had not been there.  There was no further resistance. The evening ofthe 9th the army was encamped on its old ground near the Fort
column112: and thegarrison was relieved.  The siege had lasted a number of days
column113: but thecasualties were few in number.  Major Jacob Brown
column114: of the 7th infantry
column115: the commanding officer
column116: had been killed
column117: and in his honor the fort wasnamed. Since then a town of considerable importance has sprung up on theground occupied by the fort and troops
column118: which has also taken his name.The battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma seemed to us engaged
column119: aspretty important affairs; but we had only a faint conception of theirmagnitude until they were fought over in the North by the Press and thereports came back to us.  At the same time
column120: or about the same time
column121: welearned that war existed between the United States and Mexico
column122: by theacts of the latter country.  On learning this fact General Taylortransferred our camps to the south or west bank of the river
column123: andMatamoras was occupied.  We then became the 'Army of Invasion.'Up to this time Taylor had none but regular troops in his command; butnow that invasion had already taken place
column124: volunteers for one yearcommenced arriving.  The army remained at Matamoras until sufficientlyreinforced to warrant a movement into the interior.  General Taylor wasnot an officer to trouble the administration much with his demands
column125: butwas inclined to do the best he could with the means given him.  He felthis responsibility as going no further.  If he had thought that he wassent to perform an impossibility with the means given him
column126: he wouldprobably have informed the authorities of his opinion and left them todetermine what should be done.  If the judgment was against him he wouldhave gone on and done the best he could with the means at hand withoutparading his grievance before the public.  No soldier could face eitherdanger or responsibility more calmly than he.  These are qualities morerarely found than genius or physical courage.General Taylor never made any great show or parade
column127: either of uniform orretinue.  In dress he was possibly too plain
column128: rarely wearing anything inthe field to indicate his rank
column129: or even that he was an officer; but hewas known to every soldier in his army
column130: and was respected by all.  I cancall to mind only one instance when I saw him in uniform
column131: and one otherwhen I heard of his wearing it
column132: On both occasions he was unfortunate.The first was at Corpus Christi.  He had concluded to review his armybefore starting on the march and gave orders accordingly.  ColonelTwiggs was then second in rank with the army
column133: and to him was given thecommand of the review.  Colonel and Brevet Brigadier-General Worth
column134: afar different soldier from Taylor in the use of the uniform
column135: was next toTwiggs in rank
column136: and claimed superiority by virtue of his brevet rankwhen the accidents of service threw them where one or the other had tocommand.  Worth declined to attend the review as subordinate to Twiggsuntil the question was settled by the highest authority.  This broke upthe review
column137: and the question was referred to Washington for finaldecision.General Taylor was himself only a colonel
column138: in real rank
column139: at that time
column140: and a brigadier-general by brevet.  He was assigned to duty
column141: however
column142: bythe President
column143: with the rank which his brevet gave him.  Worth was notso assigned
column144: but by virtue of commanding a division he must
column145: under thearmy regulations of that day
column146: have drawn the pay of his brevet rank.The question was submitted to Washington
column147: and no response was receiveduntil after the army had reached the Rio Grande.  It was decided againstGeneral Worth
column148: who at once tendered his resignation and left the army
column149: going north
column150: no doubt
column151: by the same vessel that carried it.  This kepthim out of the battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma.  Either theresignation was not accepted
column152: or General Worth withdrew it before actionhad been taken.  At all events he returned to the army in time tocommand his division in the battle of Monterey
column153: and served with it tothe end of the war.The second occasion on which General Taylor was said to have donned hisuniform
column154: was in order to receive a visit from the Flag Officer of thenaval squadron off the mouth of the Rio Grande.  While the army was onthat river the Flag Officer sent word that he would call on the Generalto pay his respects on a certain day.  General Taylor
column155: knowing thatnaval officers habitually wore all the uniform the 'law allowed' on alloccasions of ceremony
column156: thought it would be only civil to receive hisguest in the same style.  His uniform was therefore got out
column157: brushed up
column158: and put on
column159: in advance of the visit.  The Flag Officer
column160: knowing GeneralTaylor's aversion to the wearing of the uniform
column161: and feeling that itwould be regarded as a compliment should he meet him in civilian'sdress
column162: left off his uniform for this occasion.  The meeting was said tohave been embarrassing to both
column163: and the conversation was principallyapologetic.The time was whiled away pleasantly enough at Matamoras
column164: while we werewaiting for volunteers.  It is probable that all the most importantpeople of the territory occupied by our army left their homes before wegot there
column165: but with those remaining the best of relations apparentlyexisted.  It was the policy of the Commanding General to allow nopillaging
column166: no taking of private property for public or individual usewithout satisfactory compensation
column167: so that a better market was affordedthan the people had ever known before.Among the troops that joined us at Matamoras was an Ohio regiment
column168: ofwhich Thomas L. Hamer
column169: the Member of Congress who had given me myappointment to West Point
column170: was major.  He told me then that he couldhave had the colonelcy
column171: but that as he knew he was to be appointed abrigadier-general
column172: he preferred at first to take the lower grade.  Ihave said before that Hamer was one of the ablest men Ohio everproduced.  At that time he was in the prime of life
column173: being less thanfifty years of age
column174: and possessed an admirable physique
column175: promising longlife.  But he was taken sick before Monterey
column176: and died within a fewdays.  I have always believed that had his life been spared
column177: he wouldhave been President of the United States during the term filled byPresident Pierce.  Had Hamer filled that office his partiality for mewas such
column178: there is but little doubt I should have been appointed to oneof the staff corps of the army--the Pay Department probably--and wouldtherefore now be preparing to retire.  Neither of these speculations isunreasonable
column179: and they are mentioned to show how little men controltheir own destiny.Reinforcements having arrived
column180: in the month of August the movementcommenced from Matamoras to Camargo
column181: the head of navigation on the RioGrande.  The line of the Rio Grande was all that was necessary to hold
column182: unless it was intended to invade Mexico from the North.  In that casethe most natural route to take was the one which General Taylorselected.  It entered a pass in the Sierra Madre Mountains
column183: at Monterey
column184: through which the main road runs to the City of Mexico.  Monterey itselfwas a good point to hold
column185: even if the line of the Rio Grande covered allthe territory we desired to occupy at that time.  It is built on a plaintwo thousand feet above tide water
column186: where the air is bracing and thesituation healthy.On the 19th of August the army started for Monterey
column187: leaving a smallgarrison at Matamoras.  The troops
column188: with the exception of the artillery
column189: cavalry
column190: and the brigade to which I belonged
column191: were moved up the river toCamargo on steamers.  As there were but two or three of these
column192: the boatshad to make a number of trips before the last of the troops wereup. Those who marched did so by the south side of the river.Lieutenant-Colonel Garland
column193: of the 4th infantry
column194: was the brigadecommander
column195: and on this occasion commanded the entire marching force.One day out convinced him that marching by day in that latitude
column196: in themonth of August
column197: was not a beneficial sanitary measure
column198: particularly forNorthern men.  The order of marching was changed and night marches weresubstituted with the best results.When Camargo was reached
column199: we found a city of tents outside the Mexicanhamlet.  I was detailed to act as quartermaster and commissary to theregiment.  The teams that had proven abundantly sufficient to transportall supplies from Corpus Christi to the Rio Grande over the levelprairies of Texas
column200: were entirely inadequate to the needs of thereinforced army in a mountainous country.  To obviate the deficiency
column201: pack mules were hired
column202: with Mexicans to pack and drive them.  I hadcharge of the few wagons allotted to the 4th infantry and of the packtrain to supplement them.  There were not men enough in the army tomanage that train without the help of Mexicans who had learned how.  Asit was the difficulty was great enough.  The troops would take up theirmarch at an early hour each day.  After they had started
column203: the tents andcooking utensils had to be made into packages
column204: so that they could belashed to the backs of the mules.  Sheet-iron kettles
column205: tent-poles andmess chests were inconvenient articles to transport in that way.  Ittook several hours to get ready to start each morning
column206: and by the timewe were ready some of the mules first loaded would be tired of standingso long with their loads on their backs. Sometimes one would start torun
column207: bowing his back and kicking up until he scattered his load; otherswould lie down and try to disarrange their loads by attempting to get onthe top of them by rolling on them; others with tent-poles for part oftheir loads would manage to run a tent-pole on one side of a saplingwhile they would take the other.  I am not aware of ever having used aprofane expletive in my life; but I would have the charity to excusethose who may have done so
column208: if they were in charge of a train of Mexicanpack mules at the time.

column1: ISFP	 VIII.ADVANCE ON MONTEREY--THE BLACK FORT--THE BATTLE OF MONTEREY--SURRENDEROF THE CITY.The advance from Camargo was commenced on the 5th of September. The armywas divided into four columns
column2: separated from each other by one day'smarch.  The advance reached Cerralvo in four days and halted for theremainder of the troops to come up.  By the 13th the rear-guard hadarrived
column3: and the same day the advance resumed its march
column4: followed asbefore
column5: a day separating the divisions.  The forward division haltedagain at Marin
column6: twenty-four miles from Monterey.  Both this place andCerralvo were nearly deserted
column7: and men
column8: women and children were seenrunning and scattered over the hills as we approached; but when thepeople returned they found all their abandoned property safe
column9: which musthave given them a favorable opinion of Los Grengos--'the Yankees.'  FromMarin the movement was in mass. On the 19th General Taylor
column10: with isarmy
column11: was encamped at Walnut Springs
column12: within three miles of Monterey.The town is on a small stream coming out of the mountain-pass
column13: and isbacked by a range of hills of moderate elevation.  To the north
column14: betweenthe city and Walnut Springs
column15: stretches an extensive plain.  On thisplain
column16: and entirely outside of the last houses of the city
column17: stood astrong fort
column18: enclosed on all sides
column19: to which our army gave the name of'Black Fort.'  Its guns commanded the approaches to the city to the fullextent of their range.  There were two detached spurs of hills ormountains to the north and northwest of the city
column20: which were alsofortified.  On one of these stood the Bishop's Palace.  The road toSaltillo leaves the upper or western end of the city under the fire ofthe guns from these heights.  The lower or eastern end was defended bytwo or three small detached works
column21: armed with artillery and infantry.To the south was the mountain stream before mentioned
column22: and back of thatthe range of foot-hills.  The plaza in the centre of the city was thecitadel
column23: properly speaking.  All the streets leading from it were sweptby artillery
column24: cannon being intrenched behind temporary parapets. Thehouse-tops near the plaza were converted into infantry fortifications bythe use of sand-bags for parapets.  Such were the defences of Montereyin September
column25: 1847.  General Ampudia
column26: with a force of certainly tenthousand men
column27: was in command.General Taylor's force was about six thousand five hundred strong
column28: inthree divisions
column29: under Generals Butler
column30: Twiggs and Worth.  The troopswent into camp at Walnut Springs
column31: while the engineer officers
column32: underMajor Mansfield--a General in the late war--commenced theirreconnoissance.  Major Mansfield found that it would be practicable toget troops around
column33: out of range of the Black Fort and the works on thedetached hills to the north-west of the city
column34: to the Saltillo road.With this road in our possession
column35: the enemy would be cut off fromreceiving further supplies
column36: if not from all communication with theinterior. General Worth
column37: with his division somewhat reinforced
column38: wasgiven the task of gaining possession of the Saltillo road
column39: and ofcarrying the detached works outside the city
column40: in that quarter. Hestarted on his march early in the afternoon of the 20th.  The divisionsunder Generals Butler and Twiggs were drawn up to threaten the east andnorth sides of the city and the works on those fronts
column41: in support of themovement under General Worth. Worth's was regarded as the main attack onMonterey
column42: and all other operations were in support of it.  His marchthis day was uninterrupted; but the enemy was seen to reinforce heavilyabout the Bishop's Palace and the other outside fortifications on theirleft.  General Worth reached a defensible position just out of range ofthe enemy's guns on the heights north-west of the city
column43: and bivouackedfor the night.  The engineer officers with him--Captain Sanders andLieutenant George G. Meade
column44: afterwards the commander of the victoriousNational army at the battle of Gettysburg--made a reconnoissance to theSaltillo road under cover of night.During the night of the 20th General Taylor had established a battery
column45: consisting of two twenty-four-pounder howitzers and a ten inch mortar
column46: at a point from which they could play upon Black Fort.  A naturaldepression in the plain
column47: sufficiently deep to protect men standing in itfrom the fire from the fort
column48: was selected and the battery established onthe crest nearest the enemy.  The 4th infantry
column49: then consisting of butsix reduced companies
column50: was ordered to support the artillerists whilethey were intrenching themselves and their guns.  I was regimentalquartermaster at the time and was ordered to remain in charge of campand the public property at Walnut Springs.  It was supposed that theregiment would return to its camp in the morning.The point for establishing the siege battery was reached and the workperformed without attracting the attention of the enemy.  At daylightthe next morning fire was opened on both sides and continued with
column51: whatseemed to me at that day
column52: great fury.  My curiosity got the better of myjudgment
column53: and I mounted a horse and rode to the front to see what wasgoing on.  I had been there but a short time when an order to charge wasgiven
column54: and lacking the moral courage to return to camp--where I had beenordered to stay--I charged with the regiment As soon as the troops wereout of the depression they came under the fire of Black Fort.  As theyadvanced they got under fire from batteries guarding the east
column55: or lower
column56: end of the city
column57: and of musketry. About one-third of the men engaged inthe charge were killed or wounded in the space of a few minutes.  Weretreated to get out of fire
column58: not backward
column59: but eastward andperpendicular to the direct road running into the city from WalnutSprings.  I was
column60: I believe
column61: the only person in the 4th infantry in thecharge who was on horseback.  When we got to a lace of safety theregiment halted and drew itself together--what was left of it.  Theadjutant of the regiment
column62: Lieutenant Hoskins
column63: who was not in robusthealth
column64: found himself very much fatigued from running on foot in thecharge and retreat
column65: and
column66: seeing me on horseback
column67: expressed a wish thathe could be mounted also.  I offered him my horse and he accepted theoffer.  A few minutes later I saw a soldier
column68: a quartermaster's man
column69: mounted
column70: not far away.  I ran to him
column71: took his horse and was back withthe regiment in a few minutes.  In a short time we were off again; andthe next place of safety from the shots of the enemy that I recollect ofbeing in
column72: was a field of cane or corn to the north-east of the lowerbatteries.  The adjutant to whom I had loaned my horse was killed
column73: and Iwas designated to act in his place.This charge was ill-conceived
column74: or badly executed.  We belonged to thebrigade commanded by Lieutenant-Colonel Garland
column75: and he had receivedorders to charge the lower batteries of the city
column76: and carry them if hecould without too much loss
column77: for the purpose of creating a diversion infavor of Worth
column78: who was conducting the movement which it was intendedshould be decisive.  By a movement by the left flank Garland could haveled his men beyond the range of the fire from Black Fort and advancedtowards the northeast angle of the city
column79: as well covered from fire ascould be expected.  There was no undue loss of life in reaching thelower end of Monterey
column80: except that sustained by Garland's command.Meanwhile Quitman's brigade
column81: conducted by an officer of engineers
column82: hadreached the eastern end of the city
column83: and was placed under cover of thehouses without much loss.  Colonel Garland's brigade also arrived at thesuburbs
column84: and
column85: by the assistance of some of our troops that had reachedhouse-tops from which they could fire into a little battery covering theapproaches to the lower end of the city
column86: the battery was speedilycaptured and its guns were turned upon another work of the enemy.  Anentrance into the east end of the city was now secured
column87: and the housesprotected our troops so long as they were inactive.  On the west GeneralWorth had reached the Saltillo road after some fighting but withoutheavy loss.  He turned from his new position and captured the forts onboth heights in that quarter.  This gave him possession of the upper orwest end of Monterey.  Troops from both Twiggs's and Butler's divisionswere in possession of the east end of the town
column88: but the Black Fort tothe north of the town and the plaza in the centre were still in thepossession of the enemy.  Our camps at Walnut Springs
column89: three miles away
column90: were guarded by a company from each regiment.  A regiment of Kentuckyvolunteers guarded the mortars and howitzers engaged against Black Fort.Practically Monterey was invested.There was nothing done on the 22d by the United States troops; but theenemy kept up a harmless fire upon us from Black Fort and the batteriesstill in their possession at the east end of the city.  During the nightthey evacuated these; so that on the morning of the 23d we heldundisputed possession of the east end of Monterey.Twiggs's division was at the lower end of the city
column91: and well coveredfrom the fire of the enemy.  But the streets leading to the plaza--allSpanish or Spanish-American towns have near their centres a squarecalled a plaza--were commanded from all directions by artillery.  Thehouses were flat-roofed and but one or two stories high
column92: and about theplaza the roofs were manned with infantry
column93: the troops being protectedfrom our fire by parapets made of sand-bags.  All advances into the citywere thus attended with much danger.  While moving along streets whichdid not lead to the plaza
column94: our men were protected from the fire
column95: andfrom the view
column96: of the enemy except at the crossings; but at these avolley of musketry and a discharge of grape-shot were invariablyencountered.  The 3d and 4th regiments of infantry made an advancenearly to the plaza in this way and with heavy loss.  The loss of the 3dinfantry in commissioned officers was especially severe.  There wereonly five companies of the regiment and not over twelve officerspresent
column97: and five of these officers were killed.  When within a squareof the plaza this small command
column98: ten companies in all
column99: was brought to ahalt.  Placing themselves under cover from the shots of the enemy
column100: themen would watch to detect a head above the sand-bags on the neighboringhouses.  The exposure of a single head would bring a volley from oursoldiers.We had not occupied this position long when it was discovered that ourammunition was growing low.  I volunteered to go back (*2) to the pointwe had started from
column101: report our position to General Twiggs
column102: and ask forammunition to be forwarded.  We were at this time occupying ground offfrom the street
column103: in rear of the houses.  My ride back was an exposedone.  Before starting I adjusted myself on the side of my horse furthestfrom the enemy
column104: and with only one foot holding to the cantle of thesaddle
column105: and an arm over the neck of the horse exposed
column106: I started at fullrun.  It was only at street crossings that my horse was under fire
column107: butthese I crossed at such a flying rate that generally I was past andunder cover of the next block of houses before the enemy fired.  I gotout safely without a scratch.At one place on my ride
column108: I saw a sentry walking in front of a house
column109: andstopped to inquire what he was doing there.  Finding that the house wasfull of wounded American officers and soldiers
column110: I dismounted and wentin.  I found there Captain Williams
column111: of the Engineer Corps
column112: wounded inthe head
column113: probably fatally
column114: and Lieutenant Territt
column115: also badly woundedhis bowels protruding from his wound.  There were quite a number ofsoldiers also.  Promising them to report their situation
column116: I left
column117: readjusted myself to my horse
column118: recommenced the run
column119: and was soon withthe troops at the east end.  Before ammunition could be collected
column120: thetwo regiments I had been with were seen returning
column121: running the samegauntlet in getting out that they had passed in going in
column122: but withcomparatively little loss.  The movement was countermanded and thetroops were withdrawn.  The poor wounded officers and men I had found
column123: fell into the hands of the enemy during the night
column124: and died.While this was going on at the east
column125: General Worth
column126: with a smalldivision of troops
column127: was advancing towards the plaza from the oppositeend of the city.  He resorted to a better expedient for getting to theplaza--the citadel--than we did on the east. Instead of moving by theopen streets
column128: he advanced through the houses
column129: cutting passageways fromone to another.  Without much loss of life
column130: he got so near the plazaduring the night that before morning
column131: Ampudia
column132: the Mexican commander
column133: made overtures for the surrender of the city and garrison.  This stoppedall further hostilities.  The terms of surrender were soon agreed upon.The prisoners were paroled and permitted to take their horses andpersonal property with them.My pity was aroused by the sight of the Mexican garrison of Montereymarching out of town as prisoners
column134: and no doubt the same feeling wasexperienced by most of our army who witnessed it.  Many of the prisonerswere cavalry
column135: armed with lances
column136: and mounted on miserable littlehalf-starved horses that did not look as if they could carry theirriders out of town.  The men looked in but little better condition.  Ithought how little interest the men before me had in the results of thewar
column137: and how little knowledge they had of 'what it was all about.'After the surrender of the garrison of Monterey a quiet camp life wasled until midwinter.  As had been the case on the Rio Grande
column138: the peoplewho remained at their homes fraternized with the 'Yankees' in thepleasantest manner.  In fact
column139: under the humane policy of our commander
column140: I question whether the great majority of the Mexican people did notregret our departure as much as they had regretted our coming.  Propertyand person were thoroughly protected
column141: and a market was afforded for allthe products of the country such as the people had never enjoyed before.The educated and wealthy portion of the population here
column142: as elsewhere
column143: abandoned their homes and remained away from them as long as they werein the possession of the invaders; but this class formed a very smallpercentage of the whole population.

column1: ISFP	 IX.POLITICAL INTRIGUE--BUENA VISTA--MOVEMENT AGAINST VERA CRUZ--SIEGE ANDCAPTURE OF VERA CRUZ.The Mexican war was a political war
column2: and the administration conductingit desired to make party capital out of it.  General Scott was at thehead of the army
column3: and
column4: being a soldier of acknowledged professionalcapacity
column5: his claim to the command of the forces in the field was almostindisputable and does not seem to have been denied by President Polk
column6: orMarcy
column7: his Secretary of War.  Scott was a Whig and the administrationwas democratic.  General Scott was also known to have politicalaspirations
column8: and nothing so popularizes a candidate for high civilpositions as military victories.  It would not do therefore to give himcommand of the 'army of conquest.'  The plans submitted by Scott for acampaign in Mexico were disapproved by the administration
column9: and hereplied
column10: in a tone possibly a little disrespectful
column11: to the effect that
column12: if a soldier's plans were not to be supported by the administration
column13: success could not be expected.  This was on the 27th of May
column14: 1846.  Fourdays later General Scott was notified that he need not go to Mexico.General Gaines was next in rank
column15: but he was too old and feeble to takethe field.  Colonel Zachary Taylor--a brigadier-general by brevet--wastherefore left in command.  He
column16: too
column17: was a Whig
column18: but was not supposed toentertain any political ambitions; nor did he; but after the fall ofMonterey
column19: his third battle and third complete victory
column20: the Whig papersat home began to speak of him as the candidate of their party for thePresidency.  Something had to be done to neutralize his growingpopularity.  He could not be relieved from duty in the field where allhis battles had been victories:  the design would have been tootransparent.  It was finally decided to send General Scott to Mexico inchief command
column21: and to authorize him to carry out his own original plan:that is
column22: capture Vera Cruz and march upon the capital of the country.It was no doubt supposed that Scott's ambition would lead him toslaughter Taylor or destroy his chances for the Presidency
column23: and yet itwas hoped that he would not make sufficient capital himself to securethe prize.The administration had indeed a most embarrassing problem to solve.  Itwas engaged in a war of conquest which must be carried to a successfulissue
column24: or the political object would be unattained.  Yet all the capableofficers of the requisite rank belonged to the opposition
column25: and the manselected for his lack of political ambition had himself become aprominent candidate for the Presidency.  It was necessary to destroy hischances promptly.  The problem was to do this without the loss ofconquest and without permitting another general of the same politicalparty to acquire like popularity.  The fact is
column26: the administration ofMr. Polk made every preparation to disgrace Scott
column27: or
column28: to speak morecorrectly
column29: to drive him to such desperation that he would disgracehimself.General Scott had opposed conquest by the way of the Rio Grande
column30: Matamoras and Saltillo from the first.  Now that he was in command ofall the forces in Mexico
column31: he withdrew from Taylor most of his regulartroops and left him only enough volunteers
column32: as he thought
column33: to hold theline then in possession of the invading army.  Indeed Scott did not deemit important to hold anything beyond the Rio Grande
column34: and authorizedTaylor to fall back to that line if he chose.  General Taylor protestedagainst the depletion of his army
column35: and his subsequent movement uponBuena Vista would indicate that he did not share the views of his chiefin regard to the unimportance of conquest beyond the Rio Grande.Scott had estimated the men and material that would be required tocapture Vera Cruz and to march on the capital of the country
column36: twohundred and sixty miles in the interior.  He was promised all he askedand seemed to have not only the confidence of the President
column37: but hissincere good wishes.  The promises were all broken.  Only about half thetroops were furnished that had been pledged
column38: other war material waswithheld and Scott had scarcely started for Mexico before the Presidentundertook to supersede him by the appointment of Senator Thomas H.Benton as lieutenant-general.  This being refused by Congress
column39: thePresident asked legislative authority to place a junior over a senior ofthe same grade
column40: with the view of appointing Benton to the rank ofmajor-general and then placing him in command of the army
column41: but Congressfailed to accede to this proposition as well
column42: and Scott remained incommand: but every general appointed to serve under him was politicallyopposed to the chief
column43: and several were personally hostile.General Scott reached Brazos Santiago or Point Isabel
column44: at the mouth ofthe Rio Grande
column45: late in December
column47: and proceeded at once up theriver to Camargo
column48: where he had written General Taylor to meet him.Taylor
column49: however
column50: had gone to
column51: or towards Tampico
column52: for the purpose ofestablishing a post there.  He had started on this march before he wasaware of General Scott being in the country.  Under these circumstancesScott had to issue his orders designating the troops to be withdrawnfrom Taylor
column53: without the personal consultation he had expected to holdwith his subordinate.General Taylor's victory at Buena Vista
column54: February 22d
column56: and 24th
column58: with an army composed almost entirely of volunteers who had notbeen in battle before
column59: and over a vastly superior force numerically
column60: made his nomination for the Presidency by the Whigs a foregoneconclusion.  He was nominated and elected in 1848.  I believe that hesincerely regretted this turn in his fortunes
column61: preferring the peaceafforded by a quiet life free from abuse to the honor of filling thehighest office in the gift of any people
column62: the Presidency of the UnitedStates.When General Scott assumed command of the army of invasion
column63: I was in thedivision of General David Twiggs
column64: in Taylor's command; but under the neworders my regiment was transferred to the division of General WilliamWorth
column65: in which I served to the close of the war.  The troops withdrawnfrom Taylor to form part of the forces to operate against Vera Cruz
column66: were assembled at the mouth of the Rio Grande preparatory to embarkationfor their destination.  I found General Worth a different man from any Ihad before served directly under.  He was nervous
column67: impatient andrestless on the march
column68: or when important or responsible duty confrontedhim.  There was not the least reason for haste on the march
column69: for it wasknown that it would take weeks to assemble shipping enough at the pointof our embarkation to carry the army
column70: but General Worth moved hisdivision with a rapidity that would have been commendable had he beengoing to the relief of a beleaguered garrison.  The length of themarches was regulated by the distances between places affording a supplyof water for the troops
column71: and these distances were sometimes long andsometimes short.  General Worth on one occasion at least
column72: after havingmade the full distance intended for the day
column73: and after the troops werein camp and preparing their food
column74: ordered tents struck and made themarch that night which had been intended for the next day.  Somecommanders can move troops so as to get the maximum distance out of themwithout fatigue
column75: while others can wear them out in a few days withoutaccomplishing so much. General Worth belonged to this latter class.  Heenjoyed
column76: however
column77: a fine reputation for his fighting qualities
column78: and thusattached his officers and men to him.The army lay in camp upon the sand-beach in the neighborhood of themouth of the Rio Grande for several weeks
column79: awaiting the arrival oftransports to carry it to its new field of operations.  The transportswere all sailing vessels.  The passage was a tedious one
column80: and many ofthe troops were on shipboard over thirty days from the embarkation atthe mouth of the Rio Grande to the time of debarkation south of VeraCruz. The trip was a comfortless one for officers and men.  Thetransports used were built for carrying freight and possessed butlimited accommodations for passengers
column81: and the climate added to thediscomfort of all.The transports with troops were assembled in the harbor of AntonLizardo
column82: some sixteen miles south of Vera Cruz
column83: as they arrived
column84: andthere awaited the remainder of the fleet
column85: bringing artillery
column86: ammunitionand supplies of all kinds from the North.  With the fleet there was alittle steam propeller dispatch-boat--the first vessel of the kind I hadever seen
column87: and probably the first of its kind ever seen by any one thenwith the army.  At that day ocean steamers were rare
column88: and what therewere were sidewheelers.  This little vessel
column89: going through the fleet sofast
column90: so noiselessly and with its propeller under water out of view
column91: attracted a great deal of attention.  I recollect that Lieutenant SidneySmith
column92: of the 4th infantry
column93: by whom I happened to be standing on thedeck of a vessel when this propeller was passing
column94: exclaimed
column95: 'Why
column96: thething looks as if it was propelled by the force of circumstances.'Finally on the 7th of March
column98: the little army of ten or twelvethousand men
column99: given Scott to invade a country with a population of sevenor eight millions
column100: a mountainous country affording the greatest possiblenatural advantages for defence
column101: was all assembled and ready to commencethe perilous task of landing from vessels lying in the open sea.The debarkation took place inside of the little island of Sacrificios
column102: some three miles south of Vera Cruz.  The vessels could not get anywherenear shore
column103: so that everything had to be landed in lighters orsurf-boats; General Scott had provided these before leaving the North.The breakers were sometimes high
column104: so that the landing was tedious.  Themen were got ashore rapidly
column105: because they could wade when they came toshallow water; but the camp and garrison equipage
column106: provisions
column107: ammunition and all stores had to be protected from the salt water
column108: andtherefore their landing took several days.  The Mexicans were very kindto us
column109: however
column110: and threw no obstacles in the way of our landing exceptan occasional shot from their nearest fort.  During the debarkation oneshot took off the head of Major Albertis.  No other
column111: I believe
column112: reachedanywhere near the same distance.  On the 9th of March the troops werelanded and the investment of Vera Cruz
column113: from the Gulf of Mexico south ofthe city to the Gulf again on the north
column114: was soon and easily effected.The landing of stores was continued until everything was got ashore.Vera Cruz
column115: at the time of which I write and up to 1880
column116: was a walledcity.  The wall extended from the water's edge south of the town to thewater again on the north.  There were fortifications at intervals alongthe line and at the angles. In front of the city
column117: and on an island halfa mile out in the Gulf
column118: stands San Juan de Ulloa
column119: an enclosedfortification of large dimensions and great strength for that period.Against artillery of the present day the land forts and walls wouldprove elements of weakness rather than strength.  After the invadingarmy had established their camps out of range of the fire from the city
column120: batteries were established
column121: under cover of night
column122: far to the front ofthe line where the troops lay.  These batteries were intrenched and theapproaches sufficiently protected.  If a sortie had been made at anytime by the Mexicans
column123: the men serving the batteries could have beenquickly reinforced without great exposure to the fire from the enemy'smain line.  No serious attempt was made to capture the batteries or todrive our troops away.The siege continued with brisk firing on our side till the 27th ofMarch
column124: by which time a considerable breach had been made in the wallsurrounding the city.  Upon this General Morales
column125: who was Governor ofboth the city and of San Juan de Ulloa
column126: commenced a correspondence withGeneral Scott looking to the surrender of the town
column127: forts and garrison.On the 29th Vera Cruz and San Juan de Ulloa were occupied by Scott'sarmy.  About five thousand prisoners and four hundred pieces ofartillery
column128: besides large amounts of small arms and ammunition
column129: fell intothe hands of the victorious force.  The casualties on our side duringthe siege amounted to sixty-four officers and men
column130: killed and wounded.

column1: ISFP	 X.MARCH TO JALAPA--BATTLE OF CERRO GORDO--PEROTE--PUEBLA--SCOTT ANDTAYLOR.General Scott had less than twelve thousand men at Vera Cruz. He hadbeen promised by the administration a very much larger force
column2: or claimedthat he had
column3: and he was a man of veracity. Twelve thousand was a verysmall army with which to penetrate two hundred and sixty miles into anenemy's country
column4: and to besiege the capital; a city
column5: at that time
column6: oflargely over one hundred thousand inhabitants.  Then
column7: too
column8: any line ofmarch that could be selected led through mountain passes easilydefended. In fact
column9: there were at that time but two roads from Vera Cruzto the City of Mexico that could be taken by an army; one by Jalapa andPerote
column10: the other by Cordova and Orizaba
column11: the two coming together on thegreat plain which extends to the City of Mexico after the range ofmountains is passed.It was very important to get the army away from Vera Cruz as soon aspossible
column12: in order to avoid the yellow fever
column13: or vomito
column14: which usuallyvisits that city early in the year
column15: and is very fatal to persons notacclimated; but transportation
column16: which was expected from the North
column17: wasarriving very slowly.  It was absolutely necessary to have enough tosupply the army to Jalapa
column18: sixty-five miles in the interior and abovethe fevers of the coast.  At that point the country is fertile
column19: and anarmy of the size of General Scott's could subsist there for anindefinite period.  Not counting the sick
column20: the weak and the garrisonsfor the captured city and fort
column21: the moving column was now less than tenthousand strong.  This force was composed of three divisions
column22: underGenerals Twiggs
column23: Patterson
column24: and Worth. The importance of escaping thevomito was so great that as soon as transportation enough could be gottogether to move a division the advance was commenced.  On the 8th ofApril
column25: Twiggs's division started for Jalapa.  He was followed very soonby Patterson
column26: with his division.  General Worth was to bring up the rearwith his command as soon as transportation enough was assembled to carrysix days' rations for his troops with the necessary ammunition and campand garrison equipage.  It was the 13th of April before this divisionleft Vera Cruz.The leading division ran against the enemy at Cerro Gordo
column27: some fiftymiles west
column28: on the road to Jalapa
column29: and went into camp at Plan del Rio
column30: about three miles from the fortifications. General Patterson reachedPlan del Rio with his division soon after Twiggs arrived.  The two werethen secure against an attack from Santa Anna

The shots from our little gun dropped in upon the enemy andcreated great confusion.  Why they did not send out a small party andcapture us
