column1: ISFP	 XII.PROMOTION TO FIRST LIEUTENANT--CAPTURE OF THE CITY OF MEXICO--THE ARMY--MEXICAN SOLDIERS--PEACE NEGOTIATIONS.On entering the city the troops were fired upon by the releasedconvicts
column2: and possibly by deserters and hostile citizens.  The streetswere deserted
column3: and the place presented the appearance of a 'city of thedead
column4: ' except for this firing by unseen persons from house-tops
column5: windows
column6: and around corners.  In this firing the lieutenant-colonel ofmy regiment
column7: Garland
column8: was badly wounded
column9: Lieutenant Sidney Smith
column10: of the4th infantry
column11: was also wounded mortally.  He died a few days after
column12: andby his death I was promoted to the grade of first lieutenant.(*4)  I hadgone into the battle of Palo Alto in May
column14: a second lieutenant
column15: andI entered the city of Mexico sixteen months later with the same rank
column16: after having been in all the engagements possible for any one man and ina regiment that lost more officers during the war than it ever hadpresent at any one engagement.  My regiment lost four commissionedofficers
column17: all senior to me
column18: by steamboat explosions during the Mexicanwar.  The Mexicans were not so discriminating.  They sometimes pickedoff my juniors.General Scott soon followed the troops into the city
column19: in state.  Iwonder that he was not fired upon
column20: but I believe he was not; at allevents he was not hurt.  He took quarters at first in the 'Halls of theMontezumas
column21: ' and from there issued his wise and discreet orders for thegovernment of a conquered city
column22: and for suppressing the hostile acts ofliberated convicts already spoken of--orders which challenge the respectof all who study them.  Lawlessness was soon suppressed
column23: and the City ofMexico settled down into a quiet
column24: law-abiding place.  The people beganto make their appearance upon the streets without fear of the invaders.Shortly afterwards the bulk of the troops were sent from the city to thevillages at the foot of the mountains
column25: four or five miles to the southand south-west.Whether General Scott approved of the Mexican war and the manner inwhich it was brought about
column26: I have no means of knowing.  His orders totroops indicate only a soldierly spirit
column27: with probably a little regardfor the perpetuation of his own fame.  On the other hand
column28: GeneralTaylor's
column29: I think
column30: indicate that he considered the administrationaccountable for the war
column31: and felt no responsibility resting on himselffurther than for the faithful performance of his duties.  Both generalsdeserve the commendations of their countrymen and to live in thegrateful memory of this people to the latest generation.Earlier in this narrative I have stated that the plain
column32: reached afterpassing the mountains east of Perote
column33: extends to the cities of Pueblaand Mexico.  The route travelled by the army before reaching Puebla
column34: goes over a pass in a spur of mountain coming up from the south.  Thispass is very susceptible of defence by a smaller against a larger force.Again
column35: the highest point of the road-bed between Vera Cruz and the Cityof Mexico is over Rio Frio mountain
column36: which also might have beensuccessfully defended by an inferior against a superior force.  But bymoving north of the mountains
column37: and about thirty miles north of Puebla
column38: both of these passes would have been avoided.  The road from Perote tothe City of Mexico
column39: by this latter route
column40: is as level as the prairies inour West.  Arriving due north from Puebla
column41: troops could have beendetached to take possession of that place
column42: and then proceeding west withthe rest of the army no mountain would have been encountered beforereaching the City of Mexico.  It is true this road would have broughttroops in by Guadalupe--a town
column43: church and detached spur of mountainabout two miles north of the capital
column44: all bearing the same general name--and at this point Lake Texcoco comes near to the mountain
column45: which wasfortified both at the base and on the sides:  but troops could havepassed north of the mountain and come in only a few miles to thenorth-west
column46: and so flanked the position
column47: as they actually did on thesouth.It has always seemed to me that this northern route to the City ofMexico
column48: would have been the better one to have taken.  But my laterexperience has taught me two lessons:  first
column49: that things are seenplainer after the events have occurred; second
column50: that the most confidentcritics are generally those who know the least about the mattercriticised.  I know just enough about the Mexican war to approveheartily of most of the generalship
column51: but to differ with a little of it.It is natural that an important city like Puebla should not have beenpassed with contempt; it may be natural that the direct road to itshould have been taken; but it could have been passed
column52: its evacuationinsured and possession acquired without danger of encountering the enemyin intricate mountain defiles.  In this same way the City of Mexicocould have been approached without any danger of opposition
column53: except inthe open field.But General Scott's successes are an answer to all criticism. He invadeda populous country
column54: penetrating two hundred and sixty miles into theinterior
column55: with a force at no time equal to one-half of that opposed tohim; he was without a base; the enemy was always intrenched
column56: always onthe defensive; yet he won every battle
column57: he captured the capital
column58: andconquered the government.  Credit is due to the troops engaged
column59: it istrue
column60: but the plans and the strategy were the general's.I had now made marches and been in battle under both General Scott andGeneral Taylor.  The former divided his force of 10
column61: 500 men into fourcolumns
column62: starting a day apart
column63: in moving from Puebla to the capital ofthe nation
column64: when it was known that an army more than twice as large ashis own stood ready to resist his coming.  The road was broad and thecountry open except in crossing the Rio Frio mountain.  General Taylorpursued the same course in marching toward an enemy.  He moved even insmaller bodies.  I never thought at the time to doubt the infallibilityof these two generals in all matters pertaining to their profession.  Isupposed they moved in small bodies because more men could not be passedover a single road on the same day with their artillery and necessarytrains.  Later I found the fallacy of this belief.  The rebellion
column65: whichfollowed as a sequence to the Mexican war
column66: never could have beensuppressed if larger bodies of men could not have been moved at the sametime than was the custom under Scott and Taylor.The victories in Mexico were
column67: in every instance
column68: over vastly superiornumbers.  There were two reasons for this.  Both General Scott andGeneral Taylor had such armies as are not often got together.  At thebattles of Palo Alto and Resaca-de-la-Palma
column69: General Taylor had a smallarmy
column70: but it was composed exclusively of regular troops
column71: under the bestof drill and discipline.  Every officer
column72: from the highest to the lowest
column73: was educated in his profession
column74: not at West Point necessarily
column75: but inthe camp
column76: in garrison
column77: and many of them in Indian wars. The rank andfile were probably inferior
column78: as material out of which to make an army
column79: to the volunteers that participated in all the later battles of the war;but they were brave men
column80: and then drill and discipline brought out allthere was in them.  A better army
column81: man for man
column82: probably never faced anenemy than the one commanded by General Taylor in the earliest twoengagements of the Mexican war.  The volunteers who followed were ofbetter material
column83: but without drill or discipline at the start.  Theywere associated with so many disciplined men and professionally educatedofficers
column84: that when they went into engagements it was with a confidencethey would not have felt otherwise.  They became soldiers themselvesalmost at once.  All these conditions we would enjoy again in case ofwar.The Mexican army of that day was hardly an organization.  The privatesoldier was picked up from the lower class of the inhabitants whenwanted; his consent was not asked; he was poorly clothed
column85: worse fed
column86: andseldom paid.  He was turned adrift when no longer wanted.  The officersof the lower grades were but little superior to the men.  With all thisI have seen as brave stands made by some of these men as I have everseen made by soldiers.  Now Mexico has a standing army larger than thatof the United States.  They have a military school modelled after WESTJoint.  Their officers are educated and
column87: no doubt
column88: generally brave.  TheMexican war of 1846-8 would be an impossibility in this generation.The Mexicans have shown a patriotism which it would be well if we wouldimitate in part
column89: but with more regard to truth.  They celebrate theanniversaries of Chapultepec and Molino del Rey as of very greatvictories.  The anniversaries are recognized as national holidays.  Atthese two battles
column90: while the United States troops were victorious
column91: itwas at very great sacrifice of life compared with what the Mexicanssuffered.  The Mexicans
column92: as on many other occasions
column93: stood up as well asany troops ever did.  The trouble seemed to be the lack of experienceamong the officers
column94: which led them after a certain time to simply quit
column95: without being particularly whipped
column96: but because they had fought enough.Their authorities of the present day grow enthusiastic over their themewhen telling of these victories
column97: and speak with pride of the large sumof money they forced us to pay in the end.  With us
column98: now twenty yearsafter the close of the most stupendous war ever known
column99: we have writers--who profess devotion to the nation--engaged in trying to prove that theUnion forces were not victorious; practically
column100: they say
column101: we were slashedaround from Donelson to Vicksburg and to Chattanooga; and in the Eastfrom Gettysburg to Appomattox
column102: when the physical rebellion gave out fromsheer exhaustion.  There is no difference in the amount of romance inthe two stories.I would not have the anniversaries of our victories celebrated
column103: northose of our defeats made fast days and spent in humiliation and prayer;but I would like to see truthful history written. Such history will dofull credit to the courage
column104: endurance and soldierly ability of theAmerican citizen
column105: no matter what section of the country he hailed from
column106: or in what ranks he fought.  The justice of the cause which in the endprevailed
column107: will
column108: I doubt not
column109: come to be acknowledged by every citizenof the land
column110: in time.  For the present
column111: and so long as there are livingwitnesses of the great war of sections
column112: there will be people who willnot be consoled for the loss of a cause which they believed to be holy.As time passes
column113: people
column114: even of the South
column115: will begin to wonder how itwas possible that their ancestors ever fought for or justifiedinstitutions which acknowledged the right of property in man.After the fall of the capital and the dispersal of the government ofMexico
column116: it looked very much as if military occupation of the country fora long time might be necessary. General Scott at once began thepreparation of orders
column117: regulations and laws in view of this contingency.He contemplated making the country pay all the expenses of theoccupation
column118: without the army becoming a perceptible burden upon thepeople.  His plan was to levy a direct tax upon the separate states
column119: andcollect
column120: at the ports left open to trade
column121: a duty on all imports.  Fromthe beginning of the war private property had not been taken
column122: either forthe use of the army or of individuals
column123: without full compensation.  Thispolicy was to be pursued.  There were not troops enough in the valley ofMexico to occupy many points
column124: but now that there was no organized armyof the enemy of any size
column125: reinforcements could be got from the RioGrande
column126: and there were also new volunteers arriving from time to time
column127: all by way of Vera Cruz.  Military possession was taken of Cuernavaca
column128: fifty miles south of the City of Mexico; of Toluca
column129: nearly as far west
column130: and of Pachuca
column131: a mining town of great importance
column132: some sixty miles tothe north-east.  Vera Cruz
column133: Jalapa
column134: Orizaba
column135: and Puebla were already inour possession.Meanwhile the Mexican government had departed in the person of SantaAnna
column136: and it looked doubtful for a time whether the United Statescommissioner
column137: Mr. Trist
column138: would find anybody to negotiate with.  Atemporary government
column139: however
column140: was soon established at Queretaro
column141: andTrist began negotiations for a conclusion of the war.  Before terms werefinally agreed upon he was ordered back to Washington
column142: but General Scottprevailed upon him to remain
column143: as an arrangement had been so nearlyreached
column144: and the administration must approve his acts if he succeeded inmaking such a treaty as had been contemplated in his instructions.  Thetreaty was finally signed the 2d of February
column146: and accepted by thegovernment at Washington.  It is that known as the 'Treaty of GuadalupeHidalgo
column147: ' and secured to the United States the Rio Grande as theboundary of Texas
column148: and the whole territory then included in New Mexicoand Upper California
column149: for the sum of $15
column151: 000.Soon after entering the city of Mexico
column152: the opposition of GeneralsPillow
column153: Worth and Colonel Duncan to General Scott became very marked.Scott claimed that they had demanded of the President his removal.  I donot know whether this is so or not
column154: but I do know of their unconcealedhostility to their chief.  At last he placed them in arrest
column155: andpreferred charges against them of insubordination and disrespect.  Thisact brought on a crisis in the career of the general commanding.  He hadasserted from the beginning that the administration was hostile to him;that it had failed in its promises of men and war material; that thePresident himself had shown duplicity if not treachery in the endeavorto procure the appointment of Benton:  and the administration now gaveopen evidence of its enmity.  About the middle of February orders cameconvening a court of inquiry
column156: composed of Brevet Brigadier-GeneralTowson
column157: the paymaster-general of the army
column158: Brigadier-General Cushing andColonel Belknap
column159: to inquire into the conduct of the accused and theaccuser
column160: and shortly afterwards orders were received from Washington
column161: relieving Scott of the command of the army in the field and assigningMajor-General William O. Butler of Kentucky to the place.  This orderalso released Pillow
column162: Worth and Duncan from arrest.If a change was to be made the selection of General Butler was agreeableto every one concerned
column163: so far as I remember to have heard expressionson the subject.  There were many who regarded the treatment of GeneralScott as harsh and unjust.  It is quite possible that the vanity of theGeneral had led him to say and do things that afforded a plausiblepretext to the administration for doing just what it did and what it hadwanted to do from the start.  The court tried the accuser quite as muchas the accused.  It was adjourned before completing its labors
column164: to meetin Frederick
column165: Maryland.  General Scott left the country
column166: and never afterhad more than the nominal command of the army until early in 1861.  Hecertainly was not sustained in his efforts to maintain discipline inhigh places.The efforts to kill off politically the two successful generals
column167: madethem both candidates for the Presidency.  General Taylor was nominatedin 1848
column168: and was elected.  Four years later General Scott received thenomination but was badly beaten
column169: and the party nominating him died withhis defeat.(*5)

column1: ISFP	 XIII.TREATY OF PEACE--MEXICAN BULL FIGHTS--REGIMENTAL QUARTERMASTER--TRIP TOPOPOCATAPETL--TRIP TO THE CAVES OF MEXICO.The treaty of peace between the two countries was signed by thecommissioners of each side early in February
column2: 1848.  It took aconsiderable time for it to reach Washington
column3: receive the approval ofthe administration
column4: and be finally ratified by the Senate.  It wasnaturally supposed by the army that there would be no more fighting
column5: andofficers and men were of course anxious to get home
column6: but knowing theremust be delay they contented themselves as best they could.  EverySunday there was a bull fight for the amusement of those who would paytheir fifty cents.  I attended one of them--just one--not wishing toleave the country without having witnessed the national sport.  Thesight to me was sickening.  I could not see how human beings could enjoythe sufferings of beasts
column7: and often of men
column8: as they seemed to do onthese occasions.At these sports there are usually from four to six bulls sacrificed.The audience occupies seats around the ring in which the exhibition isgiven
column9: each seat but the foremost rising higher than the one in front
column10: so that every one can get a full view of the sport.  When all is ready abull is turned into the ring.  Three or four men come in
column11: mounted on themerest skeletons of horses blind or blind-folded and so weak that theycould not make a sudden turn with their riders without danger of fallingdown.  The men are armed with spears having a point as sharp as aneedle.  Other men enter the arena on foot
column12: armed with red flags andexplosives about the size of a musket cartridge.  To each of theseexplosives is fastened a barbed needle which serves the purpose ofattaching them to the bull by running the needle into the skin.  Beforethe animal is turned loose a lot of these explosives are attached tohim.  The pain from the pricking of the skin by the needles isexasperating; but when the explosions of the cartridges commence theanimal becomes frantic.  As he makes a lunge towards one horseman
column13: another runs a spear into him.  He turns towards his last tormentor whena man on foot holds out a red flag; the bull rushes for this and isallowed to take it on his horns.  The flag drops and covers the eyes ofthe animal so that he is at a loss what to do; it is jerked from him andthe torment is renewed.  When the animal is worked into anuncontrollable frenzy
column14: the horsemen withdraw
column15: and the matadores--literally murderers--enter
column16: armed with knives having blades twelve oreighteen inches long
column17: and sharp.  The trick is to dodge an attack fromthe animal and stab him to the heart as he passes. If these efforts failthe bull is finally lassoed
column18: held fast and killed by driving a knifeblade into the spinal column just back of the horns.  He is then draggedout by horses or mules
column19: another is let into the ring
column20: and the sameperformance is renewed.On the occasion when I was present one of the bulls was not turned asideby the attacks in the rear
column21: the presentations of the red flag
column22: etc.
column23: etc.
column24: but kept right on
column25: and placing his horns under the flanks of ahorse threw him and his rider to the ground with great force.  The horsewas killed and the rider lay prostrate as if dead.  The bull was thenlassoed and killed in the manner above described.  Men came in andcarried the dead man off in a litter.  When the slaughtered bull andhorse were dragged out
column26: a fresh bull was turned into the ring.Conspicuous among the spectators was the man who had been carried out ona litter but a few minutes before.  He was only dead so far as thatperformance went; but the corpse was so lively that it could not foregothe chance of witnessing the discomfiture of some of his brethren whomight not be so fortunate.  There was a feeling of disgust manifested bythe audience to find that he had come to life again.  I confess that Ifelt sorry to see the cruelty to the bull and the horse.  I did not stayfor the conclusion of the performance; but while I did stay
column27: there wasnot a bull killed in the prescribed way.Bull fights are now prohibited in the Federal District--embracing aterritory around the City of Mexico
column28: somewhat larger than the Districtof Columbia--and they are not an institution in any part of the country.During one of my recent visits to Mexico
column29: bull fights were got up in myhonor at Puebla and at Pachuca.  I was not notified in advance so as tobe able to decline and thus prevent the performance; but in both cases Icivilly declined to attend.Another amusement of the people of Mexico of that day
column30: and one whichnearly all indulged in
column31: male and female
column32: old and young
column33: priest andlayman
column34: was Monte playing.  Regular feast weeks were held every year atwhat was then known as St. Augustin Tlalpam
column35: eleven miles out of town.There were dealers to suit every class and condition of people.  In manyof the booths tlackos--the copper coin of the country
column36: four of themmaking six and a quarter cents of our money--were piled up in greatquantities
column37: with some silver
column38: to accommodate the people who could notbet more than a few pennies at a time.  In other booths silver formedthe bulk of the capital of the bank
column39: with a few doubloons to be changedif there should be a run of luck against the bank.  In some there was nocoin except gold.  Here the rich were said to bet away their entireestates in a single day.  All this is stopped now.For myself
column40: I was kept somewhat busy during the winter of 1847-8.  Myregiment was stationed in Tacubaya.  I was regimental quartermaster andcommissary.  General Scott had been unable to get clothing for thetroops from the North.  The men were becoming--well
column41: they neededclothing.  Material had to be purchased
column42: such as could be obtained
column43: andpeople employed to make it up into 'Yankee uniforms.'  A quartermasterin the city was designated to attend to this special duty; but clothingwas so much needed that it was seized as fast as made up.  A regimentwas glad to get a dozen suits at a time.  I had to look after thismatter for the 4th infantry.  Then our regimental fund had run down andsome of the musicians in the band had been without their extra pay for anumber of months.The regimental bands at that day were kept up partly by pay from thegovernment
column44: and partly by pay from the regimental fund. There wasauthority of law for enlisting a certain number of men as musicians.  Somany could receive the pay of non-commissioned officers of the variousgrades
column45: and the remainder the pay of privates.  This would not secure aband leader
column46: nor good players on certain instruments.  In garrison thereare various ways of keeping up a regimental fund sufficient to giveextra pay to musicians
column47: establish libraries and ten-pin alleys
column48: subscribe to magazines and furnish many extra comforts to the men.  Thebest device for supplying the fund is to issue bread to the soldiersinstead of flour.  The ration used to be eighteen ounces per day ofeither flour or bread; and one hundred pounds of flour will make onehundred and forty pounds of bread.  This saving was purchased by thecommissary for the benefit of the fund.  In the emergency the 4thinfantry was laboring under
column49: I rented a bakery in the city
column50: hiredbakers--Mexicans--bought fuel and whatever was necessary
column51: and I also gota contract from the chief commissary of the army for baking a largeamount of hard bread.  In two months I made more money for the fund thanmy pay amounted to during the entire war.  While stationed at Monterey Ihad relieved the post fund in the same way.  There
column52: however
column53: was noprofit except in the saving of flour by converting it into bread.In the spring of 1848 a party of officers obtained leave to visitPopocatapetl
column54: the highest volcano in America
column55: and to take an escort.  Iwent with the party
column56: many of whom afterwards occupied conspicuouspositions before the country.  Of those who 'went south
column57: ' and attainedhigh rank
column58: there was Lieutenant Richard Anderson
column59: who commanded a corpsat Spottsylvania; Captain Sibley
column60: a major-general
column61: and
column62: after the war
column63: for a number of years in the employ of the Khedive of Egypt; CaptainGeorge Crittenden
column64: a rebel general; S. B. Buckner
column65: who surrendered FortDonelson; and Mansfield Lovell
column66: who commanded at New Orleans before thatcity fell into the hands of the National troops.  Of those who remainedon our side there were Captain Andrew Porter
column67: Lieutenant C. P. Stone andLieutenant Z. B. Tower.  There were quite a number of other officers
column68: whose names I cannot recollect.At a little village (Ozumba) near the base of Popocatapetl
column69: where wepurposed to commence the ascent
column70: we procured guides and two pack muleswith forage for our horses.  High up on the mountain there was adeserted house of one room
column71: called the Vaqueria
column72: which had been occupiedyears before by men in charge of cattle ranging on the mountain.  Thepasturage up there was very fine when we saw it
column73: and there were stillsome cattle
column74: descendants of the former domestic herd
column75: which had nowbecome wild.  It was possible to go on horseback as far as the Vaqueria
column76: though the road was somewhat hazardous in places. Sometimes it was verynarrow with a yawning precipice on one side
column77: hundreds of feet down to aroaring mountain torrent below
column78: and almost perpendicular walls on theother side.  At one of these places one of our mules loaded with twosacks of barley
column79: one on each side
column80: the two about as big as he was
column81: struck his load against the mountain-side and was precipitated to thebottom.  The descent was steep but not perpendicular.  The mule rolledover and over until the bottom was reached
column82: and we supposed of coursethe poor animal was dashed to pieces.  What was our surprise
column83: not longafter we had gone into bivouac
column84: to see the lost mule
column85: cargo and ownercoming up the ascent.  The load had protected the animal from seriousinjury; and his owner had gone after him and found a way back to thepath leading up to the hut where we were to stay.The night at the Vaqueria was one of the most unpleasant I ever knew.It was very cold and the rain fell in torrents.  A little higher up therain ceased and snow began.  The wind blew with great velocity.  Thelog-cabin we were in had lost the roof entirely on one side
column86: and on theother it was hardly better then a sieve.  There was little or no sleepthat night.  As soon as it was light the next morning
column87: we started tomake the ascent to the summit.  The wind continued to blow with violenceand the weather was still cloudy
column88: but there was neither rain nor snow.The clouds
column89: however
column90: concealed from our view the country below us
column91: except at times a momentary glimpse could be got through a clear spacebetween them.  The wind carried the loose snow around the mountain-sidesin such volumes as to make it almost impossible to stand up against it.We labored on and on
column92: until it became evident that the top could not bereached before night
column93: if at all in such a storm
column94: and we concluded toreturn. The descent was easy and rapid
column95: though dangerous
column96: until we gotbelow the snow line.  At the cabin we mounted our horses
column97: and by nightwere at Ozumba.The fatigues of the day and the loss of sleep the night before drove usto bed early.  Our beds consisted of a place on the dirt-floor with ablanket under us.  Soon all were asleep; but long before morning firstone and then another of our party began to cry out with excruciatingpain in the eyes.  Not one escaped it.  By morning the eyes of half theparty were so swollen that they were entirely closed.  The otherssuffered pain equally.  The feeling was about what might be expectedfrom the prick of a sharp needle at a white heat.  We remained inquarters until the afternoon bathing our eyes in cold water. Thisrelieved us very much
column98: and before night the pain had entirely left.  Theswelling
column99: however
column100: continued
column101: and about half the party still had theireyes entirely closed; but we concluded to make a start back
column102: those whocould see a little leading the horses of those who could not see at all.We moved back to the village of Ameca Ameca
column103: some six miles
column104: and stoppedagain for the night.  The next morning all were entirely well and freefrom pain.  The weather was clear and Popocatapetl stood out in all itsbeauty
column105: the top looking as if not a mile away
column106: and inviting us toreturn.  About half the party were anxious to try the ascent again
column107: andconcluded to do so.  The remainder--I was with the remainder--concludedthat we had got all the pleasure there was to be had out of mountainclimbing
column108: and that we would visit the great caves of Mexico
column109: some ninetymiles from where we then were
column110: on the road to Acapulco.The party that ascended the mountain the second time succeeded inreaching the crater at the top
column111: with but little of the labor theyencountered in their first attempt.  Three of them--Anderson
column112: Stone andBuckner--wrote accounts of their journey
column113: which were published at thetime.  I made no notes of this excursion
column114: and have read nothing about itsince
column115: but it seems to me that I can see the whole of it as vividly asif it were but yesterday.  I have been back at Ameca Ameca
column116: and thevillage beyond
column117: twice in the last five years.  The scene had not changedmaterially from my recollection of it.The party which I was with moved south down the valley to the town ofCuantla
column118: some forty miles from Ameca Ameca.  The latter stands on theplain at the foot of Popocatapetl
column119: at an elevation of about eightthousand feet above tide water.  The slope down is gradual as thetraveller moves south
column120: but one would not judge that
column121: in going toCuantla
column122: descent enough had been made to occasion a material change inthe climate and productions of the soil; but such is the case.  In themorning we left a temperate climate where the cereals and fruits arethose common to the United States
column123: we halted in the evening in atropical climate where the orange and banana
column124: the coffee and thesugar-cane were flourishing.  We had been travelling
column125: apparently
column126: on a plain all day
column127: but in the direction of the flow of water.Soon after the capture of the City of Mexico an armistice had beenagreed to
column128: designating the limits beyond which troops of the respectivearmies were not to go during its continuance. Our party knew nothingabout these limits.  As we approached Cuantla bugles sounded theassembly
column129: and soldiers rushed from the guard-house in the edge of thetown towards us.  Our party halted
column130: and I tied a white pockethandkerchief to a stick and
column131: using it as a flag of truce
column132: proceeded onto the town.  Captains Sibley and Porter followed a few hundred yardsbehind.  I was detained at the guard-house until a messenger could bedispatched to the quarters of the commanding general
column133: who authorizedthat I should be conducted to him.  I had been with the general but afew minutes when the two officers following announced themselves.  TheMexican general reminded us that it was a violation of the truce for usto be there.  However
column134: as we had no special authority from our owncommanding general
column135: and as we knew nothing about the terms of the truce
column136: we were permitted to occupy a vacant house outside the guard for thenight
column137: with the promise of a guide to put us on the road to Cuernavacathe next morning.Cuernavaca is a town west of Guantla.  The country through which wepassed
column138: between these two towns
column139: is tropical in climate and productionsand rich in scenery.  At one point
column140: about half-way between the twoplaces
column141: the road goes over a low pass in the mountains in which there isa very quaint old town
column142: the inhabitants of which at that day were nearlyall full-blooded Indians.  Very few of them even spoke Spanish.  Thehouses were built of stone and generally only one story high.  Thestreets were narrow
column143: and had probably been paved before Cortez visitedthe country.  They had not been graded
column144: but the paving had been done onthe natural surface.  We had with us one vehicle
column145: a cart
column146: which wasprobably the first wheeled vehicle that had ever passed through thattown.On a hill overlooking this town stands the tomb of an ancient king; andit was understood that the inhabitants venerated this tomb very highly
column147: as well as the memory of the ruler who was supposed to be buried in it.We ascended the mountain and surveyed the tomb; but it showed noparticular marks of architectural taste
column148: mechanical skill or advancedcivilization.  The next day we went into Cuernavaca.After a day's rest at Cuernavaca our party set out again on the journeyto the great caves of Mexico.  We had proceeded but a few miles when wewere stopped
column149: as before
column150: by a guard and notified that the terms of theexisting armistice did not permit us to go further in that direction.Upon convincing the guard that we were a mere party of pleasure seekersdesirous of visiting the great natural curiosities of the country whichwe expected soon to leave
column151: we were conducted to a large hacienda nearby
column152: and directed to remain there until the commanding general of thatdepartment could be communicated with and his decision obtained as towhether we should be permitted to pursue our journey.  The guardpromised to send a messenger at once
column153: and expected a reply by night.  Atnight there was no response from the commanding general
column154: but the captainof the guard was sure he would have a reply by morning.  Again in themorning there was no reply.  The second evening the same thing happened
column155: and finally we learned that the guard had sent no message or messengerto the department commander.  We determined therefore to go on unlessstopped by a force sufficient to compel obedience.After a few hours' travel we came to a town where a scene similar to theone at Cuantia occurred.  The commanding officer sent a guide to conductour party around the village and to put us upon our road again.  Thiswas the last interruption:  that night we rested at a large coffeeplantation
column156: some eight miles from the cave we were on the way to visit.It must have been a Saturday night; the peons had been paid off
column157: andspent part of the night in gambling away their scanty week's earnings.Their coin was principally copper
column158: and I do not believe there was a manamong them who had received as much as twenty-five cents in money.  Theywere as much excited
column159: however
column160: as if they had been staking thousands.  Irecollect one poor fellow
column161: who had lost his last tlacko
column162: pulled off hisshirt and
column163: in the most excited manner
column164: put that up on the turn of acard.  Monte was the game played
column165: the place out of doors
column166: near thewindow of the room occupied by the officers of our party.The next morning we were at the mouth of the cave at an early hour
column167: provided with guides
column168: candles and rockets.  We explored to a distance ofabout three miles from the entrance
column169: and found a succession of chambersof great dimensions and of great beauty when lit up with our rockets.Stalactites and stalagmites of all sizes were discovered.  Some of theformer were many feet in diameter and extended from ceiling to floor;some of the latter were but a few feet high from the floor; but theformation is going on constantly
column170: and many centuries hence thesestalagmites will extend to the ceiling and become complete columns.  Thestalagmites were all a little concave
column171: and the cavities were filled withwater.  The water percolates through the roof
column172: a drop at a time--oftenthe drops several minutes apart--and more or less charged with mineralmatter.  Evaporation goes on slowly
column173: leaving the mineral behind.  Thisin time makes the immense columns
column174: many of them thousands of tons inweight
column175: which serve to support the roofs over the vast chambers.  Irecollect that at one point in the cave one of these columns is of suchhuge proportions that there is only a narrow passage left on either sideof it.  Some of our party became satisfied with their explorationsbefore we had reached the point to which the guides were accustomed totake explorers
column176: and started back without guides.  Coming to the largecolumn spoken of
column177: they followed it entirely around
column178: and commencedretracing their steps into the bowels of the mountain
column179: without beingaware of the fact.  When the rest of us had completed our explorations
column180: we started out with our guides
column181: but had not gone far before we saw thetorches of an approaching party.  We could not conceive who these couldbe
column182: for all of us had come in together
column183: and there were none butourselves at the entrance when we started in. Very soon we found it wasour friends.  It took them some time to conceive how they had got wherethey were.  They were sure they had kept straight on for the mouth ofthe cave
column184: and had gone about far enough to have reached it.

column1: ISFP	 XIV.RETURN OF THE ARMY--MARRIAGE--ORDERED TO THE PACIFIC COAST--CROSSING THEISTHMUS--ARRIVAL AT SAN FRANCISCO.My experience in the Mexican war was of great advantage to meafterwards.  Besides the many practical lessons it taught
column2: the warbrought nearly all the officers of the regular army together so as tomake them personally acquainted.  It also brought them in contact withvolunteers
column3: many of whom served in the war of the rebellion afterwards.Then
column4: in my particular case
column5: I had been at West Point at about the righttime to meet most of the graduates who were of a suitable age at thebreaking out of the rebellion to be trusted with large commands.Graduating in 1843
column6: I was at the military academy from one to four yearswith all cadets who graduated between 1840 and 1846--seven classes.These classes embraced more than fifty officers who afterwards becamegenerals on one side or the other in the rebellion
column7: many of them holdinghigh commands.  All the older officers
column8: who became conspicuous in therebellion
column9: I had also served with and known in Mexico:  Lee
column10: J. E.Johnston
column11: A. S. Johnston
column12: Holmes
column13: Hebert and a number of others on theConfederate side; McCall
column14: Mansfield
column15: Phil. Kearney and others on theNational side.  The acquaintance thus formed was of immense service tome in the war of the rebellion--I mean what I learned of the charactersof those to whom I was afterwards opposed.  I do not pretend to say thatall movements
column16: or even many of them
column17: were made with special reference tothe characteristics of the commander against whom they were directed.But my appreciation of my enemies was certainly affected by thisknowledge.  The natural disposition of most people is to clothe acommander of a large army whom they do not know
column18: with almost superhumanabilities.  A large part of the National army
column19: for instance
column20: and most ofthe press of the country
column21: clothed General Lee with just such qualities
column22: but I had known him personally
column23: and knew that he was mortal; and it wasjust as well that I felt this.The treaty of peace was at last ratified
column24: and the evacuation of Mexicoby United States troops was ordered.  Early in June the troops in theCity of Mexico began to move out.  Many of them
column25: including the brigadeto which I belonged
column26: were assembled at Jalapa
column27: above the vomito
column28: toawait the arrival of transports at Vera Cruz:  but with all thisprecaution my regiment and others were in camp on the sand beach in aJuly sun
column29: for about a week before embarking
column30: while the fever raged withgreat virulence in Vera Cruz
column31: not two miles away.  I can call to mindonly one person
column32: an officer
column33: who died of the disease.  My regiment wassent to Pascagoula
column34: Mississippi
column35: to spend the summer.  As soon as it wassettled in camp I obtained a leave of absence for four months andproceeded to St. Louis.  On the 22d of August
column37: I was married toMiss Julia Dent
column38: the lady of whom I have before spoken.  We visited myparents and relations in Ohio
column39: and
column40: at the end of my leave
column41: proceeded tomy post at Sackett's Harbor
column42: New York.  In April following I was orderedto Detroit
column43: Michigan
column44: where two years were spent with but few importantincidents.The present constitution of the State of Michigan was ratified duringthis time.  By the terms of one of its provisions
column45: all citizens of theUnited States residing within the State at the time of the ratificationbecame citizens of Michigan also. During my stay in Detroit there was anelection for city officers.  Mr. Zachariah Chandler was the candidate ofthe Whigs for the office of Mayor
column46: and was elected
column47: although the citywas then reckoned democratic.  All the officers stationed there at thetime who offered their votes were permitted to cast them.  I did notoffer mine
column48: however
column49: as I did not wish to consider myself a citizen ofMichigan.  This was Mr. Chandler's first entry into politics
column50: a careerhe followed ever after with great success
column51: and in which he died enjoyingthe friendship
column52: esteem and love of his countrymen.In the spring of 1851 the garrison at Detroit was transferred toSackett's Harbor
column53: and in the following spring the entire 4th infantrywas ordered to the Pacific Coast.  It was decided that Mrs. Grant shouldvisit my parents at first for a few months
column54: and then remain with her ownfamily at their St. Louis home until an opportunity offered of sendingfor her.  In the month of April the regiment was assembled at Governor'sIsland
column55: New York Harbor
column56: and on the 5th of July eight companies sailedfor Aspinwall.  We numbered a little over seven hundred persons
column57: including the families of officers and soldiers.  Passage was securedfor us on the old steamer Ohio
column58: commanded at the time by CaptainSchenck
column59: of the navy.  It had not been determined
column60: until a day or twobefore starting
column61: that the 4th infantry should go by the Ohio;consequently
column62: a complement of passengers had already been secured.  Theaddition of over seven hundred to this list crowded the steamer mostuncomfortably
column63: especially for the tropics in July.In eight days Aspinwall was reached.  At that time the streets of thetown were eight or ten inches under water
column64: and foot passengers passedfrom place to place on raised foot-walks. July is at the height of thewet season
column65: on the Isthmus.  At intervals the rain would pour down instreams
column66: followed in not many minutes by a blazing
column67: tropical summer'ssun.  These alternate changes
column68: from rain to sunshine
column69: were continuous inthe afternoons.  I wondered how any person could live many months inAspinwall
column70: and wondered still more why any one tried.In the summer of 1852 the Panama railroad was completed only to thepoint where it now crosses the Chagres River.  From there passengerswere carried by boats to Gorgona
column71: at which place they took mules forPanama
column72: some twenty-five miles further.  Those who travelled over theIsthmus in those days will remember that boats on the Chagres River werepropelled by natives not inconveniently burdened with clothing.  Theseboats carried thirty to forty passengers each.  The crews consisted ofsix men to a boat
column73: armed with long poles.  There were planks wide enoughfor a man to walk on conveniently
column74: running along the sides of each boatfrom end to end.  The men would start from the bow
column75: place one end oftheir poles against the river bottom
column76: brace their shoulders against theother end
column77: and then walk to the stern as rapidly as they could.  In thisway from a mile to a mile and a half an hour could be made
column78: against thecurrent of the river.I
column79: as regimental quartermaster
column80: had charge of the public property andhad also to look after the transportation.  A contract had been enteredinto with the steamship company in New York for the transportation ofthe regiment to California
column81: including the Isthmus transit.  A certainamount of baggage was allowed per man
column82: and saddle animals were to befurnished to commissioned officers and to all disabled persons.  Theregiment
column83: with the exception of one company left as guards to the publicproperty--camp and garrison equipage principally--and the soldiers withfamilies
column84: took boats
column85: propelled as above described
column86: for Gorgona.  Fromthis place they marched to Panama
column87: and were soon comfortably on thesteamer anchored in the bay
column88: some three or four miles from the town.  I
column89: with one company of troops and all the soldiers with families
column90: all thetents
column91: mess chests and camp kettles
column92: was sent to Cruces
column93: a town a fewmiles higher up the Chagres River than Gorgona.  There I found animpecunious American who had taken the contract to furnishtransportation for the regiment at a stipulated price per hundred poundsfor the freight and so much for each saddle animal.  But when we reachedCruces there was not a mule
column94: either for pack or saddle
column95: in the place.The contractor promised that the animals should be on hand in themorning.  In the morning he said that they were on the way from someimaginary place
column96: and would arrive in the course of the day.  This wenton until I saw that he could not procure the animals at all at the pricehe had promised to furnish them for.  The unusual number of passengersthat had come over on the steamer
column97: and the large amount of freight topack
column98: had created an unprecedented demand for mules.  Some of thepassengers paid as high as forty dollars for the use of a mule to ridetwenty-five miles
column99: when the mule would not have sold for ten dollars inthat market at other times. Meanwhile the cholera had broken out
column100: andmen were dying every hour.  To diminish the food for the disease
column101: Ipermitted the company detailed with me to proceed to Panama.  Thecaptain and the doctors accompanied the men
column102: and I was left alone withthe sick and the soldiers who had families.  The regiment at Panama wasalso affected with the disease; but there were better accommodations forthe well on the steamer
column103: and a hospital
column104: for those taken with thedisease
column105: on an old hulk anchored a mile off.  There were also hospitaltents on shore on the island of Flamingo
column106: which stands in the bay.I was about a week at Cruces before transportation began to come in.About one-third of the people with me died
column107: either at Cruces or on theway to Panama.  There was no agent of the transportation company atCruces to consult
column108: or to take the responsibility of procuringtransportation at a price which would secure it.  I therefore myselfdismissed the contractor and made a new contract with a native
column109: at morethan double the original price.  Thus we finally reached Panama.  Thesteamer
column110: however
column111: could not proceed until the cholera abated
column112: and theregiment was detained still longer.  Altogether
column113: on the Isthmus and onthe Pacific side
column114: we were delayed six weeks.  About one-seventh of thosewho left New York harbor with the 4th infantry on the 5th of July
column115: nowlie buried on the Isthmus of Panama or on Flamingo island in Panama Bay.One amusing circumstance occurred while we were lying at anchor inPanama Bay.  In the regiment there was a Lieutenant Slaughter who wasvery liable to sea-sickness.  It almost made him sick to see the wave ofa table-cloth when the servants were spreading it.  Soon after hisgraduation
column116: Slaughter was ordered to California and took passage by asailing vessel going around Cape Horn.  The vessel was seven monthsmaking the voyage
column117: and Slaughter was sick every moment of the time
column118: never more so than while lying at anchor after reaching his place ofdestination. On landing in California he found orders which had come bythe Isthmus
column119: notifying him of a mistake in his assignment; he shouldhave been ordered to the northern lakes.  He started back by the Isthmusroute and was sick all the way.  But when he arrived at the East he wasagain ordered to California
column120: this time definitely
column121: and at this date wasmaking his third trip.  He was as sick as ever
column122: and had been so for morethan a month while lying at anchor in the bay.  I remember him well
column123: seated with his elbows on the table in front of him
column124: his chin betweenhis hands
column125: and looking the picture of despair.  At last he broke out
column126: 'Iwish I had taken my father's advice; he wanted me to go into the navy;if I had done so
column127: I should not have had to go to sea so much.'  PoorSlaughter! it was his last sea voyage.  He was killed by Indians inOregon.By the last of August the cholera had so abated that it was deemed safeto start.  The disease did not break out again on the way to California
column128: and we reached San Francisco early in September.

column1: ISFP	 XV.SAN FRANCISCO--EARLY CALIFORNIA EXPERIENCES--LIFE ON THE PACIFIC COAST--PROMOTED CAPTAIN--FLUSH TIMES IN CALIFORNIA.San Francisco at that day was a lively place.  Gold
column2: or placer diggingas it was called
column3: was at its height.  Steamers plied daily between SanFrancisco and both Stockton and Sacramento. Passengers and gold from thesouthern mines came by the Stockton boat; from the northern mines bySacramento.  In the evening when these boats arrived
column4: Long Wharf--therewas but one wharf in San Francisco in 1852--was alive with peoplecrowding to meet the miners as they came down to sell their 'dust' andto 'have a time.'  Of these some were runners for hotels
column5: boardinghouses or restaurants; others belonged to a class of impecuniousadventurers
column6: of good manners and good presence
column7: who were ever on thealert to make the acquaintance of people with some ready means
column8: in thehope of being asked to take a meal at a restaurant.  Many were young menof good family
column9: good education and gentlemanly instincts.  Their parentshad been able to support them during their minority
column10: and to give themgood educations
column11: but not to maintain them afterwards.  From 1849 to 1853there was a rush of people to the Pacific coast
column12: of the class described.All thought that fortunes were to be picked up
column13: without effort
column14: in thegold fields on the Pacific.  Some realized more than their most sanguineexpectations; but for one such there were hundreds disappointed
column15: many ofwhom now fill unknown graves; others died wrecks of their former selves
column16: and many
column17: without a vicious instinct
column18: became criminals and outcasts.Many of the real scenes in early California life exceed in strangenessand interest any of the mere products of the brain of the novelist.Those early days in California brought out character.  It was a long wayoff then
column19: and the journey was expensive.  The fortunate could go by CapeHorn or by the Isthmus of Panama; but the mass of pioneers crossed theplains with their ox-teams.  This took an entire summer.  They were verylucky when they got through with a yoke of worn-out cattle.  All othermeans were exhausted in procuring the outfit on the Missouri River.  Theimmigrant
column20: on arriving
column21: found himself a stranger
column22: in a strange land

Four years later the Republican party was successful inelecting its candidate to the Presidency.  The civilized world haslearned the consequence.  Four millions of human beings held as chattelshave been liberated; the ballot has been given to them; the free schoolsof the country have been opened to their children.  The nation stilllives

The fact is the constitutiondid not apply to any such contingency as the one existing from 1861 to1865.  Its framers never dreamed of such a contingency occurring.  Ifthey had foreseen it

column148: and under unforeseencontingencies.  At the time of the framing of our constitution the onlyphysical forces that had been subdued and made to serve man and do hislabor
column149: were the currents in the streams and in the air we breathe. Rudemachinery
column150: propelled by water power

Theinstantaneous transmission of messages around the world by means ofelectricity would probably at that day have been attributed towitchcraft or a league with the Devil.  Immaterial circumstances hadchanged as greatly as material ones.  We could not and ought not to berigidly bound by the rules laid down under circumstances so differentfor emergencies so utterly unanticipated.  The fathers themselves wouldhave been the first to declare that their prerogatives were notirrevocable.  They would surely have resisted secession could they havelived to see the shape it assumed.I travelled through the Northwest considerably during the winter of1860-1.  We had customers in all the little towns in south-westWisconsin

Masked men did not ride over the countryat night intimidating voters; but there was a firm feeling that a classexisted in every State with a sort of divine right to control publicaffairs.  If they could not get this control by one means they must byanother.  The end justified the means.  The coercion

column194: Kentucky andMissouri
