column196: failed to pass ordinances of secession; butthey were all represented in the so-called congress of the so-calledConfederate States.  The Governor and Lieutenant-Governor of Missouri
column198: Jackson and Reynolds
column199: were both supporters of the rebellion andtook refuge with the enemy.  The governor soon died
column200: and thelieutenant-governor assumed his office; issued proclamations as governorof the State; was recognized as such by the Confederate Government
column201: andcontinued his pretensions until the collapse of the rebellion. The Southclaimed the sovereignty of States
column202: but claimed the right to coerce intotheir confederation such States as they wanted
column203: that is
column204: all the Stateswhere slavery existed.  They did not seem to think this courseinconsistent.  The fact is
column205: the Southern slave-owners believed that
column206: insome way
column207: the ownership of slaves conferred a sort of patent ofnobility--a right to govern independent of the interest or wishes ofthose who did not hold such property.  They convinced themselves
column208: first
column209: of the divine origin of the institution and
column210: next
column211: that that particularinstitution was not safe in the hands of any body of legislators butthemselves.Meanwhile the Administration of President Buchanan looked helplessly onand proclaimed that the general government had no power to interfere;that the Nation had no power to save its own life.  Mr. Buchanan had inhis cabinet two members at least
column212: who were as earnest--to use a mildterm--in the cause of secession as Mr. Davis or any Southern statesman.One of them
column213: Floyd
column214: the Secretary of War
column215: scattered the army so thatmuch of it could be captured when hostilities should commence
column216: anddistributed the cannon and small arms from Northern arsenals throughoutthe South so as to be on hand when treason wanted them.  The navy wasscattered in like manner.  The President did not prevent his cabinetpreparing for war upon their government
column217: either by destroying itsresources or storing them in the South until a de facto government wasestablished with Jefferson Davis as its President
column218: and Montgomery
column219: Alabama
column220: as the Capital.  The secessionists had then to leave thecabinet.  In their own estimation they were aliens in the country whichhad given them birth.  Loyal men were put into their places.  Treason inthe executive branch of the government was estopped.  But the harm hadalready been done.  The stable door was locked after the horse had beenstolen.During all of the trying winter of 1860-1
column221: when the Southerners were sodefiant that they would not allow within their borders the expression ofa sentiment hostile to their views
column222: it was a brave man indeed who couldstand up and proclaim his loyalty to the Union.  On the other hand menat the North--prominent men--proclaimed that the government had no powerto coerce the South into submission to the laws of the land; that if theNorth undertook to raise armies to go south
column223: these armies would have tomarch over the dead bodies of the speakers.  A portion of the press ofthe North was constantly proclaiming similar views. When the timearrived for the President-elect to go to the capital of the Nation to besworn into office
column224: it was deemed unsafe for him to travel
column225: not only as aPresident-elect
column226: but as any private citizen should be allowed to do.Instead of going in a special car
column227: receiving the good wishes of hisconstituents at all the stations along the road
column228: he was obliged to stopon the way and to be smuggled into the capital.  He disappeared frompublic view on his journey
column229: and the next the country knew
column230: his arrivalwas announced at the capital.  There is little doubt that he would havebeen assassinated if he had attempted to travel openly throughout hisjourney.

column1: ISFP	 XVII.OUTBREAK OF THE REBELLION--PRESIDING AT A UNION MEETING--MUSTERINGOFFICER OF STATE TROOPS--LYON AT CAMP JACKSON--SERVICES TENDERED TO THEGOVERNMENT.The 4th of March
column3: came
column4: and Abraham Lincoln was sworn to maintainthe Union against all its enemies.  The secession of one State afteranother followed
column5: until eleven had gone out.  On the 11th of April FortSumter
column6: a National fort in the harbor of Charleston
column7: South Carolina
column8: wasfired upon by the Southerners and a few days after was captured.  TheConfederates proclaimed themselves aliens
column9: and thereby debarredthemselves of all right to claim protection under the Constitution ofthe United States.  We did not admit the fact that they were aliens
column10: butall the same
column11: they debarred themselves of the right to expect bettertreatment than people of any other foreign state who make war upon anindependent nation.  Upon the firing on Sumter President Lincoln issuedhis first call for troops and soon after a proclamation conveningCongress in extra session.  The call was for 75
column12: 000 volunteers forninety days' service.  If the shot fired at Fort Sumter 'was heardaround the world
column13: ' the call of the President for 75
column14: 000 men was heardthroughout the Northern States.  There was not a state in the North of amillion of inhabitants that would not have furnished the entire numberfaster than arms could have been supplied to them
column15: if it had beennecessary.As soon as the news of the call for volunteers reached Galena
column16: posterswere stuck up calling for a meeting of the citizens at the court-housein the evening.  Business ceased entirely; all was excitement; for atime there were no party distinctions; all were Union men
column17: determined toavenge the insult to the national flag.  In the evening the court-housewas packed.  Although a comparative stranger I was called upon topreside; the sole reason
column18: possibly
column19: was that I had been in the army andhad seen service.  With much embarrassment and some prompting I made outto announce the object of the meeting.  Speeches were in order
column20: but itis doubtful whether it would have been safe just then to make other thanpatriotic ones.  There was probably no one in the house
column21: however
column22: whofelt like making any other.  The two principal speeches were by B. B.Howard
column23: the post-master and a Breckinridge Democrat at the Novemberelection the fall before
column24: and John A. Rawlins
column25: an elector on the Douglasticket.  E. B. Washburne
column26: with whom I was not acquainted at that time
column27: came in after the meeting had been organized
column28: and expressed
column29: Iunderstood afterwards
column30: a little surprise that Galena could not furnish apresiding officer for such an occasion without taking a stranger.  Hecame forward and was introduced
column31: and made a speech appealing to thepatriotism of the meeting.After the speaking was over volunteers were called for to form acompany.  The quota of Illinois had been fixed at six regiments; and itwas supposed that one company would be as much as would be accepted fromGalena.  The company was raised and the officers and non-commissionedofficers elected before the meeting adjourned.  I declined the captaincybefore the balloting
column32: but announced that I would aid the company inevery way I could and would be found in the service in some position ifthere should be a war.  I never went into our leather store after thatmeeting
column33: to put up a package or do other business.The ladies of Galena were quite as patriotic as the men.  They could notenlist
column34: but they conceived the idea of sending their first company tothe field uniformed.  They came to me to get a description of the UnitedStates uniform for infantry; subscribed and bought the material;procured tailors to cut out the garments
column35: and the ladies made them up.In a few days the company was in uniform and ready to report at theState capital for assignment.  The men all turned out the morning aftertheir enlistment
column36: and I took charge
column37: divided them into squads andsuperintended their drill.  When they were ready to go to Springfield Iwent with them and remained there until they were assigned to aregiment.There were so many more volunteers than had been called for that thequestion whom to accept was quite embarrassing to the governor
column38: RichardYates.  The legislature was in session at the time
column39: however
column40: and came tohis relief.  A law was enacted authorizing the governor to accept theservices of ten additional regiments
column41: one from each congressionaldistrict
column42: for one month
column43: to be paid by the State
column44: but pledged to go intothe service of the United States if there should be a further callduring their term.  Even with this relief the governor was still verymuch embarrassed.  Before the war was over he was like the Presidentwhen he was taken with the varioloid:  'at last he had something hecould give to all who wanted it.'In time the Galena company was mustered into the United States service
column45: forming a part of the 11th Illinois volunteer infantry.  My duties
column46: Ithought
column47: had ended at Springfield
column48: and I was prepared to start home bythe evening train
column49: leaving at nine o'clock.  Up to that time I do notthink I had been introduced to Governor Yates
column50: or had ever spoken tohim.  I knew him by sight
column51: however
column52: because he was living at the samehotel and I often saw him at table.  The evening I was to quit thecapital I left the supper room before the governor and was standing atthe front door when he came out.  He spoke to me
column53: calling me by my oldarmy title 'Captain
column54: ' and said he understood that I was about leavingthe city.  I answered that I was.  He said he would be glad if I wouldremain over-night and call at the Executive office the next morning.I complied with his request
column55: and was asked to go into theAdjutant-General's office and render such assistance as I could
column56: thegovernor saying that my army experience would be of great service there.I accepted the proposition.My old army experience I found indeed of very great service.  I was noclerk
column57: nor had I any capacity to become one.  The only place I everfound in my life to put a paper so as to find it again was either a sidecoat-pocket or the hands of a clerk or secretary more careful thanmyself.  But I had been quartermaster
column58: commissary and adjutant in thefield.  The army forms were familiar to me and I could direct how theyshould be made out.  There was a clerk in the office of theAdjutant-General who supplied my deficiencies.  The ease with which theState of Illinois settled its accounts with the government at the closeof the war is evidence of the efficiency of Mr. Loomis as an accountanton a large scale.  He remained in the office until that time.As I have stated
column59: the legislature authorized the governor to accept theservices of ten additional regiments.  I had charge of mustering theseregiments into the State service.  They were assembled at the mostconvenient railroad centres in their respective congressional districts.I detailed officers to muster in a portion of them
column60: but mustered threein the southern part of the State myself.  One of these was to assembleat Belleville
column61: some eighteen miles south-east of St. Louis.  When I gotthere I found that only one or two companies had arrived. There was noprobability of the regiment coming together under five days.  This gaveme a few idle days which I concluded to spend in St. Louis.There was a considerable force of State militia at Camp Jackson
column62: on theoutskirts of St. Louis
column63: at the time.  There is but little doubt that itwas the design of Governor Claiborn Jackson to have these troops readyto seize the United States arsenal and the city of St. Louis.  Why theydid not do so I do not know. There was but a small garrison
column64: twocompanies I think
column65: under Captain N. Lyon at the arsenal
column66: and but for thetimely services of the Hon. F. P. Blair
column67: I have little doubt that St.Louis would have gone into rebel hands
column68: and with it the arsenal with allits arms and ammunition.Blair was a leader among the Union men of St. Louis in 1861. There wasno State government in Missouri at the time that would sanction theraising of troops or commissioned officers to protect United Statesproperty
column69: but Blair had probably procured some form of authority fromthe President to raise troops in Missouri and to muster them into theservice of the United States.  At all events
column70: he did raise a regimentand took command himself as Colonel.  With this force he reported toCaptain Lyon and placed himself and regiment under his orders.  It waswhispered that Lyon thus reinforced intended to break up Camp Jacksonand capture the militia.  I went down to the arsenal in the morning tosee the troops start out.  I had known Lyon for two years at West Pointand in the old army afterwards.  Blair I knew very well by sight.  I hadheard him speak in the canvass of 1858
column71: possibly several times
column72: but Ihad never spoken to him.  As the troops marched out of the enclosurearound the arsenal
column73: Blair was on his horse outside forming them intoline preparatory to their march.  I introduced myself to him and had afew moments' conversation and expressed my sympathy with his purpose.This was my first personal acquaintance with the Honorable--afterwardsMajor-General F. P. Blair.  Camp Jackson surrendered without a fight andthe garrison was marched down to the arsenal as prisoners of war.Up to this time the enemies of the government in St. Louis had been boldand defiant
column74: while Union men were quiet but determined.  The enemies hadtheir head-quarters in a central and public position on Pine Street
column75: near Fifth--from which the rebel flag was flaunted boldly.  The Unionmen had a place of meeting somewhere in the city
column76: I did not know where
column77: and I doubt whether they dared to enrage the enemies of the governmentby placing the national flag outside their head-quarters.  As soon asthe news of the capture of Camp Jackson reached the city the conditionof affairs was changed.  Union men became rampant
column78: aggressive
column79: and
column80: ifyou will
column81: intolerant.  They proclaimed their sentiments boldly
column82: and wereimpatient at anything like disrespect for the Union.  The secessionistsbecame quiet but were filled with suppressed rage.  They had beenplaying the bully.  The Union men ordered the rebel flag taken down fromthe building on Pine Street.  The command was given in tones ofauthority and it was taken down
column83: never to be raised again in St. Louis.I witnessed the scene.  I had heard of the surrender of the camp andthat the garrison was on its way to the arsenal.  I had seen the troopsstart out in the morning and had wished them success.  I now determinedto go to the arsenal and await their arrival and congratulate them.  Istepped on a car standing at the corner of 4th and Pine streets
column84: and sawa crowd of people standing quietly in front of the head-quarters
column85: whowere there for the purpose of hauling down the flag.  There were squadsof other people at intervals down the street.  They too were quiet butfilled with suppressed rage
column86: and muttered their resentment at the insultto
column87: what they called
column88: 'their' flag.  Before the car I was in hadstarted
column89: a dapper little fellow--he would be called a dude at this day--stepped in.  He was in a great state of excitement and used adjectivesfreely to express his contempt for the Union and for those who had justperpetrated such an outrage upon the rights of a free people.  There wasonly one other passenger in the car besides myself when this young manentered.  He evidently expected to find nothing but sympathy when he gotaway from the 'mud sills' engaged in compelling a 'free people' to pulldown a flag they adored.  He turned to me saying:  'Things have come toa ---- pretty pass when a free people can't choose their own flag.Where I came from if a man dares to say a word in favor of the Union wehang him to a limb of the first tree we come to.'  I replied that 'afterall we were not so intolerant in St. Louis as we might be; I had notseen a single rebel hung yet
column90: nor heard of one; there were plenty ofthem who ought to be
column91: however.'  The young man subsided.  He was socrestfallen that I believe if I had ordered him to leave the car hewould have gone quietly out
column92: saying to himself:  'More Yankeeoppression.'By nightfall the late defenders of Camp Jackson were all within thewalls of the St. Louis arsenal
column93: prisoners of war.  The next day I leftSt. Louis for Mattoon
column94: Illinois
column95: where I was to muster in the regimentfrom that congressional district.  This was the 21st Illinois infantry
column96: the regiment of which I subsequently became colonel.  I mustered oneregiment afterwards
column97: when my services for the State were about closed.Brigadier-General John Pope was stationed at Springfield
column98: as UnitedStates mustering officer
column99: all the time I was in the State service.  Hewas a native of Illinois and well acquainted with most of the prominentmen in the State.  I was a carpet-bagger and knew but few of them.While I was on duty at Springfield the senators
column100: representatives inCongress
column101: ax-governors and the State legislators were nearly all at theState capital.  The only acquaintance I made among them was with thegovernor
column102: whom I was serving
column103: and
column104: by chance
column105: with Senator S. A.Douglas.  The only members of Congress I knew were Washburne and PhilipFoulk.  With the former
column106: though he represented my district and we werecitizens of the same town
column107: I only became acquainted at the meeting whenthe first company of Galena volunteers was raised.  Foulk I had known inSt. Louis when I was a citizen of that city.  I had been three years atWest Point with Pope and had served with him a short time during theMexican war
column108: under General Taylor.  I saw a good deal of him during myservice with the State.  On one occasion he said to me that I ought togo into the United States service.  I told him I intended to do so ifthere was a war.  He spoke of his acquaintance with the public men ofthe State
column109: and said he could get them to recommend me for a position andthat he would do all he could for me.  I declined to receive endorsementfor permission to fight for my country.Going home for a day or two soon after this conversation with GeneralPope
column110: I wrote from Galena the following letter to the Adjutant-Generalof the Army.GALENA
column111: ILLINOIS
column112: May 24
column113: 1861.COL. L. THOMAS Adjt.  Gen.  U. S. A.
column114: Washington
column115: D. C.SIR:--Having served for fifteen years in the regular army
column116: includingfour years at West Point
column117: and feeling it the duty of every one who hasbeen educated at the Government expense to offer their services for thesupport of that Government
column118: I have the honor
column119: very respectfully
column120: totender my services
column121: until the close of the war
column122: in such capacity as maybe offered.  I would say
column123: in view of my present age and length ofservice
column124: I feel myself competent to command a regiment
column125: if thePresident
column126: in his judgment
column127: should see fit to intrust one to me.Since the first call of the President I have been serving on the staffof the Governor of this State
column128: rendering such aid as I could in theorganization of our State militia
column129: and am still engaged in thatcapacity.  A letter addressed to me at Springfield
column130: Illinois
column131: will reachme.I am very respectfully
column132: Your obt. svt.
column133: U. S. GRANT.This letter failed to elicit an answer from the Adjutant-General of theArmy.  I presume it was hardly read by him
column134: and certainly it could nothave been submitted to higher authority. Subsequent to the war GeneralBadeau having heard of this letter applied to the War Department for acopy of it.  The letter could not be found and no one recollected everhaving seen it.  I took no copy when it was written.  Long after theapplication of General Badeau
column135: General Townsend
column136: who had becomeAdjutant-General of the Army
column137: while packing up papers preparatory to theremoval of his office
column138: found this letter in some out-of-the-way place.It had not been destroyed
column139: but it had not been regularly filed away.I felt some hesitation in suggesting rank as high as the colonelcy of aregiment
column140: feeling somewhat doubtful whether I would be equal to theposition.  But I had seen nearly every colonel who had been mustered infrom the State of Illinois
column141: and some from Indiana
column142: and felt that if theycould command a regiment properly
column143: and with credit
column144: I could also.Having but little to do after the muster of the last of the regimentsauthorized by the State legislature
column145: I asked and obtained of thegovernor leave of absence for a week to visit my parents in Covington
column146: Kentucky
column147: immediately opposite Cincinnati.  General McClellan had beenmade a major-general and had his headquarters at Cincinnati.  In realityI wanted to see him.  I had known him slightly at West Point
column148: where weserved one year together
column149: and in the Mexican war.  I was in hopes thatwhen he saw me he would offer me a position on his staff.  I called ontwo successive days at his office but failed to see him on eitheroccasion
column150: and returned to Springfield.

column1: ISFP	 XVIII.APPOINTED COLONEL OF THE 21ST ILLINOIS--PERSONNEL OF THE REGIMENT--GENERAL LOGAN--MARCH TO MISSOURI--MOVEMENT AGAINST HARRIS AT FLORIDA
column2: MO.--GENERAL POPE IN COMMAND--STATIONED AT MEXICO
column3: MO.While I was absent from the State capital on this occasion thePresident's second call for troops was issued.  This time it was for300
column4: 000 men
column5: for three years or the war.  This brought into the UnitedStates service all the regiments then in the State service.  These hadelected their officers from highest to lowest and were accepted withtheir organizations as they were
column6: except in two instances.  A Chicagoregiment
column7: the 19th infantry
column8: had elected a very young man to thecolonelcy.  When it came to taking the field the regiment asked to haveanother appointed colonel and the one they had previously chosen madelieutenant-colonel.  The 21st regiment of infantry
column9: mustered in by me atMattoon
column10: refused to go into the service with the colonel of theirselection in any position.  While I was still absent Governor Yatesappointed me colonel of this latter regiment.  A few days after I was incharge of it and in camp on the fair grounds near Springfield.My regiment was composed in large part of young men of as good socialposition as any in their section of the State.  It embraced the sons offarmers
column11: lawyers
column12: physicians
column13: politicians
column14: merchants
column15: bankers andministers
column16: and some men of maturer years who had filled such positionsthemselves.  There were also men in it who could be led astray; and thecolonel
column17: elected by the votes of the regiment
column18: had proved to be fullycapable of developing all there was in his men of recklessness.  It wassaid that he even went so far at times as to take the guard from theirposts and go with them to the village near by and make a night of it.When there came a prospect of battle the regiment wanted to have someone else to lead them.  I found it very hard work for a few days tobring all the men into anything like subordination; but the greatmajority favored discipline
column19: and by the application of a little regulararmy punishment all were reduced to as good discipline as one could ask.The ten regiments which had volunteered in the State service for thirtydays
column20: it will be remembered
column21: had done so with a pledge to go into theNational service if called upon within that time. When they volunteeredthe government had only called for ninety days' enlistments.  Men werecalled now for three years or the war.  They felt that this change ofperiod released them from the obligation of re-volunteering.  When I wasappointed colonel
column22: the 21st regiment was still in the State service.About the time they were to be mustered into the United States service
column23: such of them as would go
column24: two members of Congress from the State
column25: McClernand and Logan
column26: appeared at the capital and I was introduced tothem.  I had never seen either of them before
column27: but I had read a greatdeal about them
column28: and particularly about Logan
column29: in the newspapers.  Bothwere democratic members of Congress
column30: and Logan had been elected from thesouthern district of the State
column31: where he had a majority of eighteenthousand over his Republican competitor.  His district had been settledoriginally by people from the Southern States
column32: and at the breaking outof secession they sympathized with the South.  At the first outbreak ofwar some of them joined the Southern army; many others were preparing todo so; others rode over the country at night denouncing the Union
column33: andmade it as necessary to guard railroad bridges over which Nationaltroops had to pass in southern Illinois
column34: as it was in Kentucky or any ofthe border slave states.  Logan's popularity in this district wasunbounded.  He knew almost enough of the people in it by their Christiannames
column35: to form an ordinary congressional district.  As he went inpolitics
column36: so his district was sure to go.  The Republican papers hadbeen demanding that he should announce where he stood on the questionswhich at that time engrossed the whole of public thought.  Some werevery bitter in their denunciations of his silence.  Logan was not a manto be coerced into an utterance by threats.  He did
column37: however
column38: come outin a speech before the adjournment of the special session of Congresswhich was convened by the President soon after his inauguration
column39: andannounced his undying loyalty and devotion to the Union. But I had nothappened to see that speech
column40: so that when I first met Logan myimpressions were those formed from reading denunciations of him.McClernand
column41: on the other hand
column42: had early taken strong grounds for themaintenance of the Union and had been praised accordingly by theRepublican papers.  The gentlemen who presented these two members ofCongress asked me if I would have any objections to their addressing myregiment.  I hesitated a little before answering.  It was but a few daysbefore the time set for mustering into the United States service such ofthe men as were willing to volunteer for three years or the war.  I hadsome doubt as to the effect a speech from Logan might have; but as hewas with McClernand
column43: whose sentiments on the all-absorbing questions ofthe day were well known
column44: I gave my consent.  McClernand spoke first; andLogan followed in a speech which he has hardly equalled since for forceand eloquence.  It breathed a loyalty and devotion to the Union whichinspired my men to such a point that they would have volunteered toremain in the army as long as an enemy of the country continued to beararms against it.  They entered the United States service almost to aman.General Logan went to his part of the State and gave his attention toraising troops.  The very men who at first made it necessary to guardthe roads in southern Illinois became the defenders of the Union.  Loganentered the service himself as colonel of a regiment and rapidly rose tothe rank of major-general.  His district
column45: which had promised at first togive much trouble to the government
column46: filled every call made upon it fortroops
column47: without resorting to the draft.  There was no call made whenthere were not more volunteers than were asked for. That congressionaldistrict stands credited at the War Department to-day with furnishingmore men for the army than it was called on to supply.I remained in Springfield with my regiment until the 3d of July
column48: when Iwas ordered to Quincy
column49: Illinois.  By that time the regiment was in agood state of discipline and the officers and men were well up in thecompany drill.  There was direct railroad communication betweenSpringfield and Quincy
column50: but I thought it would be good preparation forthe troops to march there.  We had no transportation for our camp andgarrison equipage
column51: so wagons were hired for the occasion and on the 3dof July we started.  There was no hurry
column52: but fair marches were madeevery day until the Illinois River was crossed.  There I was overtakenby a dispatch saying that the destination of the regiment had beenchanged to Ironton
column53: Missouri
column54: and ordering me to halt where I was andawait the arrival of a steamer which had been dispatched up the IllinoisRiver to take the regiment to St. Louis.  The boat
column55: when it did come
column56: grounded on a sand-bar a few miles below where we were in camp.  Weremained there several days waiting to have the boat get off the bar
column57: but before this occurred news came that an Illinois regiment wassurrounded by rebels at a point on the Hannibal and St. Joe Railroadsome miles west of Palmyra
column58: in Missouri
column59: and I was ordered to proceedwith all dispatch to their relief.  We took the cars and reached Quincyin a few hours.When I left Galena for the last time to take command of the 21stregiment I took with me my oldest son
column60: Frederick D. Grant
column61: then a lad ofeleven years of age.  On receiving the order to take rail for Quincy Iwrote to Mrs. Grant
column62: to relieve what I supposed would be her greatanxiety for one so young going into danger
column63: that I would send Fred homefrom Quincy by river.  I received a prompt letter in reply decidedlydisapproving my proposition
column64: and urging that the lad should be allowedto accompany me.  It came too late.  Fred was already on his way up theMississippi bound for Dubuque
column65: Iowa
column66: from which place there was arailroad to Galena.My sensations as we approached what I supposed might be 'a field ofbattle' were anything but agreeable.  I had been in all the engagementsin Mexico that it was possible for one person to be in; but not incommand.  If some one else had been colonel and I had beenlieutenant-colonel I do not think I would have felt any trepidation.Before we were prepared to cross the Mississippi River at Quincy myanxiety was relieved; for the men of the besieged regiment camestraggling into town.  I am inclined to think both sides got frightenedand ran away.I took my regiment to Palmyra and remained there for a few days
column67: untilrelieved by the 19th Illinois infantry.  From Palmyra I proceeded toSalt River
column68: the railroad bridge over which had been destroyed by theenemy.  Colonel John M. Palmer at that time commanded the 13th Illinois
column69: which was acting as a guard to workmen who were engaged in rebuildingthis bridge.  Palmer was my senior and commanded the two regiments aslong as we remained together.  The bridge was finished in about twoweeks
column70: and I received orders to move against Colonel Thomas Harris
column71: whowas said to be encamped at the little town of Florida
column72: some twenty-fivemiles south of where we then were.At the time of which I now write we had no transportation and thecountry about Salt River was sparsely settled
column73: so that it took some daysto collect teams and drivers enough to move the camp and garrisonequipage of a regiment nearly a thousand strong
column74: together with a week'ssupply of provision and some ammunition.  While preparations for themove were going on I felt quite comfortable; but when we got on the roadand found every house deserted I was anything but easy.  In thetwenty-five miles we had to march we did not see a person
column75: old or young
column76: male or female
column77: except two horsemen who were on a road that crossedours.  As soon as they saw us they decamped as fast as their horsescould carry them.  I kept my men in the ranks and forbade their enteringany of the deserted houses or taking anything from them.  We halted atnight on the road and proceeded the next morning at an early hour.Harris had been encamped in a creek bottom for the sake of being nearwater. The hills on either side of the creek extend to a considerableheight
column78: possibly more than a hundred feet.  As we approached the brow ofthe hill from which it was expected we could see Harris' camp
column79: andpossibly find his men ready formed to meet us
column80: my heart kept gettinghigher and higher until it felt to me as though it was in my throat.  Iwould have given anything then to have been back in Illinois
column81: but I hadnot the moral courage to halt and consider what to do; I kept right on.When we reached a point from which the valley below was in full view Ihalted. The place where Harris had been encamped a few days before wasstill there and the marks of a recent encampment were plainly visible
column82: but the troops were gone.  My heart resumed its place.  It occurred tome at once that Harris had been as much afraid of me as I had been ofhim. This was a view of the question I had never taken before; but itwas one I never forgot afterwards.  From that event to the close of thewar
column83: I never experienced trepidation upon confronting an enemy
column84: though Ialways felt more or less anxiety.  I never forgot that he had as muchreason to fear my forces as I had his.  The lesson was valuable.Inquiries at the village of Florida divulged the fact that ColonelHarris
column85: learning of my intended movement
column86: while my transportation wasbeing collected took time by the forelock and left Florida before I hadstarted from Salt River.  He had increased the distance between us byforty miles.  The next day I started back to my old camp at Salt Riverbridge.  The citizens living on the line of our march had returned totheir houses after we passed
column87: and finding everything in good order
column88: nothing carried away
column89: they were at their front doors ready to greet usnow.  They had evidently been led to believe that the National troopscarried death and devastation with them wherever they went.In a short time after our return to Salt River bridge I was ordered withmy regiment to the town of Mexico.  General Pope was then commanding thedistrict embracing all of the State of Missouri between the Mississippiand Missouri rivers
column90: with his headquarters in the village of Mexico.  Iwas assigned to the command of a sub-district embracing the troops inthe immediate neighborhood
column91: some three regiments of infantry and asection of artillery.  There was one regiment encamped by the side ofmine.  I assumed command of the whole and the first night sent thecommander of the other regiment the parole and countersign.  Not wishingto be outdone in courtesy
column92: he immediately sent me the countersign forhis regiment for the night.  When he was informed that the countersignsent to him was for use with his regiment as well as mine
column93: it wasdifficult to make him understand that this was not an unwarrantedinterference of one colonel over another.  No doubt he attributed it forthe time to the presumption of a graduate of West Point over a volunteerpure and simple.  But the question was soon settled and we had nofurther trouble.My arrival in Mexico had been preceded by that of two or three regimentsin which proper discipline had not been maintained
column94: and the men had beenin the habit of visiting houses without invitation and helpingthemselves to food and drink
column95: or demanding them from the occupants.They carried their muskets while out of camp and made every man theyfound take the oath of allegiance to the government.  I at oncepublished orders prohibiting the soldiers from going into private housesunless invited by the inhabitants
column96: and from appropriating privateproperty to their own or to government uses.  The people were no longermolested or made afraid.  I received the most marked courtesy from thecitizens of Mexico as long as I remained there.Up to this time my regiment had not been carried in the school of thesoldier beyond the company drill
column97: except that it had received sometraining on the march from Springfield to the Illinois River.  There wasnow a good opportunity of exercising it in the battalion drill.  While Iwas at West Point the tactics used in the army had been Scott's and themusket the flint lock.  I had never looked at a copy of tactics from thetime of my graduation.  My standing in that branch of studies had beennear the foot of the class.  In the Mexican war in the summer of 1846
column98: Ihad been appointed regimental quartermaster and commissary and had notbeen at a battalion drill since.  The arms had been changed since thenand Hardee's tactics had been adopted.  I got a copy of tactics andstudied one lesson
column99: intending to confine the exercise of the first dayto the commands I had thus learned.  By pursuing this course from day today I thought I would soon get through the volume.We were encamped just outside of town on the common
column100: among scatteringsuburban houses with enclosed gardens
column101: and when I got my regiment inline and rode to the front I soon saw that if I attempted to follow thelesson I had studied I would have to clear away some of the houses andgarden fences to make room.  I perceived at once
column102: however
column103: that Hardee'stactics--a mere translation from the French with Hardee's name attached--was nothing more than common sense and the progress of the age appliedto Scott's system.  The commands were abbreviated and the movementexpedited.  Under the old tactics almost every change in the order ofmarch was preceded by a 'halt
column104: ' then came the change
column105: and then the'forward march.'  With the new tactics all these changes could be madewhile in motion.  I found no trouble in giving commands that would takemy regiment where I wanted it to go and carry it around all obstacles.I do not believe that the officers of the regiment ever discovered thatI had never studied the tactics that I used.

column1: ISFP	 XIX.COMMISSIONED BRIGADIER-GENERAL--COMMAND AT IRONTON
column2: MO.--JEFFERSON CITY--CAPE GIRARDEAU--GENERAL PRENTISS--SEIZURE OF PADUCAH--HEADQUARTERS ATCAIRO.I had not been in Mexico many weeks when
column3: reading a St. Louis paper
column4: I found the President had asked the Illinois delegation in Congressto recommend some citizens of the State for the position ofbrigadier-general
column5: and that they had unanimously recommended me as firston a list of seven.  I was very much surprised because
column6: as I have said
column7: my acquaintance with the Congressmen was very limited and I did not knowof anything I had done to inspire such confidence.  The papers of thenext day announced that my name
column8: with three others
column9: had been sent to theSenate
column10: and a few days after our confirmation was announced.When appointed brigadier-general I at once thought it proper that one ofmy aides should come from the regiment I had been commanding
column11: and soselected Lieutenant C. B. Lagow.  While living in St. Louis
column12: I had had adesk in the law office of McClellan
column13: Moody and Hillyer.  Difference inviews between the members of the firm on the questions of the day
column14: andgeneral hard times in the border cities
column15: had broken up this firm.Hillyer was quite a young man
column16: then in his twenties
column17: and very brilliant.I asked him to accept a place on my staff.  I also wanted to take oneman from my new home
column18: Galena.  The canvass in the Presidential campaignthe fall before had brought out a young lawyer by the name of John A.Rawlins
column19: who proved himself one of the ablest speakers in the State.  Hewas also a candidate for elector on the Douglas ticket.  When Sumter wasfired upon and the integrity of the Union threatened
column20: there was no manmore ready to serve his country than he.  I wrote at once asking him toaccept the position of assistant adjutant-general with the rank ofcaptain
column21: on my staff.  He was about entering the service as major of anew regiment then organizing in the north-western part of the State; buthe threw this up and accepted my offer.Neither Hillyer nor Lagow proved to have any particular taste or specialqualifications for the duties of the soldier
column22: and the former resignedduring the Vicksburg campaign; the latter I relieved after the battle ofChattanooga.  Rawlins remained with me as long as he lived
column23: and rose tothe rank of brigadier general and chief-of-staff to the General of theArmy--an office created for him--before the war closed.  He was an ableman
column24: possessed of great firmness
column25: and could say 'no' so emphatically toa request which he thought should not be granted that the person he wasaddressing would understand at once that there was no use of pressingthe matter.  General Rawlins was a very useful officer in other waysthan this.  I became very much attached to him.Shortly after my promotion I was ordered to Ironton
column26: Missouri
column27: tocommand a district in that part of the State
column28: and took the 21stIllinois
column29: my old regiment
column30: with me.  Several other regiments wereordered to the same destination about the same time.  Ironton is on theIron Mountain railroad
column31: about seventy miles south of St. Louis
column32: andsituated among hills rising almost to the dignity of mountains.  When Ireached there
column33: about the 8th of August
column34: Colonel B. Gratz Brown--afterwards Governor of Missouri and in 1872 Vice-Presidential candidate--was in command.  Some of his troops were ninety days' men and theirtime had expired some time before.  The men had no clothing but whatthey had volunteered in
column35: and much of this was so worn that it wouldhardly stay on.  General Hardee--the author of the tactics I did notstudy--was at Greenville some twenty-five miles further south
column36: it wassaid
column37: with five thousand Confederate troops.  Under these circumstancesColonel Brown's command was very much demoralized.  A squadron ofcavalry could have ridden into the valley and captured the entire force.Brown himself was gladder to see me on that occasion than he ever hasbeen since.  I relieved him and sent all his men home within a day ortwo
column38: to be mustered out of service.Within ten days after reading Ironton I was prepared to take theoffensive against the enemy at Greenville.  I sent a column east out ofthe valley we were in
column39: with orders to swing around to the south and westand come into the Greenville road ten miles south of Ironton.  Anothercolumn marched on the direct road and went into camp at the pointdesignated for the two columns to meet. I was to ride out the nextmorning and take personal command of the movement.  My experienceagainst Harris
column40: in northern Missouri
column41: had inspired me with confidence.But when the evening train came in
column42: it brought General B. M. Prentisswith orders to take command of the district.  His orders did not relieveme
column43: but I knew that by law I was senior
column44: and at that time even thePresident did not have the authority to assign a junior to command asenior of the same grade.  I therefore gave General Prentiss thesituation of the troops and the general condition of affairs
column45: andstarted for St. Louis the same day.  The movement against the rebels atGreenville went no further.From St. Louis I was ordered to Jefferson City
column46: the capital of theState
column47: to take command.  General Sterling Price
column48: of the Confederatearmy
column49: was thought to be threatening the capital
column50: Lexington
column51: Chillicotheand other comparatively large towns in the central part of Missouri.  Ifound a good many troops in Jefferson City
column52: but in the greatestconfusion
column53: and no one person knew where they all were.  ColonelMulligan
column54: a gallant man
column55: was in command
column56: but he had not been educated asyet to his new profession and did not know how to maintain discipline.I found that volunteers had obtained permission from the departmentcommander
column57: or claimed they had
column58: to raise
column59: some of them
column60: regiments; somebattalions; some companies--the officers to be commissioned according tothe number of men they brought into the service.  There were recruitingstations all over town
column61: with notices
column62: rudely lettered on boards over thedoors
column63: announcing the arm of service and length of time for whichrecruits at that station would be received.  The law required allvolunteers to serve for three years or the war.  But in Jefferson Cityin August
column65: they were recruited for different periods and ondifferent conditions; some were enlisted for six months
column66: some for ayear
column67: some without any condition as to where they were to serve
column68: otherswere not to be sent out of the State.  The recruits were principally menfrom regiments stationed there and already in the service
column69: bound forthree years if the war lasted that long.The city was filled with Union fugitives who had been driven by guerillabands to take refuge with the National troops.  They were in adeplorable condition and must have starved but for the support thegovernment gave them.  They had generally made their escape with a teamor two
column70: sometimes a yoke of oxen with a mule or a horse in the lead.  Alittle bedding besides their clothing and some food had been thrown intothe wagon.  All else of their worldly goods were abandoned andappropriated by their former neighbors; for the Union man in Missouriwho staid at home during the rebellion
column71: if he was not immediately underthe protection of the National troops
column72: was at perpetual war with hisneighbors.  I stopped the recruiting service
column73: and disposed the troopsabout the outskirts of the city so as to guard all approaches.  Orderwas soon restored.I had been at Jefferson City but a few days when I was directed fromdepartment headquarters to fit out an expedition to Lexington
column74: Booneville and Chillicothe
column75: in order to take from the banks in thosecities all the funds they had and send them to St. Louis.  The westernarmy had not yet been supplied with transportation.  It became necessarytherefore to press into the service teams belonging to sympathizers withthe rebellion or to hire those of Union men.  This afforded anopportunity of giving employment to such of the refugees within ourlines as had teams suitable for our purposes.  They accepted the servicewith alacrity.  As fast as troops could be got off they were moved westsome twenty miles or more.  In seven or eight days from my assumingcommand at Jefferson City
column76: I had all the troops
column77: except a smallgarrison
column78: at an advanced position and expected to join them myself thenext day.But my campaigns had not yet begun
column79: for while seated at my office door
column80: with nothing further to do until it was time to start for the front
column81: Isaw an officer of rank approaching
column82: who proved to be Colonel JeffersonC. Davis.  I had never met him before
column83: but he introduced himself byhanding me an order for him to proceed to Jefferson City and relieve meof the command.  The orders directed that I should report at departmentheadquarters at St. Louis without delay
column84: to receive important specialinstructions.  It was about an hour before the only regular train of theday would start.  I therefore turned over to Colonel Davis my orders
column85: and hurriedly stated to him the progress that had been made to carry outthe department instructions already described.  I had at that time butone staff officer
column86: doing myself all the detail work usually performed byan adjutant-general.  In an hour after being relieved from the command Iwas on my way to St. Louis
column87: leaving my single staff officer(*6) tofollow the next day with our horses and baggage.The 'important special instructions' which I received the next day
column88: assigned me to the command of the district of south-east Missouri
column89: embracing all the territory south of St. Louis
column90: in Missouri
column91: as well asall southern Illinois.  At first I was to take personal command of acombined expedition that had been ordered for the capture of ColonelJeff. Thompson
column92: a sort of independent or partisan commander who wasdisputing with us the possession of south-east Missouri.  Troops hadbeen ordered to move from Ironton to Cape Girardeau
column93: sixty or seventymiles to the south-east
column94: on the Mississippi River; while the forces atCape Girardeau had been ordered to move to Jacksonville
column95: ten miles outtowards Ironton; and troops at Cairo and Bird's Point
column96: at the junctionof the Ohio and Mississippi rivers
column97: were to hold themselves in readinessto go down the Mississippi to Belmont
column98: eighteen miles below
column99: to be movedwest from there when an officer should come to command them.  I was theofficer who had been selected for this purpose.  Cairo was to become myheadquarters when the expedition terminated.In pursuance of my orders I established my temporary headquarters atCape Girardeau and sent instructions to the commanding officer atJackson
column100: to inform me of the approach of General Prentiss from Ironton.Hired wagons were kept moving night and day to take additional rationsto Jackson
column101: to supply the troops when they started from there.  NeitherGeneral Prentiss nor Colonel Marsh
column102: who commanded at Jackson
column103: knew theirdestination.  I drew up all the instructions for the contemplated move
column104: and kept them in my pocket until I should hear of the junction of ourtroops at Jackson.  Two or three days after my arrival at CapeGirardeau
column105: word came that General Prentiss was approaching that place(Jackson).  I started at once to meet him there and to give him hisorders.  As I turned the first corner of a street after starting
column106: I sawa column of cavalry passing the next street in front of me.  I turnedand rode around the block the other way
column107: so as to meet the head of thecolumn.  I found there General Prentiss himself
column108: with a large escort.He had halted his troops at Jackson for the night
column109: and had come onhimself to Cape Girardeau
column110: leaving orders for his command to follow himin the morning.  I gave the General his orders--which stopped him atJackson--but he was very much aggrieved at being placed under anotherbrigadier-general
column111: particularly as he believed himself to be the senior.He had been a brigadier
column112: in command at Cairo
column113: while I was musteringofficer at Springfield without any rank.  But we were nominated at thesame time for the United States service
column114: and both our commissions boredate May 17th
column115: 1861.  By virtue of my former army rank I was
column116: by law
column117: the senior.  General Prentiss failed to get orders to his troops toremain at Jackson
column118: and the next morning early they were reported asapproaching Cape Girardeau.  I then ordered the General veryperemptorily to countermarch his command and take it back to Jackson.He obeyed the order
column119: but bade his command adieu when he got them toJackson
column120: and went to St. Louis and reported himself.  This broke up theexpedition.  But little harm was done
column121: as Jeff. Thompson moved light andhad no fixed place for even nominal headquarters.  He was as much athome in Arkansas as he was in Missouri and would keep out of the way ofa superior force.  Prentiss was sent to another part of the State.General Prentiss made a great mistake on the above occasion
column122: one that hewould not have committed later in the war.  When I came to know himbetter
column123: I regretted it much.  In consequence of this occurrence he wasoff duty in the field when the principal campaign at the West was goingon
column124: and his juniors received promotion while he was where none could beobtained.  He would have been next to myself in rank in the district ofsouth-east Missouri
column125: by virtue of his services in the Mexican war.  Hewas a brave and very earnest soldier.  No man in the service was moresincere in his devotion to the cause for which we were battling; nonemore ready to make sacrifices or risk life in it.On the 4th of September I removed my headquarters to Cairo and foundColonel Richard Oglesby in command of the post.  We had never met
column126: atleast not to my knowledge.  After my promotion I had ordered mybrigadier-general's uniform from New York
column127: but it had not yet arrived
column128: so that I was in citizen's dress.  The Colonel had his office full ofpeople
column129: mostly from the neighboring States of Missouri and Kentucky
column130: making complaints or asking favors.  He evidently did not catch my namewhen I was presented
column131: for on my taking a piece of paper from the tablewhere he was seated and writing the order assuming command of thedistrict of south-east Missouri
column132: Colonel Richard J. Oglesby to commandthe post at Bird's Point
column133: and handing it to him
column134: he put on an expressionof surprise that looked a little as if he would like to have some oneidentify me.  But he surrendered the office without question.The day after I assumed command at Cairo a man came to me who said hewas a scout of General Fremont.  He reported that he had just come fromColumbus
column135: a point on the Mississippi twenty miles below on the Kentuckyside
column136: and that troops had started from there
column137: or were about to start
column138: toseize Paducah
column139: at the mouth of the Tennessee.  There was no time fordelay; I reported by telegraph to the department commander theinformation I had received
column140: and added that I was taking steps to get offthat night to be in advance of the enemy in securing that importantpoint.  There was a large number of steamers lying at Cairo and a goodmany boatmen were staying in the town.  It was the work of only a fewhours to get the boats manned
column141: with coal aboard and steam up.  Troopswere also designated to go aboard.  The distance from Cairo to Paducahis about forty-five miles.  I did not wish to get there before daylightof the 6th
column142: and directed therefore that the boats should lie at anchorout in the stream until the time to start.  Not having received ananswer to my first dispatch
column143: I again telegraphed to departmentheadquarters that I should start for Paducah that night unless Ireceived further orders.  Hearing nothing
column144: we started before midnightand arrived early the following morning
column145: anticipating the enemy byprobably not over six or eight hours.  It proved very fortunate that theexpedition against Jeff. Thompson had been broken up. Had it not been
column146: the enemy would have seized Paducah and fortified it
column147: to our very greatannoyance.When the National troops entered the town the citizens were taken bysurprise.  I never after saw such consternation depicted on the faces ofthe people.  Men
column148: women and children came out of their doors lookingpale and frightened at the presence of the invader.  They were expectingrebel troops that day.  In fact
column149: nearly four thousand men from Columbuswere at that time within ten or fifteen miles of Paducah on their way tooccupy the place.  I had but two regiments and one battery with me
column150: butthe enemy did not know this and returned to Columbus.  I stationed mytroops at the best points to guard the roads leading into the city
column151: leftgunboats to guard the river fronts and by noon was ready to start on myreturn to Cairo.  Before leaving
column152: however
column153: I addressed a short printedproclamation to the citizens of Paducah assuring them of our peacefulintentions
column154: that we had come among them to protect them against theenemies of our country
column155: and that all who chose could continue theirusual avocations with assurance of the protection of the government.This was evidently a relief to them; but the majority would have muchpreferred the presence of the other army.  I reinforced Paducah rapidlyfrom the troops at Cape Girardeau; and a day or two later General C. F.Smith
column156: a most accomplished soldier
column157: reported at Cairo and was assignedto the command of the post at the mouth of the Tennessee.  In a shorttime it was well fortified and a detachment was sent to occupySmithland
column158: at the mouth of the Cumberland.The State government of Kentucky at that time was rebel in sentiment
column159: but wanted to preserve an armed neutrality between the North and theSouth
column160: and the governor really seemed to think the State had a perfectright to maintain a neutral position. The rebels already occupied twotowns in the State
column161: Columbus and Hickman
column162: on the Mississippi; and at thevery moment the National troops were entering Paducah from the Ohiofront
column163: General Lloyd Tilghman--a Confederate--with his staff and a smalldetachment of men
column164: were getting out in the other direction
column165: while
column166: as Ihave already said
column167: nearly four thousand Confederate troops were onKentucky soil on their way to take possession of the town. But
column168: in theestimation of the governor and of those who thought with him
column169: this didnot justify the National authorities in invading the soil of Kentucky.I informed the legislature of the State of what I was doing
column170: and myaction was approved by the majority of that body.  On my return to CairoI found authority from department headquarters for me to take Paducah'if I felt strong enough
column171: ' but very soon after I was reprimanded fromthe same quarters for my correspondence with the legislature and warnedagainst a repetition of the offence.Soon after I took command at Cairo
column172: General Fremont entered intoarrangements for the exchange of the prisoners captured at Camp Jacksonin the month of May.  I received orders to pass them through my lines toColumbus as they presented themselves with proper credentials.  Quite anumber of these prisoners I had been personally acquainted with beforethe war.  Such of them as I had so known were received at myheadquarters as old acquaintances
column173: and ordinary routine business was notdisturbed by their presence.  On one occasion when several were presentin my office my intention to visit Cape Girardeau the next day
column174: toinspect the troops at that point
column175: was mentioned.  Something transpiredwhich postponed my trip; but a steamer employed by the government waspassing a point some twenty or more miles above Cairo
column176: the next day
column177: when a section of rebel artillery with proper escort brought her to.  Amajor
column178: one of those who had been at my headquarters the day before
column179: cameat once aboard and after some search made a direct demand for mydelivery.  It was hard to persuade him that I was not there.  Thisofficer was Major Barrett
column180: of St. Louis.  I had been acquainted with hisfamily before the war.

column1: ISFP	 XX.GENERAL FREMONT IN COMMAND--MOVEMENT AGAINST BELMONT--BATTLE OF BELMONT--A NARROW ESCAPE--AFTER THE BATTLE.From the occupation of Paducah up to the early part of November nothingimportant occurred with the troops under my command.  I was reinforcedfrom time to time and the men were drilled and disciplined preparatoryfor the service which was sure to come.  By the 1st of November I hadnot fewer than 20
column2: 000 men
column3: most of them under good drill and ready tomeet any equal body of men who
column4: like themselves
column5: had not yet been in anengagement.  They were growing impatient at lying idle so long
column6: almostin hearing of the guns of the enemy they had volunteered to fightagainst.  I asked on one or two occasions to be allowed to move againstColumbus.  It could have been taken soon after the occupation ofPaducah; but before November it was so strongly fortified that it wouldhave required a large force and a long siege to capture it.In the latter part of October General Fremont took the field in personand moved from Jefferson City against General Sterling Price
column7: who wasthen in the State of Missouri with a considerable command.  About thefirst of November I was directed from department headquarters to make ademonstration on both sides of the Mississippi River with the view ofdetaining the rebels at Columbus within their lines.  Before my troopscould be got off
column8: I was notified from the same quarter that there weresome 3
column9: 000 of the enemy on the St. Francis River about fifty miles west
column10: or south-west
column11: from Cairo
column12: and was ordered to send another force againstthem.  I dispatched Colonel Oglesby at once with troops sufficient tocompete with the reported number of the enemy.  On the 5th word camefrom the same source that the rebels were about to detach a large forcefrom Columbus to be moved by boats down the Mississippi and up the WhiteRiver
column13: in Arkansas
column14: in order to reinforce Price
column15: and I was directed toprevent this movement if possible.  I accordingly sent a regiment fromBird's Point under Colonel W. H. L. Wallace to overtake and reinforceOglesby
column16: with orders to march to New Madrid
column17: a point some distance belowColumbus
column18: on the Missouri side.  At the same time I directed General C.F. Smith to move all the troops he could spare from Paducah directlyagainst Columbus
column19: halting them
column20: however
column21: a few miles from the town toawait further orders from me.  Then I gathered up all the troops atCairo and Fort Holt
column22: except suitable guards
column23: and moved them down theriver on steamers convoyed by two gunboats
column24: accompanying them myself.My force consisted of a little over 3
column25: 000 men and embraced fiveregiments of infantry
column26: two guns and two companies of cavalry.  Wedropped down the river on the 6th to within about six miles of Columbus
column27: debarked a few men on the Kentucky side and established pickets toconnect with the troops from Paducah.I had no orders which contemplated an attack by the National troops
column28: nordid I intend anything of the kind when I started out from Cairo; butafter we started I saw that the officers and men were elated at theprospect of at last having the opportunity of doing what they hadvolunteered to do--fight the enemies of their country.  I did not seehow I could maintain discipline
column29: or retain the confidence of my command
column30: if we should return to Cairo without an effort to do something.Columbus
column31: besides being strongly fortified
column32: contained a garrison muchmore numerous than the force I had with me.  It would not do
column33: therefore
column34: to attack that point.  About two o'clock on the morning of the 7th
column35: Ilearned that the enemy was crossing troops from Columbus to the westbank to be dispatched
column36: presumably
column37: after Oglesby.  I knew there was asmall camp of Confederates at Belmont
column38: immediately opposite Columbus
column39: and I speedily resolved to push down the river
column40: land on the Missouriside
column41: capture Belmont
column42: break up the camp and return.  Accordingly
column43: thepickets above Columbus were drawn in at once
column44: and about daylight theboats moved out from shore.  In an hour we were debarking on the westbank of the Mississippi
column45: just out of range of the batteries at Columbus.The ground on the west shore of the river
column46: opposite Columbus
column47: is low andin places marshy and cut up with sloughs.  The soil is rich and thetimber large and heavy.  There were some small clearings between Belmontand the point where we landed
column48: but most of the country was covered withthe native forests.  We landed in front of a cornfield.  When thedebarkation commenced
column49: I took a regiment down the river to post it as aguard against surprise.  At that time I had no staff officer who couldbe trusted with that duty.  In the woods
column50: at a short distance below theclearing
column51: I found a depression
column52: dry at the time
column53: but which at high waterbecame a slough or bayou.  I placed the men in the hollow
column54: gave themtheir instructions and ordered them to remain there until they wereproperly relieved.  These troops
column55: with the gunboats
column56: were to protect ourtransports.Up to this time the enemy had evidently failed to divine our intentions.From Columbus they could
column57: of course
column58: see our gunboats and transportsloaded with troops.  But the force from Paducah was threatening themfrom the land side
column59: and it was hardly to be expected that if Columbuswas our object we would separate our troops by a wide river.  Theydoubtless thought we meant to draw a large force from the east bank
column60: then embark ourselves
column61: land on the east bank and make a sudden assaulton Columbus before their divided command could be united.About eight o'clock we started from the point of debarkation
column62: marchingby the flank.  After moving in this way for a mile or a mile and a half
column63: I halted where there was marshy ground covered with a heavy growth oftimber in our front
column64: and deployed a large part of my force asskirmishers.  By this time the enemy discovered that we were moving uponBelmont and sent out troops to meet us.  Soon after we had started inline
column65: his skirmishers were encountered and fighting commenced.  Thiscontinued
column66: growing fiercer and fiercer
column67: for about four hours
column68: the enemybeing forced back gradually until he was driven into his camp. Early inthis engagement my horse was shot under me
column69: but I got another from oneof my staff and kept well up with the advance until the river wasreached.The officers and men engaged at Belmont were then under fire for thefirst time. column1: ISFP	 XXIII.PROMOTED MAJOR-GENERAL OF VOLUNTEERS--UNOCCUPIED TERRITORY--ADVANCE UPONNASHVILLE--SITUATION OF THE TROOPS--CONFEDERATE RETREAT--RELIEVED OF THECOMMAND--RESTORED TO THE COMMAND--GENERAL SMITH.The news of the fall of Fort Donelson caused great delight all over theNorth.  At the South
column2: particularly in Richmond
column3: the effect wascorrespondingly depressing.  I was promptly promoted to the grade ofMajor-General of Volunteers
column4: and confirmed by the Senate.  All three ofmy division commanders were promoted to the same grade and the colonelswho commanded brigades were made brigadier-generals in the volunteerservice.  My chief
column5: who was in St. Louis
column6: telegraphed hiscongratulations to General Hunter in Kansas for the services he hadrendered in securing the fall of Fort Donelson by sending reinforcementsso rapidly.  To Washington he telegraphed that the victory was due toGeneral C. F. Smith; 'promote him
column7: ' he said
column8: 'and the whole country willapplaud.'  On the 19th there was published at St. Louis a formal orderthanking Flag-officer Foote and myself

column11: his chief of staff

column14: as I did all the promotions that were made.My opinion was and still is that immediately after the fall of FortDonelson the way was opened to the National forces all over theSouth-west without much resistance.  If one general who would have takenthe responsibility had been in command of all the troops west of theAlleghanies

column16: Corinth

column97: while Donelson was still besieged.  Buell followedwith a portion of the Army of the Ohio
column98: but he had to march and did notreach the east bank of the Cumberland opposite Nashville until the 24thof the month
column99: and then with only one division of his army.The bridge at Nashville had been destroyed and all boats removed ordisabled
column100: so that a small garrison could have held the place against anyNational troops that could have been brought against it within ten daysafter the arrival of the force from Bowling Green.  Johnston seemed tolie quietly at Nashville to await the result at Fort Donelson
column101: on whichhe had staked the possession of most of the territory embraced in theStates of Kentucky and Tennessee.  It is true
column102: the two generals seniorin rank at Fort Donelson were sending him encouraging dispatches
column103: evenclaiming great Confederate victories up to the night of the 16th whenthey must have been preparing for their individual escape. Johnston madea fatal mistake in intrusting so important a command to Floyd
column104: who hemust have known was no soldier even if he possessed the elements of one.Pillow's presence as second was also a mistake.  If these officers hadbeen forced upon him and designated for that particular command
column105: then heshould have left Nashville with a small garrison under a trusty officer
column106: and with the remainder of his force gone to Donelson himself.  If he hadbeen captured the result could not have been worse than it was.Johnston's heart failed him upon the first advance of National troops.He wrote to Richmond on the 8th of February
column107: 'I think the gunboats ofthe enemy will probably take Fort Donelson without the necessity ofemploying their land force in cooperation.'  After the fall of thatplace he abandoned Nashville and Chattanooga without an effort to saveeither
column108: and fell back into northern Mississippi
column109: where
column110: six weeks later
column111: he was destined to end his career.From the time of leaving Cairo I was singularly unfortunate in notreceiving dispatches from General Halleck.  The order of the 10th ofFebruary directing me to fortify Fort Henry strongly
column112: particularly tothe land side
column113: and saying that intrenching tools had been sent for thatpurpose
column114: reached me after Donelson was invested.  I received nothingdirect which indicated that the department commander knew we were inpossession of Donelson.  I was reporting regularly to the chief ofstaff
column115: who had been sent to Cairo
column116: soon after the troops left there
column117: toreceive all reports from the front and to telegraph the substance to theSt. Louis headquarters.  Cairo was at the southern end of the telegraphwire.  Another line was started at once from Cairo to Paducah andSmithland
column118: at the mouths of the Tennessee and Cumberland respectively.My dispatches were all sent to Cairo by boat
column119: but many of thoseaddressed to me were sent to the operator at the end of the advancingwire and he failed to forward them.  This operator afterwards proved tobe a rebel; he deserted his post after a short time and went southtaking his dispatches with him.  A telegram from General McClellan to meof February 16th
column120: the day of the surrender
column121: directing me to report infull the situation
column122: was not received at my headquarters until the 3d ofMarch.On the 2d of March I received orders dated March 1st to move my commandback to Fort Henry
column123: leaving only a small garrison at Donelson.  FromFort Henry expeditions were to be sent against Eastport
column124: Mississippi
column125: and Paris
column126: Tennessee.  We started from Donelson on the 4th
column127: and the sameday I was back on the Tennessee River.  On March 4th I also received thefollowing dispatch from General Halleck:MAJ.-GEN. U. S. GRANT
column128: Fort Henry:You will place Maj.-Gen. C. F. Smith in command of expedition
column129: andremain yourself at Fort Henry.  Why do you not obey my orders to reportstrength and positions of your command?H. W. HALLECK
column130: Major-General.I was surprised.  This was the first intimation I had received thatGeneral Halleck had called for information as to the strength of mycommand.  On the 6th he wrote to me again.  'Your going to Nashvillewithout authority
column131: and when your presence with your troops was of theutmost importance
column132: was a matter of very serious complaint at Washington
column133: so much so that I was advised to arrest you on your return.'  This wasthe first I knew of his objecting to my going to Nashville.  That placewas not beyond the limits of my command
column134: which
column135: it had been expresslydeclared in orders
column136: were 'not defined.'  Nashville is west of theCumberland River
column137: and I had sent troops that had reported to me for dutyto occupy the place.  I turned over the command as directed and thenreplied to General Halleck courteously
column138: but asked to be relieved fromfurther duty under him.Later I learned that General Halleck had been calling lustily for moretroops
column139: promising that he would do something important if he could onlybe sufficiently reinforced.  McClellan asked him what force he then had.Halleck telegraphed me to supply the information so far as my commandwas concerned
column140: but I received none of his dispatches.  At last Halleckreported to Washington that he had repeatedly ordered me to give thestrength of my force
column141: but could get nothing out of me; that I had goneto Nashville
column142: beyond the limits of my command
column143: without his authority
column144: and that my army was more demoralized by victory than the army at BullRun had been by defeat.  General McClellan
column145: on this information
column146: orderedthat I should be relieved from duty and that an investigation should bemade into any charges against me.  He even authorized my arrest.  Thusin less than two weeks after the victory at Donelson
column147: the two leadinggenerals in the army were in correspondence as to what dispositionshould be made of me
column148: and in less than three weeks I was virtually inarrest and without a command.On the 13th of March I was restored to command
column149: and on the 17th Hallecksent me a copy of an order from the War Department which stated thataccounts of my misbehavior had reached Washington and directed him toinvestigate and report the facts.  He forwarded also a copy of adetailed dispatch from himself to Washington entirely exonerating me;but he did not inform me that it was his own reports that had createdall the trouble.  On the contrary
column150: he wrote to me
column151: 'Instead of relievingyou
column152: I wish you
column153: as soon as your new army is in the field
column154: to assumeimmediate command
column155: and lead it to new victories.'  In consequence I feltvery grateful to him
column156: and supposed it was his interposition that had setme right with the government.  I never knew the truth until GeneralBadeau unearthed the facts in his researches for his history of mycampaigns.General Halleck unquestionably deemed General C. F. Smith a much fitterofficer for the command of all the forces in the military district thanI was
column157: and
column158: to render him available for such command
column159: desired hispromotion to antedate mine and those of the other division commanders.It is probable that the general opinion was that Smith's long servicesin the army and distinguished deeds rendered him the more proper personfor such command.  Indeed I was rather inclined to this opinion myselfat that time
column160: and would have served as faithfully under Smith as he haddone under me.  But this did not justify the dispatches which GeneralHalleck sent to Washington
column161: or his subsequent concealment of them fromme when pretending to explain the action of my superiors.On receipt of the order restoring me to command I proceeded to Savannahon the Tennessee
column162: to which point my troops had advanced.  General Smithwas delighted to see me and was unhesitating in his denunciation of thetreatment I had received.  He was on a sick bed at the time
column163: from whichhe never came away alive.  His death was a severe loss to our westernarmy.  His personal courage was unquestioned
column164: his judgment andprofessional acquirements were unsurpassed
column165: and he had the confidenceof those he commanded as well as of those over him.

column1: ISFP	 XXIV.THE ARMY AT PITTSBURG LANDING--INJURED BY A FALL--THE CONFEDERATE ATTACKAT SHILOH--THE FIRST DAY'S FIGHT AT SHILOH--GENERAL SHERMAN--CONDITIONOF THE ARMY--CLOSE OF THE FIRST DAY'S FIGHT--THE SECOND DAY'S FIGHT--RETREAT AND DEFEAT OF THE CONFEDERATES.When I reassumed command on the 17th of March I found the army divided
column2: about half being on the east bank of the Tennessee at Savannah
column3: whileone division was at Crump's landing on the west bank about four mileshigher up
column4: and the remainder at Pittsburg landing
column5: five miles aboveCrump's.  The enemy was in force at Corinth
column6: the junction of the twomost important railroads in the Mississippi valley--one connectingMemphis and the Mississippi River with the East
column7: and the other leadingsouth to all the cotton states.  Still another railroad connects Corinthwith Jackson
column8: in west Tennessee.  If we obtained possession of Corinththe enemy would have no railroad for the transportation of armies orsupplies until that running east from Vicksburg was reached.  It was thegreat strategic position at the West between the Tennessee and theMississippi rivers and between Nashville and Vicksburg.I at once put all the troops at Savannah in motion for Pittsburglanding
column9: knowing that the enemy was fortifying at Corinth and collectingan army there under Johnston.  It was my expectation to march againstthat army as soon as Buell
column10: who had been ordered to reinforce me withthe Army of the Ohio
column11: should arrive; and the west bank of the river wasthe place to start from.  Pittsburg is only about twenty miles fromCorinth
column12: and Hamburg landing
column13: four miles further up the river
column14: is a mileor two nearer.  I had not been in command long before I selected Hamburgas the place to put the Army of the Ohio when it arrived.  The roadsfrom Pittsburg and Hamburg to Corinth converge some eight miles out.This disposition of the troops would have given additional roads tomarch over when the advance commenced
column15: within supporting distance ofeach other.Before I arrived at Savannah
column16: Sherman
column17: who had joined the Army of theTennessee and been placed in command of a division
