Sherman debarked his troopsand started out to accomplish the object of the expedition; but theriver was rising so rapidly that the back-water up the small tributariesthreatened to cut off the possibility of getting back to the boats
column21: andthe expedition had to return without reaching the railroad.  The gunshad to be hauled by hand through the water to get back to the boats.On the 17th of March the army on the Tennessee River consisted of fivedivisions

column23: McClernand
column24: L. Wallace

column26: General Smith
column27: as I havesaid

column29: first into brigades

column31: and the command given to General Prentiss

column34: Tennessee

I had no apprehension that the enemy could really captureeither place.  But I feared it was possible that he might make a rapiddash upon Crump's and destroy our transports and stores

column118: and on the extreme left
column119: Stuart withone brigade of Sherman's division.  Hurlbut was in rear of Prentiss
column120: massed
column121: and in reserve at the time of the onset.  The division ofGeneral C. F. Smith was on the right

column126: and with the change of commanders thusnecessarily effected in the heat of battle the efficiency of hisdivision was much weakened.The position of our troops made a continuous line from Lick Creek on theleft to Owl Creek
column127: a branch of Snake Creek
column128: on the right
column129: facing nearlysouth and possibly a little west.  The water in all these streams wasvery high at the time and contributed to protect our flanks.  The enemywas compelled
column130: therefore
column131: to attack directly in front.  This he did withgreat vigor
column132: inflicting heavy losses on the National side
column133: but sufferingmuch heavier on his own.The Confederate assaults were made with such a disregard of losses ontheir own side that our line of tents soon fell into their hands.  Theground on which the battle was fought was undulating

column137: but every effort was repulsed with heavy loss.  But thefront attack was kept up so vigorously that
column138: to prevent the success ofthese attempts to get on our flanks

column141: to take positions to the rear nearer Pittsburg landing.When the firing ceased at night the National line was all of a mile inrear of the position it had occupied in the morning.In one of the backward moves
column142: on the 6th
column143: the division commanded byGeneral Prentiss did not fall back with the others.  This left hisflanks exposed and enabled the enemy to capture him with about 2
column144: 200 ofhis officers and men.  General Badeau gives four o'clock of the 6th asabout the time this capture took place. He may be right as to the time
column145: but my recollection is that the hour was later.  General Prentisshimself gave the hour as half-past five.  I was with him
column146: as I was witheach of the division commanders that day
column147: several times
column148: and myrecollection is that the last time I was with him was about half-pastfour
column149: when his division was standing up firmly and the General was ascool as if expecting victory.  But no matter whether it was four orlater
column150: the story that he and his command were surprised and captured intheir camps is without any foundation whatever.  If it had been true
column151: ascurrently reported at the time and yet believed by thousands of people
column152: that Prentiss and his division had been captured in their beds

column154: with the loss of thousandskilled and wounded on the Confederate side.With the single exception of a few minutes after the capture ofPrentiss
column155: a continuous and unbroken line was maintained all day fromSnake Creek or its tributaries on the right to Lick Creek or theTennessee on the left above Pittsburg.There was no hour during the day when there was not heavy firing andgenerally hard fighting at some point on the line

column157: and many of the men had only received theirarms on the way from their States to the field.  Many of them hadarrived but a day or two before and were hardly able to load theirmuskets according to the manual.  Their officers were equally ignorantof their duties. Under these circumstances it is not astonishing thatmany of the regiments broke at the first fire.  In two cases
column158: as I nowremember
column159: colonels led their regiments from the field on first hearingthe whistle of the enemy's bullets.  In these cases the colonels wereconstitutional cowards
column160: unfit for any military position; but not so theofficers and men led out of danger by them.  Better troops never wentupon a battle-field than many of these
column161: officers and men
column162: afterwardsproved themselves to be
column163: who fled panic stricken at the first whistle ofbullets and shell at Shiloh.During the whole of Sunday I was continuously engaged in passing fromone part of the field to another
column164: giving directions to divisioncommanders.  In thus moving along the line
column165: however
column166: I never deemed itimportant to stay long with Sherman.  Although his troops were thenunder fire for the first time
column167: their commander
column168: by his constant presencewith them

column170: and the hardest fighting wasin front of these two divisions.  McClernand told me on that day
column171: the6th
column172: that he profited much by having so able a commander supporting him.A casualty to Sherman that would have taken him from the field that daywould have been a sad one for the troops engaged at Shiloh.  And hownear we came to this! On the 6th Sherman was shot twice
column173: once in thehand
column174: once in the shoulder
column175: the ball cutting his coat and making aslight wound
column176: and a third ball passed through his hat.  In addition tothis he had several horses shot during the day.The nature of this battle was such that cavalry could not be used infront; I therefore formed ours into line in rear
column177: to stop stragglers--ofwhom there were many.  When there would be enough of them to make ashow
column178: and after they had recovered from their fright
column179: they would be sentto reinforce some part of the line which needed support
column180: without regardto their companies
column181: regiments or brigades.On one occasion during the day I rode back as far as the river and metGeneral Buell
column182: who had just arrived; I do not remember the hour
column183: but atthat time there probably were as many as four or five thousandstragglers lying under cover of the river bluff

column185: most ofwhom would have been shot where they lay
column186: without resistance

column189: Buell's attention was attracted by the menlying under cover of the river bank.  I saw him berating them and tryingto shame them into joining their regiments.  He even threatened themwith shells from the gunboats near by.  But it was all to no effect.Most of these men afterward proved themselves as gallant as any of thosewho saved the battle from which they had deserted.  I have no doubt thatthis sight impressed General Buell with the idea that a line of retreatwould be a good thing just then.  If he had come in by the front insteadof through the stragglers in the rear
column190: he would have thought and feltdifferently.  Could he have come through the Confederate rear
column191: he wouldhave witnessed there a scene similar to that at our own.  The distantrear of an army engaged in battle is not the best place from which tojudge correctly what is going on in front.  Later in the war
column192: whileoccupying the country between the Tennessee and the Mississippi
column193: Ilearned that the panic in the Confederate lines had not differed muchfrom that within our own.  Some of the country people estimated thestragglers from Johnston's army as high as 20
column194: 000.  Of course this wasan exaggeration.The situation at the close of Sunday was as follows:  along the top ofthe bluff just south of the log-house which stood at Pittsburg landing

column196: of my staff

column201: like the other two
column202: wascomplete in its organization and ready
column203: like its chief
column204: for any serviceit might be called upon to render.  All three divisions were
column205: as amatter of course

Shermanhad posted some troops in a log-house and out-buildings which overlookedboth the bridge over which Wallace was expected and the creek above thatpoint.  In this last position Sherman was frequently attacked beforenight

column218: as I have said

column230: and was placed on the right. Thus night came
column231: Wallace came
column232: and the advance of Nelson's division came; but none--unless night--in time to be of material service to the gallant men whosaved Shiloh on that first day against large odds.  Buell's loss on the6th of April was two men killed and one wounded
column233: all members of the 36thIndiana infantry.  The Army of the Tennessee lost on that day at least7
column234: 000 men.  The presence of two or three regiments of Buell's army onthe west bank before firing ceased had not the slightest effect inpreventing the capture of Pittsburg landing.So confident was I before firing had ceased on the 6th that the next daywould bring victory to our arms if we could only take the initiative

column236: andpush them forward until they found the enemy
column237: following with theirentire divisions in supporting distance
column238: and to engage the enemy as soonas found.  To Sherman I told the story of the assault at Fort Donelson
column239: and said that the same tactics would win at Shiloh.  Victory was assuredwhen Wallace arrived
column240: even if there had been no other support.  I wasglad
column241: however
column242: to see the reinforcements of Buell and credit them withdoing all there was for them to do.During the night of the 6th the remainder of Nelson's division
column243: Buell'sarmy crossed the river and were ready to advance in the morning
column244: formingthe left wing.  Two other divisions
column245: Crittenden's and McCook's
column246: came upthe river from Savannah in the transports and were on the west bankearly on the 7th. Buell commanded them in person.  My command was thusnearly doubled in numbers and efficiency.During the night rain fell in torrents and our troops were exposed tothe storm without shelter.  I made my headquarters under a tree a fewhundred yards back from the river bank.  My ankle was so much swollenfrom the fall of my horse the Friday night preceding
column247: and the bruise wasso painful
column248: that I could get no rest.The drenching rain would have precluded the possibility of sleep withoutthis additional cause.  Some time after midnight
column249: growing restive underthe storm and the continuous pain
column250: I moved back to the log-house underthe bank.  This had been taken as a hospital
column251: and all night wounded menwere being brought in
column252: their wounds dressed
column253: a leg or an arm amputatedas the case might require
column254: and everything being done to save life oralleviate suffering.  The sight was more unendurable than encounteringthe enemy's fire
column255: and I returned to my tree in the rain.The advance on the morning of the 7th developed the enemy in the campsoccupied by our troops before the battle began
column256: more than a mile backfrom the most advanced position of the Confederates on the day before.It is known now that they had not yet learned of the arrival of Buell'scommand.  Possibly they fell back so far to get the shelter of our tentsduring the rain
column257: and also to get away from the shells that were droppedupon them by the gunboats every fifteen minutes during the night.The position of the Union troops on the morning of the 7th was asfollows:  General Lew. Wallace on the right; Sherman on his left; thenMcClernand and then Hurlbut.  Nelson
column258: of Buell's army
column259: was on ourextreme left
column260: next to the river.Crittenden was next in line after Nelson and on his right
column261: McCookfollowed and formed the extreme right of Buell's command.  My oldcommand thus formed the right wing
column262: while the troops directly underBuell constituted the left wing of the army.  These relative positionswere retained during the entire day
column263: or until the enemy was driven fromthe field.In a very short time the battle became general all along the line.  Thisday everything was favorable to the Union side.  We had now become theattacking party.  The enemy was driven back all day
column264: as we had been theday before
column265: until finally he beat a precipitate retreat.  The last pointheld by him was near the road leading from the landing to Corinth
column266: onthe left of Sherman and right of McClernand.  About three o'clock
column267: beingnear that point and seeing that the enemy was giving way everywhereelse
column268: I gathered up a couple of regiments
column269: or parts of regiments
column270: fromtroops near by
column271: formed them in line of battle and marched them forward
column272: going in front myself to prevent premature or long-range firing.  Atthis point there was a clearing between us and the enemy favorable forcharging
column273: although exposed.  I knew the enemy were ready to break andonly wanted a little encouragement from us to go quickly and join theirfriends who had started earlier.  After marching to within musket-rangeI stopped and let the troops pass.  The command
column274: CHARGE

column276: andwas executed with loud cheers and with a run; when the last of the enemybroke. (*7)

column1: ISFP	 XXV.STRUCK BY A BULLET--PRECIPITATE RETREAT OF THE CONFEDERATES--INTRENCHMENTS AT SHILOH--GENERAL BUELL--GENERAL JOHNSTON--REMARKS ONSHILOH.During this second day of the battle I had been moving from right toleft and back
column2: to see for myself the progress made.  In the early partof the afternoon
column3: while riding with Colonel McPherson and Major Hawkins
column4: then my chief commissary
column5: we got beyond the left of our troops.  We weremoving along the northern edge of a clearing
column6: very leisurely
column7: toward theriver above the landing.  There did not appear to be an enemy to ourright
column8: until suddenly a battery with musketry opened upon us from theedge of the woods on the other side of the clearing. The shells andballs whistled about our ears very fast for about a minute.  I do notthink it took us longer than that to get out of range and out of sight.In the sudden start we made
column9: Major Hawkins lost his hat.  He did notstop to pick it up.  When we arrived at a perfectly safe position wehalted to take an account of damages.  McPherson's horse was panting asif ready to drop.  On examination it was found that a ball had struckhim forward of the flank just back of the saddle
column10: and had gone entirelythrough.  In a few minutes the poor beast dropped dead; he had given nosign of injury until we came to a stop.  A ball had struck the metalscabbard of my sword
column11: just below the hilt
column12: and broken it nearly off;before the battle was over it had broken off entirely.  There werethree of us:  one had lost a horse
column13: killed; one a hat and one asword-scabbard.  All were thankful that it was no worse.After the rain of the night before and the frequent and heavy rains forsome days previous
column14: the roads were almost impassable.  The enemycarrying his artillery and supply trains over them in his retreat
column15: madethem still worse for troops following.  I wanted to pursue
column16: but had notthe heart to order the men who had fought desperately for two days
column17: lying in the mud and rain whenever not fighting
column18: and I did (*8) not feeldisposed to positively order Buell
column19: or any part of his command
column20: topursue.  Although the senior in rank at the time I had been so only afew weeks.  Buell was
column21: and had been for some time past
column22: a departmentcommander
column23: while I commanded only a district.  I did not meet Buell inperson until too late to get troops ready and pursue with effect; buthad I seen him at the moment of the last charge I should have at leastrequested him to follow.I rode forward several miles the day after the battle
column24: and found thatthe enemy had dropped much
column25: if not all
column26: of their provisions
column27: someammunition and the extra wheels of their caissons
column28: lightening theirloads to enable them to get off their guns. About five miles out wefound their field hospital abandoned. An immediate pursuit must haveresulted in the capture of a considerable number of prisoners andprobably some guns.Shiloh was the severest battle fought at the West during the war
column29: andbut few in the East equalled it for hard
column30: determined fighting.  I saw anopen field
column31: in our possession on the second day
column32: over which theConfederates had made repeated charges the day before
column33: so covered withdead that it would have been possible to walk across the clearing
column34: inany direction
column35: stepping on dead bodies
column36: without a foot touching theground.  On our side National and Confederate troops were mingledtogether in about equal proportions; but on the remainder of the fieldnearly all were Confederates.  On one part
column37: which had evidently not beenploughed for several years
column38: probably because the land was poor
column39: busheshad grown up
column40: some to the height of eight or ten feet. There was not oneof these left standing unpierced by bullets. The smaller ones were allcut down.Contrary to all my experience up to that time
column41: and to the experience ofthe army I was then commanding
column42: we were on the defensive.  We werewithout intrenchments or defensive advantages of any sort
column43: and more thanhalf the army engaged the first day was without experience or even drillas soldiers.  The officers with them
column44: except the division commanders andpossibly two or three of the brigade commanders
column45: were equallyinexperienced in war.  The result was a Union victory that gave the menwho achieved it great confidence in themselves ever after.The enemy fought bravely
column46: but they had started out to defeat and destroyan army and capture a position.  They failed in both
column47: with very heavyloss in killed and wounded
column48: and must have gone back discouraged andconvinced that the 'Yankee' was not an enemy to be despised.After the battle I gave verbal instructions to division commanders tolet the regiments send out parties to bury their own dead
column49: and to detailparties
column50: under commissioned officers from each division
column51: to bury theConfederate dead in their respective fronts and to report the numbers soburied.  The latter part of these instructions was not carried out byall; but they were by those sent from Sherman's division
column52: and by some ofthe parties sent out by McClernand.  The heaviest loss sustained by theenemy was in front of these two divisions.The criticism has often been made that the Union troops should have beenintrenched at Shiloh.  Up to that time the pick and spade had been butlittle resorted to at the West.  I had
column53: however
column54: taken this subjectunder consideration soon after re-assuming command in the field
column55: and
column56: asalready stated
column57: my only military engineer reported unfavorably.  Besidesthis
column58: the troops with me
column59: officers and men
column60: needed discipline and drillmore than they did experience with the pick
column61: shovel and axe.Reinforcements were arriving almost daily
column62: composed of troops that hadbeen hastily thrown together into companies and regiments--fragments ofincomplete organizations
column63: the men and officers strangers to each other.Under all these circumstances I concluded that drill and discipline wereworth more to our men than fortifications.General Buell was a brave
column64: intelligent officer
column65: with as muchprofessional pride and ambition of a commendable sort as I ever knew.  Ihad been two years at West Point with him
column66: and had served with himafterwards
column67: in garrison and in the Mexican war
column68: several years more.  Hewas not given in early life or in mature years to forming intimateacquaintances.  He was studious by habit
column69: and commanded the confidenceand respect of all who knew him.  He was a strict disciplinarian
column70: andperhaps did not distinguish sufficiently between the volunteer who'enlisted for the war' and the soldier who serves in time of peace.  Onesystem embraced men who risked life for a principle
column71: and often men ofsocial standing
column72: competence
column73: or wealth and independence of character.The other includes
column74: as a rule
column75: only men who could not do as well in anyother occupation.  General Buell became an object of harsh criticismlater
column76: some going so far as to challenge his loyalty.  No one who knewhim ever believed him capable of a dishonorable act
column77: and nothing couldbe more dishonorable than to accept high rank and command in war andthen betray the trust.  When I came into command of the army in 1864
column78: Irequested the Secretary of War to restore General Buell to duty.After the war
column79: during the summer of 1865
column80: I travelled considerablythrough the North
column81: and was everywhere met by large numbers of people.Every one had his opinion about the manner in which the war had beenconducted:  who among the generals had failed
column82: how
column83: and why.Correspondents of the press were ever on hand to hear every worddropped
column84: and were not always disposed to report correctly what did notconfirm their preconceived notions
column85: either about the conduct of the waror the individuals concerned in it.  The opportunity frequently occurredfor me to defend General Buell against what I believed to be most unjustcharges.  On one occasion a correspondent put in my mouth the verycharge I had so often refuted--of disloyalty.  This brought from GeneralBuell a very severe retort
column86: which I saw in the New York World some timebefore I received the letter itself.  I could very well understand hisgrievance at seeing untrue and disgraceful charges apparently sustainedby an officer who
column87: at the time
column88: was at the head of the army.  I repliedto him
column89: but not through the press.  I kept no copy of my letter
column90: nor didI ever see it in print; neither did I receive an answer.General Albert Sidney Johnston
column91: who commanded the Confederate forces atthe beginning of the battle
column92: was disabled by a wound on the afternoon ofthe first day.  This wound
column93: as I understood afterwards
column94: was notnecessarily fatal
column95: or even dangerous.  But he was a man who would notabandon what he deemed an important trust in the face of danger andconsequently continued in the saddle
column96: commanding
column97: until so exhausted bythe loss of blood that he had to be taken from his horse
column98: and soon afterdied.  The news was not long in reaching our side and I suppose wasquite an encouragement to the National soldiers.I had known Johnston slightly in the Mexican war and later as an officerin the regular army.  He was a man of high character and ability.  Hiscontemporaries at West Point
column99: and officers generally who came to knowhim personally later and who remained on our side
column100: expected him to provethe most formidable man to meet that the Confederacy would produce.I once wrote that nothing occurred in his brief command of an army toprove or disprove the high estimate that had been placed upon hismilitary ability; but after studying the orders and dispatches ofJohnston I am compelled to materially modify my views of that officer'squalifications as a soldier.  My judgment now is that he was vacillatingand undecided in his actions.All the disasters in Kentucky and Tennessee were so discouraging to theauthorities in Richmond that Jefferson Davis wrote an unofficial letterto Johnston expressing his own anxiety and that of the public
column101: andsaying that he had made such defence as was dictated by long friendship
column102: but that in the absence of a report he needed facts.  The letter was nota reprimand in direct terms
column103: but it was evidently as much felt as thoughit had been one.  General Johnston raised another army as rapidly as hecould
column104: and fortified or strongly intrenched at Corinth.  He knew theNational troops were preparing to attack him in his chosen position.But he had evidently become so disturbed at the results of hisoperations that he resolved to strike out in an offensive campaign whichwould restore all that was lost
column105: and if successful accomplish stillmore.  We have the authority of his son and biographer for saying thathis plan was to attack the forces at Shiloh and crush them; then tocross the Tennessee and destroy the army of Buell
column106: and push the waracross the Ohio River.  The design was a bold one; but we have the sameauthority for saying that in the execution Johnston showed vacillationand indecision.  He left Corinth on the 2d of April and was not ready toattack until the 6th.  The distance his army had to march was less thantwenty miles.  Beauregard
column107: his second in command
column108: was opposed to theattack for two reasons: first
column109: he thought
column110: if let alone the Nationaltroops would attack the Confederates in their intrenchments; second
column111: wewere in ground of our own choosing and would necessarily be intrenched.Johnston not only listened to the objection of Beauregard to an attack
column112: but held a council of war on the subject on the morning of the 5th.  Onthe evening of the same day he was in consultation with some of hisgenerals on the same subject
column113: and still again on the morning of the 6th.During this last consultation
column114: and before a decision had been reached
column115: the battle began by the National troops opening fire on the enemy. Thisseemed to settle the question as to whether there was to be any battleof Shiloh.  It also seems to me to settle the question as to whetherthere was a surprise.I do not question the personal courage of General Johnston
column116: or hisability.  But he did not win the distinction predicted for him by manyof his friends.  He did prove that as a general he was over-estimated.General Beauregard was next in rank to Johnston and succeeded to thecommand
column117: which he retained to the close of the battle and during thesubsequent retreat on Corinth
column118: as well as in the siege of that place.His tactics have been severely criticised by Confederate writers
column119: but Ido not believe his fallen chief could have done any better under thecircumstances.  Some of these critics claim that Shiloh was won whenJohnston fell
column120: and that if he had not fallen the army under me wouldhave been annihilated or captured.  IFS defeated the Confederates atShiloh.  There is little doubt that we would have been disgracefullybeaten IF all the shells and bullets fired by us had passed harmlesslyover the enemy and IF all of theirs had taken effect.  Commandinggenerals are liable to be killed during engagements; and the fact thatwhen he was shot Johnston was leading a brigade to induce it to make acharge which had been repeatedly ordered
column121: is evidence that there wasneither the universal demoralization on our side nor the unboundedconfidence on theirs which has been claimed.  There was
column122: in fact
column123: nohour during the day when I doubted the eventual defeat of the enemy
column124: although I was disappointed that reinforcements so near at hand did notarrive at an earlier hour.The description of the battle of Shiloh given by Colonel Wm. PrestonJohnston is very graphic and well told.  The reader will imagine that hecan see each blow struck
column125: a demoralized and broken mob of Unionsoldiers
column126: each blow sending the enemy more demoralized than ever towardsthe Tennessee River
column127: which was a little more than two miles away at thebeginning of the onset. If the reader does not stop to inquire why
column128: withsuch Confederate success for more than twelve hours of hard fighting
column129: the National troops were not all killed
column130: captured or driven into theriver
column131: he will regard the pen picture as perfect.  But I witnessed thefight from the National side from eight o'clock in the morning untilnight closed the contest.  I see but little in the description that Ican recognize.  The Confederate troops fought well and deservecommendation enough for their bravery and endurance on the 6th of April
column132: without detracting from their antagonists or claiming anything more thantheir just dues.The reports of the enemy show that their condition at the end of thefirst day was deplorable; their losses in killed and wounded had beenvery heavy
column133: and their stragglers had been quite as numerous as on theNational side
column134: with the difference that those of the enemy left thefield entirely and were not brought back to their respective commandsfor many days.  On the Union side but few of the stragglers fell backfurther than the landing on the river
column135: and many of these were in linefor duty on the second day.  The admissions of the highest Confederateofficers engaged at Shiloh make the claim of a victory for them absurd.The victory was not to either party until the battle was over.  It wasthen a Union victory
column136: in which the Armies of the Tennessee and the Ohioboth participated.  But the Army of the Tennessee fought the entirerebel army on the 6th and held it at bay until near night; and nightalone closed the conflict and not the three regiments of Nelson'sdivision.The Confederates fought with courage at Shiloh
column137: but the particular skillclaimed I could not and still cannot see; though there is nothing tocriticise except the claims put forward for it since.  But theConfederate claimants for superiority in strategy
column138: superiority ingeneralship and superiority in dash and prowess are not so unjust to theUnion troops engaged at Shiloh as are many Northern writers.  The troopson both sides were American
column139: and united they need not fear any foreignfoe.  It is possible that the Southern man started in with a little moredash than his Northern brother; but he was correspondingly lessenduring.The endeavor of the enemy on the first day was simply to hurl their menagainst ours--first at one point
column140: then at another
column141: sometimes at severalpoints at once.  This they did with daring and energy
column142: until at nightthe rebel troops were worn out.  Our effort during the same time was tobe prepared to resist assaults wherever made.  The object of theConfederates on the second day was to get away with as much of theirarmy and material as possible.  Ours then was to drive them from ourfront
column143: and to capture or destroy as great a part as possible of theirmen and material.  We were successful in driving them back
column144: but not sosuccessful in captures as if farther pursuit could have been made.  Asit was
column145: we captured or recaptured on the second day about as muchartillery as we lost on the first; and
column146: leaving out the one greatcapture of Prentiss
column147: we took more prisoners on Monday than the enemygained from us on Sunday.  On the 6th Sherman lost seven pieces ofartillery
column148: McClernand six
column149: Prentiss eight
column150: and Hurlbut two batteries.On the 7th Sherman captured seven guns
column151: McClernand three and the Army ofthe Ohio twenty.At Shiloh the effective strength of the Union forces on the morning ofthe 6th was 33
column152: 000 men.  Lew. Wallace brought 5
column153: 000 more afternightfall.  Beauregard reported the enemy's strength at 40
column154: 955.According to the custom of enumeration in the South
column155: this numberprobably excluded every man enlisted as musician or detailed as guard ornurse
column156: and all commissioned officers--everybody who did not carry amusket or serve a cannon. With us everybody in the field receiving payfrom the government is counted.  Excluding the troops who fled
column157: panic-stricken
column158: before they had fired a shot
column159: there was not a timeduring the 6th when we had more than 25
column160: 000 men in line. On the 7thBuell brought 20
column161: 000 more.  Of his remaining two divisions
column162: Thomas's didnot reach the field during the engagement; Wood's arrived before firinghad ceased
column163: but not in time to be of much service.Our loss in the two days' fight was 1
column164: 754 killed
column166: 408 wounded and2
column167: 885 missing.  Of these
column169: 103 were in the Army of the Ohio.Beauregard reported a total loss of 10
column171: of whom 1
column172: 728 were killed
column174: 012 wounded and 957 missing.  This estimate must be incorrect.  Weburied
column175: by actual count
column176: more of the enemy's dead in front of thedivisions of McClernand and Sherman alone than here reported
column177: and 4
column178: 000was the estimate of the burial parties of the whole field.  Beauregardreports the Confederate force on the 6th at over 40
column180: and their totalloss during the two days at 10
column181: 699; and at the same time declares thathe could put only 20
column182: 000 men in battle on the morning of the 7th.The navy gave a hearty support to the army at Shiloh
column183: as indeed italways did both before and subsequently when I was in command.  Thenature of the ground was such
column184: however
column185: that on this occasion it coulddo nothing in aid of the troops until sundown on the first day.  Thecountry was broken and heavily timbered
column186: cutting off all view of thebattle from the river
column187: so that friends would be as much in danger fromfire from the gunboats as the foe.  But about sundown
column188: when the Nationaltroops were back in their last position
column189: the right of the enemy was nearthe river and exposed to the fire of the two gun-boats
column190: which wasdelivered with vigor and effect.  After nightfall
column191: when firing hadentirely ceased on land
column192: the commander of the fleet informed himself
column193: approximately
column194: of the position of our troops and suggested the idea ofdropping a shell within the lines of the enemy every fifteen minutesduring the night.  This was done with effect
column195: as is proved by theConfederate reports.Up to the battle of Shiloh I
column196: as well as thousands of other citizens
column197: believed that the rebellion against the Government would collapsesuddenly and soon
column198: if a decisive victory could be gained over any of itsarmies.  Donelson and Henry were such victories.  An army of more than21
column199: 000 men was captured or destroyed.  Bowling Green
column200: Columbus andHickman
column201: Kentucky
column202: fell in consequence
column203: and Clarksville and Nashville
column204: Tennessee
column205: the last two with an immense amount of stores
column206: also fell intoour hands.  The Tennessee and Cumberland rivers
column207: from their mouths tothe head of navigation
column208: were secured.  But when Confederate armies werecollected which not only attempted to hold a line farther south
column209: fromMemphis to Chattanooga
column210: Knoxville and on to the Atlantic
column211: but assumedthe offensive and made such a gallant effort to regain what had beenlost
column212: then
column213: indeed
column214: I gave up all idea of saving the Union except bycomplete conquest.  Up to that time it had been the policy of our army
column215: certainly of that portion commanded by me
column216: to protect the property ofthe citizens whose territory was invaded
column217: without regard to theirsentiments
column218: whether Union or Secession.  After this
column219: however
column220: I regardedit as humane to both sides to protect the persons of those found attheir homes
column221: but to consume everything that could be used to support orsupply armies.  Protection was still continued over such supplies aswere within lines held by us and which we expected to continue to hold;but such supplies within the reach of Confederate armies I regarded asmuch contraband as arms or ordnance stores.  Their destruction wasaccomplished without bloodshed and tended to the same result as thedestruction of armies.  I continued this policy to the close of the war.Promiscuous pillaging
column222: however
column223: was discouraged and punished.Instructions were always given to take provisions and forage under thedirection of commissioned officers who should give receipts to owners
column224: if at home
column225: and turn the property over to officers of the quartermasteror commissary departments to be issued as if furnished from our Northerndepots.  But much was destroyed without receipts to owners
column226: when itcould not be brought within our lines and would otherwise have gone tothe support of secession and rebellion.This policy I believe exercised a material influence in hastening theend.The battle of Shiloh
column227: or Pittsburg landing
column228: has been perhaps lessunderstood
column229: or
column230: to state the case more accurately
column231: more persistentlymisunderstood
column232: than any other engagement between National andConfederate troops during the entire rebellion. Correct reports of thebattle have been published
column233: notably by Sherman
column234: Badeau and
column235: in a speechbefore a meeting of veterans
column236: by General Prentiss; but all of theseappeared long subsequent to the close of the rebellion and after publicopinion had been most erroneously formed.I myself made no report to General Halleck

column1: ISFP	 XXVI.HALLECK ASSUMES COMMAND IN THE FIELD--THE ADVANCE UPON CORINTH--OCCUPATION OF CORINTH--THE ARMY SEPARATED.General Halleck arrived at Pittsburg landing on the 11th of April andimmediately assumed command in the field.  On the 21st General Popearrived with an army 30
column2: 000 strong
column3: fresh from the capture of IslandNumber Ten in the Mississippi River.  He went into camp at Hamburglanding five miles above Pittsburg. Halleck had now three armies:  theArmy of the Ohio
column4: Buell commanding; the Army of the Mississippi
column5: Popecommanding; and the Army of the Tennessee.  His orders divided thecombined force into the right wing
column6: reserve
column7: centre and left wing.Major-General George H. Thomas
column8: who had been in Buell's army
column9: wastransferred with his division to the Army of the Tennessee and givencommand of the right wing
column10: composed of all of that army exceptMcClernand's and Lew. Wallace's divisions. McClernand was assigned tothe command of the reserve
column11: composed of his own and Lew. Wallace'sdivisions.  Buell commanded the centre
column12: the Army of the Ohio; and Popethe left wing
column13: the Army of the Mississippi.  I was named second incommand of the whole
column14: and was also supposed to be in command of theright wing and reserve.Orders were given to all the commanders engaged at Shiloh to send intheir reports without delay to department headquarters.  Those fromofficers of the Army of the Tennessee were sent through me; but from theArmy of the Ohio they were sent by General Buell without passing throughmy hands.  General Halleck ordered me
column15: verbally
column16: to send in my report
column17: but I positively declined on the ground that he had received the reportsof a part of the army engaged at Shiloh without their coming through me.He admitted that my refusal was justifiable under the circumstances
column18: butexplained that he had wanted to get the reports off before moving thecommand
column19: and as fast as a report had come to him he had forwarded it toWashington.Preparations were at once made upon the arrival of the new commander foran advance on Corinth.  Owl Creek
column20: on our right
column21: was bridged
column22: andexpeditions were sent to the north-west and west to ascertain if ourposition was being threatened from those quarters; the roads towardsCorinth were corduroyed and new ones made; lateral roads were alsoconstructed
column23: so that in case of necessity troops marching by differentroutes could reinforce each other.  All commanders were cautionedagainst bringing on an engagement and informed in so many words that itwould be better to retreat than to fight.  By the 30th of April allpreparations were complete; the country west to the Mobile and Ohiorailroad had been reconnoitred
column24: as well as the road to Corinth as far asMonterey twelve miles from Pittsburg. Everywhere small bodies of theenemy had been encountered
column25: but they were observers and not in force tofight battles.Corinth
column26: Mississippi

column158: Illinois
column159: by some of my subordinates with the statement that it was myorder.  I had all such released the moment I learned of their arrest;and finally sent a staff officer north to release every prisoner who wassaid to be confined by my order.  There were many citizens at home whodeserved punishment because they were soldiers when an opportunity wasafforded to inflict an injury to the National cause.  This class was notof the kind that were apt to get arrested
column160: and I deemed it better that afew guilty men should escape than that a great many innocent ones shouldsuffer.On the 14th of August I was ordered to send two more divisions to Buell.They were sent the same day by way of Decatur.  On the 22d ColonelRodney Mason surrendered Clarksville with six companies of his regiment.Colonel Mason was one of the officers who had led their regiments offthe field at almost the first fire of the rebels at Shiloh.  He was bynature and education a gentleman
column161: and was terribly mortified at hisaction when the battle was over.  He came to me with tears in his eyesand begged to be allowed to have another trial.  I felt great sympathyfor him and sent him
column162: with his regiment
column163: to garrison Clarksville andDonelson.  He selected Clarksville for his headquarters
column164: no doubtbecause he regarded it as the post of danger
column165: it being nearer the enemy.But when he was summoned to surrender by a band of guerillas
column166: hisconstitutional weakness overcame him.  He inquired the number of men theenemy had
column167: and receiving a response indicating a force greater than hisown he said if he could be satisfied of that fact he would surrender.Arrangements were made for him to count the guerillas
column168: and havingsatisfied himself that the enemy had the greater force he surrenderedand informed his subordinate at Donelson of the fact
column169: advising him to dothe same.  The guerillas paroled their prisoners and moved uponDonelson
column170: but the officer in command at that point marched out to meetthem and drove them away.Among other embarrassments
column171: at the time of which I now write
column172: was thefact that the government wanted to get out all the cotton possible fromthe South and directed me to give every facility toward that end.  Payin gold was authorized
column173: and stations on the Mississippi River and on therailroad in our possession had to be designated where cotton would bereceived.  This opened to the enemy not only the means of convertingcotton into money
column174: which had a value all over the world and which theyso much needed
column175: but it afforded them means of obtaining accurate andintelligent information in regard to our position and strength.  It wasalso demoralizing to the troops.  Citizens obtaining permits from thetreasury department had to be protected within our lines and givenfacilities to get out cotton by which they realized enormous profits.Men who had enlisted to fight the battles of their country did not liketo be engaged in protecting a traffic which went to the support of anenemy they had to fight
column176: and the profits of which went to men who sharednone of their dangers.On the 30th of August Colonel M. D. Leggett
column177: near Bolivar
column178: with the 20thand 29th Ohio volunteer infantry
column179: was attacked by a force supposed to beabout 4
column180: 000 strong.  The enemy was driven away with a loss of more thanone hundred men.  On the 1st of September the bridge guard at Medon wasattacked by guerillas. The guard held the position until reinforced
column181: when the enemy were routed leaving about fifty of their number on thefield dead or wounded
column182: our loss being only two killed and fifteenwounded.  On the same day Colonel Dennis
column183: with a force of less than 500infantry and two pieces of artillery
column184: met the cavalry of the enemy instrong force
column185: a few miles west of Medon
column186: and drove them away with greatloss.  Our troops buried 179 of the enemy's dead
column187: left upon the field.Afterwards it was found that all the houses in the vicinity of thebattlefield were turned into hospitals for the wounded.  Our loss
column188: asreported at the time
column189: was forty-five killed and wounded.  On the 2d ofSeptember I was ordered to send more reinforcements to Buell.  Jacksonand Bolivar were yet threatened
column190: but I sent the reinforcements.  On the4th I received direct orders to send Granger's division also toLouisville
column191: Kentucky.General Buell had left Corinth about the 10th of June to march uponChattanooga; Bragg
column192: who had superseded Beauregard in command
column193: sent onedivision from Tupelo on the 27th of June for the same place.  This gaveBuell about seventeen days' start. If he had not been required to repairthe railroad as he advanced
column194: the march could have been made in eighteendays at the outside
column195: and Chattanooga must have been reached by theNational forces before the rebels could have possibly got there.  Theroad between Nashville and Chattanooga could easily have been put inrepair by other troops
column196: so that communication with the North would havebeen opened in a short time after the occupation of the place by theNational troops.  If Buell had been permitted to move in the firstinstance
column197: with the whole of the Army of the Ohio and that portion of theArmy of the Mississippi afterwards sent to him
column198: he could have thrownfour divisions from his own command along the line of road to repair andguard it.Granger's division was promptly sent on the 4th of September.  I was atthe station at Corinth when the troops reached that point
column199: and foundGeneral P. H. Sheridan with them.  I expressed surprise at seeing himand said that I had not expected him to go.  He showed decideddisappointment at the prospect of being detained.  I felt a littlenettled at his desire to get away and did not detain him.Sheridan was a first lieutenant in the regiment in which I had servedeleven years
column200: the 4th infantry
column201: and stationed on the Pacific coast whenthe war broke out.  He was promoted to a captaincy in May
column203: andbefore the close of the year managed in some way
column204: I do not know how
column205: toget East.  He went to Missouri.  Halleck had known him as a verysuccessful young officer in managing campaigns against the Indians onthe Pacific coast
column206: and appointed him acting-quartermaster in south-westMissouri.  There was no difficulty in getting supplies forward whileSheridan served in that capacity; but he got into difficulty with hisimmediate superiors because of his stringent rules for preventing theuse of public transportation for private purposes.  He asked to berelieved from further duty in the capacity in which he was engaged andhis request was granted. When General Halleck took the field in April
column208: Sheridan was assigned to duty on his staff.  During the advance onCorinth a vacancy occurred in the colonelcy of the 2d Michigan cavalry.Governor Blair
column209: of Michigan
column210: telegraphed General Halleck asking him tosuggest the name of a professional soldier for the vacancy
column211: saying hewould appoint a good man without reference to his State.  Sheridan wasnamed; and was so conspicuously efficient that when Corinth was reachedhe was assigned to command a cavalry brigade in the Army of theMississippi.  He was in command at Booneville on the 1st of July withtwo small regiments
column212: when he was attacked by a force full three timesas numerous as his own.  By very skilful manoeuvres and boldness ofattack he completely routed the enemy.  For this he was made abrigadier-general and became a conspicuous figure in the army aboutCorinth.  On this account I was sorry to see him leaving me.  Hisdeparture was probably fortunate
column213: for he rendered distinguished servicesin his new field.Granger and Sheridan reached Louisville before Buell got there
column214: and onthe night of their arrival Sheridan with his command threw up worksaround the railroad station for the defence of troops as they came fromthe front.

column1: ISFP	 XXVIII.ADVANCE OF VAN DORN AND PRICE--PRICE ENTERS IUKA--BATTLE OF IUKA.At this time
column2: September 4th
column3: I had two divisions of the Army of theMississippi stationed at Corinth
column4: Rienzi
column5: Jacinto and Danville.  Therewere at Corinth also Davies' division and two brigades of McArthur's
column6: besides cavalry and artillery.  This force constituted my left wing
column7: ofwhich Rosecrans was in command.  General Ord commanded the centre
column8: fromBethel to Humboldt on the Mobile and Ohio railroad and from Jackson toBolivar where the Mississippi Central is crossed by the Hatchie River.General Sherman commanded on the right at Memphis with two of hisbrigades back at Brownsville
column9: at the crossing of the Hatchie River bythe Memphis and Ohio railroad.  This made the most convenientarrangement I could devise for concentrating all my spare forces uponany threatened point.  All the troops of the command were withintelegraphic communication of each other
column10: except those under Sherman.  Bybringing a portion of his command to Brownsville
column11: from which point therewas a railroad and telegraph back to Memphis
column12: communication could be hadwith that part of my command within a few hours by the use of couriers.In case it became necessary to reinforce Corinth
column13: by this arrangementall the troops at Bolivar
column14: except a small guard
column15: could be sent by railby the way of Jackson in less than twenty-four hours; while the troopsfrom Brownsville could march up to Bolivar to take their place.On the 7th of September I learned of the advance of Van Dorn and Price
column16: apparently upon Corinth.  One division was brought from Memphis toBolivar to meet any emergency that might arise from this move of theenemy.  I was much concerned because my first duty
column17: after holding theterritory acquired within my command
column18: was to prevent further reinforcingof Bragg in Middle Tennessee.  Already the Army of Northern Virginia haddefeated the army under General Pope and was invading Maryland.  In theCentre General Buell was on his way to Louisville and Bragg marchingparallel to him with a large Confederate force for the Ohio River.I had been constantly called upon to reinforce Buell until at this timemy entire force numbered less than 50
column19: 000 men
column20: of all arms.  Thisincluded everything from Cairo south within my jurisdiction.  If I tooshould be driven back
column21: the Ohio River would become the line dividing thebelligerents west of the Alleghanies
column22: while at the East the line wasalready farther north than when hostilities commenced at the opening ofthe war.  It is true Nashville was never given up after its firstcapture
column23: but it would have been isolated and the garrison there wouldhave been obliged to beat a hasty retreat if the troops in WestTennessee had been compelled to fall back.  To say at the end of thesecond year of the war the line dividing the contestants at the East waspushed north of Maryland
column24: a State that had not seceded
column25: and at the Westbeyond Kentucky
column26: another State which had been always loyal
column27: would havebeen discouraging indeed.  As it was
column28: many loyal people despaired in thefall of 1862 of ever saving the Union.  The administration at Washingtonwas much concerned for the safety of the cause it held so dear. But Ibelieve there was never a day when the President did not think that
column29: insome way or other
column30: a cause so just as ours would come out triumphant.Up to the 11th of September Rosecrans still had troops on the railroadeast of Corinth
column31: but they had all been ordered in.  By the 12th all werein except a small force under Colonel Murphy of the 8th Wisconsin.  Hehad been detained to guard the remainder of the stores which had not yetbeen brought in to Corinth.On the 13th of September General Sterling Price entered Iuka
column32: a townabout twenty miles east of Corinth on the Memphis and Charlestonrailroad.  Colonel Murphy with a few men was guarding the place.  Hemade no resistance
column33: but evacuated the town on the approach of the enemy.I was apprehensive lest the object of the rebels might be to get troopsinto Tennessee to reinforce Bragg
column34: as it was afterwards ascertained tobe.  The authorities at Washington
column35: including the general-in-chief ofthe army
column36: were very anxious
column37: as I have said
column38: about affairs both in Eastand Middle Tennessee; and my anxiety was quite as great on their accountas for any danger threatening my command.  I had not force enough atCorinth to attack Price even by stripping everything; and there wasdanger that before troops could be got from other points he might be faron his way across the Tennessee.  To prevent this all spare forces atBolivar and Jackson were ordered to Corinth
column39: and cars were concentratedat Jackson for their transportation.  Within twenty-four hours from thetransmission of the order the troops were at their destination
column40: althoughthere had been a delay of four hours resulting from the forward traingetting off the track and stopping all the others.  This gave areinforcement of near 8
column41: 000 men
column42: General Ord in command.  GeneralRosecrans commanded the district of Corinth with a movable force ofabout 9
column43: 000 independent of the garrison deemed necessary to be leftbehind.  It was known that General Van Dorn was about a four days' marchsouth of us
column44: with a large force.  It might have been part of his plan toattack at Corinth
column45: Price coming from the east while he came up from thesouth.  My desire was to attack Price before Van Dorn could reachCorinth or go to his relief.General Rosecrans had previously had his headquarters at Iuka
column46: where hiscommand was spread out along the Memphis and Charleston railroadeastward.  While there he had a most excellent map prepared showing allthe roads and streams in the surrounding country.  He was alsopersonally familiar with the ground
column47: so that I deferred very much to himin my plans for the approach.  We had cars enough to transport all ofGeneral Ord's command
column48: which was to go by rail to Burnsville
column49: a point onthe road about seven miles west of Iuka.  From there his troops were tomarch by the north side of the railroad and attack Price from thenorth-west
column50: while Rosecrans was to move eastward from his position southof Corinth by way of the Jacinto road.  A small force was to hold theJacinto road where it turns to the north-east
column51: while the main forcemoved on the Fulton road which comes into Iuka further east.  This planwas suggested by Rosecrans.Bear Creek
column52: a few miles to the east of the Fulton road
column53: is a formidableobstacle to the movement of troops in the absence of bridges
column54: all ofwhich
column55: in September
column57: had been destroyed in that vicinity.  TheTennessee
column58: to the north-east
column59: not many miles away
column60: was also a formidableobstacle for an army followed by a pursuing force.  Ord was on thenorth-west
column61: and even if a rebel movement had been possible in thatdirection it could have brought only temporary relief
column62: for it would havecarried Price's army to the rear of the National forces and isolated itfrom all support.  It looked to me that
column63: if Price would remain in Iukauntil we could get there
column64: his annihilation was inevitable.On the morning of the 18th of September General Ord moved by rail toBurnsville
column65: and there left the cars and moved out to perform his part ofthe programme.  He was to get as near the enemy as possible during theday and intrench himself so as to hold his position until the nextmorning.  Rosecrans was to be up by the morning of the 19th on the tworoads before described
column66: and the attack was to be from all three quarterssimultaneously.  Troops enough were left at Jacinto and Rienzi to detainany cavalry that Van Dorn might send out to make a sudden dash intoCorinth until I could be notified.  There was a telegraph wire along therailroad
column67: so there would be no delay in communication.  I detained carsand locomotives enough at Burnsville to transport the whole of Ord'scommand at once
column68: and if Van Dorn had moved against Corinth instead ofIuka I could have thrown in reinforcements to the number of 7
column70: 000 before he could have arrived.  I remained at Burnsville with adetachment of about 900 men from Ord's command and communicated with mytwo wings by courier.  Ord met the advance of the enemy soon afterleaving Burnsville.  Quite a sharp engagement ensued
column71: but he drove therebels back with considerable loss
column72: including one general officerkilled.  He maintained his position and was ready to attack by daylightthe next morning.  I was very much disappointed at receiving a dispatchfrom Rosecrans after midnight from Jacinto
column73: twenty-two miles from Iuka
column74: saying that some of his command had been delayed
column75: and that the rear ofhis column was not yet up as far as Jacinto.  He said
column76: however
column77: that hewould still be at Iuka by two o'clock the next day.  I did not believethis possible because of the distance and the condition of the roads
column78: which was bad; besides
column79: troops after a forced march of twenty miles arenot in a good condition for fighting the moment they get through.  Itmight do in marching to relieve a beleaguered garrison
column80: but not to makean assault.  I immediately sent Ord a copy of Rosecrans' dispatch andordered him to be in readiness to attack the moment he heard the soundof guns to the south or south-east.  He was instructed to notify hisofficers to be on the alert for any indications of battle. During the19th the wind blew in the wrong direction to transmit sound eithertowards the point where Ord was
column81: or to Burnsville where I had remained.A couple of hours before dark on the 19th Rosecrans arrived with thehead of his column at garnets
column82: the point where the Jacinto road to Iukaleaves the road going east.  He here turned north without sending anytroops to the Fulton road.  While still moving in column up the Jacintoroad he met a force of the enemy and had his advance badly beaten anddriven back upon the main road.  In this short engagement his loss wasconsiderable for the number engaged
column83: and one battery was taken from him.The wind was still blowing hard and in the wrong direction to transmitsounds towards either Ord or me.  Neither he nor I nor any one in eithercommand heard a gun that was fired upon the battle-field.  After theengagement Rosecrans sent me a dispatch announcing the result.  This wasbrought by a courier.  There was no road between Burnsville and theposition then occupied by Rosecrans and the country was impassable for aman on horseback.  The courier bearing the message was compelled to movewest nearly to Jacinto before he found a road leading to Burnsville.This made it a late hour of the night before I learned of the battlethat had taken place during the afternoon.  I at once notified Ord ofthe fact and ordered him to attack early in the morning.  The nextmorning Rosecrans himself renewed the attack and went into Iuka with butlittle resistance.  Ord also went in according to orders
column84: withouthearing a gun from the south of town but supposing the troops comingfrom the south-west must be up by that time.  Rosecrans
column85: however
column86: hadput no troops upon the Fulton road
column87: and the enemy had taken advantage ofthis neglect and retreated by that road during the night.  Word was soonbrought to me that our troops were in Iuka.  I immediately rode intotown and found that the enemy was not being pursued even by the cavalry.I ordered pursuit by the whole of Rosecrans' command and went on withhim a few miles in person.  He followed only a few miles after I lefthim and then went into camp
column88: and the pursuit was continued no further.I was disappointed at the result of the battle of Iuka--but I had sohigh an opinion of General Rosecrans that I found no fault at the time.

column1: ISFP	 XXIX.VAN DORN'S MOVEMENTS--BATTLE OF CORINTH--COMMAND OF THE DEPARTMENT OFTHE TENNESSEE.On the 19th of September General Geo. H. Thomas was ordered east toreinforce Buell.  This threw the army at my command still more on thedefensive.  The Memphis and Charleston railroad was abandoned
column2: except atCorinth
column3: and small forces were left at Chewalla and Grand Junction.Soon afterwards the latter of these two places was given up and Bolivarbecame our most advanced position on the Mississippi Central railroad.Our cavalry was kept well to the front and frequent expeditions weresent out to watch the movements of the enemy.  We were in a countrywhere nearly all the people
column4: except the negroes
column5: were hostile to us andfriendly to the cause we were trying to suppress.  It was easy
column6: therefore
column7: for the enemy to get early information of our every move.We
column8: on the contrary
column9: had to go after our information in force
column10: and thenoften returned without it.On the 22d Bolivar was threatened by a large force from south of GrandJunction
column11: supposed to be twenty regiments of infantry with cavalry andartillery.  I reinforced Bolivar
column12: and went to Jackson in person tosuperintend the movement of troops to whatever point the attack might bemade upon.  The troops from Corinth were brought up in time to repel thethreatened movement without a battle.  Our cavalry followed the enemysouth of Davis' mills in Mississippi.On the 30th I found that Van Dorn was apparently endeavoring to strikethe Mississippi River above Memphis.  At the same time other pointswithin my command were so threatened that it was impossible toconcentrate a force to drive him away.  There was at this juncture alarge Union force at Helena
column13: Arkansas
column14: which
column15: had it been within mycommand
column16: I could have ordered across the river to attack and break upthe Mississippi Central railroad far to the south.  This would not onlyhave called Van Dorn back
column17: but would have compelled the retention of alarge rebel force far to the south to prevent a repetition of such raidson the enemy's line of supplies.  Geographical lines between thecommands during the rebellion were not always well chosen
column18: or they weretoo rigidly adhered to.Van Dorn did not attempt to get upon the line above Memphis
column19: as hadapparently been his intention.  He was simply covering a deeper design;one much more important to his cause.  By the 1st of October it wasfully apparent that Corinth was to be attacked with great force anddetermination
column20: and that Van Dorn
column21: Lovell
column22: Price
column23: Villepigue and Rust hadjoined their strength for this purpose.  There was some skirmishingoutside of Corinth with the advance of the enemy on the 3d.  The rebelsmassed in the north-west angle of the Memphis and Charleston and theMobile and Ohio railroads
column24: and were thus between the troops at Corinthand all possible reinforcements.  Any fresh troops for us must come by acircuitous route.On the night of the 3d
column25: accordingly
column26: I ordered General McPherson
column27: whowas at Jackson
column28: to join Rosecrans at Corinth with reinforcements pickedup along the line of the railroad equal to a brigade.  Hurlbut had beenordered from Bolivar to march for the same destination; and as Van Dornwas coming upon Corinth from the north-west some of his men fell in withthe advance of Hurlbut's and some skirmishing ensued on the evening ofthe 3d.  On the 4th Van Dorn made a dashing attack
column29: hoping
column30: no doubt
column31: tocapture Rosecrans before his reinforcements could come up.  In that casethe enemy himself could have occupied the defences of Corinth and heldat bay all the Union troops that arrived.  In fact he could have takenthe offensive against the reinforcements with three or four times theirnumber and still left a sufficient garrison in the works about Corinthto hold them.  He came near success
column32: some of his troops penetrating theNational lines at least once
column33: but the works that were built afterHalleck's departure enabled Rosecrans to hold his position until thetroops of both McPherson and Hurlbut approached towards the rebel frontand rear.  The enemy was finally driven back with great slaughter:  alltheir charges
column34: made with great gallantry
column35: were repulsed.  The loss onour side was heavy
column36: but nothing to compare with Van Dorn's.  McPhersoncame up with the train of cars bearing his command as close to the enemyas was prudent
column37: debarked on the rebel flank and got in to the support ofRosecrans just after the repulse.  His approach
column38: as well as that ofHurlbut
column39: was known to the enemy and had a moral effect. GeneralRosecrans
column40: however
column41: failed to follow up the victory
column42: although I hadgiven specific orders in advance of the battle for him to pursue themoment the enemy was repelled.  He did not do so
column43: and I repeated theorder after the battle.  In the first order he was notified that theforce of 4
column44: 000 men which was going to his assistance would be in greatperil if the enemy was not pursued.General Ord had joined Hurlbut on the 4th and being senior took commandof his troops.  This force encountered the head of Van Dorn's retreatingcolumn just as it was crossing the Hatchie by a bridge some ten milesout from Corinth.  The bottom land here was swampy and bad for theoperations of troops
column45: making a good place to get an enemy into.  Ordattacked the troops that had crossed the bridge and drove them back in apanic.  Many were killed
column46: and others were drowned by being pushed offthe bridge in their hurried retreat.  Ord followed and met the mainforce.  He was too weak in numbers to assault
column47: but he held the bridgeand compelled the enemy to resume his retreat by another bridge higherup the stream.  Ord was wounded in this engagement and the commanddevolved on Hurlbut.Rosecrans did not start in pursuit till the morning of the 5th and thentook the wrong road.  Moving in the enemy's country he travelled with awagon train to carry his provisions and munitions of war.  His march wastherefore slower than that of the enemy
column48: who was moving towards hissupplies.  Two or three hours of pursuit on the day of battle
column49: withoutanything except what the men carried on their persons
column50: would have beenworth more than any pursuit commenced the next day could have possiblybeen.  Even when he did start
column51: if Rosecrans had followed the route takenby the enemy
column52: he would have come upon Van Dorn in a swamp with a streamin front and Ord holding the only bridge; but he took the road leadingnorth and towards Chewalla instead of west
column53: and
column54: after having marched asfar as the enemy had moved to get to the Hatchie
column55: he was as far frombattle as when he started.  Hurlbut had not the numbers to meet any suchforce as Van Dorn's if they had been in any mood for fighting
column56: and hemight have been in great peril.I now regarded the time to accomplish anything by pursuit as past and
column57: after Rosecrans reached Jonesboro
column58: I ordered him to return.  He kept onto Ripley
column59: however
column60: and was persistent in wanting to go farther.  Ithereupon ordered him to halt and submitted the matter to thegeneral-in-chief
column61: who allowed me to exercise my judgment in the matter
column62: but inquired 'why not pursue?'  Upon this I ordered Rosecrans back.  Hadhe gone much farther he would have met a greater force than Van Dorn hadat Corinth and behind intrenchments or on chosen ground
column63: and theprobabilities are he would have lost his army.The battle of Corinth was bloody
column64: our loss being 315 killed
column66: 812wounded and 232 missing.  The enemy lost many more. Rosecrans reported1
column67: 423 dead and 2
column68: 225 prisoners.  We fought behind breastworks
column69: whichaccounts in some degree for the disparity.  Among the killed on our sidewas General Hackelman.  General Oglesby was badly
column70: it was for some timesupposed mortally
column71: wounded.  I received a congratulatory letter from thePresident
column72: which expressed also his sorrow for the losses.This battle was recognized by me as being a decided victory
column73: though notso complete as I had hoped for
column74: nor nearly so complete as I now thinkwas within the easy grasp of the commanding officer at Corinth.  Sincethe war it is known that the result
column75: as it was
column76: was a crushing blow tothe enemy
column77: and felt by him much more than it was appreciated at theNorth.  The battle relieved me from any further anxiety for the safetyof the territory within my jurisdiction
column78: and soon after receivingreinforcements I suggested to the general-in-chief a forward movementagainst Vicksburg.On the 23d of October I learned of Pemberton's being in command at HollySprings and much reinforced by conscripts and troops from Alabama andTexas.  The same day General Rosecrans was relieved from duty with mycommand
column79: and shortly after he succeeded Buell in the command of the armyin Middle Tennessee.  I was delighted at the promotion of GeneralRosecrans to a separate command
column80: because I still believed that whenindependent of an immediate superior the qualities which I
column81: at thattime
column82: credited him with possessing
column83: would show themselves.  As asubordinate I found that I could not make him do as I wished
column84: and haddetermined to relieve him from duty that very day.At the close of the operations just described my force
column85: in roundnumbers
column86: was 48
column87: 500.  Of these 4
column88: 800 were in Kentucky and Illinois
column90: 000 in Memphis
column92: 200 from Mound City south
column93: and 17
column94: 500 at Corinth.General McClernand had been authorized from Washington to go north andorganize troops to be used in opening the Mississippi.  These new levieswith other reinforcements now began to come in.On the 25th of October I was placed in command of the Department of theTennessee.  Reinforcements continued to come from the north and by the2d of November I was prepared to take the initiative.  This was a greatrelief after the two and a half months of continued defence over a largedistrict of country
column95: and where nearly every citizen was an enemy readyto give information of our every move.  I have described veryimperfectly a few of the battles and skirmishes that took place duringthis time.  To describe all would take more space than I can allot tothe purpose; to make special mention of all the officers and troops whodistinguished themselves
column96: would take a volume. (*9)

column1: ISFP	 XXX.THE CAMPAIGN AGAINST VICKSBURG--EMPLOYING THE FREEDMEN--OCCUPATION OFHOLLY SPRINGS--SHERMAN ORDERED TO MEMPHIS--SHERMAN'S MOVEMENTS DOWN THEMISSISSIPPI--VAN DORN CAPTURES HOLLY SPRINGS--COLLECTING FORAGE ANDFOOD.Vicksburg was important to the enemy because it occupied the first highground coming close to the river below Memphis.  From there a railroadruns east
column2: connecting with other roads leading to all points of theSouthern States.  A railroad also starts from the opposite side of theriver
column3: extending west as far as Shreveport
column4: Louisiana.  Vicksburg wasthe only channel
column5: at the time of the events of which this chaptertreats
column6: connecting the parts of the Confederacy divided by theMississippi.  So long as it was held by the enemy
column7: the free navigationof the river was prevented.  Hence its importance.  Points on the riverbetween Vicksburg and Port Hudson were held as dependencies; but theirfall was sure to follow the capture of the former place.The campaign against Vicksburg commenced on the 2d of November asindicated in a dispatch to the general-in-chief in the following words:'I have commenced a movement on Grand Junction
column8: with three divisionsfrom Corinth and two from Bolivar.  Will leave here [Jackson
column9: Tennessee]to-morrow
column10: and take command in person.  If found practicable
column11: I will goto Holly Springs
column12: and
column13: may be
column14: Grenada
column15: completing railroad andtelegraph as I go.'At this time my command was holding the Mobile and Ohio railroad fromabout twenty-five miles south of Corinth
column16: north to Columbus
column17: Kentucky;the Mississippi Central from Bolivar north to its junction with theMobile and Ohio; the Memphis and Charleston from Corinth east to BearCreek
column18: and the Mississippi River from Cairo to Memphis.  My entirecommand was no more than was necessary to hold these lines
column19: and hardlythat if kept on the defensive.  By moving against the enemy and into hisunsubdued
column20: or not yet captured
column21: territory
column22: driving their army before us

column3: which he had burned.  The troops were set to work at once toconstruct a bridge across the South Fork of the Bayou Pierre.  At thistime the water was high and the current rapid.  What might be called araft-bridge was soon constructed from material obtained from woodenbuildings

column5: fences
column6: etc.

When it was finished the army crossed and marchedeight miles beyond to the North Fork that day.  One brigade of Logan'sdivision was sent down the stream to occupy the attention of a rebelbattery
column11: which had been left behind with infantry supports to preventour repairing the burnt railroad bridge.  Two of his brigades were sentup the bayou to find a crossing and reach the North Fork to repair thebridge there.  The enemy soon left when he found we were building abridge elsewhere.  Before leaving Port Gibson we were reinforced byCrocker's division

column233: in front of McClernand there was a smallforce of the enemy and posted in a good position behind a ravineobstructing his advance; but if he had moved to the right by the road mystaff officers had followed the enemy must either have fallen back orbeen cut off.  Instead of this he sent orders to Hovey
column234: who belonged tohis corps
column235: to join on to his right flank.  Hovey was bearing the bruntof the battle at the time.  To obey the order he would have had to pullout from the front of the enemy and march back as far as McClernand hadto advance to get into battle and substantially over the same ground.Of course I did not permit Hovey to obey the order of his intermediatesuperior.We had in this battle about 15
column236: 000 men absolutely engaged.  Thisexcludes those that did not get up
column237: all of McClernand's command exceptHovey.  Our loss was 410 killed
column239: 844 wounded and 187 missing.  Hoveyalone lost 1
column240: 200 killed
column241: wounded and missing--more than one-third of hisdivision.Had McClernand come up with reasonable promptness
column242: or had I known theground as I did afterwards
column243: I cannot see how Pemberton could haveescaped with any organized force.  As it was he lost over three thousandkilled and wounded and about three thousand captured in battle and inpursuit.  Loring's division
column244: which was the right of Pemberton's line
column245: was cut off from the retreating army and never got back into Vicksburg.Pemberton himself fell back that night to the Big Black River.  Histroops did not stop before midnight and many of them left before thegeneral retreat commenced
column246: and no doubt a good part of them returned totheir homes.  Logan alone captured 1
column247: 300 prisoners and eleven guns.Hovey captured 300 under fire and about 700 in all
column248: exclusive of 500sick and wounded whom he paroled
column249: thus making 1
column250: 200.McPherson joined in the advance as soon as his men could fill theircartridge-boxes
column251: leaving one brigade to guard our wounded.  The pursuitwas continued as long as it was light enough to see the road.  The nightof the 16th of May found McPherson's command bivouacked from two to sixmiles west of the battlefield
column252: along the line of the road to Vicksburg.Carr and Osterhaus were at Edward's station
column253: and Blair was about threemiles south-east; Hovey remained on the field where his troops hadfought so bravely and bled so freely.  Much war material abandoned bythe enemy was picked up on the battle-field

Finding ourselves alone we stopped andtook possession of a vacant house.  As no troops came up we moved back amile or more until we met the head of the column just going into bivouacon the road.  We had no tents
column255: so we occupied the porch of a house whichhad been taken for a rebel hospital and which was filled with woundedand dying who had been brought from the battle-field we had just left.While a battle is raging one can see his enemy mowed down by thethousand
column256: or the ten thousand
column257: with great composure; but after thebattle these scenes are distressing
column258: and one is naturally disposed to doas much to alleviate the suffering of an enemy as a friend.

column1: ISFP	 XXXVI.BATTLE OF BLACK RIVER BRIDGE--CROSSING THE BIG BLACK--INVESTMENT OFVICKSBURG--ASSAULTING THE WORKS.We were now assured of our position between Johnston and Pemberton
column2: without a possibility of a junction of their forces.  Pemberton mighthave made a night march to the Big Black
column3: crossed the bridge there and
column4: by moving north on the west side
column5: have eluded us and finally returned toJohnston.  But this would have given us Vicksburg.  It would have beenhis proper move
column6: however
column7: and the one Johnston would have made had hebeen in Pemberton's place.  In fact it would have been in conformitywith Johnston's orders to Pemberton.Sherman left Jackson with the last of his troops about noon on the 16thand reached Bolton
column8: twenty miles west
column9: before halting.  His rear guarddid not get in until two A.M. the 17th
column10: but renewed their march bydaylight.  He paroled his prisoners at Jackson
column11: and was forced to leavehis own wounded in care of surgeons and attendants.  At Bolton he wasinformed of our victory.  He was directed to commence the march earlynext day
