column12: and to diverge from the road he was on to Bridgeport on theBig Black River
column13: some eleven miles above the point where we expected tofind the enemy.  Blair was ordered to join him there with the pontoontrain as early as possible.This movement brought Sherman's corps together
column14: and at a point where Ihoped a crossing of the Big Black might be effected and Sherman's corpsused to flank the enemy out of his position in our front
column15: thus opening acrossing for the remainder of the army.  I informed him that I wouldendeavor to hold the enemy in my front while he crossed the river.The advance division
column16: Carr's (McClernand's corps)
column17: resumed the pursuitat half-past three A.M. on the 17th
column18: followed closely by Osterhaus
column19: McPherson bringing up the rear with his corps.  As I expected
column20: the enemywas found in position on the Big Black.  The point was only six milesfrom that where my advance had rested for the night
column21: and was reached atan early hour.  Here the river makes a turn to the west
column22: and has washedclose up to the high land; the east side is a low bottom
column23: sometimesoverflowed at very high water
column24: but was cleared and in cultivation.  Abayou runs irregularly across this low land
column25: the bottom of which
column26: however
column27: is above the surface of the Big Black at ordinary stages.  Whenthe river is full water runs through it
column28: converting the point of landinto an island.  The bayou was grown up with timber
column29: which the enemy hadfelled into the ditch.  At this time there was a foot or two of water init. The rebels had constructed a parapet along the inner bank of thisbayou by using cotton bales from the plantation close by and throwingdirt over them.  The whole was thoroughly commanded from the height westof the river.  At the upper end of the bayou there was a strip ofuncleared land which afforded a cover for a portion of our men.  Carr'sdivision was deployed on our right
column30: Lawler's brigade forming his extremeright and reaching through these woods to the river above.  Osterhaus'division was deployed to the left of Carr and covered the enemy's entirefront.  McPherson was in column on the road
column31: the head close by
column32: ready tocome in wherever he could be of assistance.While the troops were standing as here described an officer from Banks'staff came up and presented me with a letter from General Halleck
column33: datedthe 11th of May.  It had been sent by the way of New Orleans to Banks tobe forwarded to me.  It ordered me to return to Grand Gulf and toco-operate from there with Banks against Port Hudson
column34: and then to returnwith our combined forces to besiege Vicksburg.  I told the officer thatthe order came too late
column35: and that Halleck would not give it now if heknew our position.  The bearer of the dispatch insisted that I ought toobey the order
column36: and was giving arguments to support his position when Iheard great cheering to the right of our line and
column37: looking in thatdirection
column38: saw Lawler in his shirt sleeves leading a charge upon theenemy.  I immediately mounted my horse and rode in the direction of thecharge
column39: and saw no more of the officer who delivered the dispatch; Ithink not even to this day.The assault was successful.  But little resistance was made. The enemyfled from the west bank of the river
column40: burning the bridge behind him andleaving the men and guns on the east side to fall into our hands.  Manytried to escape by swimming the river. Some succeeded and some weredrowned in the attempt. Eighteen guns were captured and 1
column41: 751 prisoners.Our loss was 39 killed
column42: 237 wounded and 3 missing.  The enemy probablylost but few men except those captured and drowned.  But for thesuccessful and complete destruction of the bridge
column43: I have but littledoubt that we should have followed the enemy so closely as to preventhis occupying his defences around Vicksburg.As the bridge was destroyed and the river was high
column44: new bridges had tobe built.  It was but little after nine o'clock A.M. when the capturetook place.  As soon as work could be commenced
column45: orders were given forthe construction of three bridges.  One was taken charge of byLieutenant Hains
column46: of the Engineer Corps
column47: one by General McPhersonhimself and one by General Ransom
column48: a most gallant and intelligentvolunteer officer.  My recollection is that Hains built a raft bridge;McPherson a pontoon
column49: using cotton bales in large numbers
column50: for pontoons;and that Ransom felled trees on opposite banks of the river
column51: cuttingonly on one side of the tree
column52: so that they would fall with their topsinterlacing in the river
column53: without the trees being entirely severed fromtheir stumps.  A bridge was then made with these trees to support theroadway.  Lumber was taken from buildings
column54: cotton gins and whereverfound
column55: for this purpose.  By eight o'clock in the morning of the 18thall three bridges were complete and the troops were crossing.Sherman reached Bridgeport about noon of the 17th and found Blair withthe pontoon train already there.  A few of the enemy were intrenched onthe west bank
column56: but they made little resistance and soon surrendered.Two divisions were crossed that night and the third the followingmorning.On the 18th I moved along the Vicksburg road in advance of the troopsand as soon as possible joined Sherman.  My first anxiety was to securea base of supplies on the Yazoo River above Vicksburg.  Sherman's lineof march led him to the very point on Walnut Hills occupied by the enemythe December before when he was repulsed.  Sherman was equally anxiouswith myself.  Our impatience led us to move in advance of the column andwell up with the advanced skirmishers.  There were some detached worksalong the crest of the hill.  These were still occupied by the enemy
column57: orelse the garrison from Haines' Bluff had not all got past on their wayto Vicksburg.  At all events the bullets of the enemy whistled by thickand fast for a short time.  In a few minutes Sherman had the pleasure oflooking down from the spot coveted so much by him the December before onthe ground where his command had lain so helpless for offensive action.He turned to me
column58: saying that up to this minute he had felt no positiveassurance of success.  This
column59: however
column60: he said was the end of one of thegreatest campaigns in history and I ought to make a report of it atonce.  Vicksburg was not yet captured
column61: and there was no telling whatmight happen before it was taken; but whether captured or not
column62: this wasa complete and successful campaign.  I do not claim to quote Sherman'slanguage; but the substance only.  My reason for mentioning thisincident will appear further on.McPherson
column63: after crossing the Big Black
column64: came into the Jackson andVicksburg road which Sherman was on
column65: but to his rear.  He arrived atnight near the lines of the enemy
column66: and went into camp.  McClernand movedby the direct road near the railroad to Mount Albans
column67: and then turned tothe left and put his troops on the road from Baldwin's ferry toVicksburg.  This brought him south of McPherson.  I now had my threecorps up the works built for the defence of Vicksburg
column68: on three roads--one to the north
column69: one to the east and one to the south-east of the city.By the morning of the 19th the investment was as complete as my limitednumber of troops would allow.  Sherman was on the right
column70: and covered thehigh ground from where it overlooked the Yazoo as far south-east as histroops would extend.  McPherson joined on to his left
column71: and occupiedground on both sides of the Jackson road.  McClernand took up the groundto his left and extended as far towards Warrenton as he could
column72: keeping acontinuous line.On the 19th there was constant skirmishing with the enemy while we weregetting into better position.  The enemy had been much demoralized byhis defeats at Champion's Hill and the Big Black
column73: and I believed hewould not make much effort to hold Vicksburg. Accordingly
column74: at twoo'clock I ordered an assault.  It resulted in securing more advancedpositions for all our troops where they were fully covered from the fireof the enemy.The 20th and 21st were spent in strengthening our position and in makingroads in rear of the army
column75: from Yazoo River or Chickasaw Bayou.  Most ofthe army had now been for three weeks with only five days' rationsissued by the commissary.  They had an abundance of food
column76: however
column77: butbegan to feel the want of bread.  I remember that in passing around tothe left of the line on the 21st
column78: a soldier
column79: recognizing me
column80: said inrather a low voice
column81: but yet so that I heard him
column82: 'Hard tack.'  In amoment the cry was taken up all along the line
column83: 'Hard tack! Hard tack!'I told the men nearest to me that we had been engaged ever since thearrival of the troops in building a road over which to supply them witheverything they needed.  The cry was instantly changed to cheers.  Bythe night of the 21st all the troops had full rations issued to them.The bread and coffee were highly appreciated.I now determined on a second assault.  Johnston was in my rear
column84: onlyfifty miles away
column85: with an army not much inferior in numbers to the one Ihad with me
column86: and I knew he was being reinforced. There was danger of hiscoming to the assistance of Pemberton
column87: and after all he might defeat myanticipations of capturing the garrison if
column88: indeed
column89: he did not preventthe capture of the city.  The immediate capture of Vicksburg would savesending me the reinforcements which were so much wanted elsewhere
column90: andwould set free the army under me to drive Johnston from the State.  Butthe first consideration of all was--the troops believed they could carrythe works in their front
column91: and would not have worked so patiently in thetrenches if they had not been allowed to try.The attack was ordered to commence on all parts of the line at teno'clock A.M. on the 22d with a furious cannonade from every battery inposition.  All the corps commanders set their time by mine so that allmight open the engagement at the same minute. The attack was gallant
column92: and portions of each of the three corps succeeded in getting up to thevery parapets of the enemy and in planting their battle flags upon them;but at no place were we able to enter.  General McClernand reported thathe had gained the enemy's intrenchments at several points
column93: and wantedreinforcements.  I occupied a position from which I believed I could seeas well as he what took place in his front
column94: and I did not see thesuccess he reported.  But his request for reinforcements being repeatedI could not ignore it
column95: and sent him Quinby's division of the 17th corps.Sherman and McPherson were both ordered to renew their assaults as adiversion in favor of McClernand.  This last attack only served toincrease our casualties without giving any benefit whatever.  As soon asit was dark our troops that had reached the enemy's line and beenobliged to remain there for security all day
column96: were withdrawn; and thusended the last assault upon Vicksburg.

column1: ISFP	 XXXVIISIEGE OF VICKSBURG.I now determined upon a regular siege--to 'out-camp the enemy
column2: ' as itwere
column3: and to incur no more losses.  The experience of the 22d convincedofficers and men that this was best
column4: and they went to work on thedefences and approaches with a will.  With the navy holding the river
column5: the investment of Vicksburg was complete.  As long as we could hold ourposition the enemy was limited in supplies of food
column6: men and munitions ofwar to what they had on hand.  These could not last always.The crossing of troops at Bruinsburg commenced April 30th.  On the 18thof May the army was in rear of Vicksburg.  On the 19th
column7: just twenty daysafter the crossing
column8: the city was completely invested and an assault hadbeen made:  five distinct battles (besides continuous skirmishing) hadbeen fought and won by the Union forces; the capital of the State hadfallen and its arsenals
column9: military manufactories and everything usefulfor military purposes had been destroyed; an average of about onehundred and eighty miles had been marched by the troops engaged; butfive days' rations had been issued
column10: and no forage; over six thousandprisoners had been captured
column11: and as many more of the enemy had beenkilled or wounded; twenty-seven heavy cannon and sixty-one field-pieceshad fallen into our hands; and four hundred miles of the river
column12: fromVicksburg to Port Hudson
column13: had become ours.  The Union force that hadcrossed the Mississippi River up to this time was less than forty-threethousand men. One division of these
column14: Blair's
column15: only arrived in time totake part in the battle of Champion's Hill
column16: but was not engaged there;and one brigade
column17: Ransom's of McPherson's corps
column18: reached the field afterthe battle.  The enemy had at Vicksburg
column19: Grand Gulf
column20: Jackson
column21: and on theroads between these places
column22: over sixty thousand men.  They were in theirown country
column23: where no rear guards were necessary.  The country isadmirable for defence
column24: but difficult for the conduct of an offensivecampaign.  All their troops had to be met.  We were fortunate
column25: to saythe least
column26: in meeting them in detail:  at Port Gibson seven or eightthousand; at Raymond
column27: five thousand; at Jackson
column28: from eight to eleventhousand; at Champion's Hill
column29: twenty-five thousand; at the Big Black
column30: four thousand.  A part of those met at Jackson were all that was left ofthose encountered at Raymond.  They were beaten in detail by a forcesmaller than their own
column31: upon their own ground.  Our loss up to this timewas:                             KILLED  WOUNDED  MISSING Port Gibson.....              131     719      25 South Fork Bayou Pierre.....   ..       1      .. Skirmishes
column32: May 3 .....         1       9      .. Fourteen Mile Creek.....        6      24      .. Raymond...............         66     339      39 Jackson.....                   42     251       7 Champion's Hill.....          410   1
column34: 425     259Of the wounded many were but slightly so
column35: and continued on duty.  Nothalf of them were disabled for any length of time.After the unsuccessful assault of the 22d the work of the regular siegebegan.  Sherman occupied the right starting from the river aboveVicksburg
column36: McPherson the centre (McArthur's division now with him) andMcClernand the left
column37: holding the road south to Warrenton.  Lauman'sdivision arrived at this time and was placed on the extreme left of theline.In the interval between the assaults of the 19th and 22d
column38: roads had beencompleted from the Yazoo River and Chickasaw Bayou
column39: around the rear ofthe army
column40: to enable us to bring up supplies of food and ammunition;ground had been selected and cleared on which the troops were to beencamped
column41: and tents and cooking utensils were brought up.  The troopshad been without these from the time of crossing the Mississippi up tothis time.  All was now ready for the pick and spade.  Prentiss andHurlbut were ordered to send forward every man that could be spared.Cavalry especially was wanted to watch the fords along the Big Black
column42: and to observe Johnston.  I knew that Johnston was receivingreinforcements from Bragg
column43: who was confronting Rosecrans in Tennessee.Vicksburg was so important to the enemy that I believed he would makethe most strenuous efforts to raise the siege
column44: even at the risk oflosing ground elsewhere.My line was more than fifteen miles long
column45: extending from Haines' Bluffto Vicksburg
column46: thence to Warrenton.  The line of the enemy was aboutseven.  In addition to this
column47: having an enemy at Canton and Jackson
column48: inour rear
column49: who was being constantly reinforced
column50: we required a second lineof defence facing the other way.  I had not troops enough under mycommand to man these.  General Halleck appreciated the situation and
column51: without being asked
column52: forwarded reinforcements with all possibledispatch.The ground about Vicksburg is admirable for defence.  On the north it isabout two hundred feet above the Mississippi River at the highest pointand very much cut up by the washing rains; the ravines were grown upwith cane and underbrush
column53: while the sides and tops were covered with adense forest.  Farther south the ground flattens out somewhat
column54: and wasin cultivation.  But here
column55: too
column56: it was cut up by ravines and smallstreams.  The enemy's line of defence followed the crest of a ridge fromthe river north of the city eastward
column57: then southerly around to theJackson road
column58: full three miles back of the city; thence in asouthwesterly direction to the river.  Deep ravines of the descriptiongiven lay in front of these defences.  As there is a succession ofgullies
column59: cut out by rains along the side of the ridge
column60: the line wasnecessarily very irregular.  To follow each of these spurs withintrenchments
column61: so as to command the slopes on either side
column62: would havelengthened their line very much. Generally therefore
column63: or in many places
column64: their line would run from near the head of one gully nearly straight tothe head of another
column65: and an outer work triangular in shape
column66: generallyopen in the rear
column67: was thrown up on the point; with a few men in thisouter work they commanded the approaches to the main line completely.The work to be done
column68: to make our position as strong against the enemy ashis was against us
column69: was very great.  The problem was also complicated byour wanting our line as near that of the enemy as possible.  We had butfour engineer officers with us. Captain Prime
column70: of the Engineer Corps
column71: was the chief
column72: and the work at the beginning was mainly directed by him.His health soon gave out
column73: when he was succeeded by Captain Comstock
column74: also of the Engineer Corps.  To provide assistants on such a long line Idirected that all officers who had graduated at West Point
column75: where theyhad necessarily to study military engineering
column76: should in addition totheir other duties assist in the work.The chief quartermaster and the chief commissary were graduates.  Thechief commissary
column77: now the Commissary-General of the Army
column78: begged off
column79: however
column80: saying that there was nothing in engineering that he was goodfor unless he would do for a sap-roller.  As soldiers require rationswhile working in the ditches as well as when marching and fighting
column81: andas we would be sure to lose him if he was used as a sap-roller
column82: I lethim off.  The general is a large man; weighs two hundred and twentypounds
column83: and is not tall.We had no siege guns except six thirty-two pounders
column84: and there were noneat the West to draw from.  Admiral Porter
column85: however
column86: supplied us with abattery of navy-guns of large calibre
column87: and with these
column88: and the fieldartillery used in the campaign
column89: the siege began.  The first thing to dowas to get the artillery in batteries where they would occupy commandingpositions; then establish the camps
column90: under cover from the fire of theenemy but as near up as possible; and then construct rifle-pits andcovered ways
column91: to connect the entire command by the shortest route.  Theenemy did not harass us much while we were constructing our batteries.Probably their artillery ammunition was short; and their infantry waskept down by our sharpshooters
column92: who were always on the alert and readyto fire at a head whenever it showed itself above the rebel works.In no place were our lines more than six hundred yards from the enemy.It was necessary
column93: therefore
column94: to cover our men by something more thanthe ordinary parapet.  To give additional protection sand bags
column95: bullet-proof
column96: were placed along the tops of the parapets far enoughapart to make loop-holes for musketry.  On top of these
column97: logs were put.By these means the men were enabled to walk about erect when off duty
column98: without fear of annoyance from sharpshooters.  The enemy used in theirdefence explosive musket-balls
column99: no doubt thinking that
column100: bursting overour men in the trenches
column101: they would do some execution; but I do notremember a single case where a man was injured by a piece of one ofthese shells. When they were hit and the ball exploded
column102: the wound wasterrible.  In these cases a solid ball would have hit as well.  Theiruse is barbarous
column103: because they produce increased suffering without anycorresponding advantage to those using them.The enemy could not resort to our method to protect their men
column104: becausewe had an inexhaustible supply of ammunition to draw upon and used itfreely.  Splinters from the timber would have made havoc among the menbehind.There were no mortars with the besiegers
column105: except what the navy had infront of the city; but wooden ones were made by taking logs of thetoughest wood that could be found
column106: boring them out for six or twelvepound shells and binding them with strong iron bands.  These answered ascochorns
column107: and shells were successfully thrown from them into thetrenches of the enemy.The labor of building the batteries and intrenching was largely done bythe pioneers
column108: assisted by negroes who came within our lines and who werepaid for their work; but details from the troops had often to be made.The work was pushed forward as rapidly as possible
column109: and when an advancedposition was secured and covered from the fire of the enemy thebatteries were advanced.  By the 30th of June there were two hundred andtwenty guns in position
column110: mostly light field-pieces
column111: besides a battery ofheavy guns belonging to
column112: manned and commanded by the navy.  We were nowas strong for defence against the garrison of Vicksburg as they wereagainst us; but I knew that Johnston was in our rear
column113: and was receivingconstant reinforcements from the east. He had at this time a largerforce than I had had at any time prior to the battle of Champion's Hill.As soon as the news of the arrival of the Union army behind Vicksburgreached the North
column114: floods of visitors began to pour in.  Some came togratify curiosity; some to see sons or brothers who had passed throughthe terrible ordeal; members of the Christian and Sanitary Associationscame to minister to the wants of the sick and the wounded.  Often thosecoming to see a son or brother would bring a dozen or two of poultry.They did not know how little the gift would be appreciated.  Many of thesoldiers had lived so much on chickens
column115: ducks and turkeys without breadduring the march
column116: that the sight of poultry
column117: if they could get bacon
column118: almost took away their appetite.  But the intention was good.Among the earliest arrivals was the Governor of Illinois
column119: with most ofthe State officers.  I naturally wanted to show them what there was ofmost interest.  In Sherman's front the ground was the most broken andmost wooded
column120: and more was to be seen without exposure.  I therefore tookthem to Sherman's headquarters and presented them.  Before starting outto look at the lines--possibly while Sherman's horse was being saddled--there were many questions asked about the late campaign
column121: about whichthe North had been so imperfectly informed.  There was a little knotaround Sherman and another around me
column122: and I heard Sherman repeating
column123: inthe most animated manner
column124: what he had said to me when we first lookeddown from Walnut Hills upon the land below on the 18th of May
column125: adding:'Grant is entitled to every bit of the credit for the campaign; Iopposed it. I wrote him a letter about it.'  But for this speech it isnot likely that Sherman's opposition would have ever been heard of.  Hisuntiring energy and great efficiency during the campaign entitle him toa full share of all the credit due for its success.  He could not havedone more if the plan had been his own. (*13)On the 26th of May I sent Blair's division up the Yazoo to drive out aforce of the enemy supposed to be between the Big Black and the Yazoo.The country was rich and full of supplies of both food and forage.Blair was instructed to take all of it.  The cattle were to be driven infor the use of our army
column126: and the food and forage to be consumed by ourtroops or destroyed by fire; all bridges were to be destroyed
column127: and theroads rendered as nearly impassable as possible.  Blair went forty-fivemiles and was gone almost a week.  His work was effectually done.  Irequested Porter at this time to send the marine brigade
column128: a floatingnondescript force which had been assigned to his command and whichproved very useful
column129: up to Haines' Bluff to hold it until reinforcementscould be sent.On the 26th I also received a letter from Banks
column130: asking me to reinforcehim with ten thousand men at Port Hudson.  Of course I could not complywith his request
column131: nor did I think he needed them.  He was in no dangerof an attack by the garrison in his front
column132: and there was no armyorganizing in his rear to raise the siege.On the 3d of June a brigade from Hurlbut's command arrived
column133: GeneralKimball commanding.  It was sent to Mechanicsburg
column134: some miles north-eastof Haines' Bluff and about midway between the Big Black and the Yazoo.A brigade of Blair's division and twelve hundred cavalry had already
column135: onBlair's return from the Yazoo
column136: been sent to the same place withinstructions to watch the crossings of the Big Black River
column137: to destroythe roads in his (Blair's) front
column138: and to gather or destroy all supplies.On the 7th of June our little force of colored and white troops acrossthe Mississippi
column139: at Milliken's Bend
column140: were attacked by about 3
column141: 000 menfrom Richard Taylor's trans-Mississippi command.  With the aid of thegunboats they were speedily repelled.  I sent Mower's brigade over withinstructions to drive the enemy beyond the Tensas Bayou; and we had nofurther trouble in that quarter during the siege.  This was the firstimportant engagement of the war in which colored troops were under fire.These men were very raw
column142: having all been enlisted since the beginning ofthe siege
column143: but they behaved well.On the 8th of June a full division arrived from Hurlbut's command
column144: underGeneral Sooy Smith.  It was sent immediately to Haines' Bluff
column145: andGeneral C. C. Washburn was assigned to the general command at thatpoint.On the 11th a strong division arrived from the Department of theMissouri under General Herron
column146: which was placed on our left. This cutoff the last possible chance of communication between Pemberton andJohnston
column147: as it enabled Lauman to close up on McClernand's left whileHerron intrenched from Lauman to the water's edge.  At this point thewater recedes a few hundred yards from the high land.  Through thisopening no doubt the Confederate commanders had been able to getmessengers under cover of night.On the 14th General Parke arrived with two divisions of Burnside'scorps
column148: and was immediately dispatched to Haines' Bluff.  These lattertroops--Herron's and Parke's--were the reinforcements already spoken ofsent by Halleck in anticipation of their being needed.  They arrivednone too soon.I now had about seventy-one thousand men.  More than half were disposedacross the peninsula
column149: between the Yazoo at Haines' Bluff and the BigBlack
column150: with the division of Osterhaus watching the crossings of thelatter river farther south and west from the crossing of the Jacksonroad to Baldwin's ferry and below.There were eight roads leading into Vicksburg
column151: along which and theirimmediate sides
column152: our work was specially pushed and batteries advanced;but no commanding point within range of the enemy was neglected.On the 17th I received a letter from General Sherman and one on the 18thfrom General McPherson
column153: saying that their respective commands hadcomplained to them of a fulsome
column154: congratulatory order published byGeneral McClernand to the 13th corps
column155: which did great injustice to theother troops engaged in the campaign.  This order had been sent Northand published
column156: and now papers containing it had reached our camps.  Theorder had not been heard of by me
column157: and certainly not by troops outsideof McClernand's command until brought in this way.  I at once wrote toMcClernand
column158: directing him to send me a copy of this order.  He did so
column159: and I at once relieved him from the command of the 13th army corps andordered him back to Springfield
column160: Illinois.  The publication of his orderin the press was in violation of War Department orders and also of mine.

column1: ISFP	 XXXVIII.JOHNSTON'S MOVEMENTS--FORTIFICATIONS AT HAINES' BLUFF--EXPLOSION OF THEMINE--EXPLOSION OF THE SECOND MINE--PREPARING FOR THE ASSAULT--THE FLAGOF TRUCE--MEETING WITH PEMBERTON--NEGOTIATIONS FOR SURRENDER--ACCEPTINGTHE TERMS--SURRENDER OF VICKSBURG.On the 22d of June positive information was received that Johnston hadcrossed the Big Black River for the purpose of attacking our rear
column2: toraise the siege and release Pemberton. The correspondence betweenJohnston and Pemberton shows that all expectation of holding Vicksburghad by this time passed from Johnston's mind.  I immediately orderedSherman to the command of all the forces from Haines' Bluff to the BigBlack River. This amounted now to quite half the troops about Vicksburg.Besides these
column3: Herron and A. J. Smith's divisions were ordered to holdthemselves in readiness to reinforce Sherman.  Haines' Bluff had beenstrongly fortified on the land side
column4: and on all commanding points fromthere to the Big Black at the railroad crossing batteries had beenconstructed.  The work of connecting by rifle-pits where this was notalready done
column5: was an easy task for the troops that were to defend them.We were now looking west
column6: besieging Pemberton
column7: while we were alsolooking east to defend ourselves against an expected siege by Johnston.But as against the garrison of Vicksburg we were as substantiallyprotected as they were against us.  Where we were looking east and northwe were strongly fortified
column8: and on the defensive.  Johnston evidentlytook in the situation and wisely
column9: I think
column10: abstained from making anassault on us because it would simply have inflicted loss on both sideswithout accomplishing any result.  We were strong enough to have takenthe offensive against him; but I did not feel disposed to take any riskof losing our hold upon Pemberton's army
column11: while I would have rejoiced atthe opportunity of defending ourselves against an attack by Johnston.From the 23d of May the work of fortifying and pushing forward ourposition nearer to the enemy had been steadily progressing.  At threepoints on the Jackson road
column12: in front of Leggett's brigade
column13: a sap was runup to the enemy's parapet
column14: and by the 25th of June we had it underminedand the mine charged. The enemy had countermined
column15: but did not succeed inreaching our mine.  At this particular point the hill on which the rebelwork stands rises abruptly.  Our sap ran close up to the outside of theenemy's parapet.  In fact this parapet was also our protection.  Thesoldiers of the two sides occasionally conversed pleasantly across thisbarrier; sometimes they exchanged the hard bread of the Union soldiersfor the tobacco of the Confederates; at other times the enemy threw overhand-grenades
column16: and often our men
column17: catching them in their hands
column18: returnedthem.Our mine had been started some distance back down the hill; consequentlywhen it had extended as far as the parapet it was many feet below it.This caused the failure of the enemy in his search to find and destroyit.  On the 25th of June at three o'clock
column19: all being ready
column20: the mine wasexploded.  A heavy artillery fire all along the line had been ordered toopen with the explosion.  The effect was to blow the top of the hill offand make a crater where it stood.  The breach was not sufficient toenable us to pass a column of attack through.  In fact
column21: the enemy havingfailed to reach our mine had thrown up a line farther back
column22: where mostof the men guarding that point were placed.  There were a few men
column23: however
column24: left at the advance line
column25: and others working in thecountermine
column26: which was still being pushed to find ours.  All that werethere were thrown into the air
column27: some of them coming down on our side
column28: still alive.  I remember one colored man
column29: who had been under ground atwork when the explosion took place
column30: who was thrown to our side.  He wasnot much hurt
column31: but terribly frightened.  Some one asked him how high hehad gone up.  'Dun no
column32: massa
column33: but t'ink 'bout t'ree mile
column34: ' was hisreply.  General Logan commanded at this point and took this colored manto his quarters
column35: where he did service to the end of the siege.As soon as the explosion took place the crater was seized by tworegiments of our troops who were near by
column36: under cover
column37: where they hadbeen placed for the express purpose.  The enemy made a desperate effortto expel them
column38: but failed
column39: and soon retired behind the new line.  Fromhere
column40: however
column41: they threw hand-grenades
column42: which did some execution.  Thecompliment was returned by our men
column43: but not with so much effect.  Theenemy could lay their grenades on the parapet
column44: which alone divided thecontestants
column45: and roll them down upon us; while from our side they had tobe thrown over the parapet
column46: which was at considerable elevation.  Duringthe night we made efforts to secure our position in the crater againstthe missiles of the enemy
column47: so as to run trenches along the outer base oftheir parapet
column48: right and left; but the enemy continued throwing theirgrenades
column49: and brought boxes of field ammunition (shells)
column50: the fuses ofwhich they would light with portfires
column51: and throw them by hand into ourranks.  We found it impossible to continue this work.  Another mine wasconsequently started which was exploded on the 1st of July
column52: destroyingan entire rebel redan
column53: killing and wounding a considerable number of itsoccupants and leaving an immense chasm where it stood.  No attempt tocharge was made this time
column54: the experience of the 25th admonishing us.Our loss in the first affair was about thirty killed and wounded.  Theenemy must have lost more in the two explosions than we did in thefirst.  We lost none in the second.From this time forward the work of mining and pushing our positionnearer to the enemy was prosecuted with vigor
column55: and I determined toexplode no more mines until we were ready to explode a number atdifferent points and assault immediately after.  We were up now at threedifferent points
column56: one in front of each corps
column57: to where only the parapetof the enemy divided us.At this time an intercepted dispatch from Johnston to Pemberton informedme that Johnston intended to make a determined attack upon us in orderto relieve the garrison at Vicksburg.  I knew the garrison would make noformidable effort to relieve itself.  The picket lines were so close toeach other--where there was space enough between the lines to postpickets--that the men could converse.  On the 21st of June I wasinformed
column58: through this means
column59: that Pemberton was preparing to escape
column60: bycrossing to the Louisiana side under cover of night; that he hademployed workmen in making boats for that purpose; that the men had beencanvassed to ascertain if they would make an assault on the 'Yankees' tocut their way out; that they had refused
column61: and almost mutinied
column62: becausetheir commander would not surrender and relieve their sufferings
column63: andhad only been pacified by the assurance that boats enough would befinished in a week to carry them all over.  The rebel pickets also saidthat houses in the city had been pulled down to get material to buildthese boats with.  Afterwards this story was verified:  on entering thecity we found a large number of very rudely constructed boats.All necessary steps were at once taken to render such an attemptabortive.  Our pickets were doubled; Admiral Porter was notified
column64: sothat the river might be more closely watched; material was collected onthe west bank of the river to be set on fire and light up the river ifthe attempt was made; and batteries were established along the leveecrossing the peninsula on the Louisiana side.  Had the attempt been madethe garrison of Vicksburg would have been drowned
column65: or made prisoners onthe Louisiana side.  General Richard Taylor was expected on the westbank to co-operate in this movement
column66: I believe
column67: but he did not come
column68: norcould he have done so with a force sufficient to be of service.  TheMississippi was now in our possession from its source to its mouth
column69: except in the immediate front of Vicksburg and of Port Hudson.  We hadnearly exhausted the country
column70: along a line drawn from Lake Providence toopposite Bruinsburg.  The roads west were not of a character to drawsupplies over for any considerable force.By the 1st of July our approaches had reached the enemy's ditch at anumber of places.  At ten points we could move under cover to withinfrom five to one hundred yards of the enemy.  Orders were given to makeall preparations for assault on the 6th of July.  The debouches wereordered widened to afford easy egress
column71: while the approaches were also tobe widened to admit the troops to pass through four abreast.  Plank
column72: andbags filled with cotton packed in tightly
column73: were ordered prepared
column74: toenable the troops to cross the ditches.On the night of the 1st of July Johnston was between Brownsville and theBig Black
column75: and wrote Pemberton from there that about the 7th of themonth an attempt would be made to create a diversion to enable him tocut his way out.  Pemberton was a prisoner before this message reachedhim.On July 1st Pemberton
column76: seeing no hope of outside relief
column77: addressed thefollowing letter to each of his four division commanders:'Unless the siege of Vicksburg is raised
column78: or supplies are thrown in
column79: itwill become necessary very shortly to evacuate the place.  I see noprospect of the former
column80: and there are many great
column81: if not insuperableobstacles in the way of the latter. You are
column82: therefore
column83: requested toinform me with as little delay as possible
column84: as to the condition of yourtroops and their ability to make the marches and undergo the fatiguesnecessary to accomplish a successful evacuation.'Two of his generals suggested surrender
column85: and the other two practicallydid the same.  They expressed the opinion that an attempt to evacuatewould fail.  Pemberton had previously got a message to Johnstonsuggesting that he should try to negotiate with me for a release of thegarrison with their arms.  Johnston replied that it would be aconfession of weakness for him to do so; but he authorized Pemberton touse his name in making such an arrangement.On the 3d about ten o'clock A.M. white flags appeared on a portion ofthe rebel works.  Hostilities along that part of the line ceased atonce.  Soon two persons were seen coming towards our lines bearing awhite flag.  They proved to be General Bowen
column86: a division commander
column87: andColonel Montgomery
column88: aide-de-camp to Pemberton
column89: bearing the followingletter to me:'I have the honor to propose an armistice for--hours
column90: with the view toarranging terms for the capitulation of Vicksburg.  To this end
column91: ifagreeable to you
column92: I will appoint three commissioners
column93: to meet a likenumber to be named by yourself at such place and hour to-day as you mayfind convenient.  I make this proposition to save the further effusionof blood
column94: which must otherwise be shed to a frightful extent
column95: feelingmyself fully able to maintain my position for a yet indefinite period.This communication will be handed you under a flag of truce
column96: byMajor-General John S. Bowen.'It was a glorious sight to officers and soldiers on the line where thesewhite flags were visible
column97: and the news soon spread to all parts of thecommand.  The troops felt that their long and weary marches
column98: hardfighting
column99: ceaseless watching by night and day
column100: in a hot climate
column101: exposure to all sorts of weather
column102: to diseases and
column103: worst of all
column104: to thegibes of many Northern papers that came to them saying all theirsuffering was in vain
column105: that Vicksburg would never be taken
column106: were at lastat an end and the Union sure to be saved.Bowen was received by General A. J. Smith
column107: and asked to see me.  I hadbeen a neighbor of Bowen's in Missouri
column108: and knew him well and favorablybefore the war; but his request was refused.  He then suggested that Ishould meet Pemberton.  To this I sent a verbal message saying that
column109: ifPemberton desired it
column110: I would meet him in front of McPherson's corps atthree o'clock that afternoon.  I also sent the following written replyto Pemberton's letter:'Your note of this date is just received
column111: proposing an armistice forseveral hours
column112: for the purpose of arranging terms of capitulationthrough commissioners
column113: to be appointed
column114: etc.  The useless effusion ofblood you propose stopping by this course can be ended at any time youmay choose
column115: by the unconditional surrender of the city and garrison.Men who have shown so much endurance and courage as those now inVicksburg
column116: will always challenge the respect of an adversary
column117: and I canassure you will be treated with all the respect due to prisoners of war.I do not favor the proposition of appointing commissioners to arrangethe terms of capitulation
column118: because I have no terms other than thoseindicated above.'At three o'clock Pemberton appeared at the point suggested in my verbalmessage
column119: accompanied by the same officers who had borne his letter ofthe morning.  Generals Ord
column120: McPherson
column121: Logan and A. J. Smith
column122: andseveral officers of my staff
column123: accompanied me. Our place of meeting wason a hillside within a few hundred feet of the rebel lines.  Near bystood a stunted oak-tree
column124: which was made historical by the event.  Itwas but a short time before the last vestige of its body
column125: root and limbhad disappeared
column126: the fragments taken as trophies.  Since then the sametree has furnished as many cords of wood
column127: in the shape of trophies
column128: as'The True Cross.'Pemberton and I had served in the same division during part of theMexican War.  I knew him very well therefore
column129: and greeted him as an oldacquaintance.  He soon asked what terms I proposed to give his army ifit surrendered.  My answer was the same as proposed in my reply to hisletter.  Pemberton then said
column130: rather snappishly
column131: 'The conference mightas well end
column132: ' and turned abruptly as if to leave.  I said
column133: 'Very well.'General Bowen
column134: I saw
column135: was very anxious that the surrender should beconsummated. His manner and remarks while Pemberton and I were talking
column136: showed this.  He now proposed that he and one of our generals shouldhave a conference.  I had no objection to this
column137: as nothing could be madebinding upon me that they might propose. Smith and Bowen accordingly hada conference
column138: during which Pemberton and I
column139: moving a short distance awaytowards the enemy's lines were in conversation.  After a while Bowensuggested that the Confederate army should be allowed to march out withthe honors of war
column140: carrying their small arms and field artillery.  Thiswas promptly and unceremoniously rejected.  The interview here ended
column141: Iagreeing
column142: however
column143: to send a letter giving final terms by ten o'clockthat night.Word was sent to Admiral Porter soon after the correspondence withPemberton commenced
column144: so that hostilities might be stopped on the part ofboth army and navy.  It was agreed on my paging with Pemberton that theyshould not be renewed until our correspondence ceased.When I returned to my headquarters I sent for all the corps and divisioncommanders with the army immediately confronting Vicksburg.  Half thearmy was from eight to twelve miles off
column145: waiting for Johnston.  Iinformed them of the contents of Pemberton's letters
column146: of my reply andthe substance of the interview
column147: and that I was ready to hear anysuggestion; but would hold the power of deciding entirely in my ownhands.  This was the nearest approach to a 'council of war' I ever held.Against the general
column148: and almost unanimous judgment of the council I sentthe following letter:'In conformity with agreement of this afternoon
column149: I will submit thefollowing proposition for the surrender of the City of Vicksburg
column150: publicstores
column151: etc.  On your accepting the terms proposed
column152: I will march in onedivision as a guard
column153: and take possession at eight A.M. to-morrow.  Assoon as rolls can be made out
column154: and paroles be signed by officers andmen
column155: you will be allowed to march out of our lines
column156: the officers takingwith them their side-arms and clothing
column157: and the field
column158: staff and cavalryofficers one horse each.  The rank and file will be allowed all theirclothing
column159: but no other property.  If these conditions are accepted
column160: anyamount of rations you may deem necessary can be taken from the storesyou now have
column161: and also the necessary cooking utensils for preparingthem.  Thirty wagons also
column162: counting two two-horse or mule teams as one
column163: will be allowed to transport such articles as cannot be carried along.The same conditions will be allowed to all sick and wounded officers andsoldiers as fast as they become able to travel.  The paroles for theselatter must be signed
column164: however
column165: whilst officers present are authorizedto sign the roll of prisoners.'By the terms of the cartel then in force
column166: prisoners captured by eitherarmy were required to be forwarded as soon as possible to either Aiken'slanding below Dutch Gap on the James River
column167: or to Vicksburg
column168: there to beexchanged
column169: or paroled until they could be exchanged.  There was aConfederate commissioner at Vicksburg
column170: authorized to make the exchange.I did not propose to take him a prisoner
column171: but to leave him free toperform the functions of his office.  Had I insisted upon anunconditional surrender there would have been over thirty thousand mento transport to Cairo
column172: very much to the inconvenience of the army on theMississippi.  Thence the prisoners would have had to be transported byrail to Washington or Baltimore; thence again by steamer to Aiken's--allat very great expense.  At Aiken's they would have had to be paroled
column173: because the Confederates did not have Union prisoners to give inexchange.  Then again Pemberton's army was largely composed of men whosehomes were in the South-west; I knew many of them were tired of the warand would get home just as soon as they could.  A large number of themhad voluntarily come into our lines during the siege
column174: and requested tobe sent north where they could get employment until the war was over andthey could go to their homes.Late at night I received the following reply to my last letter:'I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication ofthis date
column175: proposing terms of capitulation for this garrison and post.In the main your terms are accepted; but
column176: in justice both to the honorand spirit of my troops manifested in the defence of Vicksburg
column177: I haveto submit the following amendments
column178: which
column179: if acceded to by you
column180: willperfect the agreement between us.  At ten o'clock A.M. to-morrow
column181: Ipropose to evacuate the works in and around Vicksburg
column182: and to surrenderthe city and garrison under my command
column183: by marching out with my colorsand arms
column184: stacking them in front of my present lines.  After which youwill take possession.  Officers to retain their side-arms and personalproperty
column185: and the rights and property of citizens to be respected.'This was received after midnight.  My reply was as follows:'I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of 3dJuly.  The amendment proposed by you cannot be acceded to in full.  Itwill be necessary to furnish every officer and man with a parole signedby himself
column186: which
column187: with the completion of the roll of prisoners
column188: willnecessarily take some time.  Again
column189: I can make no stipulations withregard to the treatment of citizens and their private property.  While Ido not propose to cause them any undue annoyance or loss
column190: I cannotconsent to leave myself under any restraint by stipulations. Theproperty which officers will be allowed to take with them will be asstated in my proposition of last evening; that is
column191: officers will beallowed their private baggage and side-arms
column192: and mounted officers onehorse each.  If you mean by your proposition for each brigade to marchto the front of the lines now occupied by it
column193: and stack arms at teno'clock A.M.
column194: and then return to the inside and there remain asprisoners until properly paroled
column195: I will make no objection to it.Should no notification be received of your acceptance of my terms bynine o'clock A.M. I shall regard them as having been rejected
column196: and shallact accordingly.  Should these terms be accepted
column197: white flags should bedisplayed along your lines to prevent such of my troops as may not havebeen notified
column198: from firing upon your men.'Pemberton promptly accepted these terms.During the siege there had been a good deal of friendly sparring betweenthe soldiers of the two armies
column199: on picket and where the lines were closetogether.  All rebels were known as 'Johnnies
column200: ' all Union troops as'Yanks.'  Often 'Johnny' would call:  'Well
column201: Yank
column202: when are you cominginto town?'  The reply was sometimes: 'We propose to celebrate the 4thof July there.'  Sometimes it would be:  'We always treat our prisonerswith kindness and do not want to hurt them;' or
column203: 'We are holding you asprisoners of war while you are feeding yourselves.'  The garrison
column204: fromthe commanding general down
column205: undoubtedly expected an assault on thefourth.  They knew from the temper of their men it would be successfulwhen made; and that would be a greater humiliation than to surrender.Besides it would be attended with severe loss to them.The Vicksburg paper
column206: which we received regularly through the courtesy ofthe rebel pickets
column207: said prior to the fourth
column208: in speaking of the 'Yankee'boast that they would take dinner in Vicksburg that day
column209: that the bestreceipt for cooking a rabbit was 'First ketch your rabbit.'  The paperat this time and for some time previous was printed on the plain side ofwall paper.  The last number was issued on the fourth and announced thatwe had 'caught our rabbit.'I have no doubt that Pemberton commenced his correspondence on the thirdwith a two-fold purpose:  first
column210: to avoid an assault
column211: which he knewwould be successful
column212: and second
column213: to prevent the capture taking place onthe great national holiday
column214: the anniversary of the Declaration ofAmerican Independence. Holding out for better terms as he did hedefeated his aim in the latter particular.At the appointed hour the garrison of Vicksburg marched out of theirworks and formed line in front
column215: stacked arms and marched back in goodorder.  Our whole army present witnessed this scene without cheering.Logan's division
column216: which had approached nearest the rebel works
column217: was thefirst to march in; and the flag of one of the regiments of his divisionwas soon floating over the court-house.  Our soldiers were no soonerinside the lines than the two armies began to fraternize.  Our men hadhad full rations from the time the siege commenced
column218: to the close.  Theenemy had been suffering
column219: particularly towards the last.  I myself sawour men taking bread from their haversacks and giving it to the enemythey had so recently been engaged in starving out.  It was accepted withavidity and with thanks.Pemberton says in his report:'If it should be asked why the 4th of July was selected as the day forsurrender
column220: the answer is obvious.  I believed that upon that day Ishould obtain better terms.  Well aware of the vanity of our foe
column221: I knewthey would attach vast importance to the entrance on the 4th of Julyinto the stronghold of the great river
column222: and that
column223: to gratify theirnational vanity
column224: they would yield then what could not be extorted fromthem at any other time.'This does not support my view of his reasons for selecting the day hedid for surrendering.  But it must be recollected that his first letterasking terms was received about 10 o'clock A.M.
column225: July 3d.  It then couldhardly be expected that it would take twenty-four hours to effect asurrender.  He knew that Johnston was in our rear for the purpose ofraising the siege
column226: and he naturally would want to hold out as long as hecould.  He knew his men would not resist an assault
column227: and one wasexpected on the fourth.  In our interview he told me he had rationsenough to hold out for some time--my recollection is two weeks.  It wasthis statement that induced me to insert in the terms that he was todraw rations for his men from his own supplies.On the 4th of July General Holmes
column228: with an army of eight or ninethousand men belonging to the trans-Mississippi department
column229: made anattack upon Helena
column230: Arkansas.  He was totally defeated by GeneralPrentiss
column231: who was holding Helena with less than forty-two hundredsoldiers.  Holmes reported his loss at 1
column233: of which 173 were killed;but as Prentiss buried 400
column234: Holmes evidently understated his losses.The Union loss was 57 killed
column235: 127 wounded
column236: and between 30 and 40missing.  This was the last effort on the part of the Confederacy toraise the siege of Vicksburg.On the third
column237: as soon as negotiations were commenced
column238: I notified Shermanand directed him to be ready to take the offensive against Johnston
column239: drive him out of the State and destroy his army if he could.  Steele andOrd were directed at the same time to be in readiness to join Sherman assoon as the surrender took place.  Of this Sherman was notified.I rode into Vicksburg with the troops
column240: and went to the river to exchangecongratulations with the navy upon our joint victory. At that time Ifound that many of the citizens had been living under ground.  Theridges upon which Vicksburg is built
column241: and those back to the Big Black
column242: are composed of a deep yellow clay of great tenacity.  Where roads andstreets are cut through
column243: perpendicular banks are left and stand as wellas if composed of stone.  The magazines of the enemy were made byrunning passage-ways into this clay at places where there were deepcuts.  Many citizens secured places of safety for their families bycarving out rooms in these embankments.  A door-way in these cases wouldbe cut in a high bank
column244: starting from the level of the road or street
column245: and after running in a few feet a room of the size required was carvedout of the clay
column246: the dirt being removed by the door-way.  In someinstances I saw where two rooms were cut out
column247: for a single family
column248: witha door-way in the clay wall separating them.  Some of these werecarpeted and furnished with considerable elaboration.  In these theoccupants were fully secure from the shells of the navy
column249: which weredropped into the city night and dav without intermission.I returned to my old headquarters outside in the afternoon
column250: and did notmove into the town until the sixth.  On the afternoon of the fourth Isent Captain Wm. M. Dunn of my staff to Cairo
column251: the nearest point wherethe telegraph could be reached
column252: with a dispatch to the general-in-chief.It was as follows:'The enemy surrendered this morning.  The only terms allowed is theirparole as prisoners of war.  This I regard as a great advantage to us atthis moment.  It saves
column253: probably
column254: several days in the capture
column255: andleaves troops and transports ready for immediate service.  Sherman
column256: witha large force
column257: moves immediately on Johnston
column258: to drive him from theState.  I will send troops to the relief of Banks
column259: and return the 9tharmy corps to Burnside.'This news
column260: with the victory at Gettysburg won the same day
column261: lifted agreat load of anxiety from the minds of the President
column262: his Cabinet andthe loyal people all over the North.  The fate of the Confederacy wassealed when Vicksburg fell.  Much hard fighting was to be doneafterwards and many precious lives were to be sacrificed; but the MORALEwas with the supporters of the Union ever after.I at the same time wrote to General Banks informing him of the fall andsending him a copy of the terms; also saying I would send him all thetroops he wanted to insure the capture of the only foothold the enemynow had on the Mississippi River. General Banks had a number of copiesof this letter printed
column263: or at least a synopsis of it
column264: and very soon acopy fell into the hands of General Gardner
column265: who was then in command ofPort Hudson.  Gardner at once sent a letter to the commander of theNational forces saying that he had been informed of the surrender ofVicksburg and telling how the information reached him.  He added that ifthis was true
column266: it was useless for him to hold out longer.  General Banksgave him assurances that Vicksburg had been surrendered
column267: and GeneralGardner surrendered unconditionally on the 9th of July.  Port Hudsonwith nearly 6
column268: 000 prisoners
column269: 51 guns
column271: 000 small-arms and other storesfell into the hands of the Union forces:  from that day to the close ofthe rebellion the Mississippi River
column272: from its source to its mouth
column273: remained in the control of the National troops.Pemberton and his army were kept in Vicksburg until the whole could beparoled.  The paroles were in duplicate
column274: by organization (one copy foreach
column275: Federals and Confederates)
column276: and signed by the commanding officersof the companies or regiments.  Duplicates were also made for eachsoldier and signed by each individually
column277: one to be retained by thesoldier signing and one to be retained by us.  Several hundred refusedto sign their paroles
column278: preferring to be sent to the North as prisonersto being sent back to fight again.  Others again kept out of the way
column279: hoping to escape either alternative.Pemberton appealed to me in person to compel these men to sign theirparoles
column280: but I declined.  It also leaked out that many of the men whohad signed their paroles
column281: intended to desert and go to their homes assoon as they got out of our lines.  Pemberton hearing this
column282: againappealed to me to assist him.  He wanted arms for a battalion
column283: to act asguards in keeping his men together while being marched to a camp ofinstruction
column284: where he expected to keep them until exchanged.  Thisrequest was also declined.  It was precisely what I expected and hopedthat they would do.  I told him
column286: that I would see that theymarched beyond our lines in good order.  By the eleventh
column287: just one weekafter the surrender
column288: the paroles were completed and the Confederategarrison marched out.  Many deserted
column289: and fewer of them were everreturned to the ranks to fight again than would have been the case hadthe surrender been unconditional and the prisoners sent to the JamesRiver to be paroled.As soon as our troops took possession of the city guards wereestablished along the whole line of parapet
column290: from the river above to theriver below.  The prisoners were allowed to occupy their old campsbehind the intrenchments.  No restraint was put upon them
column291: except bytheir own commanders.  They were rationed about as our own men
column292: and fromour supplies.  The men of the two armies fraternized as if they had beenfighting for the same cause.  When they passed out of the works they hadso long and so gallantly defended
column293: between lines of their lateantagonists
column294: not a cheer went up
column295: not a remark was made that would givepain.  Really
column296: I believe there was a feeling of sadness just then in thebreasts of most of the Union soldiers at seeing the dejection of theirlate antagonists.The day before the departure the following order was issued:'Paroled prisoners will be sent out of here to-morrow.  They will beauthorized to cross at the railroad bridge
column297: and move from there toEdward's Ferry
column298: (*14) and on by way of Raymond. Instruct the commands tobe orderly and quiet as these prisoners pass
column299: to make no offensiveremarks
column300: and not to harbor any who fall out of ranks after they havepassed.'

column1: ISFP	 XXXIX.RETROSPECT OF THE CAMPAIGN--SHERMAN'S MOVEMENTS--PROPOSED MOVEMENT UPONMOBILE--A PAINFUL ACCIDENT--ORDERED TO REPORT AT CAIRO.The capture of Vicksburg
column2: with its garrison
column3: ordnance and ordnancestores
column4: and the successful battles fought in reaching them
column5: gave newspirit to the loyal people of the North.  New hopes for the finalsuccess of the cause of the Union were inspired.  The victory gained atGettysburg
column6: upon the same day
column7: added to their hopes.  Now theMississippi River was entirely in the possession of the National troops;for the fall of Vicksburg gave us Port Hudson at once.  The army ofnorthern Virginia was driven out of Pennsylvania and forced back toabout the same ground it occupied in 1861.  The Army of the Tennesseeunited with the Army of the Gulf
column8: dividing the Confederate Statescompletely.The first dispatch I received from the government after the fall ofVicksburg was in these words:'I fear your paroling the prisoners at Vicksburg
column9: without actualdelivery to a proper agent as required by the seventh article of thecartel
column10: may be construed into an absolute release
column11: and that the men willimmediately be placed in the ranks of the enemy. Such has been the caseelsewhere.  If these prisoners have not been allowed to depart
column12: you willdetain them until further orders.'Halleck did not know that they had already been delivered into the handsof Major Watts
column13: Confederate commissioner for the exchange of prisoners.At Vicksburg 31
column14: 600 prisoners were surrendered
column15: together with 172 cannonabout 60
column16: 000 muskets and a large amount of ammunition.  The small-armsof the enemy were far superior to the bulk of ours.  Up to this time ourtroops at the West had been limited to the old United States flint-lockmuskets changed into percussion
column17: or the Belgian musket imported early inthe war--almost as dangerous to the person firing it as to the one aimedat--and a few new and improved arms.  These were of many differentcalibers
column18: a fact that caused much trouble in distributing ammunitionduring an engagement.  The enemy had generally new arms which had runthe blockade and were of uniform caliber.  After the surrender Iauthorized all colonels whose regiments were armed with inferiormuskets
column19: to place them in the stack of captured arms and replace themwith the latter.  A large number of arms turned in to the OrdnanceDepartment as captured
column20: were thus arms that had really been used by theUnion army in the capture of Vicksburg.In this narrative I have not made the mention I should like of officers
column21: dead and alive
column22: whose services entitle them to special mention.  Neitherhave I made that mention of the navy which its services deserve.Suffice it to say
column23: the close of the siege of Vicksburg found us with anarmy unsurpassed
column24: in proportion to its numbers
column25: taken as a whole ofofficers and men.  A military education was acquired which no otherschool could have given. Men who thought a company was quite enough forthem to command properly at the beginning
column26: would have made goodregimental or brigade commanders; most of the brigade commanders wereequal to the command of a division
column27: and one
column28: Ransom
column29: would have beenequal to the command of a corps at least. Logan and Crocker ended thecampaign fitted to command independent armies.General F. P. Blair joined me at Milliken's Bend a full-fledged general
column30: without having served in a lower grade.  He commanded a division in thecampaign.  I had known Blair in Missouri
column31: where I had voted against himin 1858 when he ran for Congress.  I knew him as a frank
column32: positive andgenerous man
column33: true to his friends even to a fault
column34: but always a leader.I dreaded his coming; I knew from experience that it was more difficultto command two generals desiring to be leaders than it was to commandone army officered intelligently and with subordination.  It affords methe greatest pleasure to record now my agreeable disappointment inrespect to his character.  There was no man braver than he
column35: nor wasthere any who obeyed all orders of his superior in rank with moreunquestioning alacrity.  He was one man as a soldier
column36: another as apolitician.The navy under Porter was all it could be
column37: during the entire campaign.Without its assistance the campaign could not have been successfullymade with twice the number of men engaged.  It could not have been madeat all
column38: in the way it was
column39: with any number of men without suchassistance.  The most perfect harmony reigned between the two arms ofthe service.  There never was a request made
column40: that I am aware of
column41: eitherof the flag-officer or any of his subordinates
column42: that was not promptlycomplied with.The campaign of Vicksburg was suggested and developed by circumstances.The elections of 1862 had gone against the prosecution of the war.Voluntary enlistments had nearly ceased and the draft had been resortedto; this was resisted
column43: and a defeat or backward movement would have madeits execution impossible.  A forward movement to a decisive victory wasnecessary.  Accordingly I resolved to get below Vicksburg
column44: unite withBanks against Port Hudson
column45: make New Orleans a base and
column46: with that baseand Grand Gulf as a starting point
column47: move our combined forces againstVicksburg.  Upon reaching Grand Gulf
column48: after running its batteries andfighting a battle
column49: I received a letter from Banks informing me that hecould not be at Port Hudson under ten days
column50: and then with only fifteenthousand men.  The time was worth more than the reinforcements; Itherefore determined to push into the interior of the enemy's country.With a large river behind us
column51: held above and below by the enemy
column52: rapidmovements were essential to success.  Jackson was captured the day aftera new commander had arrived
column53: and only a few days before largereinforcements were expected.  A rapid movement west was made; thegarrison of Vicksburg was met in two engagements and badly defeated
column54: anddriven back into its stronghold and there successfully besieged.  Itlooks now as though Providence had directed the course of the campaignwhile the Army of the Tennessee executed the decree.Upon the surrender of the garrison of Vicksburg there were three thingsthat required immediate attention.  The first was to send a force todrive the enemy from our rear
column55: and out of the State.  The second was tosend reinforcements to Banks near Port Hudson
column56: if necessary
column57: to completethe triumph of opening the Mississippi from its source to its mouth tothe free navigation of vessels bearing the Stars and Stripes.  The thirdwas to inform the authorities at Washington and the North of the goodnews
column58: to relieve their long suspense and strengthen their confidence inthe ultimate success of the cause they had so much at heart.Soon after negotiations were opened with General Pemberton for thesurrender of the city
column59: I notified Sherman
column60: whose troops extended fromHaines' Bluff on the left to the crossing of the Vicksburg and Jacksonroad over the Big Black on the right
column61: and directed him to hold hiscommand in readiness to advance and drive the enemy from the State assoon as Vicksburg surrendered.  Steele and Ord were directed to be inreadiness to join Sherman in his move against General Johnston
column62: andSherman was advised of this also.  Sherman moved promptly
column63: crossing theBig Black at three different points with as many columns
column64: allconcentrating at Bolton
column65: twenty miles west of Jackson.Johnston heard of the surrender of Vicksburg almost as soon as itoccurred
column66: and immediately fell back on Jackson.  On the 8th of JulySherman was within ten miles of Jackson and on the 11th was close up tothe defences of the city and shelling the town.  The siege was kept upuntil the morning of the 17th
column67: when it was found that the enemy hadevacuated during the night.  The weather was very hot
column68: the roads dustyand the water bad. Johnston destroyed the roads as he passed and had somuch the start that pursuit was useless; but Sherman sent one division
column69: Steele's
column70: to Brandon
column71: fourteen miles east of Jackson.The National loss in the second capture of Jackson was less than onethousand men
column72: killed
column73: wounded and missing.  The Confederate loss wasprobably less
column74: except in captured.  More than this number fell into ourhands as prisoners.Medicines and food were left for the Confederate wounded and sick whohad to be left behind.  A large amount of rations was issued to thefamilies that remained in Jackson.  Medicine and food were also sent toRaymond for the destitute families as well as the sick and wounded
column75: as Ithought it only fair that we should return to these people some of thearticles we had taken while marching through the country.  I wrote toSherman: 'Impress upon the men the importance of going through the Statein an orderly manner
column76: abstaining from taking anything not absolutelynecessary for their subsistence while travelling. They should try tocreate as favorable an impression as possible upon the people.'Provisions and forage
column77: when called for by them
column78: were issued to all thepeople
column79: from Bruinsburg to Jackson and back to Vicksburg
column80: whoseresources had been taken for the supply of our army.  Very largequantities of groceries and provisions were so issued.Sherman was ordered back to Vicksburg
column81: and his troops took much the sameposition they had occupied before--from the Big Black to Haines' Bluff.Having cleaned up about Vicksburg and captured or routed all regularConfederate forces for more than a hundred miles in all directions
column82: Ifelt that the troops that had done so much should be allowed to do morebefore the enemy could recover from the blow he had received
column83: and whileimportant points might be captured without bloodshed.  I suggested tothe General-in-chief the idea of a campaign against Mobile
column84: startingfrom Lake Pontchartrain.  Halleck preferred another course.  Thepossession of the trans-Mississippi by the Union forces seemed topossess more importance in his mind than almost any campaign east of theMississippi.  I am well aware that the President was very anxious tohave a foothold in Texas
column85: to stop the clamor of some of the foreigngovernments which seemed to be seeking a pretext to interfere in thewar
column86: at least so far as to recognize belligerent rights to theConfederate States.  This
column87: however
column88: could have been easily done withoutwasting troops in western Louisiana and eastern Texas
column89: by sending agarrison at once to Brownsville on the Rio Grande.Halleck disapproved of my proposition to go against Mobile
column90: so that Iwas obliged to settle down and see myself put again on the defensive asI had been a year before in west Tennessee.  It would have been an easything to capture Mobile at the time I proposed to go there.  Having thatas a base of operations
column91: troops could have been thrown into the interiorto operate against General Bragg's army.  This would necessarily havecompelled Bragg to detach in order to meet this fire in his rear.  If hehad not done this the troops from Mobile could have inflictedinestimable damage upon much of the country from which his army andLee's were yet receiving their supplies.  I was so much impressed withthis idea that I renewed my request later in July and again about the1st of August
column92: and proposed sending all the troops necessary
column93: askingonly the assistance of the navy to protect the debarkation of troops ator near Mobile.  I also asked for a leave of absence to visit NewOrleans
column94: particularly if my suggestion to move against Mobile should beapproved. Both requests were refused.  So far as my experience withGeneral Halleck went it was very much easier for him to refuse a favorthan to grant one.  But I did not regard this as a favor. It was simplyin line of duty
column95: though out of my department.The General-in-chief having decided against me
column96: the depletion of anarmy
column97: which had won a succession of great victories
column98: commenced
column99: as hadbeen the case the year before after the fall of Corinth when the armywas sent where it would do the least good.  By orders
column100: I sent to Banks aforce of 4
column101: 000 men; returned the 9th corps to Kentucky and
column102: whentransportation had been collected
column103: started a division of 5
column104: 000 men toSchofield in Missouri where Price was raiding the State.  I alsodetached a brigade under Ransom to Natchez
column105: to garrison that placepermanently.  This latter move was quite fortunate as to the time whenRansom arrived there.  The enemy happened to have a large number
column106: about5
column107: 000 head
column108: of beef cattle there on the way from Texas to feed theEastern armies
column109: and also a large amount of munitions of war which hadprobably come through Texas from the Rio Grande and which were on theway to Lee's and other armies in the East.The troops that were left with me around Vicksburg were very busily andunpleasantly employed in making expeditions against guerilla bands andsmall detachments of cavalry which infested the interior
column110: and indestroying mills
column111: bridges and rolling stock on the railroads.  Theguerillas and cavalry were not there to fight but to annoy
column112: andtherefore disappeared on the first approach of our troops.The country back of Vicksburg was filled with deserters from Pemberton'sarmy and
column113: it was reported
column114: many from Johnston's also.  The mendetermined not to fight again while the war lasted.  Those who livedbeyond the reach of the Confederate army wanted to get to their homes.Those who did not
column115: wanted to get North where they could work for theirsupport till the war was over.  Besides all this there was quite a peacefeeling
column116: for the time being
column117: among the citizens of that part ofMississippi
column118: but this feeling soon subsided.  It is not probable thatPemberton got off with over 4
column119: 000 of his army to the camp where heproposed taking them
column120: and these were in a demoralized condition.On the 7th of August I further depleted my army by sending the 13thcorps
column121: General Ord commanding
column122: to Banks.  Besides this I received ordersto co-operate with the latter general in movements west of theMississippi.  Having received this order I went to New Orleans to conferwith Banks about the proposed movement.  All these movements came tonaught.During this visit I reviewed Banks' army a short distance aboveCarrollton.  The horse I rode was vicious and but little used
column123: and on myreturn to New Orleans ran away and
column124: shying at a locomotive in thestreet
column125: fell
column126: probably on me.  I was rendered insensible
column127: and when Iregained consciousness I found myself in a hotel near by with severaldoctors attending me.  My leg was swollen from the knee to the thigh
column128: and the swelling
column129: almost to the point of bursting
column130: extended along thebody up to the arm-pit.  The pain was almost beyond endurance.  I lay atthe hotel something over a week without being able to turn myself inbed.  I had a steamer stop at the nearest point possible
column131: and wascarried to it on a litter.  I was then taken to Vicksburg
column132: where Iremained unable to move for some time afterwards.While I was absent General Sherman declined to assume command because
column133: he said
column134: it would confuse the records; but he let all the orders be madein my name
column135: and was glad to render any assistance he could.  No orderswere issued by my staff
column136: certainly no important orders
column137: except uponconsultation with and approval of Sherman.On the 13th of September
column138: while I was still in New Orleans
column139: Hallecktelegraphed to me to send all available forces to Memphis and thence toTuscumbia
