column140: to co-operate with Rosecrans for the relief of Chattanooga.On the 15th he telegraphed again for all available forces to go toRosecrans.  This was received on the 27th.  I was still confined to mybed
column141: unable to rise from it without assistance; but I at once orderedSherman to send one division to Memphis as fast as transports could beprovided.  The division of McPherson's corps
column142: which had got off and wason the way to join Steele in Arkansas
column143: was recalled and sent
column144: likewise
column145: to report to Hurlbut at Memphis.  Hurlbut was directed to forward thesetwo divisions with two others from his own corps at once
column146: and also tosend any other troops that might be returning there.  Halleck suggestedthat some good man
column147: like Sherman or McPherson
column148: should be sent to Memphisto take charge of the troops going east. On this I sent Sherman
column149: asbeing
column150: I thought
column151: the most suitable person for an independent command
column152: and besides he was entitled to it if it had to be given to any one.  Hewas directed to take with him another division of his corps.  This leftone back
column153: but having one of McPherson's divisions he had still theequivalent.Before the receipt by me of these orders the battle of Chickamauga hadbeen fought and Rosecrans forced back into Chattanooga. Theadministration as well as the General-in-chief was nearly frantic at thesituation of affairs there.  Mr. Charles A. Dana
column154: an officer of the WarDepartment
column155: was sent to Rosecrans' headquarters.  I do not know what hisinstructions were
column156: but he was still in Chattanooga when I arrived thereat a later period.It seems that Halleck suggested that I should go to Nashville as soon asable to move and take general direction of the troops moving from thewest. I received the following dispatch dated October 3d:  'It is thewish of the Secretary of War that as soon as General Grant is able hewill come to Cairo and report by telegraph.'  I was still very lame
column157: butstarted without delay.  Arriving at Columbus on the 16th I reported bytelegraph:  'Your dispatch from Cairo of the 3d directing me to reportfrom Cairo was received at 11.30 on the 10th.  Left the same day withstaff and headquarters and am here en route for Cairo.'

column1: ISFP	 XL.FIRST MEETING WITH SECRETARY STANTON--GENERAL ROSECRANS--COMMANDINGMILITARY DIVISION OF MISSISSIPPI--ANDREW JOHNSON'S ADDRESS--ARRIVAL ATCHATTANOOGA.The reply (to my telegram of October 16
column3: from Cairo
column4: announcing myarrival at that point) came on the morning of the 17th
column5: directing me toproceed immediately to the Galt House
column6: Louisville
column7: where I would meet anofficer of the War Department with my instructions.  I left Cairo withinan hour or two after the receipt of this dispatch
column8: going by rail viaIndianapolis. Just as the train I was on was starting out of the depotat Indianapolis a messenger came running up to stop it
column9: saying theSecretary of War was coming into the station and wanted to see me.I had never met Mr. Stanton up to that time
column10: though we had held frequentconversations over the wires the year before
column11: when I was in Tennessee.Occasionally at night he would order the wires between the WarDepartment and my headquarters to be connected
column12: and we would hold aconversation for an hour or two.  On this occasion the Secretary wasaccompanied by Governor Brough of Ohio
column13: whom I had never met
column14: though heand my father had been old acquaintances.  Mr. Stanton dismissed thespecial train that had brought him to Indianapolis
column15: and accompanied meto Louisville.Up to this time no hint had been given me of what was wanted after Ileft Vicksburg
column16: except the suggestion in one of Halleck's dispatchesthat I had better go to Nashville and superintend the operation oftroops sent to relieve Rosecrans. Soon after we started the Secretaryhanded me two orders
column17: saying that I might take my choice of them.  Thetwo were identical in all but one particular.  Both created the'Military Division of Mississippi
column18: ' (giving me the command) composed ofthe Departments of the Ohio
column19: the Cumberland
column20: and the Tennessee
column21: and allthe territory from the Alleghanies to the Mississippi River north ofBanks's command in the south-west.  One order left the departmentcommanders as they were
column22: while the other relieved Rosecrans and assignedThomas to his place.  I accepted the latter.  We reached Louisvilleafter night and
column23: if I remember rightly
column24: in a cold
column25: drizzling rain.  TheSecretary of War told me afterwards that he caught a cold on thatoccasion from which he never expected to recover.  He never did.A day was spent in Louisville
column26: the Secretary giving me the military newsat the capital and talking about the disappointment at the results ofsome of the campaigns.  By the evening of the day after our arrival allmatters of discussion seemed exhausted
column27: and I left the hotel to spendthe evening away
column28: both Mrs. Grant (who was with me) and myself havingrelatives living in Louisville.  In the course of the evening Mr.Stanton received a dispatch from Mr. C. A. Dana
column29: then in Chattanooga
column30: informing him that unless prevented Rosecrans would retreat
column31: andadvising peremptory orders against his doing so.As stated before
column32: after the fall of Vicksburg I urged strongly upon thegovernment the propriety of a movement against Mobile.  GeneralRosecrans had been at Murfreesboro'
column33: Tennessee
column34: with a large andwell-equipped army from early in the year 1863
column35: with Bragg confrontinghim with a force quite equal to his own at first
column36: considering it was onthe defensive.  But after the investment of Vicksburg Bragg's army waslargely depleted to strengthen Johnston
column37: in Mississippi
column38: who was beingreinforced to raise the siege.  I frequently wrote General Hallecksuggesting that Rosecrans should move against Bragg.  By so doing hewould either detain the latter's troops where they were or layChattanooga open to capture.  General Halleck strongly approved thesuggestion
column39: and finally wrote me that he had repeatedly orderedRosecrans to advance
column40: but that the latter had constantly failed tocomply with the order
column41: and at last
column42: after having held a council of war
column43: had replied in effect that it was a military maxim 'not to fight twodecisive battles at the same time.'  If true
column44: the maxim was notapplicable in this case.  It would be bad to be defeated in two decisivebattles fought the same day
column45: but it would not be bad to win them.  I
column46: however
column47: was fighting no battle
column48: and the siege of Vicksburg had drawnfrom Rosecrans' front so many of the enemy that his chances of victorywere much greater than they would be if he waited until the siege wasover
column49: when these troops could be returned.  Rosecrans was ordered tomove against the army that was detaching troops to raise the siege.Finally he did move
column50: on the 24th of June
column51: but ten days afterwardsVicksburg surrendered
column52: and the troops sent from Bragg were free toreturn.It was at this time that I recommended to the general-in-chief themovement against Mobile.  I knew the peril the Army of the Cumberlandwas in
column53: being depleted continually
column54: not only by ordinary casualties
column55: butalso by having to detach troops to hold its constantly extending lineover which to draw supplies
column56: while the enemy in front was as constantlybeing strengthened.  Mobile was important to the enemy
column57: and in theabsence of a threatening force was guarded by little else thanartillery.  If threatened by land and from the water at the same timethe prize would fall easily
column58: or troops would have to be sent to itsdefence.  Those troops would necessarily come from Bragg.  My judgmentwas overruled
column59: and the troops under my command were dissipated overother parts of the country where it was thought they could render themost service.Soon it was discovered in Washington that Rosecrans was in trouble andrequired assistance.  The emergency was now too immediate to allow us togive this assistance by making an attack in rear of Bragg upon Mobile.It was therefore necessary to reinforce directly
column60: and troops were sentfrom every available point.Rosecrans had very skilfully manoeuvred Bragg south of the TennesseeRiver
column61: and through and beyond Chattanooga. If he had stopped andintrenched
column62: and made himself strong there
column63: all would have been right andthe mistake of not moving earlier partially compensated.  But he pushedon
column64: with his forces very much scattered
column65: until Bragg's troops fromMississippi began to join him.  Then Bragg took the initiative.Rosecrans had to fall back in turn
column66: and was able to get his armytogether at Chickamauga
column67: some miles south-east of Chattanooga
column68: beforethe main battle was brought on.  The battle was fought on the 19th and20th of September
column69: and Rosecrans was badly defeated
column70: with a heavy lossin artillery and some sixteen thousand men killed
column71: wounded and captured.The corps under Major-General George H. Thomas stood its ground
column72: whileRosecrans
column73: with Crittenden and McCook
column74: returned to Chattanooga. Thomasreturned also
column75: but later
column76: and with his troops in good order.  Braggfollowed and took possession of Missionary Ridge
column77: overlookingChattanooga. He also occupied Lookout Mountain
column78: west of the town
column79: whichRosecrans had abandoned
column80: and with it his control of the river and theriver road as far back as Bridgeport.  The National troops were nowstrongly intrenched in Chattanooga Valley
column81: with the Tennessee Riverbehind them and the enemy occupying commanding heights to the east andwest
column82: with a strong line across the valley from mountain to mountain
column83: and with Chattanooga Creek
column84: for a large part of the way
column85: in front oftheir line.On the 29th Halleck telegraphed me the above results
column86: and directed allthe forces that could be spared from my department to be sent toRosecrans.  Long before this dispatch was received Sherman was on hisway
column87: and McPherson was moving east with most of the garrison ofVicksburg.A retreat at that time would have been a terrible disaster.  It wouldnot only have been the loss of a most important strategic position tous
column88: but it would have been attended with the loss of all the artillerystill left with the Army of the Cumberland and the annihilation of thatarmy itself
column89: either by capture or demoralization.All supplies for Rosecrans had to be brought from Nashville. Therailroad between this base and the army was in possession of thegovernment up to Bridgeport
column90: the point at which the road crosses to thesouth side of the Tennessee River; but Bragg
column91: holding Lookout andRaccoon mountains west of Chattanooga
column92: commanded the railroad
column93: the riverand the shortest and best wagon-roads
column94: both south and north of theTennessee
column95: between Chattanooga and Bridgeport.  The distance betweenthese two places is but twenty-six miles by rail
column96: but owing to theposition of Bragg
column97: all supplies for Rosecrans had to be hauled by acircuitous route north of the river and over a mountainous country
column98: increasing the distance to over sixty miles.This country afforded but little food for his animals
column99: nearly tenthousand of which had already starved
column100: and not enough were left to drawa single piece of artillery or even the ambulances to convey the sick.The men had been on half rations of hard bread for a considerable time
column101: with but few other supplies except beef driven from Nashville across thecountry.  The region along the road became so exhausted of food for thecattle that by the time they reached Chattanooga they were much in thecondition of the few animals left alive there--'on the lift.' Indeed
column102: the beef was so poor that the soldiers were in the habit of saying
column103: witha faint facetiousness
column104: that they were living on 'half rations of hardbread and BEEF DRIED ON THE HOOF.'Nothing could be transported but food
column105: and the troops were withoutsufficient shoes or other clothing suitable for the advancing season.What they had was well worn.  The fuel within the Federal lines wasexhausted
column106: even to the stumps of trees. There were no teams to draw itfrom the opposite bank
column107: where it was abundant.  The only way ofsupplying fuel
column108: for some time before my arrival
column109: had been to cut treeson the north bank of the river at a considerable distance up the stream
column110: form rafts of it and float it down with the current
column111: effecting a landingon the south side within our lines by the use of paddles or poles. Itwould then be carried on the shoulders of the men to their camps.If a retreat had occurred at this time it is not probable that any ofthe army would have reached the railroad as an organized body
column112: iffollowed by the enemy.On the receipt of Mr. Dana's dispatch Mr. Stanton sent for me. Findingthat I was out he became nervous and excited
column113: inquiring of every personhe met
column114: including guests of the house
column115: whether they knew where I was
column116: and bidding them find me and send me to him at once.  About eleveno'clock I returned to the hotel
column117: and on my way
column118: when near the house
column119: every person met was a messenger from the Secretary
column120: apparentlypartaking of his impatience to see me.  I hastened to the room of theSecretary and found him pacing the floor rapidly in his dressing-gown.Saying that the retreat must be prevented
column121: he showed me the dispatch.  Iimmediately wrote an order assuming command of the Military Division ofthe Mississippi
column122: and telegraphed it to General Rosecrans.  I thentelegraphed to him the order from Washington assigning Thomas to thecommand of the Army of the Cumberland; and to Thomas that he must holdChattanooga at all hazards
column123: informing him at the same time that I wouldbe at the front as soon as possible.  A prompt reply was received fromThomas
column124: saying
column125: 'We will hold the town till we starve.'  I appreciatedthe force of this dispatch later when I witnessed the condition ofaffairs which prompted it.  It looked
column126: indeed
column127: as if but two courseswere open:  one to starve
column128: the other to surrender or be captured.On the morning of the 20th of October I started
column129: with my staff
column130: andproceeded as far as Nashville.  At that time it was not prudent totravel beyond that point by night
column131: so I remained in Nashville until thenext morning.  Here I met for the first time Andrew Johnson
column132: MilitaryGovernor of Tennessee.  He delivered a speech of welcome.  His composureshowed that it was by no means his maiden effort.  It was long
column133: and Iwas in torture while he was delivering it
column134: fearing something would beexpected from me in response.  I was relieved
column135: however
column136: the peopleassembled having apparently heard enough.  At all events they commenceda general hand-shaking
column137: which
column138: although trying where there is so much ofit
column139: was a great relief to me in this emergency.From Nashville I telegraphed to Burnside

column141: that important points in his department ought to be fortified

column144: Mississippi
column145: thatrations were probably on their way from St. Louis by boat for supplyinghis army

column151: and made some excellentsuggestions as to what should be done.  My only wonder was that he hadnot carried them out.  We then proceeded to Bridgeport

column153: and theroads were almost impassable from mud
column154: knee-deep in places
column155: and fromwash-outs on the mountain sides.  I had been on crutches since the timeof my fall in New Orleans
column156: and had to be carried over places where itwas not safe to cross on horseback.  The roads were strewn with thedebris of broken wagons and the carcasses of thousands of starved mulesand horses.  At Jasper
column157: some ten or twelve miles from Bridgeport
column158: therewas a halt.  General O. O. Howard had his headquarters there.  From thispoint I telegraphed Burnside to make every effort to secure five hundredrounds of ammunition for his artillery and small-arms.  We stopped forthe night at a little hamlet some ten or twelve miles farther on.  Thenext day we reached Chattanooga a little before dark.  I went directlyto General Thomas's headquarters
column159: and remaining there a few days
column160: untilI could establish my own.During the evening most of the general officers called in to pay theirrespects and to talk about the condition of affairs.  They pointed outon the map the line
column161: marked with a red or blue pencil
column162: which Rosecranshad contemplated falling back upon.  If any of them had approved themove they did not say so to me.  I found General W. F. Smith occupyingthe position of chief engineer of the Army of the Cumberland.  I hadknown Smith as a cadet at West Point
column163: but had no recollection of havingmet him after my graduation

column166: by utilizing an oldengine found in the neighborhood; and
column167: by rafting logs from the northside of the river above
column168: had got out the lumber and completed pontoonsand roadway plank for a second bridge

In addition to this he had far under waya steamer for plying between Chattanooga and Bridgeport whenever wemight get possession of the river.  This boat consisted of a scow
column170: madeof the plank sawed out at the mill
column171: housed in
column172: and a stern wheelattached which was propelled by a second engine taken from some shop orfactory.I telegraphed to Washington this night
column173: notifying General Halleck of myarrival
column174: and asking to have General Sherman assigned to the command ofthe Army of the Tennessee

column1: ISFP	 XLI.ASSUMING THE COMMAND AT CHATTANOOGA--OPENING A LINE OF SUPPLIES--BATTLEOF WAUHATCHIE--ON THE PICKET LINE.The next day
column2: the 24th

column6: and
column7: movingto the north of detached spurs of hills

column11: of about twenty men
column12: in full view
column13: and we were withineasy range. They did not fire upon us nor seem to be disturbed by ourpresence.  They must have seen that we were all commissioned officers.But
column14: I suppose
column15: they looked upon the garrison of Chattanooga asprisoners of war
column16: feeding or starving themselves

column18: as the soldiers appropriately termed it.  They had been solong on short rations that my first thought was the establishment of aline over which food might reach them.Chattanooga is on the south bank of the Tennessee
column19: where that river runsnearly due west.  It is at the northern end of a valley five or sixmiles in width
column20: through which Chattanooga Creek runs.  To the east ofthe valley is Missionary Ridge
column21: rising from five to eight hundred feetabove the creek and terminating somewhat abruptly a half mile or morebefore reaching the Tennessee.  On the west of the valley is LookoutMountain
column22: twenty-two hundred feet above-tide water.  Just below the townthe Tennessee makes a turn to the south and runs to the base of LookoutMountain
column23: leaving no level ground between the mountain and river.  TheMemphis and Charleston Railroad passes this point
column24: where the mountainstands nearly perpendicular. East of Missionary Ridge flows the SouthChickamauga River; west of Lookout Mountain is Lookout Creek; and westof that
column25: Raccoon Mountains.  Lookout Mountain
column26: at its northern end
column27: rises almost perpendicularly for some distance
column28: then breaks off in agentle slope of cultivated fields to near the summit
column29: where it ends in apalisade thirty or more feet in height.  On the gently sloping ground
column30: between the upper and lower palisades
column31: there is a single farmhouse
column32: which is reached by a wagon-road from the valley east.The intrenched line of the enemy commenced on the north end ofMissionary Ridge and extended along the crest for some distance south
column33: thence across Chattanooga valley to Lookout Mountain. Lookout Mountainwas also fortified and held by the enemy
column34: who also kept troops inLookout valley west
column35: and on Raccoon Mountain
column36: with pickets extendingdown the river so as to command the road on the north bank and render ituseless to us.  In addition to this there was an intrenched line inChattanooga valley extending from the river east of the town to LookoutMountain
column37: to make the investment complete.  Besides the fortificationson Mission Ridge
column38: there was a line at the base of the hill
column39: withoccasional spurs of rifle-pits half-way up the front.  The enemy'spickets extended out into the valley towards the town
column40: so far that thepickets of the two armies could converse.  At one point they wereseparated only by the narrow creek which gives its name to the valleyand town
column41: and from which both sides drew water.  The Union lines wereshorter than those of the enemy.Thus the enemy
column42: with a vastly superior force
column43: was strongly fortified tothe east
column44: south
column45: and west
column46: and commanded the river below.  Practically
column47: the Army of the Cumberland was besieged. The enemy had stopped with hiscavalry north of the river the passing of a train loaded with ammunitionand medical supplies.  The Union army was short of both
column48: not havingammunition enough for a day's fighting.General Halleck had
column49: long before my coming into this new field
column50: orderedparts of the 11th and 12th corps
column51: commanded respectively by GeneralsHoward and Slocum
column52: Hooker in command of the whole
column53: from the Army of thePotomac to reinforce Rosecrans.  It would have been folly to send themto Chattanooga to help eat up the few rations left there.  They wereconsequently left on the railroad
column54: where supplies could be brought tothem.  Before my arrival
column55: Thomas ordered their concentration atBridgeport.General W. F. Smith had been so instrumental in preparing for the movewhich I was now about to make
column56: and so clear in his judgment about themanner of making it
column57: that I deemed it but just to him that he shouldhave command of the troops detailed to execute the design
column58: although hewas then acting as a staff officer and was not in command of troops.On the 24th of October
column59: after my return to Chattanooga
column60: the followingdetails were made:  General Hooker
column61: who was now at Bridgeport
column62: wasordered to cross to the south side of the Tennessee and march up byWhitesides and Wauhatchie to Brown's Ferry.  General Palmer
column63: with adivision of the 14th corps
column64: Army of the Cumberland

column66: by a back road
column67: until oppositeWhitesides
column68: then cross and hold the road in Hooker's rear after he hadpassed. Four thousand men were at the same time detailed to act underGeneral Smith directly from Chattanooga. Eighteen hundred of them

column71: and under cover ofnight float by the pickets of the enemy at the north base of Lookout
column72: down to Brown's Ferry

column74: also under cover of night
column75: by the north bank of the riverto Brown's Ferry

column77: Hooker crossed the river at Bridgeport and commenced hiseastward march.  At three o'clock on the morning of the 27th
column78: Hazenmoved into the stream with his sixty pontoons and eighteen hundred braveand well-equipped men.  Smith started enough in advance to be near theriver when Hazen should arrive.  There are a number of detached spurs ofhills north of the river at Chattanooga
column79: back of which is a good roadparallel to the stream

column81: surprised the picket guard
column82: and captured most of it.  Byseven o'clock the whole of Smith's force was ferried over and inpossession of a height commanding the ferry.  This was speedilyfortified
column83: while a detail was laying the pontoon bridge.  By ten o'clockthe bridge was laid
column84: and our extreme right
column85: now in Lookout valley
column86: wasfortified and connected with the rest of the army.  The two bridges overthe Tennessee River--a flying one at Chattanooga and the new one atBrown's Ferry--with the road north of the river
column87: covered from both thefire and the view of the enemy
column88: made the connection complete.  Hookerfound but slight obstacles in his way
column89: and on the afternoon of the 28themerged into Lookout valley at Wauhatchie.  Howard marched on to Brown'sFerry
column90: while Geary
column91: who commanded a division in the 12th corps
column92: stoppedthree miles south.  The pickets of the enemy on the river below were nowcut off
column93: and soon came in and surrendered.The river was now opened to us from Lookout valley to Bridgeport.Between Brown's Ferry and Kelly's Ferry the Tennessee runs through anarrow gorge in the mountains
column94: which contracts the stream so much as toincrease the current beyond the capacity of an ordinary steamer to stemit.  To get up these rapids
column95: steamers must be cordelled; that is
column96: pulledup by ropes from the shore.  But there is no difficulty in navigatingthe stream from Bridgeport to Kelly's Ferry.  The latter point is onlyeight miles from Chattanooga and connected with it by a good wagon-road
column97: which runs through a low pass in the Raccoon Mountains on the south sideof the river to Brown's Ferry
column98: thence on the north side to the riveropposite Chattanooga. There were several steamers at Bridgeport
column99: andabundance of forage
column100: clothing and provisions.On the way to Chattanooga I had telegraphed back to Nashville for a goodsupply of vegetables and small rations
column101: which the troops had been solong deprived of.  Hooker had brought with him from the east a fullsupply of land transportation.  His animals had not been subjected tohard work on bad roads without forage
column102: but were in good condition.  Infive days from my arrival in Chattanooga the way was open to Bridgeportand
column103: with the aid of steamers and Hooker's teams
column104: in a week the troopswere receiving full rations.  It is hard for any one not an eye-witnessto realize the relief this brought.  The men were soon reclothed andalso well fed
column105: an abundance of ammunition was brought up
column106: and acheerfulness prevailed not before enjoyed in many weeks.  Neitherofficers nor men looked upon themselves any longer as doomed.  The weakand languid appearance of the troops
column107: so visible before
column108: disappeared atonce.  I do not know what the effect was on the other side
column109: but assumeit must have been correspondingly depressing.  Mr. Davis had visitedBragg but a short time before
column110: and must have perceived our condition tobe about as Bragg described it in his subsequent report.  'Thesedispositions
column111: ' he said
column112: 'faithfully sustained
column113: insured the enemy'sspeedy evacuation of Chattanooga for want of food and forage.  Possessedof the shortest route to his depot
column114: and the one by which reinforcementsmust reach him
column115: we held him at our mercy
column116: and his destruction was only aquestion of time.'  But the dispositions were not 'faithfullysustained
column117: ' and I doubt not but thousands of men engaged in trying to'sustain' them now rejoice that they were not.  There was no time duringthe rebellion when I did not think
column118: and often say
column119: that the South wasmore to be benefited by its defeat than the North.  The latter had thepeople
column120: the institutions
column121: and the territory to make a great andprosperous nation.  The former was burdened with an institutionabhorrent to all civilized people not brought up under it
column122: and one whichdegraded labor
column123: kept it in ignorance
column124: and enervated the governing class.With the outside world at war with this institution
column125: they could not haveextended their territory.  The labor of the country was not skilled
column126: norallowed to become so.  The whites could not toil without becomingdegraded
column127: and those who did were denominated 'poor white trash.'  Thesystem of labor would have soon exhausted the soil and left the peoplepoor.  The non-slaveholders would have left the country
column128: and the smallslaveholder must have sold out to his more fortunate neighbor.  Soon theslaves would have outnumbered the masters
column129: and
column130: not being in sympathywith them
column131: would have risen in their might and exterminated them.  Thewar was expensive to the South as well as to the North
column132: both in bloodand treasure
column133: but it was worth all it cost.The enemy was surprised by the movements which secured to us a line ofsupplies.  He appreciated its importance
column134: and hastened to try to recoverthe line from us.  His strength on Lookout Mountain was not equal toHooker's command in the valley below.  From Missionary Ridge he had tomarch twice the distance we had from Chattanooga
column135: in order to reachLookout Valley; but on the night of the 28th and 29th an attack was madeon Geary at Wauhatchie by Longstreet's corps.  When the battlecommenced
column136: Hooker ordered Howard up from Brown's Ferry.  He had threemiles to march to reach Geary.  On his way he was fired upon by rebeltroops from a foot-hill to the left of the road and from which the roadwas commanded.  Howard turned to the left
column137: charged up the hill andcaptured it before the enemy had time to intrench
column138: taking manyprisoners.  Leaving sufficient men to hold this height
column139: he pushed on toreinforce Geary.  Before he got up
column140: Geary had been engaged for aboutthree hours against a vastly superior force.  The night was so dark thatthe men could not distinguish one from another except by the light ofthe flashes of their muskets.  In the darkness and uproar Hooker'steamsters became frightened and deserted their teams.  The mules alsobecame frightened
column141: and breaking loose from their fastenings stampededdirectly towards the enemy.  The latter
column142: no doubt
column143: took this for acharge
column144: and stampeded in turn.  By four o'clock in the morning thebattle had entirely ceased
column145: and our 'cracker line' was never afterwarddisturbed.In securing possession of Lookout Valley
column146: Smith lost one man killed andfour or five wounded.  The enemy lost most of his pickets at the ferry
column147: captured.  In the night engagement of the 28th-9th Hooker lost 416killed and wounded.  I never knew the loss of the enemy
column148: but our troopsburied over one hundred and fifty of his dead and captured more than ahundred.After we had secured the opening of a line over which to bring oursupplies to the army
column149: I made a personal inspection to see the situationof the pickets of the two armies.  As I have stated
column150: Chattanooga Creekcomes down the centre of the valley to within a mile or such a matter ofthe town of Chattanooga
column151: then bears off westerly
column152: then north-westerly
column153: and enters the Tennessee River at the foot of Lookout Mountain.  Thiscreek
column154: from its mouth up to where it bears off west
column155: lay between the twolines of pickets
column156: and the guards of both armies drew their water fromthe same stream.  As I would be under short-range fire and in an opencountry
column157: I took nobody with me
column158: except
column159: I believe
column160: a bugler
column161: who stayedsome distance to the rear.  I rode from our right around to our left.When I came to the camp of the picket guard of our side
column162: I heard thecall
column163: 'Turn out the guard for the commanding general.'  I replied
column164: 'Never mind the guard
column165: ' and they were dismissed and went back to theirtents. Just back of these
column166: and about equally distant from the creek
column167: were the guards of the Confederate pickets.  The sentinel on their postcalled out in like manner
column168: 'Turn out the guard for the commandinggeneral
column169: ' and
column170: I believe
column171: added
column172: 'General Grant.'  Their line in amoment front-faced to the north
column173: facing me
column174: and gave a salute
column175: which Ireturned.The most friendly relations seemed to exist between the pickets of thetwo armies.  At one place there was a tree which had fallen across thestream
column176: and which was used by the soldiers of both armies in drawingwater for their camps.  General Longstreet's corps was stationed thereat the time
column177: and wore blue of a little different shade from our uniform.Seeing a soldier in blue on this log
column178: I rode up to him
column179: commencedconversing with him
column180: and asked whose corps he belonged to.  He was verypolite
column181: and
column182: touching his hat to me
column183: said he belonged to GeneralLongstreet's corps.  I asked him a few questions--but not with a view ofgaining any particular information--all of which he answered
column184: and I rodeoff.

column1: ISFP	 XLII.CONDITION OF THE ARMY--REBUILDING THE RAILROAD--GENERAL BURNSIDE'SSITUATION--ORDERS FOR BATTLE--PLANS FOR THE ATTACK--HOOKER'S POSITION--SHERMAN'S MOVEMENTS.Having got the Army of the Cumberland in a comfortable position
column2: I nowbegan to look after the remainder of my new command. Burnside was inabout as desperate a condition as the Army of the Cumberland had been
column3: only he was not yet besieged.  He was a hundred miles from the nearESTJossible base
column4: Big South Fork of the Cumberland River
column5: and much fartherfrom any railroad we had possession of.  The roads back were overmountains
column6: and all supplies along the line had long since beenexhausted.  His animals
column7: too
column8: had been starved
column9: and their carcasseslined the road from Cumberland Gap
column10: and far back towards Lexington
column11: Ky.East Tennessee still furnished supplies of beef
column12: bread and forage
column13: butit did not supply ammunition
column14: clothing
column15: medical supplies
column16: or smallrations
column17: such as coffee
column18: sugar
column19: salt and rice.Sherman had started from Memphis for Corinth on the 11th of October.His instructions required him to repair the road in his rear in order tobring up supplies.  The distance was about three hundred and thirtymiles through a hostile country.  His entire command could not havemaintained the road if it had been completed.  The bridges had all beendestroyed by the enemy
column20: and much other damage done.  A hostile communitylived along the road; guerilla bands infested the country
column21: and more orless of the cavalry of the enemy was still in the West.  Often Sherman'swork was destroyed as soon as completed
column22: and he only a short distanceaway.The Memphis and Charleston Railroad strikes the Tennessee River atEastport
column23: Mississippi.  Knowing the difficulty Sherman would have tosupply himself from Memphis
column24: I had previously ordered supplies sent fromSt. Louis on small steamers
column25: to be convoyed by the navy
column26: to meet him atEastport.  These he got.  I now ordered him to discontinue his work ofrepairing roads and to move on with his whole force to Stevenson
column27: Alabama
column28: without delay.  This order was borne to Sherman by a messenger
column29: who paddled down the Tennessee in a canoe and floated over MuscleShoals; it was delivered at Iuka on the 27th.  In this Sherman wasnotified that the rebels were moving a force towards Cleveland
column30: EastTennessee
column31: and might be going to Nashville
column32: in which event his troopswere in the best position to beat them there.  Sherman
column33: with hischaracteristic promptness
column34: abandoned the work he was engaged upon andpushed on at once.  On the 1st of November he crossed the Tennessee atEastport
column35: and that day was in Florence
column36: Alabama
column37: with the head ofcolumn
column38: while his troops were still crossing at Eastport
column39: with Blairbringing up the rear.Sherman's force made an additional army
column40: with cavalry
column41: artillery
column42: andtrains
column43: all to be supplied by the single track road from Nashville.  Allindications pointed also to the probable necessity of supplyingBurnside's command in East Tennessee
column44: twenty-five thousand more
column45: by thesame route.  A single track could not do this.  I gave
column46: therefore
column47: anorder to Sherman to halt General G. M. Dodge's command
column48: of about eightthousand men
column49: at Athens
column50: and subsequently directed the latter to arrangehis troops along the railroad from Decatur north towards Nashville
column51: andto rebuild that road.  The road from Nashville to Decatur passes over abroken country
column52: cut up with innumerable streams
column53: many of them ofconsiderable width
column54: and with valleys far below the road-bed.  All thebridges over these had been destroyed
column55: and the rails taken up andtwisted by the enemy.  All the cars and locomotives not carried off hadbeen destroyed as effectually as they knew how to destroy them.  Allbridges and culverts had been destroyed between Nashville and Decatur
column56: and thence to Stevenson
column57: where the Memphis and Charleston and theNashville and Chattanooga roads unite.  The rebuilding of this roadwould give us two roads as far as Stevenson over which to supply thearmy.  From Bridgeport
column58: a short distance farther east
column59: the riversupplements the road.General Dodge
column60: besides being a most capable soldier
column61: was an experiencedrailroad builder.  He had no tools to work with except those of thepioneers--axes
column62: picks
column63: and spades.  With these he was able to intrenchhis men and protect them against surprises by small parties of theenemy.  As he had no base of supplies until the road could be completedback to Nashville
column64: the first matter to consider after protecting his menwas the getting in of food and forage from the surrounding country.  Hehad his men and teams bring in all the grain they could find
column65: or allthey needed
column66: and all the cattle for beef
column67: and such other food as couldbe found.  Millers were detailed from the ranks to run the mills alongthe line of the army.  When these were not near enough to the troops forprotection they were taken down and moved up to the line of the road.Blacksmith shops
column68: with all the iron and steel found in them
column69: were movedup in like manner.  Blacksmiths were detailed and set to work making thetools necessary in railroad and bridge building.  Axemen were put towork getting out timber for bridges and cutting fuel for locomotiveswhen the road should be completed.  Car-builders were set to workrepairing the locomotives and cars.  Thus every branch of railroadbuilding
column70: making tools to work with
column71: and supplying the workmen withfood
column72: was all going on at once
column73: and without the aid of a mechanic orlaborer except what the command itself furnished.  But rails and carsthe men could not make without material
column74: and there was not enoughrolling stock to keep the road we already had worked to its fullcapacity.  There were no rails except those in use.  To supply thesedeficiencies I ordered eight of the ten engines General McPherson had atVicksburg to be sent to Nashville
column75: and all the cars he had except ten.I also ordered the troops in West Tennessee to points on the river andon the Memphis and Charleston road
column76: and ordered the cars
column77: locomotivesand rails from all the railroads except the Memphis and Charleston toNashville.  The military manager of railroads also was directed tofurnish more rolling stock and
column78: as far as he could
column79: bridge material.General Dodge had the work assigned him finished within forty days afterreceiving his orders.  The number of bridges to rebuild was one hundredand eighty-two
column80: many of them over deep and wide chasms; the length ofroad repaired was one hundred and two miles.The enemy's troops
column81: which it was thought were either moving againstBurnside or were going to Nashville
column82: went no farther than Cleveland.Their presence there
column83: however
column84: alarmed the authorities at Washington
column85: and
column86: on account of our helpless condition at Chattanooga
column87: caused me muchuneasiness.  Dispatches were constantly coming
column88: urging me to dosomething for Burnside's relief; calling attention to the importance ofholding East Tennessee; saying the President was much concerned for theprotection of the loyal people in that section
column89: etc.  We had not atChattanooga animals to pull a single piece of artillery
column90: much less asupply train.  Reinforcements could not help Burnside
column91: because he hadneither supplies nor ammunition sufficient for them; hardly
column92: indeed
column93: bread and meat for the men he had.  There was no relief possible for himexcept by expelling the enemy from Missionary Ridge and aboutChattanooga.On the 4th of November Longstreet left our front with about fifteenthousand troops
column94: besides Wheeler's cavalry
column95: five thousand more
column96: to goagainst Burnside.  The situation seemed desperate
column97: and was moreaggravating because nothing could be done until Sherman should get up.The authorities at Washington were now more than ever anxious for thesafety of Burnside's army

column99: urging that something should be done for his relief.  On the 7th
column100: before Longstreet could possibly have reached Knoxville

column102: so as to force thereturn of the troops that had gone up the valley.  I directed him totake mules

column104: or animals wherever he could get them tomove the necessary artillery.  But he persisted in the declaration thathe could not move a single piece of artillery
column105: and could not see how hecould possibly comply with the order.  Nothing was left to be done butto answer Washington dispatches as best I could; urge Sherman forward
column106: although he was making every effort to get forward
column107: and encourageBurnside to hold on
column108: assuring him that in a short time he should berelieved.  All of Burnside's dispatches showed the greatest confidencein his ability to hold his position as long as his ammunition held out.He even suggested the propriety of abandoning the territory he heldsouth and west of Knoxville
column109: so as to draw the enemy farther from hisbase and make it more difficult for him to get back to Chattanooga whenthe battle should begin.  Longstreet had a railroad as far as Loudon;but from there to Knoxville he had to rely on wagon trains. Burnside'ssuggestion
column110: therefore
column111: was a good one
column112: and it was adopted.  On the 14thI telegraphed him:'Sherman's advance has reached Bridgeport.  His whole force will beready to move from there by Tuesday at farthest.  If you can holdLongstreet in check until he gets up
column113: or by skirmishing and falling backcan avoid serious loss to yourself and gain time
column114: I will be able toforce the enemy back from here and place a force between Longstreet andBragg that must inevitably make the former take to the mountain-passesby every available road
column115: to get to his supplies.  Sherman would havebeen here before this but for high water in Elk River driving him somethirty miles up that river to cross.'And again later in the day
column116: indicating my plans for his relief

His problem was to get from Lookout Valley to Chattanooga Valleyin the most expeditious way possible; cross the latter valley rapidly toRossville

But days before the battlebegan the advantages as well as the disadvantages of this plan of actionwere all considered. It might consume so much time as tolose us the use of the troops engaged in it at other points where theywere more wanted.  After reaching Chattanooga Valley

A dispatch was received from him saying that he was threatenedfrom the east.  The following was sent in reply:'If you can communicate with General Burnside

column1: ISFP	 XLIII.PREPARATIONS FOR BATTLE--THOMAS CARRIES THE FIRST LINE OF THE ENEMY--SHERMAN CARRIES MISSIONARY RIDGE--BATTLE OF LOOKOUT MOUNTAIN--GENERAL HOOKER'S FIGHT.On the 20th
column2: when so much was occurring to discourage--rains falling soheavily as to delay the passage of troops over the river at Brown'sFerry and threatening the entire breaking of the bridge; news coming ofa battle raging at Knoxville; of Willcox being threatened by a forcefrom the east--a letter was received from Bragg which contained thesewords:  'As there may still be some non-combatants in Chattanooga
column3: Ideem it proper to notify you that prudence would dictate their earlywithdrawal.' Of course
column4: I understood that this was a device intended todeceive; but I did not know what the intended deception was.  On the22d
column5: however
column6: a deserter came in who informed me that Bragg was leavingour front
column7: and on that day Buckner's division was sent to reinforceLongstreet at Knoxville
column8: and another division started to follow but wasrecalled.  The object of Bragg's letter
column9: no doubt
column10: was in some way todetain me until Knoxville could be captured
column11: and his troops there bereturned to Chattanooga.During the night of the 21st the rest of the pontoon boats
column12: completed
column13: one hundred and sixteen in all
column14: were carried up to and placed in NorthChickamauga. The material for the roadway over these was deposited outof view of the enemy within a few hundred yards of the bank of theTennessee
column15: where the north end of the bridge was to rest.Hearing nothing from Burnside
column16: and hearing much of the distress inWashington on his account
column17: I could no longer defer operations for hisrelief.  I determined
column18: therefore
column19: to do on the 23d
column20: with the Army of theCumberland
column21: what had been intended to be done on the 24th.The position occupied by the Army of the Cumberland had been made verystrong for defence during the months it had been besieged.  The line wasabout a mile from the town
column22: and extended from Citico Creek
column23: a smallstream running near the base of Missionary Ridge and emptying into theTennessee about two miles below the mouth of the South Chickamauga
column24: onthe left
column25: to Chattanooga Creek on the right.  All commanding points onthe line were well fortified and well equipped with artillery.  Theimportant elevations within the line had all been carefully fortifiedand supplied with a proper armament.  Among the elevations so fortifiedwas one to the east of the town
column26: named Fort Wood.  It owed itsimportance chiefly to the fact that it lay between the town andMissionary Ridge
column27: where most of the strength of the enemy was.  FortWood had in it twenty-two pieces of artillery
column28: most of which would reachthe nearer points of the enemy's line.  On the morning of the 23dThomas
column29: according to instructions
column30: moved Granger's corps of twodivisions
column31: Sheridan and T. J. Wood commanding
column32: to the foot of Fort Wood
column33: and formed them into line as if going on parade
column34: Sheridan on the right
column35: Wood to the left
column36: extending to or near Citico Creek.  Palmer
column37: commandingthe 14th corps
column38: held that part of our line facing south and southwest.He supported Sheridan with one division (Baird's)
column39: while his otherdivision under Johnson remained in the trenches
column40: under arms
column41: ready to bemoved to any point. Howard's corps was moved in rear of the centre.  Thepicket lines were within a few hundred yards of each other.  At twoo'clock in the afternoon all were ready to advance.  By this time theclouds had lifted so that the enemy could see from his elevated positionall that was going on.  The signal for advance was given by a booming ofcannon from Fort Wood and other points on the line.  The rebel picketswere soon driven back upon the main guards
column42: which occupied minor anddetached heights between the main ridge and our lines.  These too werecarried before halting
column43: and before the enemy had time to reinforce theiradvance guards.  But it was not without loss on both sides. Thismovement secured to us a line fully a mile in advance of the one weoccupied in the morning
column44: and the one which the enemy had occupied up tothis time.  The fortifications were rapidly turned to face the otherway.  During the following night they were made strong.  We lost in thispreliminary action about eleven hundred killed and wounded
column45: while theenemy probably lost quite as heavily
column46: including the prisoners that werecaptured. With the exception of the firing of artillery
column47: kept up fromMissionary Ridge and Fort Wood until night closed in
column48: this ended thefighting for the first day.The advantage was greatly on our side now
column49: and if I could only have beenassured that Burnside could hold out ten days longer I should haverested more easily.  But we were doing the best we could for him and thecause.By the night of the 23d Sherman's command was in a position to move
column50: though one division (Osterhaus's) had not yet crossed the river atBrown's Ferry.  The continuous rise in the Tennessee had rendered itimpossible to keep the bridge at that point in condition for troops tocross; but I was determined to move that night even without thisdivision.  Orders were sent to Osterhaus accordingly to report toHooker
column51: if he could not cross by eight o'clock on the morning of the24th.  Because of the break in the bridge
column52: Hooker's orders were againchanged
column53: but this time only back to those first given to him.General W. F. Smith had been assigned to duty as Chief Engineer of theMilitary Division.  To him were given the general direction of movingtroops by the boats from North Chickamauga

column55: and generally all the duties pertaining to hisoffice of chief engineer.  During the night General Morgan L. Smith'sdivision was marched to the point where the pontoons were

column62: Thomas having none.At two o'clock in the morning
column63: November 24th

column66: until arriving near the mouth of South Chickamauga. Here a fewboats were landed

column71: using the pontoons for thepurpose.  A steamer was also brought up from the town to assist.  Therest of M. L. Smith's division came first
column72: then the division of John E.Smith.  The troops as they landed were put to work intrenching theirposition.  By daylight the two entire divisions were over
column73: and wellcovered by the works they had built.The work of laying the bridge
column74: on which to cross the artillery andcavalry

column76: taking the pontoons

column78: as fastas they were wanted to put in their place in the bridge.  By a littlepast noon the bridge was completed

column82: in column

column86: andthe clouds were so low that Lookout Mountain and the top of MissionaryRidge were obscured from the view of persons in the valley.  But now theenemy opened fire upon their assailants
column87: and made several attempts withtheir skirmishers to drive them away
column88: but without avail.  Later in theday a more determined attack was made
column89: but this
column90: too
column91: failed
column92: andSherman was left to fortify what he had gained.Sherman's cavalry took up its line of march soon after the bridge wascompleted
column93: and by half-past three the whole of it was over both bridgesand on its way to strike the enemy's communications at ChickamaugaStation.  All of Sherman's command was now south of the Tennessee.During the afternoon General Giles A. Smith was severely wounded andcarried from the field.Thomas having done on the 23d what was expected of him on the 24th
column94: there was nothing for him to do this day except to strengthen hisposition.  Howard
column95: however
column96: effected a crossing of Citico Creek and ajunction with Sherman
column97: and was directed to report to him.  With two orthree regiments of his command he moved in the morning along the banksof the Tennessee
column98: and reached the point where the bridge was being laid.He went out on the bridge as far as it was completed from the south end
column99: and saw Sherman superintending the work from the north side and movinghimself south as fast as an additional boat was put in and the roadwayput upon it.  Howard reported to his new chief across the chasm betweenthem
column100: which was now narrow and in a few minutes closed.While these operations were going on to the east of Chattanooga
column101: Hookerwas engaged on the west.  He had three divisions: Osterhaus's
column102: of the15th corps
column103: Army of the Tennessee; Geary's
column104: 12th corps
column105: Army of thePotomac; and Cruft's
column106: 14th corps
column107: Army of the Cumberland.  Geary was onthe right at Wauhatchie
column108: Cruft at the centre
column109: and Osterhaus near Brown'sFerry.  These troops were all west of Lookout Creek.  The enemy had theeast bank of the creek strongly picketed and intrenched
column110: and threebrigades of troops in the rear to reinforce them if attacked.  Thesebrigades occupied the summit of the mountain.  General Carter L.Stevenson was in command of the whole.  Why any troops
column111: except artillerywith a small infantry guard
column112: were kept on the mountain-top
column113: I do notsee.  A hundred men could have held the summit--which is a palisade formore than thirty feet down--against the assault of any number of menfrom the position Hooker occupied.The side of Lookout Mountain confronting Hooker's command was rugged
column114: heavily timbered
column115: and full of chasms
column116: making it difficult to advancewith troops
column117: even in the absence of an opposing force.  Farther up
column118: theground becomes more even and level
column119: and was in cultivation.  On the eastside the slope is much more gradual
column120: and a good wagon road
column121: zigzaggingup it
column122: connects the town of Chattanooga with the summit.Early on the morning of the 24th Hooker moved Geary's division
column123: supported by a brigade of Cruft's
column124: up Lookout Creek
column125: to effect acrossing.  The remainder of Cruft's division was to seize the bridgeover the creek
column126: near the crossing of the railroad. Osterhaus was to moveup to the bridge and cross it.  The bridge was seized by Gross's brigadeafter a slight skirmish with the pickets guarding it.  This attractedthe enemy so that Geary's movement farther up was not observed.  A heavymist obscured him from the view of the troops on the top of themountain.  He crossed the creek almost unobserved
column127: and captured thepicket of over forty men on guard near by.  He then commenced ascendingthe mountain directly in his front.  By this time the enemy was seencoming down from their camps on the mountain slope
column128: and filing intotheir rifle-pits to contest the crossing of the bridge.  By eleveno'clock the bridge was complete.  Osterhaus was up
column129: and after some sharpskirmishing the enemy was driven away with considerable loss in killedand captured.While the operations at the bridge were progressing
column130: Geary was pushingup the hill over great obstacles
column131: resisted by the enemy directly in hisfront
column132: and in face of the guns on top of the mountain.  The enemy
column133: seeing their left flank and rear menaced
column134: gave way
column135: and were followed byCruft and Osterhaus.  Soon these were up abreast of Geary
column136: and the wholecommand pushed up the hill
column137: driving the enemy in advance.  By noon Gearyhad gained the open ground on the north slope of the mountain
column138: with hisright close up to the base of the upper palisade
column139: but there were strongfortifications in his front.  The rest of the command coming up
column140: a linewas formed from the base of the upper palisade to the mouth ofChattanooga Creek.Thomas and I were on the top of Orchard Knob.  Hooker's advance now madeour line a continuous one.  It was in full view
column141: extending from theTennessee River
column142: where Sherman had crossed
column143: up Chickamauga River to thebase of Mission Ridge
column144: over the top of the north end of the ridge toChattanooga Valley
column145: then along parallel to the ridge a mile or more
column146: across the valley to the mouth of Chattanooga Creek
column147: thence up the slopeof Lookout Mountain to the foot of the upper palisade.  The day washazy
column148: so that Hooker's operations were not visible to us except atmoments when the clouds would rise.  But the sound of his artillery andmusketry was heard incessantly.  The enemy on his front was partiallyfortified
column149: but was soon driven out of his works.  During the afternoonthe clouds
column150: which had so obscured the top of Lookout all day as to hidewhatever was going on from the view of those below
column151: settled down andmade it so dark where Hooker was as to stop operations for the time.  Atfour o'clock Hooker reported his position as impregnable.  By a littleafter five direct communication was established
column152: and a brigade of troopswas sent from Chattanooga to reinforce him.  These troops had to crossChattanooga Creek and met with some opposition
column153: but soon overcame it
column154: and by night the commander
column155: General Carlin
column156: reported to Hooker and wasassigned to his left.  I now telegraphed to Washington:  'The fightto-day progressed favorably.  Sherman carried the end of MissionaryRidge
column157: and his right is now at the tunnel
column158: and his left at ChickamaugaCreek. Troops from Lookout Valley carried the point of the mountain
column159: andnow hold the eastern slope and a point high up.  Hooker reports twothousand prisoners taken
column160: besides which a small number have fallen intoour hands from Missionary Ridge.'  The next day the President replied:'Your dispatches as to fighting on Monday and Tuesday are here.  Welldone. Many thanks to all.  Remember Burnside.'  And Halleck alsotelegraphed: 'I congratulate you on the success thus far of your plans.I fear that Burnside is hard pushed
column161: and that any further delay mayprove fatal.  I know you will do all in your power to relieve him.'The division of Jefferson C. Davis
column162: Army of the Cumberland
column163: had beensent to the North Chickamauga to guard the pontoons as they weredeposited in the river
column164: and to prevent all ingress or egress ofcitizens.  On the night of the 24th his division
column165: having crossed withSherman
column166: occupied our extreme left from the upper bridge over the plainto the north base of Missionary Ridge. Firing continued to a late hourin the night
column167: but it was not connected with an assault at any point.

column1: ISFP	 XLIV.BATTLE OF CHATTANOOGA--A GALLANT CHARGE--COMPLETE ROUT OF THE ENEMY--PURSUIT OF THE CONFEDERATES--GENERAL BRAGG--REMARKS ON CHATTANOOGA.At twelve o'clock at night
column2: when all was quiet
column3: I began to give ordersfor the next day
column4: and sent a dispatch to Willcox to encourage Burnside.Sherman was directed to attack at daylight.  Hooker was ordered to moveat the same hour
column5: and endeavor to intercept the enemy's retreat if hestill remained; if he had gone
column6: then to move directly to Rossville andoperate against the left and rear of the force on Missionary Ridge.Thomas was not to move until Hooker had reached Missionary Ridge.  As Iwas with him on Orchard Knob
column7: he would not move without further ordersfrom me.The morning of the 25th opened clear and bright
column8: and the whole field wasin full view from the top of Orchard Knob.  It remained so all day.Bragg's headquarters were in full view
column9: and officers--presumably staffofficers--could be seen coming and going constantly.The point of ground which Sherman had carried on the 24th was almostdisconnected from the main ridge occupied by the enemy. A low pass
column10: overwhich there is a wagon road crossing the hill
column11: and near which there is arailroad tunnel
column12: intervenes between the two hills.  The problem now wasto get to the main ridge. The enemy was fortified on the point; and backfarther
column13: where the ground was still higher
column14: was a second fortificationcommanding the first.  Sherman was out as soon as it was light enough tosee
column15: and by sunrise his command was in motion.  Three brigades held thehill already gained.  Morgan L. Smith moved along the east base ofMissionary Ridge; Loomis along the west base
column16: supported by two brigadesof John E. Smith's division; and Corse with his brigade was between thetwo
column17: moving directly towards the hill to be captured.  The ridge issteep and heavily wooded on the east side
column18: where M. L. Smith's troopswere advancing
column19: but cleared and with a more gentle slope on the westside.  The troops advanced rapidly and carried the extreme end of therebel works.  Morgan L. Smith advanced to a point which cut the enemyoff from the railroad bridge and the means of bringing up supplies byrail from Chickamauga Station
