column157: and if not to abandon it. Accordingly I left Nashville in the latterpart of December by rail for Chattanooga. From Chattanooga I took one ofthe little steamers previously spoken of as having been built there
column158: and
column159: putting my horses aboard
column160: went up to the junction of the Clinchwith the Tennessee.  From that point the railroad had been repaired upto Knoxville and out east to Strawberry Plains.  I went by railtherefore to Knoxville
column161: where I remained for several days.  General JohnG. Foster was then commanding the Department of the Ohio.  It was anintensely cold winter
column162: the thermometer being down as low as zero everymorning for more than a week while I was at Knoxville and on my way fromthere on horseback to Lexington
column163: Kentucky
column164: the first point where I couldreach rail to carry me back to my headquarters at Nashville.The road over Cumberland Gap
column165: and back of it
column166: was strewn with debris ofbroken wagons and dead animals
column167: much as I had found it on my first tripto Chattanooga over Waldron's Ridge.  The road had been cut up to asgreat a depth as clay could be by mules and wagons
column168: and in thatcondition frozen; so that the ride of six days from Strawberry Plains toLexington over these holes and knobs in the road was a very cheerlessone
column169: and very disagreeable.I found a great many people at home along that route
column170: both in Tennesseeand Kentucky
column171: and
column172: almost universally
column173: intensely loyal.  They wouldcollect in little places where we would stop of evenings
column174: to see me
column175: generally hearing of my approach before we arrived.  The peoplenaturally expected to see the commanding general the oldest person inthe party.  I was then forty-one years of age
column176: while my medical directorwas gray-haired and probably twelve or more years my senior.  The crowdswould generally swarm around him
column177: and thus give me an opportunity ofquietly dismounting and getting into the house.  It also gave me anopportunity of hearing passing remarks from one spectator to anotherabout their general.  Those remarks were apt to be more complimentary tothe cause than to the appearance of the supposed general
column178: owing to hisbeing muffled up
column179: and also owing to the travel-worn condition we wereall in after a hard day's ride.  I was back in Nashville by the 13th ofJanuary
column180: 1864.When I started on this trip it was necessary for me to have some personalong who could turn dispatches into cipher
column181: and who could also read thecipher dispatches which I was liable to receive daily and almost hourly.Under the rules of the War Department at that time
column182: Mr. Stanton hadtaken entire control of the matter of regulating the telegraph anddetermining how it should be used
column183: and of saying who
column184: and who alone
column185: should have the ciphers.  The operators possessed of the ciphers
column186: aswell as the ciphers used
column187: were practically independent of the commanderswhom they were serving immediately under
column188: and had to report to the WarDepartment through General Stager all the dispatches which they receivedor forwarded.I was obliged to leave the telegraphic operator back at Nashville
column189: because that was the point at which all dispatches to me would come
column190: tobe forwarded from there.  As I have said
column191: it was necessary for me alsoto have an operator during this inspection who had possession of thiscipher to enable me to telegraph to my division and to the WarDepartment without my dispatches being read by all the operators alongthe line of wires over which they were transmitted.  Accordingly Iordered the cipher operator to turn over the key to Captain Cyrus B.Comstock
column192: of the Corps of Engineers
column193: whom I had selected as a wise anddiscreet man who certainly could be trusted with the cipher if theoperator at my headquarters could.The operator refused point blank to turn over the key to CaptainComstock as directed by me
column194: stating that his orders from the WarDepartment were not to give it to anybody--the commanding general or anyone else.  I told him I would see whether he would or not.  He said thatif he did he would be punished.  I told him if he did not he mostcertainly would be punished. Finally
column195: seeing that punishment was certainif he refused longer to obey my order
column196: and being somewhat remote (evenif he was not protected altogether from the consequences of hisdisobedience to his orders) from the War Department
column197: he yielded.  When Ireturned from Knoxville I found quite a commotion.  The operator hadbeen reprimanded very severely and ordered to be relieved.  I informedthe Secretary of War
column198: or his assistant secretary in charge of thetelegraph
column199: Stager
column200: that the man could not be relieved
column201: for he had onlyobeyed my orders.  It was absolutely necessary for me to have thecipher
column202: and the man would most certainly have been punished if he hadnot delivered it; that they would have to punish me if they punishedanybody
column203: or words to that effect.This was about the only thing approaching a disagreeable differencebetween the Secretary of War and myself that occurred until the war wasover
column204: when we had another little spat.  Owing to his natural dispositionto assume all power and control in all matters that he had anythingwhatever to do with
column205: he boldly took command of the armies
column206: and
column207: whileissuing no orders on the subject
column208: prohibited any order from me going outof the adjutant-general's office until he had approved it.  This wasdone by directing the adjutant-general to hold any orders that came fromme to be issued from the adjutant-general's office until he had examinedthem and given his approval.  He never disturbed himself
column209: either
column210: inexamining my orders until it was entirely convenient for him; so thatorders which I had prepared would often lie there three or four daysbefore he would sanction them.  I remonstrated against this in writing
column211: and the Secretary apologetically restored me to my rightful position ofGeneral-in-Chief of the Army.  But he soon lapsed again and took controlmuch as before.After the relief of Knoxville Sherman had proposed to Burnside that heshould go with him to drive Longstreet out of Tennessee; but Burnsideassured him that with the troops which had been brought by Granger
column212: andwhich were to be left
column213: he would be amply prepared to dispose ofLongstreet without availing himself of this offer.  As before statedSherman's command had left their camps north of the Tennessee
column214: nearChattanooga
column215: with two days' rations in their haversacks
column216: without coatsor blankets
column217: and without many wagons
column218: expecting to return to their campsby the end of that time.  The weather was now cold and they weresuffering
column219: but still they were ready to make the further sacrifice
column220: hadit been required
column221: for the good of the cause which had brought them intoservice.  Sherman
column222: having accomplished the object for which he was sent
column223: marched back leisurely to his old camp on the Tennessee River.

column1: ISFP	 XLVI.OPERATIONS IN MISSISSIPPI--LONGSTREET IN EAST TENNESSEE--COMMISSIONEDLIEUTENANT-GENERAL--COMMANDING THE ARMIES OF THE UNITED STATES--FIRSTINTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT LINCOLN.Soon after his return from Knoxville I ordered Sherman to distribute hisforces from Stevenson to Decatur and thence north to Nashville; Shermansuggested that he be permitted to go back to Mississippi
column2: to the limitsof his own department and where most of his army still remained
column3: for thepurpose of clearing out what Confederates might still be left on theeast bank of the Mississippi River to impede its navigation by ourboats.  He expected also to have the co-operation of Banks to do thesame thing on the west shore.  Of course I approved heartily.About the 10th of January Sherman was back in Memphis
column4: where Hurlbutcommanded
column5: and got together his Memphis men
column6: or ordered them collectedand sent to Vicksburg.  He then went to Vicksburg and out to whereMcPherson was in command
column7: and had him organize his surplus troops so asto give him about 20
column8: 000 men in all.Sherman knew that General (Bishop) Polk was occupying Meridian with hisheadquarters
column9: and had two divisions of infantry with a considerableforce of cavalry scattered west of him.  He determined
column10: therefore
column11: tomove directly upon Meridian.I had sent some 2
column12: 500 cavalry under General Sooy Smith to Sherman'sdepartment
column13: and they had mostly arrived before Sherman got to Memphis.Hurlbut had 7
column14: 000 cavalry
column15: and Sherman ordered him to reinforce Smith soas to give the latter a force of about 7
column16: 000 with which to go againstForrest
column17: who was then known to be south-east from Memphis.  Smith wasordered to move about the 1st of February.While Sherman was waiting at Vicksburg for the arrival of Hurlbut withhis surplus men
column18: he sent out scouts to ascertain the position andstrength of the enemy and to bring back all the information they couldgather.  When these scouts returned it was through them that he got theinformation of General Polk's being at Meridian
column19: and of the strength anddisposition of his command.Forrest had about 4
column20: 000 cavalry with him
column21: composed of thoroughlywell-disciplined men
column22: who under so able a leader were very effective.Smith's command was nearly double that of Forrest
column23: but not equal
column24: man toman
column25: for the lack of a successful experience such as Forrest's men hadhad.  The fact is
column26: troops who have fought a few battles and won
column27: andfollowed up their victories
column28: improve upon what they were before to anextent that can hardly be counted by percentage.  The difference inresult is often decisive victory instead of inglorious defeat.  Thissame difference
column29: too
column30: is often due to the way troops are officered
column31: andfor the particular kind of warfare which Forrest had carried on neitherarmy could present a more effective officer than he was.Sherman got off on the 3d of February and moved out on his expedition
column32: meeting with no opposition whatever until he crossed the Big Black
column33: andwith no great deal of opposition after that until he reached Jackson
column34: Mississippi.  This latter place he reached on the 6th or 7th
column35: Brandon onthe 8th
column36: and Morton on the 9th.  Up to this time he moved in two columnsto enable him to get a good supply of forage
column37: etc.
column38: and expedite themarch. Here
column39: however
column40: there were indications of the concentration ofConfederate infantry
column41: and he was obliged to keep his army closetogether.  He had no serious engagement; but he met some of the enemywho destroyed a few of his wagons about Decatur
column42: Mississippi
column43: where
column44: bythe way
column45: Sherman himself came near being picked up.He entered Meridian on the 14th of the month
column46: the enemy having retreatedtoward Demopolis
column47: Alabama. He spent several days in Meridian inthoroughly destroying the railroad to the north and south
column48: and also forthe purpose of hearing from Sooy Smith
column49: who he supposed had met Forrestbefore this time and he hoped had gained a decisive victory because of asuperiority of numbers. Hearing nothing of him
column50: however
column51: he started onhis return trip to Vicksburg.  There he learned that Smith
column52: whilewaiting for a few of his men who had been ice-bound in the Ohio River
column53: instead of getting off on the 1st as expected
column54: had not left until the11th.  Smith did meet Forrest
column55: but the result was decidedly in Forrest'sfavor.Sherman had written a letter to Banks
column56: proposing a co-operative movementwith him against Shreveport
column57: subject to my approval.  I disapproved ofSherman's going himself
column58: because I had other important work for him todo
column59: but consented that he might send a few troops to the aid of Banks
column60: though their time to remain absent must be limited.  We must have themfor the spring campaign.  The trans-Mississippi movement provedabortive.My eldest son
column61: who had accompanied me on the Vicksburg campaign andsiege
column62: had while there contracted disease
column63: which grew worse
column64: until hehad grown so dangerously ill that on the 24th of January I obtainedpermission to go to St. Louis
column65: where he was staying at the time
column66: to seehim
column67: hardly expecting to find him alive on my arrival.  While I waspermitted to go
column68: I was not permitted to turn over my command to any oneelse
column69: but was directed to keep the headquarters with me and tocommunicate regularly with all parts of my division and with Washington
column70: just as though I had remained at Nashville.When I obtained this leave I was at Chattanooga
column71: having gone there againto make preparations to have the troops of Thomas in the southern partof Tennessee co-operate with Sherman's movement in Mississippi.  Idirected Thomas
column72: and Logan who was at Scottsboro
column73: Alabama
column74: to keep up athreatening movement to the south against J. E. Johnston
column75: who had againrelieved Bragg
column76: for the purpose of making him keep as many troops aspossible there.I learned through Confederate sources that Johnston had already sent twodivisions in the direction of Mobile
column77: presumably to operate againstSherman
column78: and two more divisions to Longstreet in East Tennessee.  Seeingthat Johnston had depleted in this way
column79: I directed Thomas to send atleast ten thousand men
column80: besides Stanley's division which was already tothe east
column81: into East Tennessee
column82: and notified Schofield
column83: who was now incommand in East Tennessee
column84: of this movement of troops into hisdepartment and also of the reinforcements Longstreet had received.  Myobject was to drive Longstreet out of East Tennessee as a part of thepreparations for my spring campaign.About this time General Foster
column85: who had been in command of theDepartment of the Ohio after Burnside until Schofield relieved him(*21)
column86: advised me that he thought it would be a good thing to keepLongstreet just where he was; that he was perfectly quiet in EastTennessee
column87: and if he was forced to leave there
column88: his whole well-equippedarmy would be free to go to any place where it could effect the most fortheir cause.  I thought the advice was good
column89: and
column90: adopting that view
column91: countermanded the orders for pursuit of Longstreet.On the 12th of February I ordered Thomas to take Dalton and hold it
column92: ifpossible; and I directed him to move without delay. Finding that he hadnot moved
column93: on the 17th I urged him again to start
column94: telling him howimportant it was
column95: that the object of the movement was to co-operate withSherman
column96: who was moving eastward and might be in danger.  Then again onthe 21st
column97: he not yet having started
column98: I asked him if he could not startthe next day.  He finally got off on the 22d or 23d.  The enemy fellback from his front without a battle
column99: but took a new position quite asstrong and farther to the rear.  Thomas reported that he could not goany farther
column100: because it was impossible with his poor teams
column101: nearlystarved
column102: to keep up supplies until the railroads were repaired.  He soonfell back.Schofield also had to return for the same reason.  He could not carrysupplies with him
column103: and Longstreet was between him and the supplies stillleft in the country.  Longstreet
column104: in his retreat
column105: would be movingtowards his supplies
column106: while our forces
column107: following
column108: would be recedingfrom theirs.  On the 2d of March
column109: however
column110: I learned of Sherman'ssuccess
column111: which eased my mind very much.  The next day
column112: the 3d
column113: I wasordered to Washington.The bill restoring the grade of lieutenant-general of the army hadpassed through Congress and became a law on the 26th of February.  Mynomination had been sent to the Senate on the 1st of March and confirmedthe next day (the 2d).  I was ordered to Washington on the 3d to receivemy commission
column114: and started the day following that.  The commission washanded to me on the 9th.  It was delivered to me at the ExecutiveMansion by President Lincoln in the presence of his Cabinet
column115: my eldestson
column116: those of my staff who were with me and and a few other visitors.The President in presenting my commission read from a paper--stating
column117: however
column118: as a preliminary
column119: and prior to the delivery of it
column120: that he haddrawn that up on paper
column121: knowing my disinclination to speak in public
column122: and handed me a copy in advance so that I might prepare a few lines ofreply.  The President said:'General Grant
column123: the nation's appreciation of what you have done
column124: and itsreliance upon you for what remains to be done in the existing greatstruggle
column125: are now presented
column126: with this commission constituting youlieutenant-general in the Army of the United States.  With this highhonor
column127: devolves upon you
column128: also
column129: a corresponding responsibility.  As thecountry herein trusts you
column130: so
column131: under God
column132: it will sustain you.  Iscarcely need to add
column133: that
column134: with what I here speak for the nation
column135: goesmy own hearty personal concurrence.'To this I replied:  'Mr. President
column136: I accept the commission
column137: withgratitude for the high honor conferred.  With the aid of the noblearmies that have fought in so many fields for our common country
column138: itwill be my earnest endeavor not to disappoint your expectations.  I feelthe full weight of the responsibilities now devolving on me; and I knowthat if they are met
column139: it will be due to those armies
column140: and above all
column141: tothe favor of that Providence which leads both nations and men.'On the 10th I visited the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac atBrandy Station; then returned to Washington
column142: and pushed west at once tomake my arrangements for turning over the commands there and givinggeneral directions for the preparations to be made for the springcampaign.It had been my intention before this to remain in the West
column143: even if Iwas made lieutenant-general; but when I got to Washington and saw thesituation it was plain that here was the point for the commandinggeneral to be.  No one else could
column144: probably
column145: resist the pressure thatwould be brought to bear upon him to desist from his own plans andpursue others.  I determined
column146: therefore
column147: before I started back to haveSherman advanced to my late position
column148: McPherson to Sherman's in commandof the department
column149: and Logan to the command of McPherson's corps. Thesechanges were all made on my recommendation and without hesitation.  Mycommission as lieutenant-general was given to me on the 9th of March
column150: 1864.  On the following day
column151: as already stated
column152: I visited General Meade
column153: commanding the Army of the Potomac
column154: at his headquarters at BrandyStation
column155: north of the Rapidan.  I had known General Meade slightly inthe Mexican war
column156: but had not met him since until this visit.  I was astranger to most of the Army of the Potomac
column157: I might say to all exceptthe officers of the regular army who had served in the Mexican war.There had been some changes ordered in the organization of that armybefore my promotion.  One was the consolidation of five corps intothree
column158: thus throwing some officers of rank out of important commands.Meade evidently thought that I might want to make still one more changenot yet ordered.  He said to me that I might want an officer who hadserved with me in the West
column159: mentioning Sherman specially
column160: to take hisplace.  If so
column161: he begged me not to hesitate about making the change.  Heurged that the work before us was of such vast importance to the wholenation that the feeling or wishes of no one person should stand in theway of selecting the right men for all positions.  For himself
column162: he wouldserve to the best of his ability wherever placed.  I assured him that Ihad no thought of substituting any one for him.  As to Sherman
column163: he couldnot be spared from the West.This incident gave me even a more favorable opinion of Meade than didhis great victory at Gettysburg the July before.  It is men who wait tobe selected
column164: and not those who seek
column165: from whom we may always expect themost efficient service.Meade's position afterwards proved embarrassing to me if not to him.  Hewas commanding an army and
column166: for nearly a year previous to my takingcommand of all the armies
column167: was in supreme command of the Army of thePotomac--except from the authorities at Washington.  All other generalofficers occupying similar positions were independent in their commandsso far as any one present with them was concerned.  I tried to makeGeneral Meade's position as nearly as possible what it would have beenif I had been in Washington or any other place away from his command.  Itherefore gave all orders for the movements of the Army of the Potomacto Meade to have them executed.  To avoid the necessity of having togive orders direct
column168: I established my headquarters near his
column169: unless therewere reasons for locating them elsewhere.  This sometimes happened
column170: andI had on occasions to give orders direct to the troops affected.  On the11th I returned to Washington and
column171: on the day after
column172: orders werepublished by the War Department placing me in command of all the armies.I had left Washington the night before to return to my old command inthe West and to meet Sherman whom I had telegraphed to join me inNashville.Sherman assumed command of the military division of the Mississippi onthe 18th of March
column173: and we left Nashville together for Cincinnati.  I hadSherman accompany me that far on my way back to Washington so that wecould talk over the matters about which I wanted to see him
column174: withoutlosing any more time from my new command than was necessary.  The firstpoint which I wished to discuss was particularly about the co-operationof his command with mine when the spring campaign should commence. Therewere also other and minor points
column175: minor as compared with the greatimportance of the question to be decided by sanguinary war--therestoration to duty of officers who had been relieved from importantcommands
column176: namely McClellan
column177: Burnside and Fremont in the East
column178: and Buell
column179: McCook
column180: Negley and Crittenden in the West.Some time in the winter of 1863-64 I had been invited by thegeneral-in-chief to give my views of the campaign I thought advisablefor the command under me--now Sherman's.  General J. E. Johnston wasdefending Atlanta and the interior of Georgia with an army
column181: the largESTJart of which was stationed at Dalton
column182: about 38 miles south ofChattanooga. Dalton is at the junction of the railroad from Clevelandwith the one from Chattanooga to Atlanta.There could have been no difference of opinion as to the first duty ofthe armies of the military division of the Mississippi.  Johnston's armywas the first objective
column183: and that important railroad centre
column184: Atlanta
column185: the second.  At the time I wrote General Halleck giving my views of theapproaching campaign
column186: and at the time I met General Sherman
column187: it wasexpected that General Banks would be through with the campaign which hehad been ordered upon before my appointment to the command of all thearmies
column188: and would be ready to co-operate with the armies east of theMississippi
column189: his part in the programme being to move upon Mobile by landwhile the navy would close the harbor and assist to the best of itsability. (*22) The plan therefore was for Sherman to attack Johnston anddestroy his army if possible
column190: to capture Atlanta and hold it
column191: and withhis troops and those of Banks to hold a line through to Mobile
column192: or atleast to hold Atlanta and command the railroad running east and west
column193: and the troops from one or other of the armies to hold important pointson the southern road
column194: the only east and west road that would be left inthe possession of the enemy.  This would cut the Confederacy in twoagain
column195: as our gaining possession of the Mississippi River had donebefore.  Banks was not ready in time for the part assigned to him
column196: andcircumstances that could not be foreseen determined the campaign whichwas afterwards made
column197: the success and grandeur of which has resoundedthroughout all lands.In regard to restoring officers who had been relieved from importantcommands to duty again
column198: I left Sherman to look after those who had beenremoved in the West while I looked out for the rest.  I directed
column199: however
column200: that he should make no assignment until I could speak to theSecretary of War about the matter.  I shortly after recommended to theSecretary the assignment of General Buell to duty.  I received theassurance that duty would be offered to him; and afterwards theSecretary told me that he had offered Buell an assignment and that thelatter had declined it
column201: saying that it would be degradation to acceptthe assignment offered.  I understood afterwards that he refused toserve under either Sherman or Canby because he had ranked them both.Both graduated before him and ranked him in the old army.  Shermanranked him as a brigadier-general.  All of them ranked me in the oldarmy
column202: and Sherman and Buell did as brigadiers.  The worst excuse asoldier can make for declining service is that he once ranked thecommander he is ordered to report to.On the 23d of March I was back in Washington
column203: and on the 26th took up myheadquarters at Culpeper Court-House
column204: a few miles south of theheadquarters of the Army of the Potomac.Although hailing from Illinois myself
column205: the State of the President
column206: Inever met Mr. Lincoln until called to the capital to receive mycommission as lieutenant-general.  I knew him
column207: however
column208: very well andfavorably from the accounts given by officers under me at the West whohad known him all their lives.  I had also read the remarkable series ofdebates between Lincoln and Douglas a few years before
column209: when they wererival candidates for the United States Senate.  I was then a resident ofMissouri
column210: and by no means a 'Lincoln man' in that contest; but Irecognized then his great ability.In my first interview with Mr. Lincoln alone he stated to me that he hadnever professed to be a military man or to know how campaigns should beconducted
column211: and never wanted to interfere in them:  but thatprocrastination on the part of commanders
column212: and the pressure from thepeople at the North and Congress
column213: WHICH WAS ALWAYS WITH HIM
column214: forced himinto issuing his series of 'Military Orders'--one
column215: two
column216: three
column217: etc.  Hedid not know but they were all wrong
column218: and did know that some of themwere.  All he wanted or had ever wanted was some one who would take theresponsibility and act
column219: and call on him for all the assistance needed
column220: pledging himself to use all the power of the government in renderingsuch assistance.  Assuring him that I would do the best I could with themeans at hand
column221: and avoid as far as possible annoying him or the WarDepartment
column222: our first interview ended.The Secretary of War I had met once before only
column223: but felt that I knewhim better.While commanding in West Tennessee we had occasionally heldconversations over the wires
column224: at night
column225: when they were not beingotherwise used.  He and General Halleck both cautioned me against givingthe President my plans of campaign
column226: saying that he was so kind-hearted
column227: so averse to refusing anything asked of him
column228: that some friend would besure to get from him all he knew.  I should have said that in ourinterview the President told me he did not want to know what I proposedto do.  But he submitted a plan of campaign of his own which he wantedme to hear and then do as I pleased about.  He brought out a map ofVirginia on which he had evidently marked every position occupied by theFederal and Confederate armies up to that time.  He pointed out on themap two streams which empty into the Potomac
column229: and suggested that thearmy might be moved on boats and landed between the mouths of thesestreams.  We would then have the Potomac to bring our supplies
column230: and thetributaries would protect our flanks while we moved out.  I listenedrespectfully
column231: but did not suggest that the same streams would protectLee's flanks while he was shutting us up.I did not communicate my plans to the President
column232: nor did I to theSecretary of War or to General Halleck.March the 26th my headquarters were
column233: as stated
column234: at Culpeper
column235: and thework of preparing for an early campaign commenced.

column1: ISFP	 XLVII.THE MILITARY SITUATION--PLANS FOR THE CAMPAIGN--SHERIDAN ASSIGNED TOCOMMAND OF THE CAVALRY--FLANK MOVEMENTS--FORREST AT FORT PILLOW--GENERALBANKS'S EXPEDITION--COLONEL MOSBY--AN INCIDENT OF THE WILDERNESSCAMPAIGN.When I assumed command of all the armies the situation was about this:the Mississippi River was guarded from St. Louis to its mouth; the lineof the Arkansas was held
column2: thus giving us all the North-west north ofthat river.  A few points in Louisiana not remote from the river wereheld by the Federal troops
column3: as was also the mouth of the Rio Grande.East of the Mississippi we held substantially all north of the Memphisand Charleston Railroad as far east as Chattanooga
column4: thence along theline of the Tennessee and Holston rivers
column5: taking in nearly all of theState of Tennessee.  West Virginia was in our hands; and that part ofold Virginia north of the Rapidan and east of the Blue Ridge we alsoheld.  On the sea-coast we had Fortress Monroe and Norfolk in Virginia;Plymouth
column6: Washington and New Berne in North Carolina; Beaufort
column7: Follyand Morris islands
column8: Hilton Head
column9: Port Royal and Fort Pulaski in SouthCarolina and Georgia; Fernandina
column10: St. Augustine
column11: Key West and Pensacolain Florida. The balance of the Southern territory
column12: an empire in extent
column13: was still in the hands of the enemy.Sherman
column14: who had succeeded me in the command of the military division ofthe Mississippi
column15: commanded all the troops in the territory west of theAlleghanies and north of Natchez
column16: with a large movable force aboutChattanooga. His command was subdivided into four departments
column17: but thecommanders all reported to Sherman and were subject to his orders.  Thisarrangement
column18: however
column19: insured the better protection of all lines ofcommunication through the acquired territory
column20: for the reason that thesedifferent department commanders could act promptly in case of a suddenor unexpected raid within their respective jurisdictions withoutawaiting the orders of the division commander.In the East the opposing forces stood in substantially the samerelations towards each other as three years before
column21: or when the warbegan; they were both between the Federal and Confederate capitals.  Itis true
column22: footholds had been secured by us on the sea-coast
column23: in Virginiaand North Carolina
column24: but
column25: beyond that
column26: no substantial advantage had beengained by either side.  Battles had been fought of as great severity ashad ever been known in war
column27: over ground from the James River andChickahominy
column28: near Richmond
column29: to Gettysburg and Chambersburg
column30: inPennsylvania
column31: with indecisive results
column32: sometimes favorable to theNational army

column108: have passed through the inner ones.  But having no supports nearhe could not have remained.  After caring for his wounded he struck forthe James River below the city
column109: to communicate with Butler and to resthis men and horses as well as to get food and forage for them.He moved first between the Chickahominy and the James
column110: but in themorning (the 12th) he was stopped by batteries at Mechanicsville.  Hethen turned to cross to the north side of the Chickahominy by MeadowBridge.  He found this barred
column111: and the defeated Confederate cavalry
column112: reorganized
column113: occupying the opposite side.  The panic created by hisfirst entrance within the outer works of Richmond having subsided troopswere sent out to attack his rear.He was now in a perilous position
column114: one from which but few generals couldhave extricated themselves.  The defences of Richmond
column115: manned
column116: were tothe right
column117: the Chickahominy was to the left with no bridge remaining andthe opposite bank guarded
column118: to the rear was a force from Richmond.  Thisforce was attacked and beaten by Wilson's and Gregg's divisions
column119: whileSheridan turned to the left with the remaining division and hastilybuilt a bridge over the Chickahominy under the fire of the enemy
column120: forceda crossing and soon dispersed the Confederates he found there. The enemywas held back from the stream by the fire of the troops not engaged inbridge building.On the 13th Sheridan was at Bottom's Bridge
column121: over the Chickahominy.  Onthe 14th he crossed this stream and on that day went into camp on theJames River at Haxall's Landing.  He at once put himself intocommunication with General Butler
column122: who directed all the supplies hewanted to be furnished.Sheridan had left the Army of the Potomac at Spottsylvania
column123: but did notknow where either this or Lee's army was now.  Great caution thereforehad to be exercised in getting back.  On the 17th
column124: after resting hiscommand for three days
column125: he started on his return.  He moved by the wayof White House.  The bridge over the Pamunkey had been burned by theenemy
column126: but a new one was speedily improvised and the cavalry crossedover it.  On the 22d he was at Aylett's on the Matapony
column127: where helearned the position of the two armies.  On the 24th he joined us on themarch from North Anna to Cold Harbor
column128: in the vicinity of Chesterfield.Sheridan in this memorable raid passed entirely around Lee's army:encountered his cavalry in four engagements
column129: and defeated them in all;recaptured four hundred Union prisoners and killed and captured many ofthe enemy; destroyed and used many supplies and munitions of war;destroyed miles of railroad and telegraph
column130: and freed us from annoyanceby the cavalry of the enemy for more than two weeks.

column1: ISFP	 XLIX.SHERMAN'S CAMPAIGN IN GEORGIA--SIEGE OF ATLANTA--DEATH OF GENERALMCPHERSON--ATTEMPT TO CAPTURE ANDERSONVILLE--CAPTURE OF ATLANTA.After separating from Sherman in Cincinnati I went on to Washington
column2: asalready stated
column3: while he returned to Nashville to assume the duties ofhis new command.  His military division was now composed of fourdepartments and embraced all the territory west of the AlleghanyMountains and east of the Mississippi River
column4: together with the State ofArkansas in the trans-Mississippi.  The most easterly of these was theDepartment of the Ohio
column5: General Schofield commanding; the next was theDepartment of the Cumberland
column6: General Thomas commanding; the third theDepartment of the Tennessee
column7: General McPherson commanding; and GeneralSteele still commanded the trans-Mississippi
column8: or Department of Arkansas.The last-named department was so far away that Sherman could notcommunicate with it very readily after starting on his spring campaign
column9: and it was therefore soon transferred from his military division to thatof the Gulf
column10: where General Canby
column11: who had relieved General Banks
column12: was incommand.The movements of the armies
column13: as I have stated in a former chapter
column14: wereto be simultaneous
column15: I fixing the day to start when the season should befar enough advanced
column16: it was hoped
column17: for the roads to be in a conditionfor the troops to march.General Sherman at once set himself to work preparing for the task whichwas assigned him to accomplish in the spring campaign.  McPherson lay atHuntsville with about twenty-four thousand men
column18: guarding those points ofTennessee which were regarded as most worth holding; Thomas
column19: with oversixty thousand men of the Army of the Cumberland
column20: was at Chattanooga;and Schofield
column21: with about fourteen thousand men
column22: was at Knoxville. Withthese three armies
column23: numbering about one hundred thousand men in all
column24: Sherman was to move on the day fixed for the general advance
column25: with aview of destroying Johnston's army and capturing Atlanta. He visitedeach of these commands to inform himself as to their condition
column26: and itwas found to be
column27: speaking generally
column28: good.One of the first matters to turn his attention to was that of getting
column29: before the time arrived for starting
column30: an accumulation of suppliesforward to Chattanooga
column31: sufficiently large to warrant a movement.  Hefound
column32: when he got to that place
column33: that the trains over the single-trackrailroad
column34: which was frequently interrupted for a day or two at a time
column35: were only sufficient to meet the daily wants of the troops withoutbringing forward any surplus of any kind.  He found
column36: however
column37: thattrains were being used to transport all the beef cattle
column38: horses for thecavalry
column39: and even teams that were being brought to the front.  He atonce changed all this
column40: and required beef cattle
column41: teams
column42: cavalry horses
column43: and everything that could travel
column44: even the troops
column45: to be marched
column46: andused the road exclusively for transporting supplies.  In this way he wasable to accumulate an abundance before the time finally fixed upon forthe move
column47: the 4th of May.As I have said already
column48: Johnston was at Dalton
column49: which was nearlyone-fourth of the way between Chattanooga and Atlanta. The country ismountainous all the way to Atlanta
column50: abounding in mountain streams
column51: someof them of considerable volume.  Dalton is on ground where water drainstowards Atlanta and into one of the main streams rising north-east fromthere and flowing south-west--this being the general direction which allthe main streams of that section take
column52: with smaller tributaries enteringinto them.  Johnston had been preparing himself for this campaign duringthe entire winter.  The best positions for defence had been selected allthe way from Dalton back to Atlanta
column53: and very strongly intrenched; sothat
column54: as he might be forced to fall back from one position
column55: he wouldhave another to fall into in his rear.  His position at Dalton was sovery strongly intrenched that no doubt he expected
column56: or at least hoped
column57: to hold Sherman there and prevent him from getting any further.  With aless skilful general
column58: and one disposed to take no risks
column59: I have no doubtthat he would have succeeded.Sherman's plan was to start Schofield
column60: who was farthest back
column61: a few daysin advance from Knoxville
column62: having him move on the direct road to Dalton.Thomas was to move out to Ringgold.  It had been Sherman's intention tocross McPherson over the Tennessee River at Huntsville or Decatur
column63: andmove him south from there so as to have him come into the road runningfrom Chattanooga to Atlanta a good distance to the rear of the pointJohnston was occupying; but when that was contemplated it was hoped thatMcPherson alone would have troops enough to cope with Johnston
column64: if thelatter should move against him while unsupported by the balance of thearmy.  In this he was disappointed.  Two of McPherson's veterandivisions had re-enlisted on the express provision that they were tohave a furlough.  This furlough had not yet expired
column65: and they were notback.Then
column66: again
column67: Sherman had lent Banks two divisions under A. J. Smith
column68: thewinter before
column69: to co-operate with the trans-Mississippi forces
column70: and thiswith the express pledge that they should be back by a time specified
column71: soas to be prepared for this very campaign.  It is hardly necessary to saythey were not returned.  That department continued to absorb troops tono purpose to the end of the war.  This left McPherson so weak that thepart of the plan above indicated had to be changed.  He was thereforebrought up to Chattanooga and moved from there on a road to the right ofThomas--the two coming together about Dalton.  The three armies wereabreast
column72: all ready to start promptly on time.Sherman soon found that Dalton was so strongly fortified that it wasuseless to make any attempt to carry it by assault; and even to carry itby regular approaches was impracticable.  There was a narrowing up inthe mountain
column73: between the National and Confederate armies
column74: through whicha stream
column75: a wagon road and a railroad ran.  Besides
column76: the stream had beendammed so that the valley was a lake.  Through this gorge the troopswould have to pass.  McPherson was therefore sent around by the right
column77: to come out by the way of Snake Creek Gap into the rear of the enemy.This was a surprise to Johnston
column78: and about the 13th he decided toabandon his position at Dalton.On the 15th there was very hard fighting about Resaca; but our cavalryhaving been sent around to the right got near the road in the enemy'srear.  Again Johnston fell back
column79: our army pursuing.  The pursuit wascontinued to Kingston
column80: which was reached on the 19th with very littlefighting
column81: except that Newton's division overtook the rear of Johnston'sarmy and engaged it.  Sherman was now obliged to halt for the purpose ofbringing up his railroad trains.  He was depending upon the railroad forall of his supplies
column82: and as of course the railroad was wholly destroyedas Johnston fell back
column83: it had to be rebuilt.  This work was pushedforward night and day
column84: and caused much less delay than most personswould naturally expect in a mountainous country where there were so manybridges to be rebuilt.The campaign to Atlanta was managed with the most consummate skill
column85: theenemy being flanked out of one position after another all the way there.It is true this was not accomplished without a good deal of fighting--some of it very hard fighting
column86: rising to the dignity of very importantbattles--neither were single positions gained in a day.  On thecontrary
column87: weeks were spent at some; and about Atlanta more than a monthwas consumed.It was the 23d of May before the road was finished up to the rear ofSherman's army and the pursuit renewed.  This pursuit brought him up tothe vicinity of Allatoona. This place was very strongly intrenched
column88: andnaturally a very defensible position. An assault upon it was not thoughtof
column89: but preparations were made to flank the enemy out of it.  This wasdone by sending a large force around our right
column90: by the way of Dallas
column91: toreach the rear of the enemy.  Before reaching there
column92: however
column93: they foundthe enemy fortified in their way
column94: and there resulted hard fighting forabout a week at a place called New Hope Church.  On the left our troopsalso were fortified
column95: and as close up to the enemy as they could get.They kept working still farther around to the left toward the railroad.This was the case more particularly with the cavalry.  By the 4th ofJune Johnston found that he was being hemmed in so rapidly that he drewoff and Allatoona was left in our possession.Allatoona
column96: being an important place
column97: was strongly intrenched foroccupation by our troops before advancing farther
column98: and made a secondarybase of supplies.  The railroad was finished up to that point
column99: theintrenchments completed
column100: storehouses provided for food
column101: and the army gotin readiness for a further advance. The rains
column102: however
column103: were falling insuch torrents that it was impossible to move the army by the side roadswhich they would have to move upon in order to turn Johnston out of hisnew position.While Sherman's army lay here
column104: General F. P. Blair returned to it
column105: bringing with him the two divisions of veterans who had been onfurlough.Johnston had fallen back to Marietta and Kenesaw Mountain
column106: where strongintrenchments awaited him.  At this latter place our troops made anassault upon the enemy's lines after having got their own lines up closeto him
column107: and failed
column108: sustaining considerable loss.  But during theprogress of the battle Schofield was gaining ground to the left; and thecavalry on his left were gaining still more toward the enemy's rear.These operations were completed by the 3d of July
column109: when it was foundthat Johnston had evacuated the place.  He was pursued at once.  Shermanhad made every preparation to abandon the railroad
column110: leaving a strongguard in his intrenchments.  He had intended
column111: moving out with twentydays' rations and plenty of ammunition
column112: to come in on the railroad againat the Chattahoochee River.  Johnston frustrated this plan by himselfstarting back as above stated.  This time he fell back to theChattahoochee.About the 5th of July he was besieged again
column113: Sherman getting easypossession of the Chattahoochee River both above and below him.  Theenemy was again flanked out of his position
column114: or so frightened byflanking movements that on the night of the 9th he fell back across theriver.Here Johnston made a stand until the 17th
column115: when Sherman's old tacticsprevailed again and the final movement toward Atlanta began.  Johnstonwas now relieved of the command
column116: and Hood superseded him.Johnston's tactics in this campaign do not seem to have met with muchfavor
column117: either in the eyes of the administration at Richmond
column118: or of thepeople of that section of the South in which he was commanding.  Thevery fact of a change of commanders being ordered under suchcircumstances was an indication of a change of policy
column119: and that now theywould become the aggressors--the very thing our troops wanted.For my own part
column120: I think that Johnston's tactics were right. Anythingthat could have prolonged the war a year beyond the time that it didfinally close
column121: would probably have exhausted the North to such an extentthat they might then have abandoned the contest and agreed to aseparation.Atlanta was very strongly intrenched all the way around in a circleabout a mile and a half outside of the city.  In addition to this
column122: therewere advanced intrenchments which had to be taken before a close siegecould be commenced.Sure enough
column123: as indicated by the change of commanders
column124: the enemy wasabout to assume the offensive.  On the 20th he came out and attacked theArmy of the Cumberland most furiously.  Hooker's corps
column125: and Newton's andJohnson's divisions were the principal ones engaged in this contest
column126: which lasted more than an hour; but the Confederates were then forced tofall back inside their main lines.  The losses were quite heavy on bothsides.  On this day General Gresham
column127: since our Postmaster-General
column128: wasvery badly wounded.  During the night Hood abandoned his outer lines
column129: and our troops were advanced.  The investment had not been relinquishedfor a moment during the day.During the night of the 21st Hood moved out again
column130: passing by our leftflank
column131: which was then in motion to get a position farther in rear ofhim
column132: and a desperate battle ensued
column133: which lasted most of the day of the22d.  At first the battle went very much in favor of the Confederates
column134: our troops being somewhat surprised.  While our troops were advancingthey were struck in flank
column135: and their flank was enveloped.  But they hadbecome too thorough veterans to be thrown into irreparable confusion byan unexpected attack when off their guard
column136: and soon they were in orderand engaging the enemy
column137: with the advantage now of knowing where theirantagonist was.  The field of battle continued to expand until itembraced about seven miles of ground.  Finally
column138: however
column139: and beforenight
column140: the enemy was driven back into the city (*26).It was during this battle that McPherson
column141: while passing from one columnto another
column142: was instantly killed.  In his death the army lost one of itsablest
column143: purest and best generals.Garrard had been sent out with his cavalry to get upon the railroad eastof Atlanta and to cut it in the direction of Augusta. He was successfulin this
column144: and returned about the time of the battle.  Rousseau had alsocome up from Tennessee with a small division of cavalry
column145: having crossedthe Tennessee River about Decatur and made a raid into Alabama. Finally
column146: when hard pressed
column147: he had come in
column148: striking the railroad in rear ofSherman
column149: and reported to him about this time.The battle of the 22d is usually known as the Battle of Atlanta
column150: although the city did not fall into our hands until the 2d of September.Preparations went on
column151: as before
column152: to flank the enemy out of his position.The work was tedious
column153: and the lines that had to be maintained were verylong.  Our troops were gradually worked around to the east until theystruck the road between Decatur and Atlanta. These lines were stronglyfortified
column154: as were those to the north and west of the city--all as closeup to the enemy's lines as practicable--in order to hold them with thesmallest possible number of men
column155: the design being to detach an army tomove by our right and try to get upon the railroad down south ofAtlanta.On the 27th the movement by the right flank commenced.  On the 28th theenemy struck our right flank
column156: General Logan commanding
column157: with greatvigor.  Logan intrenched himself hastily
column158: and by that means was enabledto resist all assaults and inflict a great deal of damage upon theenemy.  These assaults were continued to the middle of the afternoon
column159: and resumed once or twice still later in the day.  The enemy's losses inthese unsuccessful assaults were fearful.During that evening the enemy in Logan's front withdrew into the town.This now left Sherman's army close up to the Confederate lines
column160: extending from a point directly east of the city around by the north andwest of it for a distance of fully ten miles; the whole of this linebeing intrenched
column161: and made stronger every day they remained there.In the latter part of July Sherman sent Stoneman to destroy therailroads to the south
column162: about Macon.  He was then to go east and
column163: ifpossible
column164: release our prisoners about Andersonville. There were painfulstories current at the time about the great hardships these prisonershad to endure in the way of general bad treatment
column165: in the way in whichthey were housed
column166: and in the way in which they were fed.  Great sympathywas felt for them; and it was thought that even if they could be turnedloose upon the country it would be a great relief to them.  But theattempt proved a failure.  McCook
column167: who commanded a small brigade
column168: wasfirst reported to have been captured; but he got back
column169: having inflicteda good deal of damage upon the enemy.  He had also taken some prisoners;but encountering afterwards a largely superior force of the enemy he wasobliged to drop his prisoners and get back as best he could with whatmen he had left.  He had lost several hundred men out of his smallcommand.  On the 4th of August Colonel Adams
column170: commanding a littlebrigade of about a thousand men
column171: returned reporting Stoneman and all buthimself as lost.  I myself had heard around Richmond of the capture ofStoneman
column172: and had sent Sherman word
column173: which he received.  The rumor wasconfirmed there
column174: also
column175: from other sources.  A few days after ColonelAdams's return Colonel Capron also got in with a small detachment andconfirmed the report of the capture of Stoneman with something less thana thousand men.It seems that Stoneman
column176: finding the escape of all his force wasimpossible
column177: had made arrangements for the escape of two divisions.  Hecovered the movement of these divisions to the rear with a force ofabout seven hundred men
column178: and at length surrendered himself and thisdetachment to the commanding Confederate.  In this raid
column179: however
column180: muchdamage was inflicted upon the enemy by the destruction of cars
column181: locomotives
column182: army wagons
column183: manufactories of military supplies
column184: etc.On the 4th and 5th Sherman endeavored to get upon the railroad to ourright
column185: where Schofield was in command
column186: but these attempts failedutterly.  General Palmer was charged with being the cause of thisfailure
column187: to a great extent
column188: by both General Sherman and GeneralSchofield; but I am not prepared to say this
column189: although a question seemsto have arisen with Palmer as to whether Schofield had any right tocommand him.  If he did raise this question while an action was goingon
column190: that act alone was exceedingly reprehensible.About the same time Wheeler got upon our railroad north of Resaca anddestroyed it nearly up to Dalton.  This cut Sherman off fromcommunication with the North for several days.  Sherman responded tothis attack on his lines of communication by directing one upon theirs.Kilpatrick started on the night of the 18th of August to reach the Maconroad about Jonesboro.  He succeeded in doing so
column191: passed entirely aroundthe Confederate lines of Atlanta
column192: and was back again in his formerposition on our left by the 22d.  These little affairs
column193: however
column194: contributed but very little to the grand result.  They annoyed
column195: it istrue
column196: but any damage thus done to a railroad by any cavalry expeditionis soon repaired.Sherman made preparations for a repetition of his tactics; that is
column197: fora flank movement with as large a force as could be got together to somepoint in the enemy's rear.  Sherman commenced this last movement on the25th of August
column198: and on the 1st of September was well up towards therailroad twenty miles south of Atlanta.  Here he found Hardeeintrenched
column199: ready to meet him.  A battle ensued
column200: but he was unable todrive Hardee away before night set in.  Under cover of the night
column201: however
column202: Hardee left of his own accord.  That night Hood blew up hismilitary works
column203: such as he thought would be valuable in our hands
column204: anddecamped.The next morning at daylight General H. W. Slocum
column205: who was commandingnorth of the city
column206: moved in and took possession of Atlanta
column207: and notifiedSherman.  Sherman then moved deliberately back
column208: taking three days toreach the city
column209: and occupied a line extending from Decatur on the leftto Atlanta in the centre
column210: with his troops extending out of the city forsome distance to the right.The campaign had lasted about four months
column211: and was one of the mostmemorable in history.  There was but little if anything in the wholecampaign
column212: now that it is over
column213: to criticise at all
column214: and nothing tocriticise severely.  It was creditable alike to the general whocommanded and the army which had executed it. Sherman had on thiscampaign some bright
column215: wide-awake division and brigade commanders whosealertness added a host to the efficiency of his command.The troops now went to work to make themselves comfortable
column216: and to enjoya little rest after their arduous campaign.  The city of Atlanta wasturned into a military base.  The citizens were all compelled to leave.Sherman also very wisely prohibited the assembling of the army ofsutlers and traders who always follow in the wake of an army in thefield
column217: if permitted to do so
column218: from trading with the citizens and gettingthe money of the soldiers for articles of but little use to them
column219: andfor which they are made to pay most exorbitant prices.  He limited thenumber of these traders to one for each of his three armies.The news of Sherman's success reached the North instantaneously
column220: and setthe country all aglow.  This was the first great political campaign forthe Republicans in their canvass of 1864.  It was followed later bySheridan's campaign in the Shenandoah Valley; and these two campaignsprobably had more effect in settling the election of the followingNovember than all the speeches
column221: all the bonfires
column222: and all the paradingwith banners and bands of music in the North.

column1: ISFP	 L.GRAND MOVEMENT OF THE ARMY OF THE POTOMAC--CROSSING THE RAPIDAN--ENTERING THE WILDERNESS--BATTLE OF THE WILDERNESS.Soon after midnight
column2: May 3d-4th
column3: the Army of the Potomac moved out fromits position north Rapidan
column4: to start upon that memorable campaign
column5: destined to result in the capture of the Confederate capital and thearmy defending it.  This was not to be accomplished
column6: however
column7: without asdesperate fighting as the world has ever witnessed; not to beconsummated in a day
column8: a week
column9: a month
column10: single season.  The lossesinflicted
column11: and endured
column12: were destined to be severe; but the armies nowconfronting each other had already been in deadly conflict for a periodof three years
column13: with immense losses in killed
column14: by death from sickness
column15: captured and wounded; and neither had made any real progressaccomplishing the final end.  It is true the Confederates had
column16: so far
column17: held their capital
column18: and they claimed this to be their sole object.  Butpreviously they had boldly proclaimed their intention to capturePhiladelphia
column19: New York
column20: and the National Capital
column21: and had made severalattempts to do so
column22: and once or twice had come fearfully near makingtheir boast good--too near for complacent contemplation by the loyalNorth. They had also come near losing their own capital on at least oneoccasion.  So here was a stand-off.  The campaign now begun was destinedto result in heavier losses
column23: to both armies
column24: in a given time
column25: than anypreviously suffered; but the carnage was to be limited to a single year
column26: and to accomplish all that had been anticipated or desired at thebeginning in that time.  We had to have hard fighting to achieve this.The two armies had been confronting each other so long
column27: without anydecisive result
column28: that they hardly knew which could whip.Ten days' rations
column29: with a supply of forage and ammunition were taken inwagons.  Beef cattle were driven with the trains
column30: and butchered aswanted.  Three days rations in addition
column31: in haversacks
column32: and fifty roundsof cartridges
column33: were carried on the person of each soldier.The country over which the army had to operate
column34: from the Rapidan to thecrossing of the James River
column35: is rather flat
column36: and is cut by numerousstreams which make their way to the Chesapeake Bay.  The crossings ofthese streams by the army were generally made not far above tide-water
column37: and where they formed a considerable obstacle to the rapid advance oftroops even when the enemy did not appear in opposition.  The countryroads were narrow and poor. Most of the country is covered with a denseforest
column38: in places
column39: like the Wilderness and along the Chickahominy
column40: almost impenetrable even for infantry except along the roads.  Allbridges were naturally destroyed before the National troops came tothem.The Army of the Potomac was composed of three infantry and one cavalrycorps
column41: commanded respectively by Generals W. S. Hancock
column42: G. K. Warren
column43: (*27) John Sedgwick and P. H. Sheridan.  The artillery was commanded byGeneral Henry J. Hunt.  This arm was in such abundance that the fourthof it could not be used to advantage in such a country as we weredestined to pass through.  The surplus was much in the way
column44: taking up asit did so much of the narrow and bad roads
column45: and consuming so much of theforage and other stores brought up by the trains.The 5th corps
column46: General Warren commanding
column47: was in advance on the right
column48: and marched directly for Germania Ford
column49: preceded by one division ofcavalry
column50: under General J. H. Wilson.  General Sedgwick followed Warrenwith the 6th corps.  Germania Ford was nine or ten miles below the rightof Lee's line.  Hancock
column51: with the 2d corps
column52: moved by another road
column53: farther east
column54: directly upon Ely's Ford
column55: six miles below Germania
column56: preceded by Gregg's division of cavalry
column57: and followed by the artillery.Torbert's division of cavalry was left north of the Rapidan
column58: for thetime
column59: to picket the river and prevent the enemy from crossing andgetting into our rear.  The cavalry seized the two crossings beforedaylight
column60: drove the enemy's pickets guarding them away
column61: and by sixo'clock A.M. had the pontoons laid ready for the crossing of theinfantry and artillery.  This was undoubtedly a surprise to Lee.  Thefact that the movement was unopposed proves this.Burnside
column62: with the 9th corps
column63: was left back at Warrenton
column64: guarding therailroad from Bull Run forward to preserve control of it in case ourcrossing the Rapidan should be long delayed. He was instructed
column65: however
column66: to advance at once on receiving notice that the army had crossed; and adispatch was sent to him a little after one P.M. giving the informationthat our crossing had been successful.The country was heavily wooded at all the points of crossing
column67: particularly on the south side of the river.  The battle-field from thecrossing of the Rapidan until the final movement from the Wildernesstoward Spottsylvania was of the same character. There were someclearings and small farms within what might be termed the battle-field;but generally the country was covered with a dense forest.  The roadswere narrow and bad.  All the conditions were favorable for defensiveoperations.There are two roads
column68: good for that part of Virginia
column69: running from OrangeCourt House to the battle-field.  The most southerly of these roads isknown as the Orange Court House Plank Road
column70: the northern one as theOrange Turnpike.  There are also roads from east of the battle-fieldrunning to Spottsylvania Court House
column71: one from Chancellorsville
column72: branching at Aldrich's; the western branch going by Piney Branch Church
column73: Alsop's
column74: thence by the Brock Road to Spottsylvania; the east branch goesby Gates's
column75: thence to Spottsylvania.  The Brock Road runs from GermaniaFord through the battle-field and on to the Court House.  AsSpottsylvania is approached the country is cut up with numerous roads
column76: some going to the town direct
column77: and others crossing so as to connect thefarms with roads going there.Lee's headquarters were at Orange Court House.  From there toFredericksburg he had the use of the two roads above described runningnearly parallel to the Wilderness.  This gave him unusual facilities
column78: for that country
column79: for concentrating his forces to his right.  Theseroads strike the road from Germania Ford in the Wilderness.As soon as the crossing of the infantry was assured
column80: the cavalry pushedforward
column81: Wilson's division by Wilderness Tavern to Parker's store
column82: onthe Orange Plank Road; Gregg to the left towards Chancellorsville.Warren followed Wilson and reached the Wilderness Tavern by noon
column83: tookposition there and intrenched.  Sedgwick followed Warren.  He was acrossthe river and in camp on the south bank
column84: on the right of Warren
column85: bysundown.  Hancock
column86: with the 2d corps
column87: moved parallel with Warren andcamped about six miles east of him.  Before night all the troops
column88: and bythe evening of the 5th the trains of more than four thousand wagons

Our left occupied its intrenchments while the two corps to theright passed.  If an attack had been made by the enemy he would havefound the 2d corps in position

column152: practically
