column1: ISFP	 LII.BATTLE OF SPOTTSYLVANIA--HANCOCK'S POSITION--ASSAULT OF WARREN'S ANDWRIGHT'S CORPS--UPTON PROMOTED ON THE FIELD--GOOD NEWS FROM BUTLER ANDSHERIDAN.The Mattapony River is formed by the junction of the Mat
column2: the Ta
column3: the Poand the Ny rivers
column4: the last being the northernmost of the four.  Ittakes its rise about a mile south and a little east of the WildernessTavern.  The Po rises south-west of the place
column5: but farther away.Spottsylvania is on the ridge dividing these two streams
column6: and where theyare but a few miles apart.  The Brock Road reaches Spottsylvania withoutcrossing either of these streams. Lee's army coming up by the CatharpinRoad
column7: had to cross the Po at Wooden Bridge.  Warren and Hancock came bythe Brock Road.  Sedgwick crossed the Ny at Catharpin Furnace. Burnsidecoming by Aldrich's to Gates's house
column8: had to cross the Ny near theenemy.  He found pickets at the bridge
column9: but they were soon driven off bya brigade of Willcox's division
column10: and the stream was crossed.  Thisbrigade was furiously attacked; but the remainder of the division comingup
column11: they were enabled to hold their position
column12: and soon fortified it.About the time I received the news of this attack
column13: word came fromHancock that Early had left his front.  He had been forced over to theCatharpin Road
column14: crossing the Po at Corbin's and again at Wooden Bridge.These are the bridges Sheridan had given orders to his cavalry to occupyon the 8th
column15: while one division should occupy Spottsylvania.  Thesemovements of the enemy gave me the idea that Lee was about to make theattempt to get to
column16: or towards
column17: Fredericksburg to cut off my supplies.  Imade arrangements to attack his right and get between him and Richmondif he should try to execute this design.  If he had any such intentionit was abandoned as soon as Burnside was established south of the Ny.The Po and the Ny are narrow little streams
column18: but deep
column19: with abruptbanks
column20: and bordered by heavily wooded and marshy bottoms--at the time wewere there--and difficult to cross except where bridged.  The countryabout was generally heavily timbered
column21: but with occasional clearings.  Itwas a much better country to conduct a defensive campaign in than anoffensive one.By noon of the 9th the position of the two armies was as follows:  Leeoccupied a semicircle facing north
column22: north-west and north-east
column23: inclosingthe town.  Anderson was on his left extending to the Po
column24: Ewell camenext
column25: then Early.  Warren occupied our right
column26: covering the Brock andother roads converging at Spottsylvania; Sedgwick was to his left andBurnside on our extreme left.  Hancock was yet back at Todd's Tavern
column27: but as soon as it was known that Early had left Hancock's front thelatter was ordered up to Warren's right.  He formed a line with threedivisions on the hill overlooking the Po early in the afternoon
column28: and wasordered to cross the Po and get on the enemy's flank.  The fourthdivision of Hancock's corps
column29: Mott commanding
column30: was left at Todd's whenthe corps first came up; but in the afternoon it was brought up andplaced to the left of Sedgwick's--now Wright's--6th corps.  In themorning General Sedgwick had been killed near the right of hisintrenchments by rebel sharpshooters.  His loss was a severe one to theArmy of the Potomac and to the Nation.  General H. G. Wright succeededhim in the command of his corps.Hancock was now
column31: nine P.M. of the 9th of May
column32: across the left flank ofLee's army
column33: but separated from it
column34: and also from the remainder ofMeade's army
column35: by the Po River.  But for the lateness of the hour and thedarkness of the night he would have attempted to cross the river againat Wooden Bridge
column36: thus bringing himself on the same side with bothfriend and foe.The Po at the points where Hancock's corps crossed runs nearly due east.Just below his lower crossing--the troops crossed at three points--itturns due south
column37: and after passing under Wooden Bridge soon resumes amore easterly direction.  During the night this corps built threebridges over the Po; but these were in rear.The position assumed by Hancock's corps forced Lee to reinforce his leftduring the night.  Accordingly on the morning of the 10th
column38: when Hancockrenewed his effort to get over the Po to his front
column39: he found himselfconfronted by some of Early's command
column40: which had been brought from theextreme right of the enemy during the night.  He succeeded in effectinga crossing with one brigade
column41: however
column42: but finding the enemy intrenchedin his front
column43: no more were crossed.Hancock reconnoitred his front on the morning of the 10th
column44: with the viewof forcing a crossing
column45: if it was found that an advantage could begained.  The enemy was found strongly intrenched on the high groundoverlooking the river
column46: and commanding the Wooden Bridge with artillery.Anderson's left rested on the Po
column47: where it turns south; therefore
column48: forHancock to cross over--although it would bring him to the same side ofthe stream with the rest of the army--would still farther isolate himfrom it.  The stream would have to be crossed twice in the face of theenemy to unite with the main body.  The idea of crossing was thereforeabandoned.Lee had weakened the other parts of his line to meet this movement ofHancock's
column49: and I determined to take advantage of it.  Accordingly in themorning
column50: orders were issued for an attack in the afternoon on the centreby Warren's and Wright's corps
column51: Hancock to command all the attackingforce.  Two of his divisions were brought to the north side of the Po.Gibbon was placed to the right of Warren
column52: and Birney in his rear as areserve.  Barlow's division was left south of the stream
column53: and Mott ofthe same corps was still to the left of Wright's corps.  Burnside wasordered to reconnoitre his front in force
column54: and
column55: if an opportunitypresented
column56: to attack with vigor.  The enemy seeing Barlow's divisionisolated from the rest of the army
column57: came out and attacked with fury.Barlow repulsed the assault with great slaughter
column58: and with considerableloss to himself.  But the enemy reorganized and renewed the assault.Birney was now moved to the high ground overlooking the river crossingsbuilt by our troops
column59: and covered the crossings.  The second assault wasrepulsed
column60: again with severe loss to the enemy
column61: and Barlow was withdrawnwithout further molestation. General T. G. Stevenson was killed in thismove.Between the lines
column62: where Warren's assault was to take place
column63: there was aravine grown up with large trees and underbrush
column64: making it almostimpenetrable by man.  The slopes on both sides were also covered with aheavy growth of timber.  Warren
column65: before noon
column66: reconnoitred his fronttwice
column67: the first time with one and the second with two divisions.  Hewas repulsed on both occasions
column68: but gained such information of theground as to induce him to report recommending the assault.Wright also reconnoitred his front and gained a considerably advancedposition from the one he started from.  He then organized a stormingparty
column69: consisting of twelve regiments
column70: and assigned Colonel Emory Upton
column71: of the 121st New York Volunteers
column72: to the command of it.  About fouro'clock in the afternoon the assault was ordered
column73: Warren's and Wright'scorps
column74: with Mott's division of Hancock's corps
column75: to move simultaneously.The movement was prompt
column76: and in a few minutes the fiercest of strugglesbegan.  The battle-field was so densely covered with forest that butlittle could be seen
column77: by any one person
column78: as to the progress made.  Meadeand I occupied the best position we could get
column79: in rear of Warren.Warren was repulsed with heavy loss
column80: General J. C. Rice being among thekilled.  He was not followed
column81: however
column82: by the enemy
column83: and was therebyenabled to reorganize his command as soon as covered from the guns ofthe enemy.  To the left our success was decided
column84: but the advantage waslost by the feeble action of Mott.  Upton with his assaulting partypushed forward and crossed the enemy's intrenchments.  Turning to theright and left he captured several guns and some hundreds of prisoners.Mott was ordered to his assistance but failed utterly.  So much time waslost in trying to get up the troops which were in the right position toreinforce
column85: that I ordered Upton to withdraw; but the officers and men ofhis command were so averse to giving up the advantage they had gainedthat I withdrew the order.  To relieve them
column86: I ordered a renewal of theassault.  By this time Hancock
column87: who had gone with Birney's division torelieve Barlow
column88: had returned
column89: bringing the division with him.  His corpswas now joined with Warren's and Wright's in this last assault.  It wasgallantly made
column90: many men getting up to
column91: and over
column92: the works of theenemy; but they were not able to hold them.  At night they werewithdrawn.  Upton brought his prisoners with him
column93: but the guns he hadcaptured he was obliged to abandon.  Upton had gained an importantadvantage
column94: but a lack in others of the spirit and dash possessed by himlost it to us.  Before leaving Washington I had been authorized topromote officers on the field for special acts of gallantry.  By thisauthority I conferred the rank of brigadier-general upon Upton on thespot
column95: and this act was confirmed by the President.  Upton had been badlywounded in this fight.Burnside on the left had got up to within a few hundred yards ofSpottsylvania Court House
column96: completely turning Lee's right.  He was notaware of the importance of the advantage he had gained
column97: and I
column98: beingwith the troops where the heavy fighting was
column99: did not know of it at thetime.  He had gained his position with but little fighting
column100: and almostwithout loss.  Burnside's position now separated him widely fromWright's corps
column101: the corps nearest to him.  At night he was ordered tojoin on to this.  This brought him back about a mile
column102: and lost to us animportant advantage.  I attach no blame to Burnside for this
column103: but I doto myself for not having had a staff officer with him to report to mehis position.The enemy had not dared to come out of his line at any point to followup his advantage
column104: except in the single instance of his attack on Barlow.Then he was twice repulsed with heavy loss
column105: though he had an entirecorps against two brigades.  Barlow took up his bridges in the presenceof this force.On the 11th there was no battle and but little firing; none except byMott who made a reconnoissance to ascertain if there was a weak point inthe enemy's line.I wrote the following letter to General Halleck:NEAR SPOTTSYLVANIA C. H.
column106: May 11
column107: 1864--8.30 A.M.MAJOR-GENERAL HALLECK
column108: Chief of Staff of the Army
column109: Washington
column110: D. C.We have now ended the 6th day of very hard fighting.  The result up tothis time is much in our favor.  But our losses have been heavy as wellas those of the enemy.  We have lost to this time eleven generalofficers killed
column111: wounded and missing
column112: and probably twenty thousand men.I think the loss of the enemy must be greater--we having taken over fourthousand prisoners in battle
column113: whilst he has taken from us but few excepta few stragglers.  I am now sending back to Belle Plain all my wagonsfor a fresh supply of provisions and ammunition
column114: and purpose to fight itout on this line if it takes all summer.The arrival of reinforcements here will be very encouraging to the men
column115: and I hope they will be sent as fast as possible
column116: and in as greatnumbers.  My object in having them sent to Belle Plain was to use themas an escort to our supply trains.  If it is more convenient to sendthem out by train to march from the railroad to Belle Plain orFredericksburg
column117: send them so.I am satisfied the enemy are very shaky
column118: and are only kept up to themark by the greatest exertions on the part of their officers
column119: and bykeeping them intrenched in every position they take.Up to this time there is no indication of any portion of Lee's armybeing detached for the defence of Richmond.U. S. GRANT
column120: Lieut.-General.And also
column121: I received information
column122: through the War Department
column123: fromGeneral Butler that his cavalry under Kautz had cut the railroad southof Petersburg
column124: separating Beauregard from Richmond
column125: and had whippedHill
column126: killing
column127: wounding and capturing many.  Also that he wasintrenched
column128: and could maintain himself.  On this same day came news fromSheridan to the effect that he had destroyed ten miles of the railroadand telegraph between Lee and Richmond
column129: one and a half million rations
column130: and most of the medical stores for his army.On the 8th I had directed Sheridan verbally to cut loose from the Armyof the Potomac and pass around the left of Lee's army and attack hiscavalry and communications

column1: ISFP	 LIII.HANCOCK'S ASSAULT-LOSSES OF THE CONFEDERATES--PROMOTIONS RECOMMENDED--DISCOMFITURE OF THE ENEMY--EWELL'S ATTACK-REDUCING THE ARTILLERY.In the reconnoissance made by Mott on the 11th
column2: a salient was discoveredat the right centre. I determined that an assault should be made at thatpoint. (*28) Accordingly in the afternoon Hancock was ordered to movehis command by the rear of Warren and Wright
column3: under cover of night
column4: toWright's left
column5: and there form it for an assault at four o'clock the nextmorning.  The night was dark
column6: it rained heavily
column7: and the road wasdifficult
column8: so that it was midnight when he reached the point where hewas to halt.  It took most of the night to get the men in position fortheir advance in the morning.  The men got but little rest.  Burnsidewas ordered to attack (*29) on the left of the salient at the same hour.I sent two of my staff officers to impress upon him the importance ofpushing forward vigorously.  Hancock was notified of this.  Warren andWright were ordered to hold themselves in readiness to join in theassault if circumstances made it advisable.  I occupied a centralposition most convenient for receiving information from all points.Hancock put Barlow on his left
column9: in double column
column10: and Birney to hisright.  Mott followed Birney
column11: and Gibbon was held in reserve.The morning of the 12th opened foggy
column12: delaying the start more than halfan hour.The ground over which Hancock had to pass to reach the enemy
column13: wasascending and heavily wooded to within two or three hundred yards of theenemy's intrenchments.  In front of Birney there was also a marsh tocross.  But
column14: notwithstanding all these difficulties
column15: the troops pushedon in quick time without firing a gun
column16: and when within four or fivehundred yards of the enemy's line broke out in loud cheers
column17: and with arush went up to and over the breastworks.  Barlow and Birney enteredalmost simultaneously.  Here a desperate hand-to-hand conflict tookplace.  The men of the two sides were too close together to fire
column18: butused their guns as clubs.  The hand conflict was soon over.  Hancock'scorps captured some four thousand prisoners among them a division and abrigade commander twenty or more guns with their horses
column19: caissons
column20: andammunition
column21: several thousand stand of arms
column22: and many colors.  Hancock
column23: as soon as the hand-to-hand conflict was over
column24: turned the guns of theenemy against him and advanced inside the rebel lines.  About sixo'clock I ordered Warren's corps to the support of Hancock's. Burnside
column25: on the left
column26: had advanced up east of the salient to the very parapet ofthe enemy.  Potter
column27: commanding one of his divisions
column28: got over but wasnot able to remain there.  However
column29: he inflicted a heavy loss upon theenemy; but not without loss in return.This victory was important
column30: and one that Lee could not afford to leaveus in full possession of.  He made the most strenuous efforts to regainthe position he had lost.  Troops were brought up from his left andattacked Hancock furiously.  Hancock was forced to fall back:  but hedid so slowly
column31: with his face to the enemy
column32: inflicting on him heavy loss
column33: until behind the breastworks he had captured.  These he turned
column34: facingthem the other way
column35: and continued to hold.  Wright was ordered up toreinforce Hancock
column36: and arrived by six o'clock.  He was wounded soonafter coming up but did not relinquish the command of his corps
column37: although the fighting lasted until one o'clock the next morning.  Ateight o'clock Warren was ordered up again
column38: but was so slow in making hisdispositions that his orders were frequently repeated
column39: and withemphasis.  At eleven o'clock I gave Meade written orders to relieveWarren from his command if he failed to move promptly. Hancock placedbatteries on high ground in his rear
column40: which he used against the enemy
column41: firing over the heads of his own troops.Burnside accomplished but little on our left of a positive nature
column42: butnegatively a great deal.  He kept Lee from reinforcing his centre fromthat quarter.  If the 5th corps
column43: or rather if Warren
column44: had been as promptas Wright was with the 6th corps
column45: better results might have beenobtained.Lee massed heavily from his left flank on the broken point of his line.Five times during the day he assaulted furiously
column46: but without dislodgingour troops from their new position.  His losses must have been fearful.Sometimes the belligerents would be separated by but a few feet.  In oneplace a tree
column47: eighteen inches in diameter
column48: was cut entirely down bymusket balls.  All the trees between the lines were very much cut topieces by artillery and musketry.  It was three o'clock next morningbefore the fighting ceased.  Some of our troops had then been twentyhours under fire.  In this engagement we did not lose a singleorganization
column49: not even a company.  The enemy lost one division with itscommander
column50: one brigade and one regiment
column51: with heavy losseselsewhere.(*30)  Our losses were heavy
column52: but
column53: as stated
column54: no whole companywas captured.  At night Lee took a position in rear of his former one
column55: and by the following morning he was strongly intrenched in it.Warren's corps was now temporarily broken up
column56: Cutler's division sent toWright
column57: and Griffin's to Hancock.  Meade ordered his chief of staff
column58: General Humphreys
column59: to remain with Warren and the remaining division
column60: andauthorized him to give it orders in his name.During the day I was passing along the line from wing to wingcontinuously.  About the centre stood a house which proved to beoccupied by an old lady and her daughter.  She showed such unmistakablesigns of being strongly Union that I stopped.  She said she had not seena Union flag for so long a time that it did her heart good to look uponit again.  She said her husband and son
column61: being
column62: Union men
column63: had had toleave early in the war
column64: and were now somewhere in the Union army
column65: ifalive.  She was without food or nearly so
column66: so I ordered rations issuedto her
column67: and promised to find out if I could where the husband and sonwere.There was no fighting on the 13th
column68: further than a little skirmishingbetween Mott's division and the enemy.  I was afraid that Lee might bemoving out
column69: and I did not want him to go without my knowing it. Theindications were that he was moving
column70: but it was found that he was onlytaking his new position back from the salient that had been captured.Our dead were buried this day.  Mott's division was reduced to abrigade
column71: and assigned to Birney's division.During this day I wrote to Washington recommending Sherman and Meade(*31) for promotion to the grade of Major-General in the regular army;Hancock for Brigadier-General; Wright
column72: Gibbon and Humphreys to beMajor-Generals of Volunteers; and Upton and Carroll to be Brigadiers.Upton had already been named as such
column73: but the appointment had to beconfirmed by the Senate on the nomination of the President.The night of the 13th Warren and Wright were moved by the rear to theleft of Burnside.  The night was very dark and it rained heavily
column74: theroads were so bad that the troops had to cut trees and corduroy the roada part of the way
column75: to get through.  It was midnight before they got tothe point where they were to halt
column76: and daylight before the troops couldbe organized to advance to their position in line.  They gained theirposition in line
column77: however
column78: without any fighting
column79: except a little inWright's front.  Here Upton had to contend for an elevation which wewanted and which the enemy was not disposed to yield.  Upton first drovethe enemy
column80: and was then repulsed in turn.  Ayres coming to his supportwith his brigade (of Griffin's division
column81: Warren's corps)
column82: the positionwas secured and fortified.  There was no more battle during the 14th.This brought our line east of the Court House and running north andsouth and facing west.During the night of the 14th-15th Lee moved to cover this new front.This left Hancock without an enemy confronting him.  He was brought tothe rear of our new centre
column83: ready to be moved in any direction he mightbe wanted.On the 15th news came from Butler and Averill.  The former reported thecapture of the outer works at Drury's Bluff
column84: on the James River
column85: andthat his cavalry had cut the railroad and telegraph south of Richmond onthe Danville road:  and the latter
column86: the destruction of a depot ofsupplies at Dublin
column87: West Virginia
column88: and the breaking of New River Bridgeon the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad.  The next day news came fromSherman and Sheridan.  Sherman had forced Johnston out of Dalton
column89: Georgia
column90: and was following him south.  The report from Sheridan embracedhis operations up to his passing the outer defences of Richmond.  Theprospect must now have been dismal in Richmond. The road and telegraphwere cut between the capital and Lee. The roads and wires were cut inevery direction from the rebel capital.  Temporarily that city was cutoff from all communication with the outside except by courier.  Thiscondition of affairs
column91: however
column92: was of but short duration.I wrote Halleck:NEAR SPOTTSYLVANIA C. H.
column93: May 16
column95: 8 A.M.MAJOR-GENERAL HALLECK
column96: Washington
column97: D. C.:We have had five days almost constant rain without any prospect yet ofit clearing up.  The roads have now become so impassable that ambulanceswith wounded men can no longer run between here and Fredericksburg.  Alloffensive operations necessarily cease until we can have twenty-fourhours of dry weather.  The army is in the best of spirits
column98: and feel thegreatest confidence of ultimate success. *        *        *        **        * You can assure the President and Secretary of War that theelements alone have suspended hostilities
column99: and that it is in no mannerdue to weakness or exhaustion on our part.U. S. GRANT
column100: Lieut.-General.The condition of the roads was such that nothing was done on the 17th.But that night Hancock and Wright were to make a night march back totheir old positions
column101: and to make an assault at four o'clock in themorning.  Lee got troops back in time to protect his old line
column102: so theassault was unsuccessful.  On this day (18th) the news was almost asdiscouraging to us as it had been two days before in the rebel capital.As stated above
column103: Hancock's and Wright's corps had made an unsuccessfulassault. News came that Sigel had been defeated at New Market
column104: badly
column105: and was retreating down the valley.  Not two hours before
column106: I had sentthe inquiry to Halleck whether Sigel could not get to Staunton to stopsupplies coming from there to Lee.  I asked at once that Sigel might berelieved
column107: and some one else put in his place. Hunter's name wassuggested
column108: and I heartily approved.  Further news from Butler reportedhim driven from Drury's Bluff
column109: but still in possession of the Petersburgroad.  Banks had been defeated in Louisiana
column110: relieved
column111: and Canby put inhis place. This change of commander was not on my suggestion.  All thisnews was very discouraging.  All of it must have been known by the enemybefore it was by me.  In fact
column112: the good news (for the enemy) must havebeen known to him at the moment I thought he was in despair
column113: and hisanguish had been already relieved when we were enjoying his supposeddiscomfiture
column114: But this was no time for repining.  I immediately gaveorders for a movement by the left flank
column115: on towards Richmond
column116: tocommence on the night of the 19th.  I also asked Halleck to secure thecooperation of the navy in changing our base of supplies fromFredericksburg to Port Royal
column117: on the Rappahannock.Up to this time I had received no reinforcements
column118: except six thousandraw troops under Brigadier General Robert O. Tyler
column119: just arrived.  Theyhad not yet joined their command
column120: Hancock's corps
column121: but were on ourright.  This corps had been brought to the rear of the centre
column122: ready tomove in any direction.  Lee
column123: probably suspecting some move on my part
column124: and seeing our right entirely abandoned
column125: moved Ewell's corps about fiveo'clock in the afternoon
column126: with Early's as a reserve
column127: to attack us inthat quarter.  Tyler had come up from Fredericksburg
column128: and had beenhalted on the road to the right of our line
column129: near Kitching's brigade ofWarren's corps.  Tyler received the attack with his raw troops
column130: and theymaintained their position
column131: until reinforced
column132: in a manner worthy ofveterans.Hancock was in a position to reinforce speedily
column133: and was the soldier todo it without waiting to make dispositions.  Birney was thrown toTyler's right and Crawford to his left
column134: with Gibbon as a reserve; andEwell was whirled back speedily and with heavy loss.Warren had been ordered to get on Ewell's flank and in his rear
column135: to cuthim off from his intrenchments.  But his efforts were so feeble thatunder the cover of night Ewell got back with only the loss of a fewhundred prisoners
column136: besides his killed and wounded.  The army beingengaged until after dark
column137: I rescinded the order for the march by ourleft flank that night.As soon as it was discovered that the enemy were coming out to attack
column138: Inaturally supposed they would detach a force to destroy our trains.  Thewithdrawal of Hancock from the right uncovered one road fromSpottsylvania to Fredericksburg over which trains drew our supplies.This was guarded by a division of colored troops
column139: commanded by GeneralFerrero
column140: belonging to Burnside's corps.  Ferrero was therefore promptlynotified
column141: and ordered to throw his cavalry pickets out to the south andbe prepared to meet the enemy if he should come; if he had to retreat todo so towards Fredericksburg.  The enemy did detach as expected
column142: andcaptured twenty-five or thirty wagons which
column143: however
column144: were soon retaken.In consequence of the disasters that had befallen us in the past fewdays
column145: Lee could be reinforced largely
column146: and I had no doubt he would be.Beauregard had come up from the south with troops to guard theConfederate capital when it was in danger.  Butler being driven back
column147: most of the troops could be sent to Lee. Hoke was no longer needed inNorth Carolina; and Sigel's troops having gone back to Cedar Creek
column148: whipped
column149: many troops could be spared from the valley.The Wilderness and Spottsylvania battles convinced me that we had moreartillery than could ever be brought into action at any one time.  Itoccupied much of the road in marching
column150: and taxed the trains in bringingup forage.  Artillery is very useful when it can be brought into action
column151: but it is a very burdensome luxury where it cannot be used.  Beforeleaving Spottsylvania
column152: therefore
column153: I sent back to the defences ofWashington over one hundred pieces of artillery
column154: with the horses andcaissons.  This relieved the roads over which we were to march of morethan two hundred six-horse teams
column155: and still left us more artillery thancould be advantageously used.  In fact
column156: before reaching the James RiverI again reduced the artillery with the army largely.I believed that
column157: if one corps of the army was exposed on the road toRichmond
column158: and at a distance from the main army
column159: Lee would endeavor toattack the exposed corps before reinforcements could come up; in whichcase the main army could follow Lee up and attack him before he had timeto intrench.  So I issued the following orders:NEAR SPOTTSYLVANIA C. H.
column160: VA.
column161: May 18
column162: 1864.MAJOR-GENERAL MEADE
column163: Commanding Army of the Potomac.Before daylight to-morrow morning I propose to draw Hancock and Burnsidefrom the position they now hold
column164: and put Burnside to the left of Wright.Wright and Burnside should then force their way up as close to the enemyas they can get without a general engagement
column165: or with a generalengagement if the enemy will come out of their works to fight
column166: andintrench.  Hancock should march and take up a position as if in supportof the two left corps. To-morrow night
column167: at twelve or one o'clock

column169: to get as far towards Richmond on the line of theFredericksburg Railroad as he can make
column170: fighting the enemy in whateverforce he can find him.  If the enemy make a general move to meet this
column171: they will be followed by the other three corps of the army
column172: andattacked
column173: if possible
column174: before time is given to intrench.Suitable directions will at once be given for all trains and surplusartillery to conform to this movement.U. S. GRANT.On the 20th
column175: Lee showing no signs of coming out of his lines
column176: orderswere renewed for a left-flank movement
column177: to commence after night.

column1: ISFP	 LIV.MOVEMENT BY THE LEFT FLANK--BATTLE OF NORTH ANNA--AN INCIDENT OF THEMARCH--MOVING ON RICHMOND--SOUTH OF THE PAMUNKEY--POSITION OF THENATIONAL ARMY.We were now to operate in a different country from any we had beforeseen in Virginia.  The roads were wide and good
column2: and the country wellcultivated.  No men were seen except those bearing arms
column3: even the blackman having been sent away.  The country
column4: however
column5: was new to us
column6: and wehad neither guides nor maps to tell us where the roads were
column7: or wherethey led to.  Engineer and staff officers were put to the dangerous dutyof supplying the place of both maps and guides.  By reconnoitring theywere enabled to locate the roads in the vicinity of each army corps.Our course was south
column8: and we took all roads leading in that directionwhich would not separate the army too widely.Hancock who had the lead had marched easterly to Guiney's Station
column9: onthe Fredericksburg Railroad
column10: thence southerly to Bowling Green andMilford.  He was at Milford by the night of the 21st.  Here he met adetachment of Pickett's division coming from Richmond to reinforce Lee.They were speedily driven away
column11: and several hundred captured.  Warrenfollowed on the morning of the 21st
column12: and reached Guiney's Station thatnight without molestation.  Burnside and Wright were retained atSpottsylvania to keep up the appearance of an intended assault
column13: and tohold Lee
column14: if possible
column15: while Hancock and Warren should get start enoughto interpose between him and Richmond.Lee had now a superb opportunity to take the initiative either byattacking Wright and Burnside alone
column16: or by following by the TelegraphRoad and striking Hancock's and Warren's corps
column17: or even Hancock's alone
column18: before reinforcements could come up.  But he did not avail himself ofeither opportunity.  He seemed really to be misled as to my designs; butmoved by his interior line--the Telegraph Road--to make sure of keepingbetween his capital and the Army of the Potomac.  He never again hadsuch an opportunity of dealing a heavy blow.The evening of the 21st Burnside
column19: 9th corps
column20: moved out followed byWright
column21: 6th corps.  Burnside was to take the Telegraph Road; but findingStanard's Ford
column22: over the Po
column23: fortified and guarded
column24: he turned east tothe road taken by Hancock and Warren without an attempt to dislodge theenemy.  The night of the 21st I had my headquarters near the 6th corps
column25: at Guiney's Station
column26: and the enemy's cavalry was between us and Hancock.There was a slight attack on Burnside's and Wright's corps as they movedout of their lines; but it was easily repulsed.  The object probably wasonly to make sure that we were not leaving a force to follow upon therear of the Confederates.By the morning of the 22d Burnside and Wright were at Guiney's Station.Hancock's corps had now been marching and fighting continuously forseveral days
column27: not having had rest even at night much of the time.  Theywere
column28: therefore
column29: permitted to rest during the 22d.  But Warren waspushed to Harris's Store
column30: directly west of Milford
column31: and connected withit by a good road
column32: and Burnside was sent to New Bethel Church.  Wright'scorps was still back at Guiney's Station.I issued the following order for the movement of the troops the nextday:NEW BETHEL
column33: VA.
column34: May 22
column35: 1864MAJOR-GENERAL MEADE
column36: Commanding Army of the Potomac.Direct corps commanders to hold their troops in readiness to march atfive A.M. to-morrow.  At that hour each command will send out cavalryand infantry on all roads to their front leading south
column37: and ascertain
column38: if possible
column39: where the enemy is. If beyond the South Anna
column40: the 5th and6th corps will march to the forks of the road
column41: where one branch leads toBeaver Dam Station
column42: the other to Jericho Bridge
column43: then south by roadsreaching the Anna
column44: as near to and east of Hawkins Creek as they can befound.The 2d corps will move to Chesterfield Ford.  The 9th corps will bedirected to move at the same time to Jericho Bridge.  The map only showstwo roads for the four corps to march upon
column45: but
column46: no doubt
column47: by the use ofplantation roads
column48: and pressing in guides
column49: others can be found
column50: to giveone for each corps.The troops will follow their respective reconnoitring parties. Thetrains will be moved at the same time to Milford Station.Headquarters will follow the 9th corps.U. S. GRANT
column51: Lieut.-General.Warren's corps was moved from Harris's Store to Jericho Ford
column52: Wright'sfollowing.  Warren arrived at the ford early in the afternoon
column53: and byfive o'clock effected a crossing under the protection of sharpshooters.The men had to wade in water up to their waists.  As soon as enoughtroops were over to guard the ford
column54: pontoons were laid and the artilleryand the rest of the troops crossed.  The line formed was almostperpendicular to the course of the river--Crawford on the left
column55: next tothe river
column56: Griffin in the centre
column57: and Cutler on the right.  Lee wasfound intrenched along the front of their line.  The whole of Hill'scorps was sent against Warren's right before it had got in position.  Abrigade of Cutler's division was driven back
column58: the enemy following
column59: butassistance coming up the enemy was in turn driven back into his trencheswith heavy loss in killed and wounded
column60: with about five hundred prisonersleft in our hands. By night Wright's corps was up ready to reinforceWarren.On the 23d Hancock's corps was moved to the wooden bridge which spansthe North Anna River just west of where the Fredericksburg Railroadcrosses.  It was near night when the troops arrived. They found thebridge guarded
column61: with troops intrenched
column62: on the north side.  Hancock senttwo brigades
column63: Egan's and Pierce's
column64: to the right and left
column65: and whenproperly disposed they charged simultaneously.  The bridge was carriedquickly
column66: the enemy retreating over it so hastily that many were shovedinto the river
column67: and some of them were drowned.  Several hundredprisoners were captured.  The hour was so late that Hancock did notcross until next morning.Burnside's corps was moved by a middle road running between thosedescribed above
column68: and which strikes the North Anna at Ox Ford
column69: midwaybetween Telegraph Road and Jericho Ford.  The hour of its arrival wastoo late to cross that night.On the 24th Hancock's corps crossed to the south side of the riverwithout opposition
column70: and formed line facing nearly west. The railroad inrear was taken possession of and destroyed as far as possible.  Wright'scorps crossed at Jericho early the same day
column71: and took position to theright of Warren's corps
column72: extending south of the Virginia CentralRailroad.  This road was torn up for a considerable distance to the rear(west)
column73: the ties burned
column74: and the rails bent and twisted by heating themover the burning ties.  It was found
column75: however
column76: that Burnside's corpscould not cross at Ox Ford.  Lee had taken a position with his centre onthe river at this point
column77: with the two wings thrown back
column78: his line makingan acute angle where it overlooked the river.Before the exact position of the whole of Lee's line was accuratelyknown
column79: I directed Hancock and Warren each to send a brigade to Ox Fordby the south side of the river.  They found the enemy too strong tojustify a serious attack.  A third ford was found between Ox Ford andJericho.  Burnside was directed to cross a division over this ford
column80: andto send one division to Hancock.  Crittenden was crossed by thisnewly-discovered ford
column81: and formed up the river to connect withCrawford's left.  Potter joined Hancock by way of the wooden bridge.Crittenden had a severe engagement with some of Hill's corps on hiscrossing the river
column82: and lost heavily.  When joined to Warren's corps hewas no further molested.  Burnside still guarded Ox Ford from the northside.Lee now had his entire army south of the North Anna.  Our lines coveredhis front
column83: with the six miles separating the two wings guarded by but asingle division.  To get from one wing to the other the river would haveto be crossed twice.  Lee could reinforce any part of his line from allpoints of it in a very short march; or could concentrate the whole of itwherever he might choose to assault.  We were
column84: for the time
column85: practicallytwo armies besieging.Lee had been reinforced
column86: and was being reinforced
column87: largely. About thistime the very troops whose coming I had predicted
column88: had arrived or werecoming in.  Pickett with a full division from Richmond was up; Hoke fromNorth Carolina had come with a brigade; and Breckinridge was there:  inall probably not less than fifteen thousand men.  But he did not attemptto drive us from the field.On the 22d or 23d I received dispatches from Washington saying thatSherman had taken Kingston
column89: crossed the Etowah River and was advancinginto Georgia.I was seated at the time on the porch of a fine plantation house waitingfor Burnside's corps to pass.  Meade and his staff
column90: besides my ownstaff
column91: were with me.  The lady of the house
column92: a Mrs. Tyler
column93: and anelderly lady
column94: were present.  Burnside seeing us
column95: came up on the porch
column96: his big spurs and saber rattling as he walked.  He touched his hatpolitely to the ladies
column97: and remarked that he supposed they had neverseen so many 'live Yankees' before in their lives.  The elderly ladyspoke up promptly saying
column98: 'Oh yes
column99: I have; many more.'  'Where?' saidBurnside. 'In Richmond.'  Prisoners
column100: of course
column101: was understood.I read my dispatch aloud
column102: when it was received.  This threw the youngerlady into tears. I found the information she had received (and I supposeit was the information generally in circulation through the South) wasthat Lee was driving us from the State in the most demoralized conditionand that in the South-west our troops were but little better thanprisoners of war.  Seeing our troops moving south was ocular proof thata part of her information was incorrect
column103: and she asked me if my newsfrom Sherman was true.  I assured her that there was no doubt about it.I left a guard to protect the house from intrusion until the troopsshould have all passed
column104: and assured her that if her husband was inhiding she could bring him in and he should be protected also.  But Ipresume he was in the Confederate army.On the 25th I gave orders
column105: through Halleck
column106: to Hunter
column107: who had relievedSigel
column108: to move up the Valley of Virginia
column109: cross over the Blue Ridge toCharlottesville and go as far as Lynchburg if possible
column110: living upon thecountry and cutting the railroads and canal as he went.  After doingthis he could find his way back to his base
column111: or join me.On the same day news was received that Lee was falling back on Richmond.This proved not to be true.  But we could do nothing where we wereunless Lee would assume the offensive. I determined
column112: therefore
column113: to drawout of our present position and make one more effort to get between himand Richmond.  I had no expectation now
column114: however
column115: of succeeding in this;but I did expect to hold him far enough west to enable me to reach theJames River high up.  Sheridan was now again with the Army of thePotomac.On the 26th I informed the government at Washington of the position ofthe two armies; of the reinforcements the enemy had received; of themove I proposed to make (*32); and directed that our base of suppliesshould be shifted to White House
column116: on the Pamunkey.  The wagon train andguards moved directly from Port Royal to White House.  Supplies movedaround by water
column117: guarded by the navy.  Orders had previously been sent
column118: through Halleck
column119: for Butler to send Smith's corps to White House.  Thisorder was repeated on the 25th
column120: with directions that they should belanded on the north side of the Pamunkey
column121: and marched until they joinedthe Army of the Potomac.It was a delicate move to get the right wing of the Army of the Potomacfrom its position south of the North Anna in the presence of the enemy.To accomplish it
column122: I issued the following order:QUARLES' MILLS
column123: VA.
column124: May 25
column125: 1864.MAJOR GENERAL MEADE
column126: Commanding A. P.Direct Generals Warren and Wright to withdraw all their teams andartillery
column127: not in position
column128: to the north side of the river to-morrow.Send that belonging to General Wright's corps as far on the road toHanover Town as it can go
column129: without attracting attention to the fact.Send with it Wright's best division or division under his ablestcommander.  Have their places filled up in the line so if possible theenemy will not notice their withdrawal.  Send the cavalry to-morrowafternoon
column130: or as much of it as you may deem necessary
column131: to watch andseize
column132: if they can
column133: Littlepage's Bridge and Taylor's Ford
column134: and to remainon one or other side of the river at these points until the infantry andartillery all pass.  As soon as it is dark to-morrow night start thedivision which you withdraw first from Wright's corps to make a forcedmarch to Hanover Town
column135: taking with them no teams to impede their march.At the same time this division starts commence withdrawing all of the5th and 6th corps from the south side of the river

As soon as the troops reach Hanover Town they should getpossession of all the crossings they can in that neighborhood.  I thinkit would be well to make a heavy cavalry demonstration on the enemy'sleft
column140: to-morrow afternoon
column141: also.U. S. GRANT
column142: Lieut.-General.Wilson's division of cavalry was brought up from the left and moved byour right south to Little River.  Here he manoeuvred to give theimpression that we were going to attack the left flank of Lee's army.Under cover of night our right wing was withdrawn to the north side ofthe river
column143: Lee being completely deceived by Wilson's feint.  On theafternoon of the 26th Sheridan moved
column144: sending Gregg's and Torbert'scavalry to Taylor's and Littlepage's fords towards Hanover.  As soon asit was dark both divisions moved quietly to Hanover Ferry
column145: leaving smallguards behind to keep up the impression that crossings were to beattempted in the morning.  Sheridan was followed by a division ofinfantry under General Russell.  On the morning of the 27th the crossingwas effected with but little loss
column146: the enemy losing thirty or forty
column147: taken prisoners.  Thus a position was secured south of the Pamunkey.Russell stopped at the crossing while the cavalry pushed on to HanoverTown.  Here Barringer's
column148: formerly Gordon's
column149: brigade of rebel cavalry wasencountered

column151: leaving pickets confronting the enemy.  Wilson's cavalry followed last
column152: watching all the fords until everything had recrossed; then taking upthe pontoons and destroying other bridges
column153: became the rear-guard.Two roads were traversed by the troops in this move.  The one nearest toand north of the North Anna and Pamunkey was taken by Wright
column154: followedby Hancock.  Warren
column155: followed by Burnside
column156: moved by a road farthernorth
column157: and longer.  The trains moved by a road still farther north
column158: andhad to travel a still greater distance.  All the troops that had crossedthe Pamunkey on the morning of the 27th remained quiet during the restof the day
column159: while the troops north of that stream marched to reach thecrossing that had been secured for them.Lee had evidently been deceived by our movement from North Anna; for onthe morning of the 27th he telegraphed to Richmond: 'Enemy crossed tonorth side
column160: and cavalry and infantry crossed at Hanover Town.'  Thetroops that had then crossed left his front the night of the 25th.The country we were now in was a difficult one to move troops over.  Thestreams were numerous
column161: deep and sluggish
column162: sometimes spreading out intoswamps grown up with impenetrable growths of trees and underbrush.  Thebanks were generally low and marshy
column163: making the streams difficult toapproach except where there were roads and bridges.Hanover Town is about twenty miles from Richmond.  There are two roadsleading there; the most direct and shortest one crossing theChickahominy at Meadow Bridge
column164: near the Virginia Central Railroad
column165: thesecond going by New and Old Cold Harbor.  A few miles out from HanoverTown there is a third road by way of Mechanicsville to Richmond.  NewCold Harbor was important to us because while there we both covered theroads back to White House (where our supplies came from)
column166: and the roadssouth-east over which we would have to pass to get to the James Riverbelow the Richmond defences.On the morning of the 28th the army made an early start
column167: and by noon allhad crossed except Burnside's corps.  This was left on the north sidetemporarily to guard the large wagon train.  A line was at once formedextending south from the river

column169: Hancock'sin the centre

column180: while Burnside was held in reserve. Our advance waspushed forward three miles on the left with but little fighting.  Therewas now an appearance of a movement past our left flank

column1: ISFP	 LV.ADVANCE ON COLD HARBOR--AN ANECDOTE OF THE WAR--BATTLE OF COLD HARBOR--CORRESPONDENCE WITH LEE--RETROSPECTIVE.On the 31st Sheridan advanced to near Old Cold Harbor.  He found itintrenched and occupied by cavalry and infantry.  A hard fight ensuedbut the place was carried.  The enemy well knew the importance of ColdHarbor to us
column2: and seemed determined that we should not hold it.  Hereturned with such a large force that Sheridan was about withdrawingwithout making any effort to hold it against such odds; but about thetime he commenced the evacuation he received orders to hold the place atall hazards
column3: until reinforcements could be sent to him.  He speedilyturned the rebel works to face against them and placed his men inposition for defence.  Night came on before the enemy was ready forassault.Wright's corps was ordered early in the evening to march directly toCold Harbor passing by the rear of the army.  It was expected to arriveby daylight or before; but the night was dark and the distance great
column4: sothat it was nine o'clock the 1st of June before it reached itsdestination.  Before the arrival of Wright the enemy had made twoassaults on Sheridan
column5: both of which were repulsed with heavy loss to theenemy.  Wright's corps coming up
column6: there was no further assault on ColdHarbor.Smith
column7: who was coming up from White House
column8: was also directed to marchdirectly to Cold Harbor
column9: and was expected early on the morning of the1st of June; but by some blunder the order which reached Smith directedhim to Newcastle instead of Cold Harbor.  Through this blunder Smith didnot reach his destination until three o'clock in the afternoon
column10: and thenwith tired and worn-out men from their long and dusty march.  He landedtwelve thousand five hundred men from Butler's command
column11: but a divisionwas left at White House temporarily and many men had fallen out of ranksin their long march.Before the removal of Wright's corps from our right
column12: after dark on the31st
column13: the two lines
column14: Federal and Confederate
column15: were so close together atthat point that either side could detect directly any movement made bythe other.  Finding at daylight that Wright had left his front
column16: Leeevidently divined that he had gone to our left.  At all events
column17: soonafter light on the 1st of June Anderson
column18: who commanded the corps onLee's left
column19: was seen moving along Warren's front.  Warren was ordered toattack him vigorously in flank
column20: while Wright was directed to move outand get on his front.  Warren fired his artillery at the enemy; but lostso much time in making ready that the enemy got by
column21: and at three o'clockhe reported the enemy was strongly intrenched in his front
column22: and besideshis lines were so long that he had no mass of troops to move with.  Heseemed to have forgotten that lines in rear of an army hold themselveswhile their defenders are fighting in their front.  Wright reconnoitredsome distance to his front:  but the enemy finding Old Cold Harboralready taken had halted and fortified some distance west.By six o'clock in the afternoon Wright and Smith were ready to make anassault.  In front of both the ground was clear for several hundredyards and then became wooded.  Both charged across this open space andinto the wood
column23: capturing and holding the first line of rifle-pits of theenemy
column24: and also capturing seven or eight hundred prisoners.While this was going on
column25: the enemy charged Warren three separate timeswith vigor
column26: but were repulsed each time with loss.  There was no officermore capable
column27: nor one more prompt in acting
column28: than Warren when the enemyforced him to it.  There was also an attack upon Hancock's andBurnside's corps at the same time; but it was feeble and probably onlyintended to relieve Anderson who was being pressed by Wright and Smith.During the night the enemy made frequent attacks with the view ofdispossessing us of the important position we had gained
column29: but withouteffecting their object.Hancock was moved from his place in line during the night and ordered tothe left of Wright.  I expected to take the offensive on the morning ofthe 2d
column30: but the night was so dark
column31: the heat and dust so excessive andthe roads so intricate and hard to keep
column32: that the head of column onlyreached Old Cold Harbor at six o'clock
column33: but was in position at 7.30 A.M.Preparations were made for an attack in the afternoon
column34: but did not takeplace until the next morning.  Warren's corps was moved to the left toconnect with Smith:  Hancock's corps was got into position to the leftof Wright's
column35: and Burnside was moved to Bethesda Church in reserve. WhileWarren and Burnside were making these changes the enemy came out severaltimes and attacked them
column36: capturing several hundred prisoners.  Theattacks were repulsed
column37: but not followed up as they should have been.  Iwas so annoyed at this that I directed Meade to instruct his corpscommanders that they should seize all such opportunities when theyoccurred
column38: and not wait for orders

In fact

Hold our most advanced positions and strengthen them.Whilst on the defensive our line may be contracted from the right ifpracticable.Reconnoissances should be made in front of every corps and advances madeto advantageous positions by regular approaches. column118: VA

column145: U. S. GRANT

This charge seemed to revive their hopestemporarily; but it was of short duration.  The effect upon the Army ofthe Potomac was the reverse.  When we reached the James River
column155: however

column161: wounded

column1: ISFP	 LVI.LEFT FLANK MOVEMENT ACROSS THE CHICKAHOMINY AND JAMES--GENERAL LEE--VISIT TO BUTLER--THE MOVEMENT ON PETERSBURG--THE INVESTMENT OFPETERSBURG.Lee's position was now so near Richmond
column2: and the intervening swamps ofthe Chickahominy so great an obstacle to the movement of troops in theface of an enemy
column3: that I determined to make my next left flank movecarry the Army of the Potomac south of the James River. (*34)Preparations for this were promptly commenced. The move was a hazardousone to make:  the Chickahominy River
column4: with its marshy and heavilytimbered approaches
column5: had to be crossed; all the bridges over it east ofLee were destroyed; the enemy had a shorter line and better roads totravel on to confront me in crossing; more than fifty miles intervenedbetween me and Butler
column6: by the roads I should have to travel
column7: with boththe James and the Chickahominy unbridged to cross; and last
column8: the Army ofthe Potomac had to be got out of a position but a few hundred yards fromthe enemy at the widest place.  Lee
column9: if he did not choose to follow me
column10: might
column11: with his shorter distance to travel and his bridges over theChickahominy and the James
column12: move rapidly on Butler and crush him beforethe army with me could come to his relief.  Then too he might sparetroops enough to send against Hunter who was approaching Lynchburg
column13: living upon the country he passed through
column14: and without ammunitionfurther than what he carried with him.But the move had to be made
column15: and I relied upon Lee's not seeing mydanger as I saw it.  Besides we had armies on both sides of the JamesRiver and not far from the Confederate capital.  I knew that its safetywould be a matter of the first consideration with the executive
column16: legislative and judicial branches of the so-called Confederategovernment
column17: if it was not with the military commanders.  But I took allthe precaution I knew of to guard against all dangers.Sheridan was sent with two divisions
column18: to communicate with Hunter and tobreak up the Virginia Central Railroad and the James River Canal
column19: on the7th of June
column20: taking instructions to Hunter to come back with him (*35).Hunter was also informed by way of Washington and the Valley thatSheridan was on the way to meet him.  The canal and Central Road
column21: andthe regions penetrated by them
column22: were of vast importance to the enemy
column23: furnishing and carrying a large per cent. of all the supplies for theArmy of Northern Virginia and the people of Richmond.  Before Sheridangot off on the 7th news was received from Hunter reporting his advanceto Staunton and successful engagement with the enemy near that place onthe 5th
column24: in which the Confederate commander
column25: W. S. Jones
column26: was killed.On the 4th of June the enemy having withdrawn his left corps
column27: Burnsideon our right was moved up between Warren and Smith.  On the 5th Birneyreturned to Hancock
column28: which extended his left now to the Chickahominy
column29: and Warren was withdrawn to Cold Harbor.  Wright was directed to sendtwo divisions to the left to extend down the banks of that stream toBottom's Bridge.  The cavalry extended still farther east to Jones'sBridge.On the 7th Abercrombie--who was in command at White House
column30: and who hadbeen in command at our base of supplies in all the changes made from thestart--was ordered to take up the iron from the York River Railroad andput it on boats
column31: and to be in readiness to move by water to City Point.On the 8th Meade was directed to fortify a line down the bankoverlooking the Chickahominy
column32: under cover of which the army could move.On the 9th Abercrombie was directed to send all organized troopsarriving at White House
column33: without debarking from their transports
column34: toreport to Butler.  Halleck was at this time instructed to send allreinforcements to City Point.On the 11th I wrote:COLD HARBOR
column35: VA.
column36: June 11
column37: 1864.MAJOR-GEN. B. F. BUTLER

column72: June 11
column73: 1864.MAJOR-GENERAL G. G. MEADE

column95: and start them as fast as loadedwithout waiting for the whole corps or even whole divisions to gotogether.U. S. GRANT.About this time word was received (through the Richmond papers of the11th) that Crook and Averell had united and were moving east.  This
column96: with the news of Hunter's successful engagement near Staunton
column97: was nodoubt known to Lee before it was to me. Then Sheridan leaving with twodivisions of cavalry

column99: both to Lee'scommunications and supplies. Much of his cavalry was sent afterSheridan
column100: and Early with Ewell's entire corps was sent to the Valley.Supplies were growing scarce in Richmond

column103: and to take boats at once for City Point
column104: leaving his trains and artillery to move by land.Soon after dark some of the cavalry at Long Bridge effected a crossingby wading and floundering through the water and mud
column105: leaving theirhorses behind
column106: and drove away the cavalry pickets.  A pontoon bridge wasspeedily thrown across
column107: over which the remainder of the army soon passedand pushed out for a mile or two to watch and detain any advance thatmight be made from the other side.  Warren followed the cavalry
column108: and bythe morning of the 13th had his whole corps over.  Hancock followedWarren.  Burnside took the road to Jones's Bridge
column109: followed by Wright.Ferrero's division
column110: with the wagon train
column111: moved farther east
column112: by WindowShades and Cole's Ferry
column113: our rear being covered by cavalry.It was known that the enemy had some gunboats at Richmond. These mightrun down at night and inflict great damage upon us before they could besunk or captured by our navy.  General Butler had
column114: in advance
column115: loadedsome vessels with stone ready to be sunk so as to obstruct the channelin an emergency.  On the 13th I sent orders to have these sunk as highup the river as we could guard them
column116: and prevent their removal by theenemy.As soon as Warren's corps was over the Chickahominy it marched out andjoined the cavalry in holding the roads from Richmond while the armypassed.  No attempt was made by the enemy to impede our march
column117: however
column118: but Warren and Wilson reported the enemy strongly fortified in theirfront.  By the evening of the 13th Hancock's corps was at Charles CityCourt House on the James River.  Burnside's and Wright's corps were onthe Chickahominy
column119: and crossed during the night
column120: Warren's corps and thecavalry still covering the army.  The material for a pontoon bridge wasalready at hand and the work of laying it was commenced immediately
column121: under the superintendence of Brigadier-General Benham
column122: commanding theengineer brigade.  On the evening of the 14th the crossing commenced
column123: Hancock in advance
column124: using both the bridge and boats.When the Wilderness campaign commenced the Army of the Potomac
column125: including Burnside's--which was a separate command until the 24th of Maywhen it was incorporated with the main army--numbered about 116
column126: 000 men.During the progress of the campaign about 40
column127: 000 reinforcements werereceived.  At the crossing of the James River June 14th-15th the armynumbered about 115
column128: 000.  Besides the ordinary losses incident to acampaign of six weeks' nearly constant fighting or skirmishing
column129: aboutone-half of the artillery was sent back to Washington
column130: and many men weredischarged by reason of the expiration of their term of service.* Inestimating our strength every enlisted man and every commissionedofficer present is included
column131: no matter how employed; in bands
column132: sick infield hospitals
column133: hospital attendants
column134: company cooks and all.  Operatingin an enemy's country
column135: and being supplied always from a distant base
column136: large detachments had at all times to be sent from the front
column137: not onlyto guard the base of supplies and the roads to it
column138: but all the roadsleading to our flanks and rear.  We were also operating in a countryunknown to us
column139: and without competent guides or maps showing the roadsaccurately.The manner of estimating numbers in the two armies differs materially.In the Confederate army often only bayonets are taken into account
column140: never
column141: I believe
column142: do they estimate more than are handling the guns ofthe artillery and armed with muskets (*36) or carbines.  Generally thelatter are far enough away to be excluded from the count in any onefield.  Officers and details of enlisted men are not included.  In theNorthern armies the estimate is most liberal
column143: taking in all connectedwith the army and drawing pay.Estimated in the same manner as ours
column144: Lee had not less than 80
column145: 000 menat the start.  His reinforcements were about equal to ours during thecampaign
column146: deducting the discharged men and those sent back.  He was onthe defensive
column147: and in a country in which every stream
column148: every road
column149: everyobstacle to the movement of troops and every natural defence wasfamiliar to him and his army.  The citizens were all friendly to him andhis cause
column150: and could and did furnish him with accurate reports of ourevery move.  Rear guards were not necessary for him
column151: and having always arailroad at his back
column152: large wagon trains were not required. Allcircumstances considered we did not have any advantage in numbers.General Lee
column153: who had led the Army of Northern Virginia in all thesecontests
column154: was a very highly estimated man in the Confederate army andStates
column155: and filled also a very high place in the estimation of thepeople and press of the Northern States.  His praise was soundedthroughout the entire North after every action he was engaged in:  thenumber of his forces was always lowered and that of the National forcesexaggerated.  He was a large
column156: austere man
column157: and I judge difficult ofapproach to his subordinates.  To be extolled by the entire press of theSouth after every engagement
column158: and by a portion of the press North withequal vehemence
column159: was calculated to give him the entire confidence of histroops and to make him feared by his antagonists.  It was not anuncommon thing for my staff-officers to hear from Eastern officers
column160: 'Well
column161: Grant has never met Bobby Lee yet.'  There were good and trueofficers who believe now that the Army of Northern Virginia was superiorto the Army of the Potomac man to man.  I do not believe so
column162: except asthe advantages spoken of above made them so.  Before the end I believethe difference was the other way.  The Army of Northern Virginia becamedespondent and saw the end.  It did not please them.  The National armysaw the same thing
column163: and were encouraged by it.The advance of the Army of the Potomac reached the James on the 14th ofJune.  Preparations were at once commenced for laying the pontoonbridges and crossing the river.  As already stated
column164: I had previouslyordered General Butler to have two vessels loaded with stone and carriedup the river to a point above that occupied by our gunboats
column165: where thechannel was narrow
column166: and sunk there so as to obstruct the passage andprevent Confederate gunboats from coming down the river.  Butler had hadthese boats filled and put in position
column167: but had not had them sunk beforemy arrival.  I ordered this done
column168: and also directed that he should turnover all material and boats not then in use in the river to be used inferrying the troops across.I then
column169: on the 14th
column170: took a steamer and ran up to Bermuda Hundred to seeGeneral Butler for the purpose of directing a movement againstPetersburg
column171: while our troops of the Army of the Potomac were crossing.I had sent General W. F. Smith back from Cold Harbor by the way of WhiteHouse
column172: thence on steamers to City Point for the purpose of givingGeneral Butler more troops with which to accomplish this result.General Butler was ordered to send Smith with his troops reinforced
column173: asfar as that could be conveniently done
column174: from other parts of the Army ofthe James.  He gave Smith about six thousand reinforcements
column175: includingsome twenty-five hundred cavalry under Kautz
column176: and about thirty-fivehundred colored infantry under Hinks.The distance which Smith had to move to reach the enemy's lines wasabout six miles

The position of the two lines at that point were only abouta hundred yards apart with a comparatively deep ravine intervening.  Inthe bottom of this ravine the work commenced.  The position wasunfavorable in this particular: that the enemy's line at that point wasre-entering

I somewhat based my calculationsupon this state of feeling

column261: ' andsoon got off

column269: giving directions topush for Halltown

column273: no matter how much he was scattered at that time

column276: Cumberland

column278: or elsewhere
column279: and give Sheridan command of the troops in the field.  The generalreplied to this

column281: in any way
column282: to embarrass the cause; thus showing apatriotism that was none too common in the army.  There were not manymajor-generals who would voluntarily have asked to have the command of adepartment taken from them on the supposition that for some particularreason

column292: at the same time

column294: 000 men to move with
column296: 000 of them beingcavalry.  Early had about the same number

column300: butnot to the extent that we thought and feared he would.To prevent as much as possible these reinforcements from being sent outfrom Richmond

There wasno particular victory gained on either side; but during that time nomore reinforcements were sent to the valley.I informed Sheridan of what had been done to prevent reinforcementsbeing sent from Richmond against him

column311: because we had captured six or sevenhundred prisoners from that division

I therefore asked that alltroops in camps of instruction in the North-west be sent to him.Sherman also wanted to be assured that no Eastern troops were moving outagainst him.  I informed him of what I had done and assured him that Iwould hold all the troops there that it was possible for me to hold
column317: andthat up to that time none had gone.  I also informed him that his realdanger was from Kirby Smith
column318: who commanded the trans-MississippiDepartment.  If Smith should escape Steele
column319: and get across theMississippi River

column321: therefore

column326: however
column327: and while mostof Lee's force was on that side of the river

column331: near theold line

column333: while a division was brought back from the north side of the James Riverto take its place.This road was very important to the enemy.  The limits from which hissupplies had been drawn were already very much contracted

column335: though with heavy loss on both sides.  He fortified his new position

column338: and with heavy loss.As soon as Warren was fortified and reinforcements reached him
column339: troopswere sent south to destroy the bridges on the Weldon Railroad; and withsuch success that the enemy had to draw in wagons
column340: for a distance ofabout thirty miles
column341: all the supplies they got thereafter from thatsource.  It was on the 21st that Lee seemed to have given up the WeldonRailroad as having been lost to him; but along about the 24th or 25th hemade renewed attempts to recapture it; again he failed and with veryheavy losses to him as compared with ours.On the night of the 20th our troops on the north side of the James werewithdrawn
