column1: ISFP	 LVIII.SHERIDAN'S ADVANCE--VISIT TO SHERIDAN--SHERIDAN'S VICTORY IN THESHENANDOAH--SHERIDAN'S RIDE TO WINCHESTER--CLOSE OF THE CAMPAIGN FOR THEWINTER.We had our troops on the Weldon Railroad contending against a largeforce that regarded this road of so much importance that they couldafford to expend many lives in retaking it; Sherman just getting throughto Atlanta with great losses of men from casualties
column2: discharges anddetachments left along as guards to occupy and hold the road in rear ofhim; Washington threatened but a short time before
column3: and now Early beingstrengthened in the valley so as
column4: probably
column5: to renew that attempt.  Itkept me pretty active in looking after all these points.On the 10th of August Sheridan had advanced on Early up the ShenandoahValley
column6: Early falling back to Strasburg.  On the 12th I learned that Leehad sent twenty pieces of artillery
column7: two divisions of infantry and aconsiderable cavalry force to strengthen Early.  It was important thatSheridan should be informed of this
column8: so I sent the information toWashington by telegraph
column9: and directed a courier to be sent from there toget the message to Sheridan at all hazards
column10: giving him the information.The messenger
column11: an officer of the army
column12: pushed through with great energyand reached Sheridan just in time. The officer went through by way ofSnicker's Gap
column13: escorted by some cavalry.  He found Sheridan just makinghis preparations to attack Early in his chosen position.  Now
column14: however
column15: he was thrown back on the defensive.On the 15th of September I started to visit General Sheridan in theShenandoah Valley.  My purpose was to have him attack Early
column16: or drivehim out of the valley and destroy that source of supplies for Lee'sarmy.  I knew it was impossible for me to get orders through Washingtonto Sheridan to make a move
column17: because they would be stopped there and suchorders as Halleck's caution (and that of the Secretary of War) wouldsuggest would be given instead
column18: and would
column19: no doubt
column20: be contradictory tomine.  I therefore
column21: without stopping at Washington
column22: went directlythrough to Charlestown
column23: some ten miles above Harper's Ferry
column24: and waitedthere to see General Sheridan
column25: having sent a courier in advance toinform him where to meet me.When Sheridan arrived I asked him if he had a map showing the positionsof his army and that of the enemy.  He at once drew one out of his sidepocket
column26: showing all roads and streams
column27: and the camps of the two armies.He said that if he had permission he would move so and so (pointing outhow) against the Confederates
column28: and that he could 'whip them.'  Beforestarting I had drawn up a plan of campaign for Sheridan
column29: which I hadbrought with me; but
column30: seeing that he was so clear and so positive in hisviews and so confident of success
column31: I said nothing about this and did nottake it out of my pocket.Sheridan's wagon trains were kept at Harper's Ferry
column32: where all of hisstores were.  By keeping the teams at that place
column33: their forage did nothave to be hauled to them.  As supplies of ammunition
column34: provisions andrations for the men were wanted
column35: trains would be made up to deliver thestores to the commissaries and quartermasters encamped at Winchester.Knowing that he
column36: in making preparations to move at a given day
column37: wouldhave to bring up wagons trains from Harper's Ferry
column38: I asked him if hecould be ready to get off by the following Tuesday.  This was on Friday.'O Yes
column39: ' he said
column40: he 'could be off before daylight on Monday.'  I toldhim then to make the attack at that time and according to his own plan;and I immediately started to return to the army about Richmond.  Aftervisiting Baltimore and Burlington
column41: New Jersey
column42: I arrived at City Pointon the 19th.On the way out to Harper's Ferry I had met Mr. Robert Garrett
column43: Presidentof the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.  He seemed very anxious to know whenworkmen might be put upon the road again so as to make repairs and putit in shape for running.  It was a large piece of property to havestanding idle.  I told him I could not answer then positively but wouldtry and inform him before a great while.  On my return Mr. Garrett metme again with the same and I told him I thought that by the Wednesday hemight send his workmen out on his road.  I gave him no furtherinformation however
column44: and he had no suspicion of how I expected to havethe road cleared for his workmen.Sheridan moved at the time he had fixed upon.  He met Early at thecrossing of Opequon Creek
column45: a most decisive victory--one which thecountry.  Early had invited this attack himself by his bad generalshipand made the victory easy.  He had sent G. T. Anderson's division eastof the Blue Ridge before I went to Harper's Ferry; and about the time Iarrived there he started other divisions (leaving but two in theircamps) to march to Martinsburg for the purpose destroying the Baltimoreand Ohio Railroad at that point.  Early here learned that I had beenwith Sheridan and
column46: supposing there was some movement on foot
column47: startedback as soon as he got the information.  But his forces were separatedand
column48: as I have said
column49: he was very badly defeated.  He fell back toFisher's Hill
column50: Sheridan following.The valley is narrow at that point
column51: and Early made another stand there
column52: behind works which extended across.  But Sheridan turned both his flanksand again sent him speeding up the valley
column53: following in hot pursuit.The pursuit was continued up the valley to Mount Jackson and New Market.Sheridan captured about eleven hundred prisoners and sixteen guns.  Thehouses which he passed all along the route were found to be filled withEarly's wounded
column54: and the country swarmed with his deserters.  Finally
column55: on the 25th
column56: Early turned from the valley eastward
column57: leaving Sheridan atHarrisonburg in undisputed possession.Now one of the main objects of the expedition began to be accomplished.Sheridan went to work with his command
column58: gathering in the crops
column59: cattle
column60: and everything in the upper part of the valley required by our troops;and especially taking what might be of use to the enemy.  What he couldnot take away he destroyed
column61: so that the enemy would not be invited tocome back there.  I congratulated Sheridan upon his recent great victoryand had a salute of a hundred guns fired in honor of it
column62: the guns beingaimed at the enemy around Petersburg.  I also notified the othercommanders throughout the country
column63: who also fired salutes in honor ofhis victory.I had reason to believe that the administration was a little afraid tohave a decisive battle at that time
column64: for fear it might go against us andhave a bad effect on the November elections. The convention which hadmet and made its nomination of the Democratic candidate for thepresidency had declared the war a failure.  Treason was talked as boldlyin Chicago at that convention as ever been in Charleston.  It was aquestion whether the government would then have had the power to makearrests and punish those who talked treason.  But this decisive victorywas the most effective campaign argument made in the canvass.Sheridan
column65: in his pursuit
column66: got beyond where they could hear from him inWashington
column67: and the President became very much frightened about him.  Hewas afraid that the hot pursuit had been a little like that of GeneralCass was said to have been
column68: in one of our Indian wars
column69: when he was anofficer of army.  Cass was pursuing the Indians so closely that thefirst thing he knew he found himself in front
column70: and the Indians pursuinghim.  The President was afraid that Sheridan had got on the other sideof Early and that Early was in behind him.  He was afraid that Sheridanwas getting so far away that reinforcements would be sent out fromRichmond to enable Early to beat him.  I replied to the President that Ihad taken steps to prevent Lee from sending reinforcements to Early
column71: byattacking the former where he was.On the 28th of September
column72: to retain Lee in his position
column73: I sent Ord withthe 18th corps and Birney with the 10th corps to make an advance onRichmond
column74: to threaten it.  Ord moved with the left wing up to Chaffin'sBluff; Birney with the 10th corps took a road farther north; while Kautzwith the cavalry took the Darby road
column75: still farther to the north.  Theygot across the river by the next morning
column76: and made an effort to surprisethe enemy.  In that
column77: however
column78: they were unsuccessful.The enemy's lines were very strong and very intricate. Stannard'sdivision of the 18th corps with General Burnham's brigade leading
column79: triedan assault against Fort Harrison and captured it with sixteen guns and agood many prisoners. Burnham was killed in the assault.  Colonel Stevenswho succeeded him was badly wounded; and his successor also fell in thesame way.  Some works to the right and left were also carried with theguns in them--six in number--and a few more prisoners.  Birney's troopsto the right captured the enemy's intrenched picket-lines
column80: but wereunsuccessful in their efforts upon the main line.Our troops fortified their new position
column81: bringing Fort Harrison into thenew line and extending it to the river.  This brought us pretty close tothe enemy on the north side of the James
column82: and the two opposing linesmaintained their relative positions to the close of the siege.In the afternoon a further attempt was made to advance
column83: but it failed.Ord fell badly wounded
column84: and had to be relieved; the command devolvedupon General Heckman
column85: and later General Weitzel was assigned to thecommand of the 18th corps.  During the night Lee reinforced his troopsabout Fort Gilmer
column86: which was at the right of Fort Harrison
column87: by eightadditional brigades from Petersburg
column88: and attempted to retake the workswhich we had captured by concentrating ten brigades against them.  Alltheir efforts failed
column89: their attacks being all repulsed with very heavyloss.  In one of these assaults upon us General Stannard
column90: a gallantofficer who was defending Fort Harrison
column91: lost an arm. Our casualtiesduring these operations amounted to 394 killed
column92: I
column93: 554 wounded and 324missing.Whilst this was going on General Meade was instructed to keep up anappearance of moving troops to our extreme left.  Parke and Warren werekept with two divisions
column94: each under arms
column95: ready to move leaving theirenclosed batteries manned
column96: with a scattering line on the otherintrenchments.  The object of this was to prevent reinforcements fromgoing to the north side of the river.  Meade was instructed to watch theenemy closely and
column97: if Lee weakened his lines
column98: to make an attack.On the 30th these troops moved out
column99: under Warren
column100: and captured anadvanced intrenched camp at Peeble's farm
column101: driving the enemy back to themain line.  Our troops followed and made an attack in the hope ofcarrying the enemy's main line; but in this they were unsuccessful andlost a large number of men
column102: mostly captured.  The number of killed andwounded was not large.  The next day our troops advanced again andestablished themselves
column103: intrenching a new line about a mile in front ofthe enemy.  This advanced Warren's position on the Weldon Railroad veryconsiderably.Sheridan having driven the enemy out of the valley
column104: and taken theproductions of the valley so that instead of going there for suppliesthe enemy would have to bring his provisions with him if he againentered it
column105: recommended a reduction of his own force
column106: the surplus to besent where it could be of more use.  I approved of his suggestion
column107: andordered him to send Wright's corps back to the James River.  I furtherdirected him to repair the railroad up the Shenandoah Valley towards theadvanced position which we would hold with a small force.  The troopswere to be sent to Washington by the way of Culpeper
column108: in order to watchthe east side of the Blue Ridge
column109: and prevent the enemy from getting intothe rear of Sheridan while he was still doing his work of destruction.The valley was so very important
column110: however
column111: to the Confederate army that
column112: contrary to our expectations
column113: they determined to make one more strike
column114: and save it if possible before the supplies should be all destroyed.Reinforcements were sent therefore to Early
column115: and this before any of ourtroops had been withdrawn. Early prepared to strike Sheridan atHarrisonburg; but the latter had not remained there.On the 6th of October Sheridan commenced retiring down the valley
column116: taking or destroying all the food and forage and driving the cattlebefore him
column117: Early following.  At Fisher's Hill Sheridan turned hiscavalry back on that of Early
column118: which
column119: under the lead of Rosser
column120: waspursuing closely
column121: and routed it most completely
column122: capturing eleven gunsand a large number of prisoners.  Sheridan lost only about sixty men.His cavalry pursued the enemy back some twenty-five miles.  On the 10thof October the march down the valley was again resumed
column123: Early againfollowing.I now ordered Sheridan to halt
column124: and to improve the opportunity ifafforded by the enemy's having been sufficiently weakened
column125: to move backagain and cut the James River Canal and Virginia Central Railroad.  Butthis order had to go through Washington where it was intercepted; andwhen Sheridan received what purported to be a statement of what I wantedhim to do it was something entirely different.  Halleck informedSheridan that it was my wish for him to hold a forward position as abase from which to act against Charlottesville and Gordonsville; that heshould fortify this position and provision it.Sheridan objected to this most decidedly; and I was impelled totelegraph him
column126: on the 14th
column127: as follows:CITY POINT
column128: VA.
column129: October 14
column130: 1864.--12.30 P.M.MAJOR-GENERAL SHERIDAN
column131: Cedar Creek
column132: Va.What I want is for you to threaten the Virginia Central Railroad andcanal in the manner your judgment tells you is best
column133: holding yourselfready to advance
column134: if the enemy draw off their forces. If you make theenemy hold a force equal to your own for the protection of thosethoroughfares
column135: it will accomplish nearly as much as their destruction.If you cannot do this
column136: then the next best thing to do is to send hereall the force you can.  I deem a good cavalry force necessary for youroffensive
column137: as well as defensive operations.  You need not therefore sendhere more than one division of cavalry.U. S. GRANT
column138: Lieutenant-General.Sheridan having been summoned to Washington City
column139: started on the 15thleaving Wright in command.  His army was then at Cedar Creek
column140: sometwenty miles south of Winchester.  The next morning while at FrontRoyal
column141: Sheridan received a dispatch from Wright
column142: saying that a dispatchfrom Longstreet to Early had been intercepted.  It directed the latterto be ready to move and to crush Sheridan as soon as he
column143: Longstreet
column144: arrived.  On the receipt of this news Sheridan ordered the cavalry upthe valley to join Wright.On the 18th of October Early was ready to move
column145: and during the nightsucceeded in getting his troops in the rear of our left flank
column146: whichfled precipitately and in great confusion down the valley
column147: losingeighteen pieces of artillery and a thousand or more prisoners.  Theright under General Getty maintained a firm and steady front
column148: fallingback to Middletown where it took a position and made a stand.  Thecavalry went to the rear
column149: seized the roads leading to Winchester andheld them for the use of our troops in falling back
column150: General Wrighthaving ordered a retreat back to that place.Sheridan having left Washington on the 18th
column151: reached Winchester thatnight.  The following morning he started to join his command.  He hadscarcely got out of town
column152: when he met his men returning in panic fromthe front and also heard heavy firing to the south.  He immediatelyordered the cavalry at Winchester to be deployed across the valley tostop the stragglers.  Leaving members of his staff to take care ofWinchester and the public property there
column153: he set out with a small escortdirectly for the scene of battle.  As he met the fugitives he orderedthem to turn back
column154: reminding them that they were going the wrong way.His presence soon restored confidence.  Finding themselves worsefrightened than hurt the men did halt and turn back.  Many of those whohad run ten miles got back in time to redeem their reputation as gallantsoldiers before night.When Sheridan got to the front he found Getty and Custer still holdingtheir ground firmly between the Confederates and our retreating troops.Everything in the rear was now ordered up. Sheridan at once proceeded tointrench his position; and he awaited an assault from the enemy.  Thiswas made with vigor
column155: and was directed principally against Emory's corps
column156: which had sustained the principal loss in the first attack.  By oneo'clock the attack was repulsed.  Early was so badly damaged that heseemed disinclined to make another attack
column157: but went to work to intrenchhimself with a view to holding the position he had already gained.  Hethought
column158: no doubt
column159: that Sheridan would be glad enough to leave himunmolested; but in this he was mistaken.About the middle of the afternoon Sheridan advanced.  He sent hiscavalry by both flanks
column160: and they penetrated to the enemy's rear.  Thecontest was close for a time
column161: but at length the left of the enemy broke
column162: and disintegration along the whole line soon followed.  Early tried torally his men
column163: but they were followed so closely that they had to giveway very quickly every time they attempted to make a stand.  Ourcavalry
column164: having pushed on and got in the rear of the Confederates
column165: captured twenty-four pieces of artillery
column166: besides retaking what had beenlost in the morning.  This victory pretty much closed the campaigning inthe Valley of Virginia.  All the Confederate troops were sent back toRichmond with the exception of one division of infantry and a littlecavalry.  Wright's corps was ordered back to the Army of the Potomac
column167: and two other divisions were withdrawn from the valley.  Early had lostmore men in killed
column168: wounded and captured in the valley than Sheridan hadcommanded from first to last.On more than one occasion in these engagements General R. B. Hayes
column169: whosucceeded me as President of the United States
column170: bore a very honorablepart.  His conduct on the field was marked by conspicuous gallantry aswell as the display of qualities of a higher order than that of merepersonal daring.  This might well have been expected of one who couldwrite at the time he is said to have done so:  'Any officer fit for dutywho at this crisis would abandon his post to electioneer for a seat inCongress
column171: ought to be scalped.'  Having entered the army as a Major ofVolunteers at the beginning of the war
column172: General Hayes attained bymeritorious service the rank of Brevet Major-General before its close.On the north side of the James River the enemy attacked Kautz's cavalryon the 7th of October
column173: and drove it back with heavy loss in killed
column174: wounded and prisoners
column175: and the loss of all the artillery.  This wasfollowed up by an attack on our intrenched infantry line
column176: but wasrepulsed with severe slaughter.  On the 13th a reconnoissance was sentout by General Butler
column177: with a view to drive the enemy from some newworks he was constructing
column178: which resulted in heavy loss to us.On the 24th I ordered General Meade to attempt to get possession of theSouth Side Railroad
column179: and for that purpose to advance on the 27th.  Theattempt proved a failure
column180: however
column181: the most advanced of our troops notgetting nearer than within six miles of the point aimed for.  Seeing theimpossibility of its accomplishment I ordered the troops to withdraw
column182: and they were all back in their former positions the next day.Butler
column183: by my directions
column184: also made a demonstration on the north side ofthe James River in order to support this move
column185: by detaining there theConfederate troops who were on that side. He succeeded in this
column186: butfailed of further results by not marching past the enemy's left beforeturning in on the Darby road and by reason of simply coming up againsttheir lines in place.This closed active operations around Richmond for the winter. Of coursethere was frequent skirmishing between pickets
column187: but no serious battlewas fought near either Petersburg or Richmond. It would prolong thiswork to give a detailed account of all that took place from day to dayaround Petersburg and at other parts of my command
column188: and it would notinterest the general reader if given.  All these details can be found bythe military student in a series of books published by the Scribners
column189: Badeau's history of my campaigns
column190: and also in the publications of theWar Department
column191: including both the National and Confederate reports.In the latter part of November General Hancock was relieved from thecommand of the 2d corps by the Secretary of War and ordered toWashington
column192: to organize and command a corps of veteran troops to bedesignated the 1st corps.  It was expected that this would give him alarge command to co-operate with in the spring.  It was my expectation
column193: at the time
column194: that in the final operations Hancock should move either upthe valley
column195: or else east of the Blue Ridge to Lynchburg; the idea beingto make the spring campaign the close of the war.  I expected
column196: withSherman coming up from the South
column197: Meade south of Petersburg and aroundRichmond
column198: and Thomas's command in Tennessee with depots of suppliesestablished in the eastern part of that State
column199: to move from thedirection of Washington or the valley towards Lynchburg.  We would thenhave Lee so surrounded that his supplies would be cut off entirely
column200: making it impossible for him to support his army.General Humphreys
column201: chief-of-staff of the Army of the Potomac
column202: wasassigned to the command of the 2d corps
column203: to succeed Hancock.

column1: ISFP	 LIX.THE CAMPAIGN IN GEORGIA--SHERMAN'S MARCH TO THE SEA--WAR ANECDOTES--THEMARCH ON SAVANNAH--INVESTMENT OF SAVANNAH--CAPTURE OF SAVANNAH.Let us now return to the operations in the military division of theMississippi
column2: and accompany Sherman in his march to the sea.The possession of Atlanta by us narrowed the territory of the enemy verymaterially and cut off one of his two remaining lines of roads from eastto west.A short time after the fall of Atlanta Mr. Davis visited Palmetto andMacon and made speeches at each place.  He spoke at Palmetto on the 20thof September
column3: and at Macon on the 22d. Inasmuch as he had relievedJohnston and appointed Hood
column4: and Hood had immediately taken theinitiative
column5: it is natural to suppose that Mr. Davis was disappointedwith General Johnston's policy.  My own judgment is that Johnston actedvery wisely:  he husbanded his men and saved as much of his territory ashe could
column6: without fighting decisive battles in which all might be lost.As Sherman advanced
column7: as I have show
column8: his army became spread out

The cavalry was sent to make a rapid march in hope ofsurprising Millen before the Union prisoners could be carried away; butthey failed in this.The distance from Milledgeville to Millen was about one hundred miles.At this point Wheeler
column376: who had been ordered from Tennessee
column377: arrived andswelled the numbers and efficiency of the troops confronting Sherman.Hardee
column378: a native of Georgia
column379: also came
column380: but brought no troops with him.It was intended that he should raise as large an army as possible withwhich to intercept Sherman's march.  He did succeed in raising sometroops
column381: and with these and those under the command of Wheeler and Wayne
column382: had an army sufficient to cause some annoyance but no great detention.Our cavalry and Wheeler's had a pretty severe engagement
column383: in whichWheeler was driven towards Augusta
column384: thus giving the idea that Shermanwas probably making for that point.Millen was reached on the 3d of December
column385: and the march was resumed thefollowing day for Savannah
column386: the final objective. Bragg had now been sentto Augusta with some troops.  Wade Hampton was there also trying toraise cavalry sufficient to destroy Sherman's army.  If he ever raised aforce it was too late to do the work expected of it.  Hardee's wholeforce probably numbered less than ten thousand men.From Millen to Savannah the country is sandy and poor
column387: and affords butvery little forage other than rice straw
column388: which was then growing.  Thisanswered a very good purpose as forage
column389: and the rice grain was anaddition to the soldier's rations.  No further resistance worthy of notewas met with
column390: until within a few miles of Savannah.  This place wasfound to be intrenched and garrisoned.  Sherman proceeded at once on hisarrival to invest the place
column391: and found that the enemy had placedtorpedoes in the ground
column392: which were to explode when stepped on by man orbeast. One of these exploded under an officer's horse
column393: blowing theanimal to pieces and tearing one of the legs of the officer so badlythat it had to be amputated.  Sherman at once ordered his prisoners tothe front
column394: moving them in a compact body in advance
column395: to either explodethe torpedoes or dig them up.  No further explosion took place.On the 10th of December the siege of Savannah commenced. Sherman then
column396: before proceeding any further with operations for the capture of theplace
column397: started with some troops to open communication with our fleet
column398: which he expected to find in the lower harbor or as near by as the fortsof the enemy would permit. In marching to the coast he encountered FortMcAllister
column399: which it was necessary to reduce before the supplies hemight find on shipboard could be made available.  Fort McAllister wassoon captured by an assault made by General Hazen's division.Communication was then established with the fleet.  The capture ofSavannah then only occupied a few days
column400: and involved no great loss oflife.  The garrison
column403: was enabled to escape bycrossing the river and moving eastward.When Sherman had opened communication with the fleet he found there asteamer
column404: which I had forwarded to him
column405: carrying the accumulated mailsfor his army
column406: also supplies which I supposed he would be in need of.General J. G. Foster
column407: who commanded all the troops south of NorthCarolina on the Atlantic sea-board
column408: visited General Sherman before hehad opened communication with the fleet
column409: with the view of ascertainingwhat assistance he could be to him.  Foster returned immediately to hisown headquarters at Hilton Head
column410: for the purpose of sending Shermansiege guns
column411: and also if he should find he had them to spare
column415: thinking that these articles might not befound outside.  The mail on the steamer which I sent down
column416: had beencollected by Colonel A. H. Markland of the Post Office Department
column417: whowent in charge of it.  On this same vessel I sent an officer of my staff(Lieutenant Dunn) with the following letter to General Sherman:CITY POINT
column422: Ga.The little information gleaned from the Southern press
column423: indicating nogreat obstacle to your progress
column424: I have directed your mails (which hadbeen previously collected at Baltimore by Colonel Markland
column425: SpecialAgent of the Post Office Department) to be sent as far as the blockadingsquadron off Savannah
column426: to be forwarded to you as soon as heard from onthe coast.Not liking to rejoice before the victory is assured
column427: I abstain fromcongratulating you and those under your command
column428: until bottom has beenstruck.  I have never had a fear
column430: for the result.Since you left Atlanta
column431: no very great progress has been made here. Theenemy has been closely watched though
column432: and prevented from detachingagainst you.  I think not one man has gone from here
column433: except some twelveor fifteen hundred dismounted cavalry.  Bragg has gone from Wilmington.I am trying to take advantage of his absence to get possession of thatplace.  Owing to some preparations Admiral Porter and General Butler aremaking to blow up Fort Fisher (which
column435: I donot believe a particle in)
column436: there is a delay in getting this expeditionoff.  I hope they will be ready to start by the 7th
column437: and that Bragg willnot have started back by that time.In this letter I do not intend to give you anything like directions forfuture action
column438: but will state a general idea I have
column439: and will get yourviews after you have established yourself on the sea-coast. With yourveteran army I hope to get control of the only two through routes fromeast to west possessed by the enemy before the fall of Atlanta.  Thecondition will be filled by holding Savannah and Augusta
column440: or by holdingany other port to the east of Savannah and Branchville.  If Wilmingtonfalls
column441: a force from there can co-operate with you.Thomas has got back into the defences of Nashville
column442: with Hood close uponhim.  Decatur has been abandoned
column443: and so have all the roads except themain one leading to Chattanooga.  Part of this falling back wasundoubtedly necessary and all of it may have been.  It did not look so
column446: Thomas far outnumbers Hood in infantry.In cavalry
column447: Hood has the advantage in morale and numbers.  I hope yetthat Hood will be badly crippled if not destroyed.  The general news youwill learn from the papers better than I could give it.After all becomes quiet
column448: and roads become so bad up here that there islikely to be a week or two when nothing can be done
column449: I will run down thecoast to see you.  If you desire it
column450: I will ask Mrs. Sherman to go withme.Yours truly
column452: Lieutenant-GeneralI quote this letter because it gives the reader a full knowledge of theevents of that period.Sherman now (the 15th) returned to Savannah to complete its investmentand insure the surrender of the garrison.  The country about Savannah islow and marshy
column453: and the city was well intrenched from the river above tothe river below; and assaults could not be made except along acomparatively narrow causeway. For this reason assaults must haveresulted in serious destruction of life to the Union troops
column454: with thechance of failing altogether. Sherman therefore decided upon a completeinvestment of the place.  When he believed this investment completed
column455: hesummoned the garrison to surrender.  General Hardee
column457: replied in substance that the condition of affairs was not such asSherman had described.  He said he was in full communication with hisdepartment and was receiving supplies constantly.Hardee
column459: was cut off entirely from all communication with thewest side of the river
column460: and by the river itself to the north and south.On the South Carolina side the country was all rice fields
column461: throughwhich it would have been impossible to bring supplies so that Hardee hadno possible communication with the outside world except by a dilapidatedplank road starting from the west bank of the river.  Sherman
column463: proceeded in person to a point on the coast
column464: where GeneralFoster had troops stationed under General Hatch
column465: for the purpose ofmaking arrangements with the latter officer to go through by one of thenumerous channels running inland along that part of the coast of SouthCarolina
column466: to the plank road which General Hardee still possessed
column467: andthus to cut him off from the last means he had of getting supplies
column468: ifnot of communication.While arranging for this movement
column469: and before the attempt to execute theplan had been commenced
column470: Sherman received information through one of hisstaff officers that the enemy had evacuated Savannah the night before.This was the night of the 21st of December.  Before evacuating the placeHardee had blown up the navy yard.  Some iron-clads had been destroyed
column471: as well as other property that might have been valuable to us; but heleft an immense amount of stores untouched
column476: and severalthousand stands of small arms.A little incident occurred
column477: soon after the fall of Savannah
column479: and which is worthy of repetition.Savannah was one of the points where blockade runners entered. Shortlyafter the city fell into our possession
column480: a blockade runner came sailingup serenely
column481: not doubting but the Confederates were still in possession.It was not molested
column482: and the captain did not find out his mistake untilhe had tied up and gone to the Custom House
column483: where he found a newoccupant of the building
column484: and made a less profitable disposition of hisvessel and cargo than he had expected.As there was some discussion as to the authorship of Sherman's march tothe sea
column485: by critics of his book when it appeared before the public
column486: Iwant to state here that no question upon that subject was ever raisedbetween General Sherman and myself. Circumstances made the plan on whichSherman expected to act impracticable
column487: as as commander of the forces henecessarily had to devise a new on which would give more promise ofsuccess: consequently he recommended the destruction of the railroadback to Chattanooga
column488: and that he should be authorized then to move
column490: from Atlanta forward.  His suggestions were finally approved
column491: although they did not immediately find favor in Washington.  Even whenit came to the time of starting
column493: as to thepropriety of the campaign he was about commence
column495: induced no doubt by his advisers.  This went so far as tomove the President to ask me to suspend Sherman's march for a day or twountil I could think the matter over.  My recollection is
column496: though I findno record to show it
column497: that out of deference to the President's wish Idid send a dispatch to Sherman asking him to wait a day or two
column498: or elsethe connections between us were already cut so that I could not do so.However this may be
column499: the question of who devised the plan of march fromAtlanta to Savannah is easily answered:  it was clearly Sherman
column500: and tohim also belongs the credit of its brilliant execution.  It was hardlypossible that any one else than those on the spot could have devised anew plan of campaign to supersede one that did not promise success.(*40)I was in favor of Sherman's plan from the time it was first submitted tome.  My chief of staff
column502: was very bitterly opposed to it and
column504: finding that he could not move me
column505: he appealedto the authorities at Washington to stop it.

column1: ISFP	 LX.THE BATTLE OF FRANKLIN--THE BATTLE OF NASHVILLE.As we have seen
column2: Hood succeeded in crossing the Tennessee River betweenMuscle Shoals and the lower shoals at the end of October
column3: 1864.  Thomassent Schofield with the 4th and 23d corps
column4: together with three brigadesof Wilson's cavalry to Pulaski to watch him.  On the 17th of NovemberHood started and moved in such a manner as to avoid Schofield
column5: therebyturning his position.  Hood had with him three infantry corps
column6: commandedrespectively by Stephen D. Lee
column7: Stewart and Cheatham.  These
column8: with hiscavalry
column9: numbered about forty-five thousand men. Schofield had
column10: of allarms
column11: about thirty thousand.  Thomas's orders were
column12: therefore
column13: forSchofield to watch the movements of the enemy
column14: but not to fight a battleif he could avoid it; but to fall back in case of an advance onNashville
column15: and to fight the enemy
column16: as he fell back
column17: so as to retard theenemy's movements until he could be reinforced by Thomas himself.  Assoon as Schofield saw this movement of Hood's
column18: he sent his trains to therear
column19: but did not fall back himself until the 21st
column20: and then only toColumbia.  At Columbia there was a slight skirmish but no battle.  Fromthis place Schofield then retreated to Franklin.  He had sent his wagonsin advance
column21: and Stanley had gone with them with two divisions to protectthem.  Cheatham's corps of Hood's army pursued the wagon train and wentinto camp at Spring Hill
column22: for the night of the 29th.Schofield retreating from Columbia on the 29th
column23: passed Spring Hill
column24: where Cheatham was bivouacked
column25: during the night without molestation
column26: though within half a mile of where the Confederates were encamped.  Onthe morning of the 30th he had arrived at Franklin.Hood followed closely and reached Franklin in time to make an attack thesame day.  The fight was very desperate and sanguinary.  The Confederategenerals led their men in the repeated charges
column27: and the loss among themwas of unusual proportions.  This fighting continued with great severityuntil long after the night closed in
column28: when the Confederates drew off.General Stanley
column29: who commanded two divisions of the Union troops
column30: andwhose troops bore the brunt of the battle
column31: was wounded in the fight
column32: butmaintained his position.The enemy's loss at Franklin
column33: according to Thomas's report
column34: was 1
column35: 750buried upon the field by our troops
column37: 800 in the hospital
column38: and 702prisoners besides.  Schofield's loss
column39: as officially reported
column40: was 189killed
column42: 033 wounded
column43: and 1
column44: 104 captured and missing.Thomas made no effort to reinforce Schofield at Franklin
column45: as it seemedto me at the time he should have done
column46: and fight out the battle there.He simply ordered Schofield to continue his retreat to Nashville
column47: whichthe latter did during that night and the next day.Thomas
column48: in the meantime
column49: was making his preparations to receive Hood.The road to Chattanooga was still well guarded with strong garrisons atMurfreesboro
column50: Stevenson
column51: Bridgeport and Chattanooga.  Thomas hadpreviously given up Decatur and had been reinforced by A. J. Smith's twodivisions just returned from Missouri.  He also had Steedman's divisionand R. S. Granger's
column52: which he had drawn from the front.  Hisquartermaster's men
column53: about ten thousand in number
column54: had been organizedand armed under the command of the chief quartermaster
column55: General J. L.Donaldson
column56: and placed in the fortifications under the generalsupervision of General Z. B. Tower
column57: of the United States Engineers.Hood was allowed to move upon Nashville
column58: and to invest that place almostwithout interference.  Thomas was strongly fortified in his position
column59: sothat he would have been safe against the attack of Hood.  He had troopsenough even to annihilate him in the open field.  To me his delay wasunaccountable--sitting there and permitting himself to be invested
column60: sothat
column61: in the end
column62: to raise the siege he would have to fight the enemystrongly posted behind fortifications.  It is true the weather was verybad.  The rain was falling and freezing as it fell
column63: so that the groundwas covered with a sheet of ice
column64: that made it very difficult to move.But I was afraid that the enemy would find means of moving
column65: elude Thomasand manage to get north of the Cumberland River.  If he did this
column66: Iapprehended most serious results from the campaign in the North
column67: and wasafraid we might even have to send troops from the East to head him offif he got there
column68: General Thomas's movements being always so deliberateand so slow
column69: though effective in defence.I consequently urged Thomas in frequent dispatches sent from CityPoint(*41) to make the attack at once.  The country was alarmed
column70: theadministration was alarmed
column71: and I was alarmed lest the very thing wouldtake place which I have just described that is
column72: Hood would get north.It was all without avail further than to elicit dispatches from Thomassaying that he was getting ready to move as soon as he could
column73: that hewas making preparations
column74: etc.  At last I had to say to General Thomasthat I should be obliged to remove him unless he acted promptly.  Hereplied that he was very sorry
column75: but he would move as soon as he could.General Logan happening to visit City Point about that time
column76: and knowinghim as a prompt
column77: gallant and efficient officer
column78: I gave him an order toproceed to Nashville to relieve Thomas.  I directed him
column79: however
column80: not todeliver the order or publish it until he reached there
column81: and if Thomashad moved
column82: then not to deliver it at all
column83: but communicate with me bytelegraph.  After Logan started
column84: in thinking over the situation
column85: Ibecame restless
column86: and concluded to go myself.  I went as far asWashington City
column87: when a dispatch was received from General Thomasannouncing his readiness at last to move
column88: and designating the time ofhis movement.  I concluded to wait until that time. He did move
column89: and wassuccessful from the start.  This was on the 15th of December.  GeneralLogan was at Louisville at the time this movement was made
column90: andtelegraphed the fact to Washington
column91: and proceeded no farther himself.The battle during the 15th was severe
column92: but favorable to the Uniontroops
column93: and continued until night closed in upon the combat.  The nextday the battle was renewed.  After a successful assault upon Hood's menin their intrenchments the enemy fled in disorder
column94: routed and broken
column95: leaving their dead
column96: their artillery and small arms in great numbers onthe field
column97: besides the wounded that were captured.  Our cavalry hadfought on foot as infantry
column98: and had not their horses with them; so thatthey were not ready to join in the pursuit the moment the enemyretreated.  They sent back
column99: however
column100: for their horses
column101: and endeavored toget to Franklin ahead of Hood's broken army by the Granny White Road
column102: but too much time was consumed in getting started.  They had got but afew miles beyond the scene of the battle when they found the enemy'scavalry dismounted and behind intrenchments covering the road on whichthey were advancing. Here another battle ensued
column103: our men dismounting andfighting on foot
column104: in which the Confederates were again routed and drivenin great disorder.  Our cavalry then went into bivouac
column105: and renewed thepursuit on the following morning.  They were too late.  The enemyalready had possession of Franklin
column106: and was beyond them. It now became achase in which the Confederates had the lead.Our troops continued the pursuit to within a few miles of Columbia
column107: where they found the rebels had destroyed the railroad bridge as well asall other bridges over Duck River.  The heavy rains of a few days beforehad swelled the stream into a mad torrent
column108: impassable except on bridges.Unfortunately
column109: either through a mistake in the wording of the order orotherwise
column110: the pontoon bridge which was to have been sent by rail out toFranklin
column111: to be taken thence with the pursuing column
column112: had gone towardChattanooga.  There was
column113: consequently
column114: a delay of some four days inbuilding bridges out of the remains of the old railroad bridge.  Ofcourse Hood got such a start in this time that farther pursuit wasuseless
column115: although it was continued for some distance
column116: but without comingupon him again.

column1: ISFP	 LXI.EXPEDITION AGAINST FORT FISHER--ATTACK ON THE FORT--FAILURE OF THEEXPEDITION--SECOND EXPEDITION AGAINST THE FORT--CAPTURE OF FORT FISHER.Up to January
column3: the enemy occupied Fort Fisher
column4: at the mouth ofCape Fear River and below the City of Wilmington.  This port was ofimmense importance to the Confederates
column5: because it formed theirprincipal inlet for blockade runners by means of which they brought infrom abroad such supplies and munitions of war as they could not produceat home.  It was equally important to us to get possession of it
column6: notonly because it was desirable to cut off their supplies so as to insurea speedy termination of the war
column7: but also because foreign governments
column8: particularly the British Government
column9: were constantly threatening thatunless ours could maintain the blockade of that coast they should ceaseto recognize any blockade.  For these reasons I determined
column10: with theconcurrence of the Navy Department
column11: in December
column12: to send an expeditionagainst Fort Fisher for the purpose of capturing it.To show the difficulty experienced in maintaining the blockade
column13: I willmention a circumstance that took place at Fort Fisher after its fall.Two English blockade runners came in at night.  Their commanders
column14: notsupposing the fort had fallen
column15: worked their way through all our fleetand got into the river unobserved.  They then signalled the fort
column16: announcing their arrival.  There was a colored man in the fort who hadbeen there before and who understood these signals.  He informed GeneralTerry what reply he should make to have them come in
column17: and Terry did ashe advised.  The vessels came in
column18: their officers entirely unconsciousthat they were falling into the hands of the Union forces.  Even afterthey were brought in to the fort they were entertained in conversationfor some little time before suspecting that the Union troops wereoccupying the fort.  They were finally informed that their vessels andcargoes were prizes.I selected General Weitzel
column19: of the Army of the James
column20: to go with theexpedition
column21: but gave instructions through General Butler.  He commandedthe department within whose geographical limits Fort Fisher wassituated
column22: as well as Beaufort and other points on that coast held by ourtroops; he was
column23: therefore
column24: entitled to the right of fitting out theexpedition against Fort Fisher.General Butler conceived the idea that if a steamer loaded heavily withpowder could be run up to near the shore under the fort and exploded
column25: itwould create great havoc and make the capture an easy matter.  AdmiralPorter
column26: who was to command the naval squadron
column27: seemed to fall in withthe idea
column28: and it was not disapproved of in Washington; the navy wastherefore given the task of preparing the steamer for this purpose.  Ihad no confidence in the success of the scheme
column29: and so expressed myself;but as no serious harm could come of the experiment
column30: and the authoritiesat Washington seemed desirous to have it tried
column31: I permitted it.  Thesteamer was sent to Beaufort
column32: North Carolina
column33: and was there loaded withpowder and prepared for the part she was to play in the reduction ofFort Fisher.General Butler chose to go in command of the expedition himself
column34: and wasall ready to sail by the 9th of December (1864).  Very heavy stormsprevailed
column35: however
column36: at that time along that part of the sea-coast
column37: andprevented him from getting off until the 13th or 14th.  His advancearrived off Fort Fisher on the 15th.  The naval force had been alreadyassembled
column38: or was assembling
column39: but they were obliged to run into Beaufortfor munitions
column40: coal
column41: etc.; then
column42: too
column43: the powder-boat was not yet fullyprepared. The fleet was ready to proceed on the 18th; but Butler
column44: whohad remained outside from the 15th up to that time
column45: now found himselfout of coal
column46: fresh water
column47: etc.
column48: and had to put into Beaufort toreplenish.  Another storm overtook him
column49: and several days more were lostbefore the army and navy were both ready at the same time to co-operate.On the night of the 23d the powder-boat was towed in by a gunboat asnear to the fort as it was safe to run.  She was then propelled by herown machinery to within about five hundred yards of the shore.  Therethe clockwork
column50: which was to explode her within a certain length of time
column51: was set and she was abandoned.  Everybody left
column52: and even the vessels putout to sea to prevent the effect of the explosion upon them.  At twoo'clock in the morning the explosion took place--and produced no moreeffect on the fort
column53: or anything else on land
column54: than the bursting of aboiler anywhere on the Atlantic Ocean would have done.  Indeed when thetroops in Fort Fisher heard the explosion they supposed it was thebursting of a boiler in one of the Yankee gunboats.Fort Fisher was situated upon a low
column55: flat peninsula north of Cape FearRiver.  The soil is sandy.  Back a little the peninsula is very heavilywooded
column56: and covered with fresh-water swamps.  The fort ran across thispeninsula
column57: about five hundred yards in width
column58: and extended along the seacoast about thirteen hundred yards.  The fort had an armament of 21 gunsand 3 mortars on the land side
column59: and 24 guns on the sea front.  At thattime it was only garrisoned by four companies of infantry
column60: one lightbattery and the gunners at the heavy guns less than seven hundred menwith a reserve of less than a thousand men five miles up the peninsula.General Whiting of the Confederate army was in command
column61: and GeneralBragg was in command of the force at Wilmington.  Both commenced callingfor reinforcements the moment they saw our troops landing.  The Governorof North Carolina called for everybody who could stand behind a parapetand shoot a gun
column62: to join them.  In this way they got two or threehundred additional men into Fort Fisher; and Hoke's division
column63: five orsix thousand strong
column64: was sent down from Richmond.  A few of these troopsarrived the very day that Butler was ready to advance.On the 24th the fleet formed for an attack in arcs of concentriccircles
column65: their heavy iron-clads going in very close range
column66: being nearestthe shore
column67: and leaving intervals or spaces so that the outer vesselscould fire between them.  Porter was thus enabled to throw one hundredand fifteen shells per minute.  The damage done to the fort by theseshells was very slight
column68: only two or three cannon being disabled in thefort.  But the firing silenced all the guns by making it too hot for themen to maintain their positions about them and compelling them to seekshelter in the bomb-proofs.On the next day part of Butler's troops under General Adelbert Ameseffected a landing out of range of the fort without difficulty.  Thiswas accomplished under the protection of gunboats sent for the purpose
column69: and under cover of a renewed attack upon the fort by the fleet.  Theyformed a line across the peninsula and advanced
column70: part going north andpart toward the fort
column71: covering themselves as they did so.  Curtis pushedforward and came near to Fort Fisher
column72: capturing the small garrison atwhat was called the Flag Pond Battery.  Weitzel accompanied him towithin a half a mile of the works.  Here he saw that the fort had notbeen injured
column73: and so reported to Butler
column74: advising against an assault.Ames
column75: who had gone north in his advance
column76: captured 228 of the reserves.These prisoners reported to Butler that sixteen hundred of Hoke'sdivision of six thousand from Richmond had already arrived and the restwould soon be in his rear.Upon these reports Butler determined to withdraw his troops from thepeninsula and return to the fleet.  At that time there had not been aman on our side injured except by one of the shells from the fleet.Curtis had got within a few yards of the works.  Some of his men hadsnatched a flag from the parapet of the fort
column77: and others had taken ahorse from the inside of the stockade.  At night Butler informed Porterof his withdrawal
column78: giving the reasons above stated
column79: and announced hispurpose as soon as his men could embark to start for Hampton Roads.Porter represented to him that he had sent to Beaufort for moreammunition.  He could fire much faster than he had been doing
column80: and wouldkeep the enemy from showing himself until our men were within twentyyards of the fort
column81: and he begged that Butler would leave some bravefellows like those who had snatched the flag from the parapet and takenthe horse from the fort.Butler was unchangeable.  He got all his troops aboard
column82: except Curtis'sbrigade
column83: and started back.  In doing this
column84: Butler made a fearfulmistake.  My instructions to him
column85: or to the officer who went in commandof the expedition
column86: were explicit in the statement that to effect alanding would be of itself a great victory
column87: and if one should beeffected
column88: the foothold must not be relinquished; on the contrary
column89: aregular siege of the fort must be commenced and
column90: to guard againstinterference by reason of storms
column91: supplies of provisions must be laid inas soon as they could be got on shore.  But General Butler seems to havelost sight of this part of his instructions
column92: and was back at Fort Monroeon the 28th.I telegraphed to the President as follows:CITY POINT
column93: VA.
column94: Dec. 28
column95: 1864.--8.30 P.M.The Wilmington expedition has proven a gross and culpable failure.  Manyof the troops are back here.  Delays and free talk of the object of theexpedition enabled the enemy to move troops to Wilmington to defeat it.After the expedition sailed from Fort Monroe
column96: three days of fine weatherwere squandered
column97: during which the enemy was without a force to protecthimself. Who is to blame will
column98: I hope
column99: be known.U. S. GRANT
column100: Lieutenant-General.Porter sent dispatches to the Navy Department in which he complainedbitterly of having been abandoned by the army just when the fort wasnearly in our possession
column101: and begged that our troops might be sent backagain to cooperate
column102: but with a different commander.  As soon as I heardthis I sent a messenger to Porter with a letter asking him to hold on.I assured him that I fully sympathized with him in his disappointment
column103: and that I would send the same troops back with a different commander
column104: with some reinforcements to offset those which the enemy had received.I told him it would take some little time to get transportation for theadditional troops; but as soon as it could be had the men should be ontheir way to him
column105: and there would be no delay on my part.  I selected A.H. Terry to command.It was the 6th of January before the transports could be got ready andthe troops aboard.  They sailed from Fortress Monroe on that day.  Theobject and destination of the second expedition were at the time kept asecret to all except a few in the Navy Department and in the army towhom it was necessary to impart the information.  General Terry had notthe slightest idea of where he was going or what he was to do.  Hesimply knew that he was going to sea and that he had his orders withhim
column106: which were to be opened when out at sea.He was instructed to communicate freely with Porter and have entireharmony between army and navy
column107: because the work before them wouldrequire the best efforts of both arms of service. They arrived offBeaufort on the 8th. A heavy storm
column108: however
column109: prevented a landing atForth Fisher until the 13th.  The navy prepared itself for attack aboutas before
column110: and the same time assisted the army in landing
