column333: even if they could have been induced to remain onduty.  The men of both Lee's and Johnston's armies were
column334: like theirbrethren of the North
column335: as brave as men can be; but no man is so bravethat he may not meet such defeats and disasters as to discourage him anddampen his ardor for any cause
column336: no matter how just he deems it.

column1: ISFP	 LXIII.ARRIVAL OF THE PEACE COMMISSIONERS--LINCOLN AND THE PEACE COMMISSIONERS--AN ANECDOTE OF LINCOLN--THE WINTER BEFORE PETERSBURG--SHERIDAN DESTROYSTHE RAILROAD--GORDON CARRIES THE PICKET LINE--PARKE RECAPTURES THE LINE--THE LINE OF BATTLE OF WHITE OAK ROAD.On the last of January
column3: peace commissioners from the so-calledConfederate States presented themselves on our lines around Petersburg
column4: and were immediately conducted to my headquarters at City Point.  Theyproved to be Alexander H. Stephens
column5: Vice-President of the Confederacy
column6: Judge Campbell
column7: Assistant-Secretary of War
column8: and R. M. T. Hunt
column9: formerlyUnited States Senator and then a member of the Confederate Senate.It was about dark when they reached my headquarters
column10: and I at onceconducted them to the steam Mary Martin
column11: a Hudson River boat which wasvery comfortably fitted up for the use of passengers.  I at oncecommunicated by telegraph with Washington and informed the Secretary ofWar and the President of the arrival of these commissioners and thattheir object was to negotiate terms of peace between the United Statesand
column12: as they termed it
column13: the Confederate Government.  I was instructed toretain them at City Point
column14: until the President
column15: or some one whom hewould designate
column16: should come to meet them.  They remained several daysas guests on board the boat.  I saw them quite frequently
column17: though I haveno recollection of having had any conversation whatever with them on thesubject of their mission.  It was something I had nothing to do with
column18: and I therefore did not wish to express any views on the subject.  Formy own part I never had admitted
column19: and never was ready to admit
column20: thatthey were the representatives of a GOVERNMENT.  There had been too greata waste of blood and treasure to concede anything of the kind.  As longas they remained there
column21: however
column22: our relations were pleasant and I foundthem all very agreeable gentlemen.  I directed the captain to furnishthem with the best the boat afforded
column23: and to administer to their comfortin every way possible.  No guard was placed over them and no restrictionwas put upon their movements; nor was there any pledge asked that theywould not abuse the privileges extended to them.  They were permitted toleave the boat when they felt like it
column24: and did so
column25: coming up on the bankand visiting me at my headquarters.I had never met either of these gentlemen before the war
column26: but knew themwell by reputation and through their public services
column27: and I had been aparticular admirer of Mr. Stephens.  I had always supposed that he was avery small man
column28: but when I saw him in the dusk of the evening I was verymuch surprised to find so large a man as he seemed to be.  When he gotdown on to the boat I found that he was wearing a coarse gray woollenovercoat
column29: a manufacture that had been introduced into the South duringthe rebellion.  The cloth was thicker than anything of the kind I hadever seen
column30: even in Canada.  The overcoat extended nearly to his feet
column31: and was so large that it gave him the appearance of being anaverage-sized man.  He took this off when he reached the cabin of theboat
column32: and I was struck with the apparent change in size
column33: in the coat andout of it.After a few days
column34: about the 2d of February
column35: I received a dispatch fromWashington
column36: directing me to send the commissioners to Hampton Roads tomeet the President and a member of the cabinet.  Mr. Lincoln met themthere and had an interview of short duration.  It was not a great whileafter they met that the President visited me at City Point.  He spoke ofhis having met the commissioners
column37: and said he had told them that therewould be no use in entering into any negotiations unless they wouldrecognize
column38: first:  that the Union as a whole must be forever preserved
column39: and second:  that slavery must be abolished. If they were willing toconcede these two points
column40: then he was ready to enter into negotiationsand was almost willing to hand them a blank sheet of paper with hissignature attached for them to fill in the terms upon which they werewilling to live with us in the Union and be one people.  He alwaysshowed a generous and kindly spirit toward the Southern people
column41: and Inever heard him abuse an enemy.  Some of the cruel things said aboutPresident Lincoln
column42: particularly in the North
column43: used to pierce him to theheart; but never in my presence did he evince a revengeful dispositionand I saw a great deal of him at City Point
column44: for he seemed glad to getaway from the cares and anxieties of the capital.Right here I might relate an anecdote of Mr. Lincoln.  It was on theoccasion of his visit to me just after he had talked with the peacecommissioners at Hampton Roads.  After a little conversation
column45: he askedme if I had seen that overcoat of Stephens's.  I replied that I had.'Well
column46: ' said he
column47: 'did you see him take it off?'  I said yes.  'Well
column48: 'said he
column49: 'didn't you think it was the biggest shuck and the littlest earthat ever you did see?'  Long afterwards I told this story to theConfederate General J. B. Gordon
column50: at the time a member of the Senate.He repeated it to Stephens
column51: and
column52: as I heard afterwards
column53: Stephens laughedimmoderately at the simile of Mr. Lincoln.The rest of the winter
column54: after the departure of the peace commissioners
column55: passed off quietly and uneventfully
column56: except for two or three littleincidents.  On one occasion during this period
column57: while I was visitingWashington City for the purpose of conferring with the administration
column58: the enemy's cavalry under General Wade Hampton
column59: passing our extreme leftand then going to the south
column60: got in east of us.  Before their presencewas known
column61: they had driven off a large number of beef cattle that weregrazing in that section.  It was a fair capture
column62: and they weresufficiently needed by the Confederates.  It was only retaliating forwhat we had done
column63: sometimes for many weeks at a time
column64: when out ofsupplies taking what the Confederate army otherwise would have gotten.As appears in this book
column65: on one single occasion we captured fivethousand head of cattle which were crossing the Mississippi River nearPort Hudson on their way from Texas to supply the Confederate army inthe East.One of the most anxious periods of my experience during the rebellionwas the last few weeks before Petersburg.  I felt that the situation ofthe Confederate army was such that they would try to make an escape atthe earliest practicable moment
column66: and I was afraid
column67: every morning
column68: that Iwould awake from my sleep to hear that Lee had gone
column69: and that nothingwas left but a picket line.  He had his railroad by the way of Danvillesouth
column70: and I was afraid that he was running off his men and all storesand ordnance except such as it would be necessary to carry with him forhis immediate defence.  I knew he could move much more lightly and morerapidly than I
column71: and that
column72: if he got the start
column73: he would leave me behindso that we would have the same army to fight again farther south and thewar might be prolonged another year.I was led to this fear by the fact that I could not see how it waspossible for the Confederates to hold out much longer where they were.There is no doubt that Richmond would have been evacuated much soonerthan it was
column74: if it had not been that it was the capital of the so-calledConfederacy
column75: and the fact of evacuating the capital would
column76: of course
column77: have had a very demoralizing effect upon the Confederate army.  When itwas evacuated (as we shall see further on)
column78: the Confederacy at oncebegan to crumble and fade away.  Then
column79: too
column80: desertions were takingplace
column81: not only among those who were with General Lee in theneighborhood of their capital
column82: but throughout the whole Confederacy.  Iremember that in a conversation with me on one occasion long prior tothis
column83: General Butler remarked that the Confederates would find greatdifficulty in getting more men for their army; possibly adding
column84: though Iam not certain as to this
column85: 'unless they should arm the slave.'The South
column86: as we all knew
column87: were conscripting every able-bodied manbetween the ages of eighteen and forty-five; and now they had passed alaw for the further conscription of boys from fourteen to eighteen
column88: calling them the junior reserves
column89: and men from forty-five to sixty to becalled the senior reserves.  The latter were to hold the necessarypoints not in immediate danger
column90: and especially those in the rear.General Butler
column91: in alluding to this conscription
column92: remarked that theywere thus 'robbing both the cradle and the grave
column93: ' an expression which Iafterwards used in writing a letter to Mr. Washburn.It was my belief that while the enemy could get no more recruits theywere losing at least a regiment a day
column94: taking it throughout the entirearmy
column95: by desertions alone.  Then by casualties of war
column96: sickness
column97: andother natural causes
column98: their losses were much heavier.  It was a merequestion of arithmetic to calculate how long they could hold out whilethat rate of depletion was going on.  Of course long before their armywould be thus reduced to nothing the army which we had in the fieldwould have been able to capture theirs.  Then too I knew from the greatnumber of desertions
column99: that the men who had fought so bravely
column100: sogallantly and so long for the cause which they believed in--and asearnestly
column101: I take it
column102: as our men believed in the cause for which theywere fighting--had lost hope and become despondent.  Many of them weremaking application to be sent North where they might get employmentuntil the war was over
column103: when they could return to their Southern homes.For these and other reasons I was naturally very impatient for the timeto come when I could commence the spring campaign
column104: which I thoroughlybelieved would close the war.There were two considerations I had to observe
column105: however
column106: and whichdetained me.  One was the fact that the winter had been one of heavyrains
column107: and the roads were impassable for artillery and teams.  It wasnecessary to wait until they had dried sufficiently to enable us to movethe wagon trains and artillery necessary to the efficiency of an armyoperating in the enemy's country.  The other consideration was thatGeneral Sheridan with the cavalry of the Army of the Potomac wasoperating on the north side of the James River
column108: having come down fromthe Shenandoah. It was necessary that I should have his cavalry with me
column109: and I was therefore obliged to wait until he could join me south of theJames River.Let us now take account of what he was doing.On the 5th of March I had heard from Sheridan.  He had met Early betweenStaunton and Charlottesville and defeated him
column110: capturing nearly hisentire command.  Early and some of his officers escaped by findingrefuge in the neighboring houses or in the woods.On the 12th I heard from him again.  He had turned east
column111: to come toWhite House.  He could not go to Lynchburg as ordered
column112: because the rainshad been so very heavy and the streams were so very much swollen.  Hehad a pontoon train with him
column113: but it would not reach half way acrosssome of the streams
column114: at their then stage of water
column115: which he would haveto get over in going south as first ordered.I had supplies sent around to White House for him
column116: and kept the depotthere open until he arrived.  We had intended to abandon it because theJames River had now become our base of supplies.Sheridan had about ten thousand cavalry with him
column117: divided into twodivisions commanded respectively by Custer and Devin. General Merrittwas acting as chief of cavalry.  Sheridan moved very light
column118: carryingonly four days' provisions with him
column119: with a larger supply of coffee
column120: salt and other small rations
column121: and a very little else besides ammunition.They stopped at Charlottesville and commenced tearing up the railroadback toward Lynchburg.  He also sent a division along the James RiverCanal to destroy locks
column122: culverts etc.  All mills and factories along thelines of march of his troops were destroyed also.Sheridan had in this way consumed so much time that his making a marchto White House was now somewhat hazardous.  He determined therefore tofight his way along the railroad and canal till he was as near toRichmond as it was possible to get
column123: or until attacked.  He did this
column124: destroying the canal as far as Goochland
column125: and the railroad to a point asnear Richmond as he could get.  On the 10th he was at Columbia.  Negroeshad joined his column to the number of two thousand or more
column126: and theyassisted considerably in the work of destroying the railroads and thecanal.  His cavalry was in as fine a condition as when he started
column127: because he had been able to find plenty of forage. He had captured mostof Early's horses and picked up a good many others on the road.  When hereached Ashland he was assailed by the enemy in force.  He resistedtheir assault with part of his command
column128: moved quickly across the Southand North Anna
column129: going north
column130: and reached White House safely on the 19th.The time for Sherman to move had to be fixed with reference to the timehe could get away from Goldsboro where he then was. Supplies had to begot up to him which would last him through a long march
column131: as there wouldprobably not be much to be obtained in the country through which hewould pass.  I had to arrange
column132: therefore
column133: that he should start fromwhere he was
column134: in the neighborhood of Goldsboro on the 18th of April
column135: theearliest day at which he supposed he could be ready.Sherman was anxious that I should wait where I was until he could comeup
column136: and make a sure thing of it; but I had determined to move as soon asthe roads and weather would admit of my doing so.  I had been tied downsomewhat in the matter of fixing any time at my pleasure for starting
column137: until Sheridan
column138: who was on his way from the Shenandoah Valley to joinme
column139: should arrive
column140: as both his presence and that of his cavalry werenecessary to the execution of the plans which I had in mind.  However
column141: having arrived at White House on the 19th of March
column142: I was enabled tomake my plans.Prompted by my anxiety lest Lee should get away some night before I wasaware of it
column143: and having the lead of me
column144: push into North Carolina to joinwith Johnston in attempting to crush out Sherman
column145: I had
column146: as early as the1st of the month of March
column147: given instructions to the troops aroundPetersburg to keep a sharp lookout to see that such a movement shouldnot escape their notice
column148: and to be ready strike at once if it wasundertaken.It is now known that early in the month of March Mr. Davis and GeneralLee had a consultation about the situation of affairs in and about andPetersburg
column149: and they both agreed places were no longer tenable for them
column150: and that they must get away as soon as possible.  They
column151: too
column152: werewaiting for dry roads
column153: or a condition of the roads which would make itpossible to move.General Lee
column154: in aid of his plan of escape
column155: and to secure a wider openingto enable them to reach the Danville Road with greater security than hewould have in the way the two armies were situated
column156: determined upon anassault upon the right of our lines around Petersburg.  The night of the24th of March was fixed upon for this assault
column157: and General Gordon wasassigned to the execution of the plan.  The point between Fort Stedmanand Battery No. 10
column158: where our lines were closest together
column159: was selectedas the point of his attack.  The attack was to be made at night
column160: and thetroops were to get possession of the higher ground in the rear wherethey supposed we had intrenchments
column161: then sweep to the right and left
column162: create a panic in the lines of our army
column163: and force me to contract mylines.  Lee hoped this would detain me a few days longer and give him anopportunity of escape.  The plan was well conceived and the execution ofit very well done indeed
column164: up to the point of carrying a portion of ourline.Gordon assembled his troops under the cover of night
column165: at the point atwhich they were to make their charge
column166: and got possession of ourpicket-line
column167: entirely without the knowledge of the troops inside of ourmain line of intrenchments; this reduced the distance he would have tocharge over to not much more than fifty yards.  For some time before thedeserters had been coming in with great frequency
column168: often bringing theirarms with them
column169: and this the Confederate general knew.  Taking advantageof this knowledge he sent his pickets
column170: with their arms
column171: creeping throughto ours as if to desert.  When they got to our lines they at once tookpossession and sent our pickets to the rear as prisoners. In the mainline our men were sleeping serenely
column172: as if in great security.  This planwas to have been executed and much damage done before daylight; but thetroops that were to reinforce Gordon had to be brought from the northside of the James River and
column173: by some accident on the railroad on theirway over
column174: they were detained for a considerable time; so that it got tobe nearly daylight before they were ready to make the charge.The charge
column175: however
column176: was successful and almost without loss
column177: the enemypassing through our lines between Fort Stedman and Battery No. 10.  Thenturning to the right and left they captured the fort and the battery
column178: with all the arms and troops in them. Continuing the charge
column179: they alsocarried batteries Eleven and Twelve to our left
column180: which they turnedtoward City Point.Meade happened to be at City Point that night
column181: and this break in hisline cut him off from all communication with his headquarters.  Parke
column182: however
column183: commanding the 9th corps when this breach took place
column184: telegraphed the facts to Meade's headquarters
column185: and learning that thegeneral was away
column186: assumed command himself and with commendablepromptitude made all preparations to drive the enemy back.  GeneralTidball gathered a large number of pieces of artillery and planted themin rear of the captured works so as to sweep the narrow space of groundbetween the lines very thoroughly.  Hartranft was soon out with hisdivision
column187: as also was Willcox.  Hartranft to the right of the breachheaded the rebels off in that direction and rapidly drove them back intoFort Stedman.  On the other side they were driven back into theintrenchments which they had captured
column188: and batteries eleven and twelvewere retaken by Willcox early in the morning.Parke then threw a line around outside of the captured fort andbatteries
column189: and communication was once more established.  The artilleryfire was kept up so continuously that it was impossible for theConfederates to retreat
column190: and equally impossible for reinforcements tojoin them.  They all
column191: therefore
column192: fell captives into our hands.  Thiseffort of Lee's cost him about four thousand men
column193: and resulted in theirkilling
column194: wounding and capturing about two thousand of ours.After the recapture of the batteries taken by the Confederates
column195: ourtroops made a charge and carried the enemy's intrenched picket line
column196: which they strengthened and held.  This
column197: in turn
column198: gave us but a shortdistance to charge over when our attack came to be made a few dayslater.The day that Gordon was making dispositions for this attack (24th ofMarch) I issued my orders for the movement to commence on the 29th.Ord
column199: with three divisions of infantry and Mackenzie's cavalry
column200: was tomove in advance on the night of the 27th
column201: from the north side of theJames River and take his place on our extreme left
column202: thirty miles away.He left Weitzel with the rest of the Army of the James to hold BermudaHundred and the north of the James River.  The engineer brigade was tobe left at City Point
column203: and Parke's corps in the lines about Petersburg.(*42)Ord was at his place promptly.  Humphreys and Warren were then on ourextreme left with the 2d and 5th corps.  They were directed on thearrival of Ord
column204: and on his getting into position in their places
column205: tocross Hatcher's Run and extend out west toward Five Forks
column206: the objectbeing to get into a position from which we could strike the South SideRailroad and ultimately the Danville Railroad.  There was considerablefighting in taking up these new positions for the 2d and 5th corps
column207: inwhich the Army of the James had also to participate somewhat
column208: and thelosses were quite severe.This was what was known as the Battle of White Oak Road.

column1: ISFP	 LXIV.INTERVIEW WITH SHERIDAN--GRAND MOVEMENT OF THE ARMY OF THE POTOMAC--SHERIDAN'S ADVANCE ON FIVE FORKS--BATTLE OF FIVE FORKS--PARKE ANDWRIGHT STORM THE ENEMY'S LINE--BATTLES BEFORE PETERSBURG.Sheridan reached City Point on the 26th day of March.  His horses
column2: ofcourse
column3: were jaded and many of them had lost their shoes.  A few days ofrest were necessary to recuperate the animals and also to have them shodand put in condition for moving.  Immediately on General Sheridan'sarrival at City Point I prepared his instructions for the move which Ihad decided upon.  The movement was to commence on the 29th of themonth.After reading the instructions I had given him
column4: Sheridan walked out ofmy tent
column5: and I followed to have some conversation with him by himself--not in the presence of anybody else
column6: even of a member of my staff.  Inpreparing his instructions I contemplated just what took place; that isto say
column7: capturing Five Forks
column8: driving the enemy from Petersburg andRichmond and terminating the contest before separating from the enemy.But the Nation had already become restless and discouraged at theprolongation of the war
column9: and many believed that it would never terminateexcept by compromise.  Knowing that unless my plan proved an entiresuccess it would be interpreted as a disastrous defeat
column10: I provided inthese instructions that in a certain event he was to cut loose from theArmy of the Potomac and his base of supplies
column11: and living upon thecountry proceed south by the way of the Danville Railroad
column12: or near it
column13: across the Roanoke
column14: get in the rear of Johnston
column15: who was guarding thatroad
column16: and cooperate with Sherman in destroying Johnston; then with thesecombined forces to help carry out the instructions which Sherman alreadyhad received
column17: to act in cooperation with the armies around Petersburgand Richmond.I saw that after Sheridan had read his instructions he seemed somewhatdisappointed at the idea
column18: possibly
column19: of having to cut loose again fromthe Army of the Potomac
column20: and place himself between the two main armiesof the enemy.  I said to him: 'General
column21: this portion of yourinstructions I have put in merely as a blind;' and gave him the reasonfor doing so
column22: heretofore described.  I told him that
column23: as a matter offact
column24: I intended to close the war right here
column25: with this movement
column26: andthat he should go no farther.  His face at once brightened up
column27: andslapping his hand on his leg he said:  'I am glad to hear it
column28: and we cando it.'Sheridan was not however to make his movement against Five Forks untilhe got further instructions from me.One day
column29: after the movement I am about to describe had commenced
column30: andwhen his cavalry was on our extreme left and far to the rear
column31: south
column32: Sheridan rode up to where my headquarters were then established
column33: atDabney's Mills.  He met some of my staff officers outside
column34: and washighly jubilant over the prospects of success
column35: giving reasons why hebelieved this would prove the final and successful effort.  Although mychief-of-staff had urged very strongly that we return to our positionabout City Point and in the lines around Petersburg
column36: he asked Sheridanto come in to see me and say to me what he had been saying to them.Sheridan felt a little modest about giving his advice where it had notbeen asked; so one of my staff came in and told me that Sheridan hadwhat they considered important news
column37: and suggested that I send for him.I did so
column38: and was glad to see the spirit of confidence with which he wasimbued. Knowing as I did from experience
column39: of what great value thatfeeling of confidence by a commander was
column40: I determined to make amovement at once
column41: although on account of the rains which had fallenafter I had started out the roads were still very heavy.  Orders weregiven accordingly.Finally the 29th of March came
column42: and fortunately there having been a fewdays free from rain
column43: the surface of the ground was dry
column44: givingindications that the time had come when we could move.  On that date Imoved out with all the army available after leaving sufficient force tohold the line about Petersburg.  It soon set in raining again however
column45: and in a very short time the roads became practically impassable forteams
column46: and almost so for cavalry.  Sometimes a horse or mule would bestanding apparently on firm ground
column47: when all at once one foot wouldsink
column48: and as he commenced scrambling to catch himself all his feet wouldsink and he would have to be drawn by hand out of the quicksands socommon in that part of Virginia and other southern States.  It becamenecessary therefore to build corduroy roads every foot of the way as weadvanced
column49: to move our artillery upon.  The army had become so accustomedto this kind of work
column50: and were so well prepared for it
column51: that it was donevery rapidly.  The next day
column52: March 30th
column53: we had made sufficient progressto the south-west to warrant me in starting Sheridan with his cavalryover by Dinwiddie with instructions to then come up by the road leadingnorth-west to Five Forks
column54: thus menacing the right of Lee's line.This movement was made for the purpose of extending our lines to thewest as far as practicable towards the enemy's extreme right
column55: or FiveForks.  The column moving detached from the army still in the trencheswas
column56: excluding the cavalry
column57: very small.  The forces in the trenches werethemselves extending to the left flank. Warren was on the extreme leftwhen the extension began
column58: but Humphreys was marched around later andthrown into line between him and Five Forks.My hope was that Sheridan would be able to carry Five Forks
column59: get on theenemy's right flank and rear
column60: and force them to weaken their centre toprotect their right so that an assault in the centre might besuccessfully made.  General Wright's corps had been designated to makethis assault
column61: which I intended to order as soon as information reachedme of Sheridan's success.  He was to move under cover as close to theenemy as he could get.It is natural to suppose that Lee would understand my design to be toget up to the South Side and ultimately to the Danville Railroad
column62: assoon as he had heard of the movement commenced on the 29th.  These roadswere so important to his very existence while he remained in Richmondand Petersburg
column63: and of such vital importance to him even in case ofretreat
column64: that naturally he would make most strenuous efforts to defendthem.  He did on the 30th send Pickett with five brigades to reinforceFive Forks.  He also sent around to the right of his army some two orthree other divisions
column65: besides directing that other troops be held inreadiness on the north side of the James River to come over on call.  Hecame over himself to superintend in person the defence of his rightflank.Sheridan moved back to Dinwiddie Court-House on the night of the 30th
column66: and then took a road leading north-west to Five Forks.  He had only hiscavalry with him.  Soon encountering the rebel cavalry he met with avery stout resistance.  He gradually drove them back however until inthe neighborhood of Five Forks.  Here he had to encounter other troopsbesides those he had been contending with
column67: and was forced to give way.In this condition of affairs he notified me of what had taken place andstated that he was falling back toward Dinwiddie gradually and slowly
column68: and asked me to send Wright's corps to his assistance.  I replied to himthat it was impossible to send Wright's corps because that corps wasalready in line close up to the enemy
column69: where we should want to assaultwhen the proper time came
column70: and was besides a long distance from him; butthe 2d (Humphreys's) and 5th (Warren's) corps were on our extreme leftand a little to the rear of it in a position to threaten the left flankof the enemy at Five Forks
column71: and that I would send Warren.Accordingly orders were sent to Warren to move at once that night (the31st) to Dinwiddie Court House and put himself in communication withSheridan as soon as possible
column72: and report to him.  He was very slow inmoving
column73: some of his troops not starting until after 5 o'clock nextmorning.  When he did move it was done very deliberately
column74: and onarriving at Gravelly Run he found the stream swollen from the recentrains so that he regarded it as not fordable.  Sheridan of course knewof his coming
column75: and being impatient to get the troops up as soon aspossible
column76: sent orders to him to hasten.  He was also hastened or atleast ordered to move up rapidly by General Meade.  He now felt that hecould not cross that creek without bridges
column77: and his orders were changedto move so as to strike the pursuing enemy in flank or get in theirrear; but he was so late in getting up that Sheridan determined to moveforward without him.  However
column78: Ayres's division of Warren's corpsreached him in time to be in the fight all day
column79: most of the timeseparated from the remainder of the 5th corps and fighting directlyunder Sheridan.Warren reported to Sheridan about 11 o'clock on the 1st
column80: but the wholeof his troops were not up so as to be much engaged until late in theafternoon.  Griffin's division in backing to get out of the way of asevere cross fire of the enemy was found marching away from thefighting.  This did not continue long
column81: however; the division was broughtback and with Ayres's division did most excellent service during theday.  Crawford's division of the same corps had backed still fartheroff
column82: and although orders were sent repeatedly to bring it up
column83: it waslate before it finally got to where it could be of material assistance.Once there it did very excellent service.Sheridan succeeded by the middle of the afternoon or a little later
column84: inadvancing up to the point from which to make his designed assault uponFive Forks itself.  He was very impatient to make the assault and haveit all over before night
column85: because the ground he occupied would beuntenable for him in bivouac during the night.  Unless the assault wasmade and was successful
column86: he would be obliged to return to DinwiddieCourt-House
column87: or even further than that for the night.It was at this junction of affairs that Sheridan wanted to getCrawford's division in hand
column88: and he also wanted Warren.  He sent staffofficer after staff officer in search of Warren
column89: directing that generalto report to him
column90: but they were unable to find him.  At all eventsSheridan was unable to get that officer to him.  Finally he wenthimself.  He issued an order relieving Warren and assigning Griffin tothe command of the 5th corps. column1: ISFP	 LXV.THE CAPTURE OF PETERSBURG--MEETING PRESIDENT LINCOLN IN PETERSBURG--THECAPTURE OF RICHMOND--PURSUING THE ENEMY--VISIT TO SHERIDAN AND MEADE.General Meade and I entered Petersburg on the morning of the 3d and tooka position under cover of a house which protected us from the enemy'smusketry which was flying thick and fast there.  As we wouldoccasionally look around the corner we could see the streets and theAppomattox bottom
column2: presumably near the bridge
column3: packed with theConfederate army.  I did not have artillery brought up
column4: because I wassure Lee was trying to make his escape
column5: and I wanted to push immediatelyin pursuit.  At all events I had not the heart to turn the artilleryupon such a mass of defeated and fleeing men
column6: and I hoped to capturethem soon.Soon after the enemy had entirely evacuated Petersburg
column7: a man came inwho represented himself to be an engineer of the Army of NorthernVirginia.  He said that Lee had for some time been at work preparing astrong enclosed intrenchment
column8: into which he would throw himself whenforced out of Petersburg
column9: and fight his final battle there; that he wasactually at that time drawing his troops from Richmond
column10: and falling backinto this prepared work. This statement was made to General Meade andmyself when we were together.  I had already given orders for themovement up the south side of the Appomattox for the purpose of headingoff Lee; but Meade was so much impressed by this man's story that hethought we ought to cross the Appomattox there at once and move againstLee in his new position.  I knew that Lee was no fool
column11: as he would havebeen to have put himself and his army between two formidable streamslike the James and Appomattox rivers
column12: and between two such armies asthose of the Potomac and the James. Then these streams coming togetheras they did to the east of him
column13: it would be only necessary to close upin the west to have him thoroughly cut off from all supplies orpossibility of reinforcement.  It would only have been a question ofdays
column14: and not many of them
column15: if he had taken the position assigned to himby the so-called engineer
column16: when he would have been obliged to surrenderhis army.  Such is one of the ruses resorted to in war to deceive yourantagonist.  My judgment was that Lee would necessarily have to evacuateRichmond
column17: and that the only course for him to pursue would be to followthe Danville Road. Accordingly my object was to secure a point on thatroad south of Lee
column18: and I told Meade this.  He suggested that if Lee wasgoing that way we would follow him.  My reply was that we did not wantto follow him; we wanted to get ahead of him and cut him off
column19: and if hewould only stay in the position he (Meade) believed him to be in at thattime
column20: I wanted nothing better; that when we got in possession of theDanville Railroad
column21: at its crossing of the Appomattox River
column22: if we stillfound him between the two rivers
column23: all we had to do was to move eastwardand close him up.  That we would then have all the advantage we couldpossibly have by moving directly against him from Petersburg
column24: even if heremained in the position assigned him by the engineer officer.I had held most of the command aloof from the intrenchments
column25: so as tostart them out on the Danville Road early in the morning
column26: supposing thatLee would be gone during the night.  During the night I strengthenedSheridan by sending him Humphreys's corps.Lee
column27: as we now know
column28: had advised the authorities at Richmond
column29: during theday
column30: of the condition of affairs

The congregationwas dismissed with the notice that there would be no evening service.The rebel government left Richmond about two o'clock in the afternoon ofthe 2d.At night Lee ordered his troops to assemble at Amelia Court House

Parke's corps followed by the same road
