column187: if carried out
column188: moving to theright flank
column189: would give him the coveted opportunity of escaping us andputting us in rear of him.We then together visited Meade
column190: reaching his headquarters aboutmidnight.  I explained to Meade that we did not want to follow theenemy; we wanted to get ahead of him
column191: and that his orders would allowthe enemy to escape
column192: and besides that
column193: I had no doubt that Lee wasmoving right then.  Meade changed his orders at once.  They were nowgiven for an advance on Amelia Court House
column194: at an early hour in themorning
column195: as the army then lay; that is
column196: the infantry being across therailroad
column197: most of it to the west of the road
column198: with the cavalry swung outstill farther to the left.

column1: ISFP	 LXVI.BATTLE OF SAILOR'S CREEK--ENGAGEMENT AT FARMVILLE--CORRESPONDENCE WITHGENERAL LEE--SHERIDAN INTERCEPTS THE ENEMY.The Appomattox
column2: going westward
column3: takes a long sweep to the south-westfrom the neighborhood of the Richmond and Danville Railroad bridge
column4: andthen trends north-westerly.  Sailor's Creek
column5: an insignificant stream
column6: running northward
column7: empties into the Appomattox between the High Bridgeand Jetersville.  Near the High Bridge the stage road from Petersburg toLynchburg crosses the Appomattox River
column8: also on a bridge.  The railroadruns on the north side of the river to Farmville
column9: a few miles west
column10: andfrom there
column11: recrossing
column12: continues on the south side of it.  The roadscoming up from the south-east to Farmville cross the Appomattox Riverthere on a bridge and run on the north side
column13: leaving the Lynchburg andPetersburg Railroad well to the left.Lee
column14: in pushing out from Amelia Court House
column15: availed himself of all theroads between the Danville Road and Appomattox River to move upon
column16: andnever permitted the head of his columns to stop because of any fightingthat might be going on in his rear.  In this way he came very nearsucceeding in getting to his provision trains and eluding us with atleast part of his army.As expected
column17: Lee's troops had moved during the night before
column18: and ourarmy in moving upon Amelia Court House soon encountered them.  There wasa good deal of fighting before Sailor's Creek was reached.  Our cavalrycharged in upon a body of theirs which was escorting a wagon train inorder to get it past our left.  A severe engagement ensued
column19: in which wecaptured many prisoners
column20: and many men also were killed and wounded.There was as much gallantry displayed by some of the Confederates inthese little engagements as was displayed at any time during the war
column21: notwithstanding the sad defeats of the past week.The armies finally met on Sailor's Creek
column22: when a heavy engagement tookplace
column23: in which infantry
column24: artillery and cavalry were all brought intoaction.  Our men on the right
column25: as they were brought in against theenemy
column26: came in on higher ground
column27: and upon his flank
column28: giving us everyadvantage to be derived from the lay of the country.  Our firing wasalso very much more rapid
column29: because the enemy commenced his retreatwestward and in firing as he retreated had to turn around every time hefired.  The enemy's loss was very heavy
column30: as well in killed and woundedas in captures.  Some six general officers fell into our hands in thisengagement
column31: and seven thousand men were made prisoners.  This engagementwas commenced in the middle of the afternoon of the 6th
column32: and the retreatand pursuit were continued until nightfall
column33: when the armies bivouackedupon the ground where the night had overtaken them.When the move towards Amelia Court House had commenced that morning
column34: Iordered Wright's corps
column35: which was on the extreme right
column36: to be moved tothe left past the whole army
column37: to take the place of Griffin's
column38: andordered the latter at the same time to move by and place itself on theright.  The object of this movement was to get the 6th corps
column39: Wright's
column40: next to the cavalry
column41: with which they had formerly served so harmoniouslyand so efficiently in the valley of Virginia.The 6th corps now remained with the cavalry and under Sheridan's directcommand until after the surrender.Ord had been directed to take possession of all the roads southwardbetween Burkesville and the High Bridge.  On the morning of the 6th hesent Colonel Washburn with two infantry regiments with instructions todestroy High Bridge and to return rapidly to Burkesville Station; and heprepared himself to resist the enemy there.  Soon after Washburn hadstarted Ord became a little alarmed as to his safety and sent ColonelRead
column42: of his staff
column43: with about eighty cavalrymen
column44: to overtake him andbring him back.  Very shortly after this he heard that the head of Lee'scolumn had got up to the road between him and where Washburn now was
column45: and attempted to send reinforcements
column46: but the reinforcements could notget through.  Read
column47: however
column48: had got through ahead of the enemy.  Herode on to Farmville and was on his way back again when he found hisreturn cut off
column49: and Washburn confronting apparently the advance of Lee'sarmy.  Read drew his men up into line of battle
column50: his force nowconsisting of less than six hundred men
column51: infantry and cavalry
column52: and rodealong their front
column53: making a speech to his men to inspire them with thesame enthusiasm that he himself felt.  He then gave the order to charge.This little band made several charges
column54: of course unsuccessful ones
column55: butinflicted a loss upon the enemy more than equal to their own entirenumber.  Colonel Read fell mortally wounded
column56: and then Washburn; and atthe close of the conflict nearly every officer of the command and mostof the rank and file had been either killed or wounded.  The remainderthen surrendered.  The Confederates took this to be only the advance ofa larger column which had headed them off
column57: and so stopped to intrench;so that this gallant band of six hundred had checked the progress of astrong detachment of the Confederate army.This stoppage of Lee's column no doubt saved to us the trains following.Lee himself pushed on and crossed the wagon road bridge near the HighBridge
column58: and attempted to destroy it.  He did set fire to it
column59: but theflames had made but little headway when Humphreys came up with his corpsand drove away the rear-guard which had been left to protect it while itwas being burned up.  Humphreys forced his way across with some loss
column60: and followed Lee to the intersection of the road crossing at Farmvillewith the one from Petersburg.  Here Lee held a position which was verystrong
column61: naturally
column62: besides being intrenched.  Humphreys was alone
column63: confronting him all through the day
column64: and in a very hazardous position.He put on a bold face
column65: however
column66: and assaulted with some loss
column67: but wasnot assaulted in return.Our cavalry had gone farther south by the way of Prince Edward's CourtHouse
column68: along with the 5th corps (Griffin's)
column69: Ord falling in betweenGriffin and the Appomattox.  Crook's division of cavalry and Wright'scorps pushed on west of Farmville.  When the cavalry reached Farmvillethey found that some of the Confederates were in ahead of them
column70: and hadalready got their trains of provisions back to that point; but ourtroops were in time to prevent them from securing anything to eat
column71: although they succeeded in again running the trains off
column72: so that we didnot get them for some time.  These troops retreated to the north side ofthe Appomattox to join Lee
column73: and succeeded in destroying the bridge afterthem.  Considerable fighting ensued there between Wright's corps and aportion of our cavalry and the Confederates
column74: but finally the cavalryforded the stream and drove them away.  Wright built a foot-bridge forhis men to march over on and then marched out to the junction of theroads to relieve Humphreys
column75: arriving there that night.  I had stoppedthe night before at Burkesville Junction.  Our troops were then prettymuch all out of the place
column76: but we had a field hospital there
column77: and Ord'scommand was extended from that point towards Farmville.Here I met Dr. Smith
column78: a Virginian and an officer of the regular army
column79: who told me that in a conversation with General Ewell
column80: one of theprisoners and a relative of his
column81: Ewell had said that when we had gotacross the James River he knew their cause was lost
column82: and it was the dutyof their authorities to make the best terms they could while they stillhad a right to claim concessions. The authorities thought differently
column83: however.  Now the cause was lost and they had no right to claimanything.  He said further
column84: that for every man that was killed afterthis in the war somebody is responsible
column85: and it would be but very littlebetter than murder.  He was not sure that Lee would consent to surrenderhis army without being able to consult with the President
column86: but he hopedhe would.I rode in to Farmville on the 7th
column87: arriving there early in the day.Sheridan and Ord were pushing through
column88: away to the south.  Meade wasback towards the High Bridge
column89: and Humphreys confronting Lee as beforestated.  After having gone into bivouac at Prince Edward's Court House
column90: Sheridan learned that seven trains of provisions and forage were atAppomattox
column91: and determined to start at once and capture them; and aforced march was necessary in order to get there before Lee's army couldsecure them.  He wrote me a note telling me this.  This fact
column92: togetherwith the incident related the night before by Dr. Smith
column93: gave me theidea of opening correspondence with General Lee on the subject of thesurrender of his army.  I therefore wrote to him on this day
column94: asfollows:HEADQUARTERS ARMIES OF THE U. S.
column95: 5 P.M.
column96: April 7
column97: 1865.GENERAL R. E. LEE Commanding C. S. A.The result of the last week must convince you of the hopelessness offurther resistance on the part of the Army of Northern Virginia in thisstruggle.  I feel that it is so
column98: and regard it as my duty to shift frommyself the responsibility of any further effusion of blood
column99: by asking ofyou the surrender of that portion of the Confederate States army knownas the Army of Northern Virginia.U. S. GRANT
column100: Lieut.-General.Lee replied on the evening of the same day as follows:April 7
column101: 1865.GENERAL:  I have received your note of this day.  Though notentertaining the opinion you express on the hopelessness of furtherresistance on the part of the Army of Northern Virginia
column102: I reciprocateyour desire to avoid useless effusion of blood
column103: and therefore beforeconsidering your proposition
column104: ask the terms you will offer on conditionof its surrender.R. E. LEE
column105: General.LIEUT.-GENERAL U. S. GRANT
column106: Commanding Armies of the U. S.This was not satisfactory
column107: but I regarded it as deserving another letterand wrote him as follows:April 8
column108: 1865.GENERAL R. E. LEE
column109: Commanding C. S. A.Your note of last evening in reply to mine of same date
column110: asking thecondition on which I will accept the surrender of the Army of NorthernVirginia is just received.  In reply I would say that
column111: peace being mygreat desire
column112: there is but one condition I would insist upon
column113: namely:that the men and officers surrendered shall be disqualified for takingup arms again against the Government of the United States until properlyexchanged.  I will meet you
column114: or will designate officers to meet anyofficers you may name for the same purpose
column115: at any point agreeable toyou
column116: for the purpose of arranging definitely the terms upon which thesurrender of the Army of Northern Virginia will be received.U. S. GRANT
column117: Lieut.-General.Lee's army was rapidly crumbling.  Many of his soldiers had enlistedfrom that part of the State where they now were
column118: and were continuallydropping out of the ranks and going to their homes.  I know that Ioccupied a hotel almost destitute of furniture at Farmville
column119: which hadprobably been used as a Confederate hospital.  The next morning when Icame out I found a Confederate colonel there
column120: who reported to me andsaid that he was the proprietor of that house
column121: and that he was a colonelof a regiment that had been raised in that neighborhood.  He said thatwhen he came along past home
column122: he found that he was the only man of theregiment remaining with Lee's army
column123: so he just dropped out
column124: and nowwanted to surrender himself.  I told him to stay there and he would notbe molested.  That was one regiment which had been eliminated from Lee'sforce by this crumbling process.Although Sheridan had been marching all day
column125: his troops moved withalacrity and without any straggling.  They began to see the end of whatthey had been fighting four years for.  Nothing seemed to fatigue them.They were ready to move without rations and travel without rest untilthe end.  Straggling had entirely ceased
column126: and every man was now a rivalfor the front.  The infantry marched about as rapidly as the cavalrycould.Sheridan sent Custer with his division to move south of AppomattoxStation
column127: which is about five miles south-west of the Court House
column128: to getwest of the trains and destroy the roads to the rear.  They got therethe night of the 8th
column129: and succeeded partially; but some of the train menhad just discovered the movement of our troops and succeeded in runningoff three of the trains.  The other four were held by Custer.The head of Lee's column came marching up there on the morning of the9th
column130: not dreaming
column131: I suppose
column132: that there were any Union soldiers near.The Confederates were surprised to find our cavalry had possession ofthe trains.  However
column133: they were desperate and at once assaulted
column134: hopingto recover them.  In the melee that ensued they succeeded in burning oneof the trains
column135: but not in getting anything from it.  Custer then orderedthe other trains run back on the road towards Farmville
column136: and the fightcontinued.So far
column137: only our cavalry and the advance of Lee's army were engaged.Soon
column138: however
column139: Lee's men were brought up from the rear
column140: no doubtexpecting they had nothing to meet but our cavalry.  But our infantryhad pushed forward so rapidly that by the time the enemy got up theyfound Griffin's corps and the Army of the James confronting them.  Asharp engagement ensued
column141: but Lee quickly set up a white flag.

column1: ISFP	 LXVII.NEGOTIATIONS AT APPOMATTOX--INTERVIEW WITH LEE AT MCLEAN'S HOUSE--THETERMS OF SURRENDER--LEE'S SURRENDER--INTERVIEW WITH LEE AFTER THESURRENDER.On the 8th I had followed the Army of the Potomac in rear of Lee.  I wassuffering very severely with a sick headache
column2: and stopped at a farmhouseon the road some distance in rear of the main body of the army.  I spentthe night in bathing my feet in hot water and mustard
column3: and puttingmustard plasters on my wrists and the back part of my neck
column4: hoping to becured by morning. During the night I received Lee's answer to my letterof the 8th
column5: inviting an interview between the lines on the followingmorning. (*43)  But it was for a different purpose from that ofsurrendering his army
column6: and I answered him as follows:HEADQUARTERS ARMIES OF THE U. S.
column7: April 9
column8: 1865.GENERAL R. E. LEE
column9: Commanding C. S. A.Your note of yesterday is received.  As I have no authority to treat onthe subject of peace
column10: the meeting proposed for ten A.M. to-day couldlead to no good.  I will state
column11: however
column12: General
column13: that I am equallyanxious for peace with yourself
column14: and the whole North entertains the samefeeling.  The terms upon which peace can be had are well understood.  Bythe South laying down their arms they will hasten that most desirableevent
column15: save thousands of human lives and hundreds of millions ofproperty not yet destroyed.  Sincerely hoping that all our difficultiesmay be settled without the loss of another life
column16: I subscribe myself
column17: etc.
column18: U. S. GRANT
column19: Lieutenant-General.I proceeded at an early hour in the morning
column20: still suffering with theheadache
column21: to get to the head of the column.  I was not more than two orthree miles from Appomattox Court House at the time
column22: but to go direct Iwould have to pass through Lee's army
column23: or a portion of it.  I hadtherefore to move south in order to get upon a road coming up fromanother direction.When the white flag was put out by Lee
column24: as already described
column25: I was inthis way moving towards Appomattox Court House
column26: and consequently couldnot be communicated with immediately
column27: and be informed of what Lee haddone.  Lee
column28: therefore
column29: sent a flag to the rear to advise Meade and oneto the front to Sheridan
column30: saying that he had sent a message to me forthe purpose of having a meeting to consult about the surrender of hisarmy
column31: and asked for a suspension of hostilities until I could becommunicated with.  As they had heard nothing of this until the fightinghad got to be severe and all going against Lee
column32: both of these commandershesitated very considerably about suspending hostilities at all.  Theywere afraid it was not in good faith
column33: and we had the Army of NorthernVirginia where it could not escape except by some deception.  They
column34: however
column35: finally consented to a suspension of hostilities for two hoursto give an opportunity of communicating with me in that time
column36: ifpossible.  It was found that
column37: from the route I had taken
column38: they wouldprobably not be able to communicate with me and get an answer backwithin the time fixed unless the messenger should pass through the rebellines.Lee
column39: therefore
column40: sent an escort with the officer bearing this messagethrough his lines to me.April 9
column41: 1865.GENERAL:  I received your note of this morning on the picket-linewhither I had come to meet you and ascertain definitely what terms wereembraced in your proposal of yesterday with reference to the surrenderof this army.  I now request an interview in accordance with the offercontained in your letter of yesterday for that purpose.R. E. LEE
column42: General.LIEUTENANT-GENERAL U. S. GRANT Commanding U. S. Armies.When the officer reached me I was still suffering with the sickheadache
column43: but the instant I saw the contents of the note I was cured.  Iwrote the following note in reply and hastened on:April 9
column44: 1865.GENERAL R. E. LEE
column45: Commanding C. S. Armies.Your note of this date is but this moment (11.50 A.M.) received
column46: inconsequence of my having passed from the Richmond and Lynchburg road tothe Farmville and Lynchburg road.  I am at this writing about four mileswest of Walker's Church and will push forward to the front for thepurpose of meeting you. Notice sent to me on this road where you wishthe interview to take place will meet me.U. S. GRANT
column47: Lieutenant-General.I was conducted at once to where Sheridan was located with his troopsdrawn up in line of battle facing the Confederate army near by.  Theywere very much excited
column48: and expressed their view that this was all aruse employed to enable the Confederates to get away.  They said theybelieved that Johnston was marching up from North Carolina now
column49: and Leewas moving to join him; and they would whip the rebels where they nowwere in five minutes if I would only let them go in.  But I had no doubtabout the good faith of Lee
column50: and pretty soon was conducted to where hewas.  I found him at the house of a Mr. McLean
column51: at Appomattox CourtHouse
column52: with Colonel Marshall
column53: one of his staff officers
column54: awaiting myarrival.  The head of his column was occupying a hill
column55: on a portion ofwhich was an apple orchard
column56: beyond a little valley which separated itfrom that on the crest of which Sheridan's forces were drawn up in lineof battle to the south.Before stating what took place between General Lee and myself
column57: I willgive all there is of the story of the famous apple tree.Wars produce many stories of fiction
column58: some of which are told until theyare believed to be true.  The war of the rebellion was no exception tothis rule
column59: and the story of the apple tree is one of those fictionsbased on a slight foundation of fact. As I have said
column60: there was an appleorchard on the side of the hill occupied by the Confederate forces.Running diagonally up the hill was a wagon road
column61: which
column62: at one point
column63: ran very near one of the trees
column64: so that the wheels of vehicles had
column65: onthat side
column66: cut off the roots of this tree
column67: leaving a little embankment.General Babcock
column68: of my staff
column69: reported to me that when he first metGeneral Lee he was sitting upon this embankment with his feet in theroad below and his back resting against the tree.  The story had noother foundation than that.  Like many other stories
column70: it would be verygood if it was only true.I had known General Lee in the old army
column71: and had served with him in theMexican War; but did not suppose
column72: owing to the difference in our age andrank
column73: that he would remember me
column74: while I would more naturally rememberhim distinctly
column75: because he was the chief of staff of General Scott inthe Mexican War.When I had left camp that morning I had not expected so soon the resultthat was then taking place
column76: and consequently was in rough garb.  I waswithout a sword
column77: as I usually was when on horseback on the field
column78: andwore a soldier's blouse for a coat
column79: with the shoulder straps of my rankto indicate to the army who I was. When I went into the house I foundGeneral Lee.  We greeted each other
column80: and after shaking hands took ourseats.  I had my staff with me
column81: a good portion of whom were in the roomduring the whole of the interview.What General Lee's feelings were I do not know.  As he was a man of muchdignity
column82: with an impassible face
column83: it was impossible to say whether hefelt inwardly glad that the end had finally come
column84: or felt sad over theresult
column85: and was too manly to show it. Whatever his feelings
column86: they wereentirely concealed from my observation; but my own feelings
column87: which hadbeen quite jubilant on the receipt of his letter
column88: were sad anddepressed.  I felt like anything rather than rejoicing at the downfallof a foe who had fought so long and valiantly
column89: and had suffered so muchfor a cause
column90: though that cause was
column91: I believe
column92: one of the worst forwhich a people ever fought
column93: and one for which there was the leastexcuse.  I do not question
column94: however
column95: the sincerity of the great mass ofthose who were opposed to us.General Lee was dressed in a full uniform which was entirely new
column96: andwas wearing a sword of considerable value
column97: very likely the sword whichhad been presented by the State of Virginia; at all events
column98: it was anentirely different sword from the one that would ordinarily be worn inthe field.  In my rough traveling suit
column99: the uniform of a private withthe straps of a lieutenant-general
column100: I must have contrasted verystrangely with a man so handsomely dressed
column101: six feet high and offaultless form. But this was not a matter that I thought of untilafterwards.We soon fell into a conversation about old army times.  He remarked thathe remembered me very well in the old army; and I told him that as amatter of course I remembered him perfectly
column102: but from the difference inour rank and years (there being about sixteen years' difference in ourages)
column103: I had thought it very likely that I had not attracted hisattention sufficiently to be remembered by him after such a longinterval.  Our conversation grew so pleasant that I almost forgot theobject of our meeting.  After the conversation had run on in this stylefor some time
column104: General Lee called my attention to the object of ourmeeting
column105: and said that he had asked for this interview for the purposeof getting from me the terms I proposed to give his army.  I said that Imeant merely that his army should lay down their arms
column106: not to take themup again during the continuance of the war unless duly and properlyexchanged.  He said that he had so understood my letter.Then we gradually fell off again into conversation about matters foreignto the subject which had brought us together.  This continued for somelittle time
column107: when General Lee again interrupted the course of theconversation by suggesting that the terms I proposed to give his armyought to be written out. I called to General Parker
column108: secretary on mystaff
column109: for writing materials
column110: and commenced writing out the followingterms:APPOMATTOX C. H.
column111: VA.
column112: Ap 19th
column113: 1865.GEN. R. E. LEE
column114: Comd'g C. S. A.GEN:  In accordance with the substance of my letter to you of the 8thinst.
column115: I propose to receive the surrender of the Army of N. Va. on thefollowing terms
column116: to wit:  Rolls of all the officers and men to be madein duplicate.  One copy to be given to an officer designated by me
column117: theother to be retained by such officer or officers as you may designate.The officers to give their individual paroles not to take up armsagainst the Government of the United States until properly exchanged
column118: and each company or regimental commander sign a like parole for the menof their commands.  The arms
column119: artillery and public property to be parkedand stacked
column120: and turned over to the officer appointed by me to receivethem.  This will not embrace the side-arms of the officers
column121: nor theirprivate horses or baggage.  This done
column122: each officer and man will beallowed to return to their homes
column123: not to be disturbed by United Statesauthority so long as they observe their paroles and the laws in forcewhere they may reside.Very respectfully
column124: U. S. GRANT
column125: Lt. Gen.When I put my pen to the paper I did not know the first word that Ishould make use of in writing the terms.  I only knew what was in mymind
column126: and I wished to express it clearly
column127: so that there could be nomistaking it.  As I wrote on
column128: the thought occurred to me that theofficers had their own private horses and effects
column129: which were importantto them
column130: but of no value to us; also that it would be an unnecessaryhumiliation to call upon them to deliver their side arms.No conversation
column131: not one word
column132: passed between General Lee and myself
column133: either about private property
column134: side arms
column135: or kindred subjects.  Heappeared to have no objections to the terms first proposed; or if he hada point to make against them he wished to wait until they were inwriting to make it.  When he read over that part of the terms about sidearms
column136: horses and private property of the officers
column137: he remarked
column138: withsome feeling
column139: I thought
column140: that this would have a happy effect upon hisarmy.Then
column141: after a little further conversation
column142: General Lee remarked to meagain that their army was organized a little differently from the armyof the United States (still maintaining by implication that we were twocountries); that in their army the cavalrymen and artillerists ownedtheir own horses; and he asked if he was to understand that the men whoso owned their horses were to be permitted to retain them.  I told himthat as the terms were written they would not; that only the officerswere permitted to take their private property.  He then
column143: after readingover the terms a second time
column144: remarked that that was clear.I then said to him that I thought this would be about the last battle ofthe war--I sincerely hoped so; and I said further I took it that most ofthe men in the ranks were small farmers. The whole country had been soraided by the two armies that it was doubtful whether they would be ableto put in a crop to carry themselves and their families through the nextwinter without the aid of the horses they were then riding.  The UnitedStates did not want them and I would
column145: therefore
column146: instruct the officers Ileft behind to receive the paroles of his troops to let every man of theConfederate army who claimed to own a horse or mule take the animal tohis home.  Lee remarked again that this would have a happy effect.He then sat down and wrote out the following letter:HEADQUARTERS ARMY OF NORTHERN VIRGINIA
column147: April 9
column148: 1865.GENERAL:--I received your letter of this date containing the terms ofthe surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia as proposed by you.  Asthey are substantially the same as those expressed in your letter of the8th inst.
column149: they are accepted.  I will proceed to designate the properofficers to carry the stipulations into effect.R. E. LEE
column150: General. LIEUT.-GENERAL U. S. GRANT.While duplicates of the two letters were being made
column151: the Union generalspresent were severally presented to General Lee.The much talked of surrendering of Lee's sword and my handing it back
column152: this and much more that has been said about it is the purest romance.The word sword or side arms was not mentioned by either of us until Iwrote it in the terms.  There was no premeditation
column153: and it did not occurto me until the moment I wrote it down.  If I had happened to omit it
column154: and General Lee had called my attention to it
column155: I should have put it inthe terms precisely as I acceded to the provision about the soldiersretaining their horses.General Lee
column156: after all was completed and before taking his leave
column157: remarked that his army was in a very bad condition for want of food
column158: andthat they were without forage; that his men had been living for somedays on parched corn exclusively
column159: and that he would have to ask me forrations and forage.  I told him 'certainly
column160: ' and asked for how many menhe wanted rations.  His answer was 'about twenty-five thousand;' and Iauthorized him to send his own commissary and quartermaster toAppomattox Station
column161: two or three miles away
column162: where he could have
column163: out ofthe trains we had stopped
column164: all the provisions wanted.  As for forage
column165: wehad ourselves depended almost entirely upon the country for that.Generals Gibbon
column166: Griffin and Merritt were designated by me to carry intoeffect the paroling of Lee's troops before they should start for theirhomes--General Lee leaving Generals Longstreet
column167: Gordon and Pendleton forthem to confer with in order to facilitate this work.  Lee and I thenseparated as cordially as we had met
column168: he returning to his own lines
column169: andall went into bivouac for the night at Appomattox.Soon after Lee's departure I telegraphed to Washington as follows:HEADQUARTERS APPOMATTOX C. H.
column170: VA.
column171: April 9th
column173: 4.30 P.M.HON. E. M. STANTON
column174: Secretary of War
column175: Washington.General Lee surrendered the Army of Northern Virginia this afternoon onterms proposed by myself.  The accompanying additional correspondencewill show the conditions fully.U. S. GRANT
column176: Lieut.-General.When news of the surrender first reached our lines our men commencedfiring a salute of a hundred guns in honor of the victory.  I at oncesent word
column177: however
column178: to have it stopped.  The Confederates were now ourprisoners
column179: and we did not want to exult over their downfall.I determined to return to Washington at once
column180: with a view to putting astop to the purchase of supplies
column181: and what I now deemed other uselessoutlay of money.  Before leaving
column182: however
column183: I thought I (*44) would liketo see General Lee again; so next morning I rode out beyond our linestowards his headquarters
column184: preceded by a bugler and a staff-officercarrying a white flag.Lee soon mounted his horse
column185: seeing who it was
column186: and met me.  We had therebetween the lines
column187: sitting on horseback
column188: a very pleasant conversation ofover half an hour
column189: in the course of which Lee said to me that the Southwas a big country and that we might have to march over it three or fourtimes before the war entirely ended
column190: but that we would now be able to doit as they could no longer resist us.  He expressed it as his earnesthope
column191: however
column192: that we would not be called upon to cause more loss andsacrifice of life; but he could not foretell the result.  I thensuggested to General Lee that there was not a man in the Confederacywhose influence with the soldiery and the whole people was as great ashis
column193: and that if he would now advise the surrender of all the armies Ihad no doubt his advice would be followed with alacrity.  But Lee said
column194: that he could not do that without consulting the President first.  Iknew there was no use to urge him to do anything against his ideas ofwhat was right.I was accompanied by my staff and other officers
column195: some of whom seemed tohave a great desire to go inside the Confederate lines.  They finallyasked permission of Lee to do so for the purpose of seeing some of theirold army friends
column196: and the permission was granted.  They went over
column197: had avery pleasant time with their old friends
column198: and brought some of them backwith them when they returned.When Lee and I separated he went back to his lines and I returned to thehouse of Mr. McLean.  Here the officers of both armies came in greatnumbers
column199: and seemed to enjoy the meeting as much as though they had beenfriends separated for a long time while fighting battles under the sameflag.  For the time being it looked very much as if all thought of thewar had escaped their minds.  After an hour pleasantly passed in thisway I set out on horseback
column200: accompanied by my staff and a small escort
column201: for Burkesville Junction
column202: up to which point the railroad had by thistime been repaired.

column1: ISFP	 LXVIII.MORALE OF THE TWO ARMIES--RELATIVE CONDITIONS OF THE NORTH AND SOUTH--PRESIDENT LINCOLN VISITS RICHMOND--ARRIVAL AT WASHINGTON--PRESIDENTLINCOLN'S ASSASSINATION--PRESIDENT JOHNSON'S POLICY.After the fall of Petersburg
column2: and when the armies of the Potomac and theJames were in motion to head off Lee's army
column3: the morale of the Nationaltroops had greatly improved.  There was no more straggling
column4: no more rearguards.  The men who in former times had been falling back
column5: were now
column6: asI have already stated
column7: striving to get to the front.  For the first timein four weary years they felt that they were now nearing the time whenthey could return to their homes with their country saved.  On the otherhand
column8: the Confederates were more than correspondingly depressed.  Theirdespondency increased with each returning day
column9: and especially after thebattle of Sailor's Creek.  They threw away their arms in constantlyincreasing numbers
column10: dropping out of the ranks and betaking themselves tothe woods in the hope of reaching their homes.  I have already instancedthe case of the entire disintegration of a regiment whose colonel I metat Farmville.  As a result of these and other influences
column11: when Leefinally surrendered at Appomattox
column12: there were only 28
column13: 356 officers andmen left to be paroled
column14: and many of these were without arms.  It wasprobably this latter fact which gave rise to the statement sometimesmade
column15: North and South
column16: that Lee surrendered a smaller number of men thanwhat the official figures show.  As a matter of official record
column17: and inaddition to the number paroled as given above
column18: we captured between March29th and the date of surrender 19
column19: 132 Confederates
column20: to say nothing ofLee's other losses
column21: killed
column22: wounded and missing
column23: during the series ofdesperate conflicts which marked his headlong and determined flight.The same record shows the number of cannon
column24: including those atAppomattox
column25: to have been 689 between the dates named.There has always been a great conflict of opinion as to the number oftroops engaged in every battle
column26: or all important battles
column27: fought betweenthe sections
column28: the South magnifying the number of Union troops engagedand belittling their own. Northern writers have fallen
column29: in manyinstances
column30: into the same error.  I have often heard gentlemen
column31: who werethoroughly loyal to the Union
column32: speak of what a splendid fight the Southhad made and successfully continued for four years before yielding
column33: withtheir twelve million of people against our twenty
column34: and of the twelvefour being colored slaves
column35: non-combatants.  I will add to theirargument.  We had many regiments of brave and loyal men who volunteeredunder great difficulty from the twelve million belonging to the South.But the South had rebelled against the National government.  It was notbound by any constitutional restrictions.  The whole South was amilitary camp.  The occupation of the colored people was to furnishsupplies for the army.  Conscription was resorted to early
column36: and embracedevery male from the age of eighteen to forty-five
column37: excluding only thosephysically unfit to serve in the field
column38: and the necessary number ofcivil officers of State and intended National government.  The old andphysically disabled furnished a good portion of these.  The slaves
column39: thenon-combatants
column40: one-third of the whole
column41: were required to work in thefield without regard to sex
column42: and almost without regard to age.  Childrenfrom the age of eight years could and did handle the hoe; they were notmuch older when they began to hold the plough.  The four million ofcolored non-combatants were equal to more than three times their numberin the North
column43: age for age and sex for sex
column44: in supplying food from thesoil to support armies.  Women did not work in the fields in the North
column45: and children attended school.The arts of peace were carried on in the North.  Towns and cities grewduring the war.  Inventions were made in all kinds of machinery toincrease the products of a day's labor in the shop
column46: and in the field.In the South no opposition was allowed to the government which had beenset up and which would have become real and respected if the rebellionhad been successful.  No rear had to be protected.  All the troops inservice could be brought to the front to contest every inch of groundthreatened with invasion.  The press of the South
column47: like the people whoremained at home
column48: were loyal to the Southern cause.In the North
column49: the country
column50: the towns and the cities presented about thesame appearance they do in time of peace.  The furnace was in blast
column51: theshops were filled with workmen
column52: the fields were cultivated
column53: not only tosupply the population of the North and the troops invading the South
column54: but to ship abroad to pay a part of the expense of the war.  In theNorth the press was free up to the point of open treason.  The citizencould entertain his views and express them.  Troops were necessary inthe Northern States to prevent prisoners from the Southern army beingreleased by outside force
column55: armed and set at large to destroy by fire ourNorthern cities.  Plans were formed by Northern and Southern citizens toburn our cities
column56: to poison the water supplying them
column57: to spread infectionby importing clothing from infected regions
column58: to blow up our river andlake steamers--regardless of the destruction of innocent lives.  Thecopperhead disreputable portion of the press magnified rebel successes
column59: and belittled those of the Union army.  It was
column60: with a large following
column61: an auxiliary to the Confederate army.  The North would have been muchstronger with a hundred thousand of these men in the Confederate ranksand the rest of their kind thoroughly subdued
column62: as the Union sentimentwas in the South
column63: than we were as the battle was fought.As I have said
column64: the whole South was a military camp.  The coloredpeople
column65: four million in number
column66: were submissive
column67: and worked in the fieldand took care of the families while the able-bodied white men were atthe front fighting for a cause destined to defeat.  The cause waspopular
column68: and was enthusiastically supported by the young men.  Theconscription took all of them.  Before the war was over
column69: furtherconscriptions took those between fourteen and eighteen years of age asjunior reserves
column70: and those between forty-five and sixty as seniorreserves.  It would have been an offence
column71: directly after the war
column72: andperhaps it would be now
column73: to ask any able-bodied man in the South
column74: whowas between the ages of fourteen and sixty at any time during the war
column75: whether he had been in the Confederate army.  He would assert that hehad
column76: or account for his absence from the ranks.  Under suchcircumstances it is hard to conceive how the North showed such asuperiority of force in every battle fought.  I know they did not.During 1862 and '3
column77: John H. Morgan
column78: a partisan officer
column79: of no militaryeducation
column80: but possessed of courage and endurance
column81: operated in the rearof the Army of the Ohio in Kentucky and Tennessee.  He had no base ofsupplies to protect
column82: but was at home wherever he went.  The armyoperating against the South
column83: on the contrary
column84: had to protect its linesof communication with the North
column85: from which all supplies had to come tothe front.  Every foot of road had to be guarded by troops stationed atconvenient distances apart.  These guards could not render assistancebeyond the points where stationed.  Morgan Was foot-loose and couldoperate where
column86: his information--always correct--led him to believe hecould do the greatest damage.  During the time he was operating in thisway he killed
column87: wounded and captured several times the number he ever hadunder his command at any one time.  He destroyed many millions ofproperty in addition. Places he did not attack had to be guarded as ifthreatened by him.  Forrest
column88: an abler soldier
column89: operated farther west
column90: and held from the National front quite as many men as could be sparedfor offensive operations.  It is safe to say that more than half theNational army was engaged in guarding lines of supplies
column91: or were onleave
column92: sick in hospital or on detail which prevented their bearing arms.Then
column93: again
column94: large forces were employed where no Confederate armyconfronted them.  I deem it safe to say that there were no largeengagements where the National numbers compensated for the advantage ofposition and intrenchment occupied by the enemy.While I was in pursuit of General Lee
column95: the President went to Richmond incompany with Admiral Porter
column96: and on board his flagship.  He found thepeople of that city in great consternation.  The leading citizens amongthe people who had remained at home surrounded him
column97: anxious thatsomething should be done to relieve them from suspense.  General Weitzelwas not then in the city
column98: having taken offices in one of the neighboringvillages after his troops had succeeded in subduing the conflagrationwhich they had found in progress on entering the Confederate capital.The President sent for him
column99: and
column100: on his arrival
column101: a short interview washad on board the vessel
column102: Admiral Porter and a leading citizen ofVirginia being also present. After this interview the President wrote anorder in about these words
column103: which I quote from memory:  'General Weitzelis authorized to permit the body calling itself the Legislature ofVirginia to meet for the purpose of recalling the Virginia troops fromthe Confederate armies.'Immediately some of the gentlemen composing that body wrote out a callfor a meeting and had it published in their papers.  This call
column104: however
column105: went very much further than Mr. Lincoln had contemplated
column106: as he did notsay the 'Legislature of Virginia' but 'the body which called itself theLegislature of Virginia.' Mr. Stanton saw the call as published in theNorthern papers the very next issue and took the liberty ofcountermanding the order authorizing any meeting of the Legislature
column107: orany other body
column108: and this notwithstanding the fact that the President wasnearer the spot than he was.This was characteristic of Mr. Stanton.  He was a man who neverquestioned his own authority
column109: and who always did in war time what hewanted to do.  He was an able constitutional lawyer and jurist; but theConstitution was not an impediment to him while the war lasted.  In thislatter particular I entirely agree with the view he evidently held.  TheConstitution was not framed with a view to any such rebellion as that of1861-5.  While it did not authorize rebellion it made no provisionagainst it.  Yet the right to resist or suppress rebellion is asinherent as the right of self-defence
column110: and as natural as the right of anindividual to preserve his life when in jeopardy.  The Constitution wastherefore in abeyance for the time being
column111: so far as it in any wayaffected the progress and termination of the war.Those in rebellion against the government of the United States were notrestricted by constitutional provisions
column112: or any other
column113: except the actsof their Congress
column114: which was loyal and devoted to the cause for whichthe South was then fighting.  It would be a hard case when one-third ofa nation
column115: united in rebellion against the national authority
column116: isentirely untrammeled
column117: that the other two-thirds
column118: in their efforts tomaintain the Union intact
column119: should be restrained by a Constitutionprepared by our ancestors for the express purpose of insuring thepermanency of the confederation of the States.After I left General Lee at Appomattox Station
column120: I went with my staff anda few others directly to Burkesville Station on my way to Washington.The road from Burkesville back having been newly repaired and the groundbeing soft
column121: the train got off the track frequently
column122: and
column123: as a result
column124: itwas after midnight of the second day when I reached City Point.  As soonas possible I took a dispatch-boat thence to Washington City.While in Washington I was very busy for a time in preparing thenecessary orders for the new state of affairs; communicating with mydifferent commanders of separate departments
column125: bodies of troops
column126: etc.But by the 14th I was pretty well through with this work
column127: so as to beable to visit my children
column128: who were then in Burlington
column129: New Jersey
column130: attending school.  Mrs. Grant was with me in Washington at the time
column131: andwe were invited by President and Mrs. Lincoln to accompany them to thetheatre on the evening of that day.  I replied to the President's verbalinvitation to the effect
column132: that if we were in the city we would takegreat pleasure in accompanying them; but that I was very anxious to getaway and visit my children
column133: and if I could get through my work duringthe day I should do so.  I did get through and started by the eveningtrain on the 14th
column134: sending Mr. Lincoln word
column135: of course
column136: that I would notbe at the theatre.At that time the railroad to New York entered Philadelphia on BroadStreet; passengers were conveyed in ambulances to the Delaware River
column137: and then ferried to Camden
column138: at which point they took the cars again.When I reached the ferry
column139: on the east side of the City of Philadelphia
column140: I found people awaiting my arrival there; and also dispatches informingme of the assassination of the President and Mr. Seward
column141: and of theprobable assassination of the Vice President
column142: Mr. Johnson
column143: andrequesting my immediate return.It would be impossible for me to describe the feeling that overcame meat the news of these assassinations
column144: more especially the assassinationof the President.  I knew his goodness of heart
column145: his generosity
column146: hisyielding disposition
column147: his desire to have everybody happy
column148: and above allhis desire to see all the people of the United States enter again uponthe full privileges of citizenship with equality among all.  I knew alsothe feeling that Mr. Johnson had expressed in speeches and conversationagainst the Southern people
column149: and I feared that his course towards themwould be such as to repel
column150: and make them unwilling citizens; and if theybecame such they would remain so for a long while.  I felt thatreconstruction had been set back
column151: no telling how far.I immediately arranged for getting a train to take me back to WashingtonCity; but Mrs. Grant was with me; it was after midnight and Burlingtonwas but an hour away.  Finding that I could accompany her to our houseand return about as soon as they would be ready to take me from thePhiladelphia station
column152: I went up with her and returned immediately by thesame special train.  The joy that I had witnessed among the people inthe street and in public places in Washington when I left there
column153: hadbeen turned to grief; the city was in reality a city of mourning.  Ihave stated what I believed then the effect of this would be
column154: and myjudgment now is that I was right.  I believe the South would have beensaved from very much of the hardness of feeling that was engendered byMr. Johnson's course towards them during the first few months of hisadministration.  Be this as it may
column155: Mr. Lincoln's assassination wasparticularly unfortunate for the entire nation.Mr. Johnson's course towards the South did engender bitterness offeeling.  His denunciations of treason and his ever-ready remark
column156: 'Treason is a crime and must be made odious
column157: ' was repeated to all thosemen of the South who came to him to get some assurances of safety sothat they might go to work at something with the feeling that what theyobtained would be secure to them.  He uttered his denunciations withgreat vehemence
column158: and as they were accompanied with no assurances ofsafety
column159: many Southerners were driven to a point almost beyond endurance.The President of the United States is
column160: in a large degree
column161: or ought tobe
column162: a representative of the feeling
column163: wishes and judgment of those overwhom he presides; and the Southerners who read the denunciations ofthemselves and their people must have come to the conclusion that heuttered the sentiments of the Northern people; whereas
column164: as a matter offact
column165: but for the assassination of Mr. Lincoln
column166: I believe the greatmajority of the Northern people
column167: and the soldiers unanimously
column168: wouldhave been in favor of a speedy reconstruction on terms that would be theleast humiliating to the people who had rebelled against theirgovernment.  They believed
column169: I have no doubt
column170: as I did
column171: that besidesbeing the mildest
column172: it was also the wisest
column173: policy.The people who had been in rebellion must necessarily come back into theUnion
column174: and be incorporated as an integral part of the nation.  Naturallythe nearer they were placed to an equality with the people who had notrebelled
column175: the more reconciled they would feel with their oldantagonists
column176: and the better citizens they would be from the beginning.They surely would not make good citizens if they felt that they had ayoke around their necks.I do not believe that the majority of the Northern people at that timewere in favor of negro suffrage.  They supposed that it would naturallyfollow the freedom of the negro
column177: but that there would be a time ofprobation
column178: in which the ex-slaves could prepare themselves for theprivileges of citizenship before the full right would be conferred; butMr. Johnson
column179: after a complete revolution of sentiment
column180: seemed to regardthe South not only as an oppressed people
column181: but as the people bestentitled to consideration of any of our citizens.  This was more thanthe people who had secured to us the perpetuation of the Union wereprepared for
column182: and they became more radical in their views.  TheSoutherners had the most power in the executive branch
column183: Mr. Johnsonhaving gone to their side; and with a compact South
column184: and such sympathyand support as they could get from the North
column185: they felt that they wouldbe able to control the nation at once
column186: and already many of them acted asif they thought they were entitled to do so.Thus Mr. Johnson
column187: fighting Congress on the one hand
column188: and receiving thesupport of the South on the other
column189: drove Congress
column190: which wasoverwhelmingly republican
column191: to the passing of first one measure and thenanother to restrict his power.  There being a solid South on one sidethat was in accord with the political party in the North which hadsympathized with the rebellion
column192: it finally
column193: in the judgment of Congressand of the majority of the legislatures of the States
column194: became necessaryto enfranchise the negro
column195: in all his ignorance.  In this work
column196: I shallnot discuss the question of how far the policy of Congress in thisparticular proved a wise one.  It became an absolute necessity
column197: however
column198: because of the foolhardiness of the President and the blindness of theSouthern people to their own interest.  As to myself
column199: while stronglyfavoring the course that would be the least humiliating to the peoplewho had been in rebellion
column200: I gradually worked up to the point where
column201: with the majority of the people
column202: I favored immediate enfranchisement.

column1: ISFP	 LXIX.SHERMAN AND JOHNSTON--JOHNSTON'S SURRENDER TO SHERMAN--CAPTURE OFMOBILE--WILSON'S EXPEDITION--CAPTURE OF JEFFERSON DAVIS--GENERALTHOMAS'S QUALITIES--ESTIMATE OF GENERAL CANBY.When I left Appomattox I ordered General Meade to proceed leisurely backto Burkesville Station with the Army of the Potomac and the Army of theJames
column2: and to go into camp there until further orders from me.  GeneralJohnston
column3: as has been stated before
column4: was in North Carolina confrontingGeneral Sherman.  It could not be known positively
column5: of course
column6: whetherJohnston would surrender on the news of Lee's surrender
column7: though Isupposed he would; and if he did not
column8: Burkesville Station was thenatural point from which to move to attack him.  The army which I couldhave sent against him was superior to his
column9: and that with which Shermanconfronted him was also superior; and between the two he wouldnecessarily have been crushed
column10: or driven away.  With the loss of theircapital and the Army of Northern Virginia it was doubtful whetherJohnston's men would have the spirit to stand.  My belief was that hewould make no such attempt; but I adopted this course as a precautionagainst what might happen
column11: however improbable.Simultaneously with my starting from City Point
column12: I sent a messenger toNorth Carolina by boat with dispatches to General Sherman
column13: informing himof the surrender of Lee and his army; also of the terms which I hadgiven him; and I authorized Sherman to give the same terms to Johnstonif the latter chose to accept them.  The country is familiar with theterms that Sherman agreed to CONDITIONALLY
column14: because they embraced apolitical question as well as a military one and he would therefore haveto confer with the government before agreeing to them definitely.General Sherman had met Mr. Lincoln at City Point while visiting thereto confer with me about our final movement
column15: and knew what Mr. Lincolnhad said to the peace commissioners when he met them at Hampton Roads
column16: viz.:  that before he could enter into negotiations with them they wouldhave to agree to two points: one being that the Union should bepreserved
column17: and the other that slavery should be abolished; and if theywere ready to concede these two points he was almost ready to sign hisname to a blank piece of paper and permit them to fill out the balanceof the terms upon which we would live together.  He had also seennotices in the newspapers of Mr. Lincoln's visit to Richmond
column18: and hadread in the same papers that while there he had authorized the conveningof the Legislature of Virginia.Sherman thought
column19: no doubt
column20: in adding to the terms that I had made withgeneral Lee
column21: that he was but carrying out the wishes of the President ofthe United States.  But seeing that he was going beyond his authority
column22: he made it a point that the terms were only conditional.  They signedthem with this understanding
column23: and agreed to a truce until the termscould be sent to Washington for approval; if approved by the properauthorities there
column24: they would then be final; if not approved
column25: then hewould give due notice
column26: before resuming hostilities.  As the world knows
column27: Sherman
column28: from being one of the most popular generals of the land(Congress having even gone so far as to propose a bill providing for asecond lieutenant-general for the purpose of advancing him to thatgrade)
column29: was denounced by the President and Secretary of War in verybitter terms.  Some people went so far as to denounce him as a traitor--a most preposterous term to apply to a man who had rendered so muchservice as he had
column30: even supposing he had made a mistake in granting suchterms as he did to Johnston and his army.  If Sherman had takenauthority to send Johnston with his army home
column31: with their arms to be putin the arsenals of their own States
column32: without submitting the question tothe authorities at Washington
column33: the suspicions against him might havesome foundation.  But the feeling against Sherman died out very rapidly
column34: and it was not many weeks before he was restored to the fullestconfidence of the American people.When
column35: some days after my return to Washington
column36: President Johnson and theSecretary of war received the terms which General Sherman had forwardedfor approval
column37: a cabinet meeting was immediately called and I was sentfor.  There seemed to be the greatest consternation
column38: lest Sherman wouldcommit the government to terms which they were not willing to accede toand which he had no right to grant.  A message went out directing thetroops in the South not to obey General Sherman.  I was ordered toproceed at once to North Carolina and take charge of matter theremyself. Of course I started without delay
column39: and reached there as soon aspossible.  I repaired to Raleigh
column40: where Sherman was
column41: as quietly aspossible
column42: hoping to see him without even his army learning of mypresence.When I arrived I went to Sherman's headquarters
column43: and we were at oncecloseted together.  I showed him the instruction and orders under whichI visited him.  I told him that I wanted him to notify General Johnstonthat the terms which they had conditionally agreed upon had not beenapproved in Washington
column44: and that he was authorized to offer the sameterms I had given General Lee.  I sent Sherman to do this himself.  Idid not wish the knowledge of my presence to be known to the armygenerally; so I left it to Sherman to negotiate the terms of thesurrender solely by himself
column45: and without the enemy knowing that I wasanywhere near the field.  As soon as possible I started to get away
column46: toleave Sherman quite free and untrammelled.At Goldsboro'
column47: on my way back
column48: I met a mail
column49: containing the lastnewspapers
column50: and I found in them indications of great excitement in theNorth over the terms Sherman had given Johnston; and harsh orders thathad been promulgated by the President and Secretary of War.  I knew thatSherman must see these papers
column51: and I fully realized what greatindignation they would cause him
column52: though I do not think his feelingscould have been more excited than were my own.  But like the true andloyal soldier that he was
column53: he carried out the instructions I had givenhim
column54: obtained the surrender of Johnston's army
column55: and settled down in hiscamp about Raleigh
column56: to await final orders.There were still a few expeditions out in the South that could not becommunicated with
column57: and had to be left to act according to the judgmentof their respective commanders.  With these it was impossible to tellhow the news of the surrender of Lee and Johnston
column58: of which they musthave heard
column59: might affect their judgment as to what was best to do.The three expeditions which I had tried so hard to get off from thecommands of Thomas and Canby did finally get off:  one under Canbyhimself
column60: against Mobile
column61: late in March; that under Stoneman from EastTennessee on the 20th; and the one under Wilson
column62: starting from Eastport
column63: Mississippi
column64: on the 22d of March.  They were all eminently successful
column65: but without any good result. Indeed much valuable property was destroyedand many lives lost at a time when we would have liked to spare them.The war was practically over before their victories were gained.  Theywere so late in commencing operations
column66: that they did not hold any troopsaway that otherwise would have been operating against the armies whichwere gradually forcing the Confederate armies to a surrender.  The onlypossible good that we may have experienced from these raids was byStoneman's getting near Lynchburg about the time the armies of thePotomac and the James were closing in on Lee at Appomattox.Stoneman entered North Carolina and then pushed north to strike theVirginia and Tennessee Railroad.  He got upon that road
column67: destroyed itsbridges at different places and rendered the road useless to the enemyup to within a few miles of Lynchburg.  His approach caused theevacuation of that city about the time we were at Appomattox
column68: and wasthe cause of a commotion we heard of there.  He then pushed south
column69: andwas operating in the rear of Johnston's army about the time thenegotiations were going on between Sherman and Johnston for the latter'ssurrender.  In this raid Stoneman captured and destroyed a large amountof stores
column70: while fourteen guns and nearly two thousand prisoners werethe trophies of his success.Canby appeared before Mobile on the 27th of March.  The city of Mobilewas protected by two forts
column71: besides other intrenchments--Spanish Fort
column72: on the east side of the bay
column73: and Fort Blakely
column74: north of the city.  Theseforts were invested.  On the night of the 8th of April
column75: the Nationaltroops having carried the enemy's works at one point
column76: Spanish Fort wasevacuated; and on the 9th
column77: the very day of Lee's surrender
column78: Blakely wascarried by assault
column79: with a considerable loss to us.  On the 11th thecity was evacuated.I had tried for more than two years to have an expedition sent againstMobile when its possession by us would have been of great advantage.  Itfinally cost lives to take it when its possession was of no importance
column80: and when
column81: if left alone
column82: it would within a few days have fallen into ourhands without any bloodshed whatever.Wilson moved out with full 12
column83: 000 men
column84: well equipped and well armed.  Hewas an energetic officer and accomplished his work rapidly.  Forrest wasin his front
column85: but with neither his old-time army nor his old-timeprestige.  He now had principally conscripts.  His conscripts weregenerally old men and boys.  He had a few thousand regular cavalry left
column86: but not enough to even retard materially the progress of Wilson'scavalry.  Selma fell on the 2d of April
column87: with a large number ofprisoners and a large quantity of war material
column88: machine shops
column89: etc.
column90: tobe disposed of by the victors.  Tuscaloosa
column91: Montgomery and West Pointfell in quick succession.  These were all important points to the enemyby reason of their railroad connections
column92: as depots of supplies
column93: andbecause of their manufactories of war material.  They were fortified orintrenched
column94: and there was considerable fighting before they werecaptured.  Macon surrendered on the 21st of April.  Here news wasreceived of the negotiations for the surrender of Johnston's army.Wilson belonged to the military division commanded by Sherman

column98: Georgia

column105: I believe
column106: wanted Mr. Davis to escape

At all events he did not wish to be thejudge to decide whether more should be shed or not.  But his own lifewas sacrificed at the hands of an assassin before the ex-president ofthe Confederacy was a prisoner in the hands of the government which hehad lent all his talent and all his energies to destroy.All things are said to be wisely directed
column109: and for the best interest ofall concerned.  This reflection does not
column110: however

column113: but who stillsought their recognition
column114: and in a short time conceived the idea andadvanced the proposition to become their Moses to lead them triumphantlyout of all their difficulties.The story of the legislation enacted during the reconstruction period tostay the hands of the President is too fresh in the minds of the peopleto be told now.  Much of it

column128: as well as to him

column141: as he has received

column144: ifany

column1: ISFP	 LXX.THE END OF THE WAR--THE MARCH TO WASHINGTON--ONE OF LINCOLN'S ANECDOTES--GRAND REVIEW AT WASHINGTON--CHARACTERISTICS OF LINCOLN AND STANTON--ESTIMATE OF THE DIFFERENT CORPS COMMANDERS.Things began to quiet down
column2: and as the certainty that there would be nomore armed resistance became clearer
column3: the troops in North Carolina andVirginia were ordered to march immediately to the capital
column4: and go intocamp there until mustered out.  Suitable garrisons were left at theprominent places throughout the South to insure obedience to the lawsthat might be enacted for the government of the several States
column5: and toinsure security to the lives and property of all classes.  I do not knowhow far this was necessary
column6: but I deemed it necessary
column7: at that time
column8: that such a course should be pursued.  I think now that these garrisonswere continued after they ceased to be absolutely required; but it isnot to be expected that such a rebellion as was fought between thesections from 1861 to 1865 could terminate without leaving many seriousapprehensions in the mind of the people as to what should be done.Sherman marched his troops from Goldsboro

column11: opposite Richmond
column12: and there put them incamp

column15: Sherman's

column17: containingthis order of Halleck

column26: and to gointo camp on the south side of the city pending the mustering-out of thetroops.There was no incident worth noting in the march northward fromGoldsboro
column27: to Richmond
column28: or in that from Richmond to Washington City.The army
column29: however
column30: commanded by Sherman
column31: which had been engaged in allthe battles of the West and had marched from the Mississippi through theSouthern States to the sea
column32: from there to Goldsboro
column33: and thence toWashington City

column35: thus having seen
column36: to a greater extent than any otherbody of troops
column37: the entire theatre of the four years' war for thepreservation of the Union.The march of Sherman's army from Atlanta to the sea and north toGoldsboro
column38: while it was not accompanied with the danger that wasanticipated
column39: yet was magnificent in its results
column40: and equally magnificentin the way it was conducted.  It had an important bearing
column41: in variousways
column42: upon the great object we had in view
column43: that of closing the war.All the States east of the Mississippi River up to the State of Georgia
column44: had felt the hardships of the war.  Georgia
column45: and South Carolina
column46: andalmost all of North Carolina
column47: up to this time
column48: had been exempt frominvasion by the Northern armies
column49: except upon their immediate sea coasts.Their newspapers had given such an account of Confederate success
column50: thatthe people who remained at home had been convinced that the Yankees hadbeen whipped from first to last
column51: and driven from pillar to post
column52: andthat now they could hardly be holding out for any other purpose than tofind a way out of the war with honor to themselves.Even during this march of Sherman's the newspapers in his front wereproclaiming daily that his army was nothing better than a mob of men whowere frightened out of their wits and hastening
column53: panic-stricken
column54: to tryto get under the cover of our navy for protection against the Southernpeople.  As the army was seen marching on triumphantly
column55: however
column56: theminds of the people became disabused and they saw the true state ofaffairs.  In turn they became disheartened
column57: and would have been glad tosubmit without compromise.Another great advantage resulting from this march
column58: and which wascalculated to hasten the end
