column60: the destruction of the railroads in SouthCarolina and the southern part of North Carolina
column61: further cut off theirresources and left the armies still in Virginia and North Carolinadependent for supplies upon a very small area of country
column62: already verymuch exhausted of food and forage.In due time the two armies
column63: one from Burkesville Junction and the otherfrom the neighborhood of Raleigh
column64: North Carolina
column65: arrived and went intocamp near the Capital
column66: as directed.  The troops were hardy
column67: being inuredto fatigue
column68: and they appeared in their respective camps as ready and fitfor duty as they had ever been in their lives.  I doubt whether an equalbody of men of any nation
column69: take them man for man
column70: officer for officer
column71: was ever gotten together that would have proved their equal in a greatbattle.The armies of Europe are machines; the men are brave and the officerscapable; but the majority of the soldiers in most of the nations ofEurope are taken from a class of people who are not very intelligent andwho have very little interest in the contest in which they are calledupon to take part.  Our armies were composed of men who were able toread
column72: men who knew what they were fighting for
column73: and could not be inducedto serve as soldiers
column74: except in an emergency when the safety of thenation was involved
column75: and so necessarily must have been more than equalto men who fought merely because they were brave and because they werethoroughly drilled and inured to hardships.There was nothing of particular importance occurred during the timethese troops were in camp before starting North.I remember one little incident which I will relate as an anecdotecharacteristic of Mr. Lincoln.  It occurred a day after I reachedWashington
column76: and about the time General Meade reached Burkesville withthe army.  Governor Smith of Virginia had left Richmond with theConfederate States government
column77: and had gone to Danville.  Supposing Iwas necessarily with the army at Burkesville
column78: he addressed a letter tome there informing me that
column79: as governor of the Commonwealth of the Stateof Virginia
column80: he had temporarily removed the State capital from Richmondto Danville
column81: and asking if he would be permitted to perform thefunctions of his office there without molestation by the Federalauthorities.  I give this letter only in substance.  He also inquired ofme whether in case he was not allowed to perform the duties of hisoffice
column82: he with a few others might not be permitted to leave the countryand go abroad without interference.  General Meade being informed that aflag of truce was outside his pickets with a letter to me
column83: at once sentout and had the letter brought in without informing the officer whobrought it that I was not present.  He read the letter and telegraphedme its contents. Meeting Mr. Lincoln shortly after receiving thisdispatch
column84: I repeated its contents to him.  Mr. Lincoln
column85: supposing I wasasking for instructions
column86: said
column87: in reply to that part of Governor Smith'sletter which inquired whether he with a few friends would be permittedto leave the country unmolested
column88: that his position was like that of acertain Irishman (giving the name) he knew in Springfield who was verypopular with the people
column89: a man of considerable promise
column90: and very muchliked.  Unfortunately he had acquired the habit of drinking
column91: and hisfriends could see that the habit was growing on him.  These friendsdetermined to make an effort to save him
column92: and to do this they drew up apledge to abstain from all alcoholic drinks.  They asked Pat to jointhem in signing the pledge
column93: and he consented.  He had been so long outof the habit of using plain water as a beverage that he resorted tosoda-water as a substitute.  After a few days this began to growdistasteful to him.  So holding the glass behind him
column94: he said:  'Doctor
column95: couldn't you drop a bit of brandy in that unbeknownst to myself.'I do not remember what the instructions were the President gave me
column96: butI know that Governor Smith was not permitted to perform the duties ofhis office.  I also know that if Mr. Lincoln had been spared
column97: therewould have been no efforts made to prevent any one from leaving thecountry who desired to do so.  He would have been equally willing topermit the return of the same expatriated citizens after they had timeto repent of their choice.On the 18th of May orders were issued by the adjutant-general for agrand review by the President and his cabinet of Sherman's and Meade'sarmies.  The review commenced on the 23d and lasted two days.  Meade'sarmy occupied over six hours of the first day in passing the grand standwhich had been erected in front of the President's house.  Shermanwitnessed this review from the grand stand which was occupied by thePresident and his cabinet.  Here he showed his resentment for the crueland harsh treatment that had unnecessarily been inflicted upon him bythe Secretary of War
column98: by refusing to take his extended hand.Sherman's troops had been in camp on the south side of the Potomac.During the night of the 23d he crossed over and bivouacked not far fromthe Capitol.  Promptly at ten o'clock on the morning of the 24th
column99: histroops commenced to pass in review.  Sherman's army made a differentappearance from that of the Army of the Potomac.  The latter had beenoperating where they received directly from the North full supplies offood and clothing regularly:  the review of this army therefore was thereview of a body of 65
column100: 000 well-drilled
column101: well-disciplined and orderlysoldiers inured to hardship and fit for any duty
column102: but without theexperience of gathering their own food and supplies in an enemy'scountry
column103: and of being ever on the watch. Sherman's army was not sowell-dressed as the Army of the Potomac
column104: but their marching could notbe excelled; they gave the appearance of men who had been thoroughlydrilled to endure hardships
column105: either by long and continuous marches orthrough exposure to any climate
column106: without the ordinary shelter of a camp.They exhibited also some of the order of march through Georgia where the'sweet potatoes sprung up from the ground' as Sherman's army wentmarching through.  In the rear of a company there would be a capturedhorse or mule loaded with small cooking utensils
column107: captured chickens andother food picked up for the use of the men.  Negro families who hadfollowed the army would sometimes come along in the rear of a company
column108: with three or four children packed upon a single mule
column109: and the motherleading it.The sight was varied and grand:  nearly all day for two successive days
column110: from the Capitol to the Treasury Building
column111: could be seen a mass oforderly soldiers marching in columns of companies.  The National flagwas flying from almost every house and store; the windows were filledwith spectators; the door-steps and side-walks were crowded with coloredpeople and poor whites who did not succeed in securing better quartersfrom which to get a view of the grand armies.  The city was about asfull of strangers who had come to see the sights as it usually is oninauguration day when a new President takes his seat.It may not be out of place to again allude to President Lincoln and theSecretary of War
column112: Mr. Stanton
column113: who were the great conspicuous figures inthe executive branch of the government. There is no great difference ofopinion now
column114: in the public mind
column115: as to the characteristics of thePresident.  With Mr. Stanton the case is different.  They were the veryopposite of each other in almost every particular
column116: except that eachpossessed great ability.  Mr. Lincoln gained influence over men bymaking them feel that it was a pleasure to serve him.  He preferredyielding his own wish to gratify others
column117: rather than to insist uponhaving his own way.  It distressed him to disappoint others.  In mattersof public duty
column118: however
column119: he had what he wished
column120: but in the leastoffensive way.  Mr. Stanton never questioned his own authority tocommand
column121: unless resisted.  He cared nothing for the feeling of others.In fact it seemed to be pleasanter to him to disappoint than to gratify.He felt no hesitation in assuming the functions of the executive
column122: or inacting without advising with him.  If his act was not sustained
column123: hewould change it--if he saw the matter would be followed up until he didso.It was generally supposed that these two officials formed the complementof each other.  The Secretary was required to prevent the President'sbeing imposed upon.  The President was required in the more responsibleplace of seeing that injustice was not done to others.  I do not knowthat this view of these two men is still entertained by the majority ofthe people.  It is not a correct view
column124: however
column125: in my estimation.  Mr.Lincoln did not require a guardian to aid him in the fulfilment of apublic trust.Mr. Lincoln was not timid
column126: and he was willing to trust his generals inmaking and executing their plans.  The Secretary was very timid
column127: and itwas impossible for him to avoid interfering with the armies covering thecapital when it was sought to defend it by an offensive movement againstthe army guarding the Confederate capital.  He could see our weakness
column128: but he could not see that the enemy was in danger.  The enemy would nothave been in danger if Mr. Stanton had been in the field.  Thesecharacteristics of the two officials were clearly shown shortly afterEarly came so near getting into the capital.Among the army and corps commanders who served with me during the warbetween the States
column129: and who attracted much public attention
column130: but ofwhose ability as soldiers I have not yet given any estimate
column131: are Meade
column132: Hancock
column133: Sedgwick
column134: Burnside
column135: Terry and Hooker.  There were others ofgreat merit
column136: such as Griffin
column137: Humphreys
column138: Wright and Mackenzie.  Of thosefirst named
column139: Burnside at one time had command of the Army of thePotomac
column140: and later of the Army of the Ohio.  Hooker also commanded theArmy of the Potomac for a short time.General Meade was an officer of great merit
column141: with drawbacks to hisusefulness that were beyond his control.  He had been an officer of theengineer corps before the war
column142: and consequently had never served withtroops until he was over forty-six years of age.  He never had
column143: Ibelieve
column144: a command of less than a brigade.  He saw clearly anddistinctly the position of the enemy
column145: and the topography of the countryin front of his own position.  His first idea was to take advantage ofthe lay of the ground
column146: sometimes without reference to the direction wewanted to move afterwards.  He was subordinate to his superiors in rankto the extent that he could execute an order which changed his own planswith the same zeal he would have displayed if the plan had been his own.He was brave and conscientious
column147: and commanded the respect of all whoknew him.  He was unfortunately of a temper that would get beyond hiscontrol
column148: at times
column149: and make him speak to officers of high rank in themost offensive manner.  No one saw this fault more plainly than hehimself
column150: and no one regretted it more.  This made it unpleasant attimes
column151: even in battle
column152: for those around him to approach him even withinformation.  In spite of this defect he was a most valuable officer anddeserves a high place in the annals of his country.General Burnside was an officer who was generally liked and respected.He was not
column153: however
column154: fitted to command an army.  No one knew this betterthan himself.  He always admitted his blunders
column155: and extenuated those ofofficers under him beyond what they were entitled to.  It was hardly hisfault that he was ever assigned to a separate command.Of Hooker I saw but little during the war.  I had known him very wellbefore
column156: however.  Where I did see him
column157: at Chattanooga
column158: his achievementin bringing his command around the point of Lookout Mountain and intoChattanooga Valley was brilliant.  I nevertheless regarded him as adangerous man.  He was not subordinate to his superiors.  He wasambitious to the extent of caring nothing for the rights of others.  Hisdisposition was
column159: when engaged in battle
column160: to get detached from the mainbody of the army and exercise a separate command
column161: gathering to hisstandard all he could of his juniors.Hancock stands the most conspicuous figure of all the general officerswho did not exercise a separate command.  He commanded a corps longerthan any other one
column162: and his name was never mentioned as having committedin battle a blunder for which he was responsible.  He was a man of veryconspicuous personal appearance.  Tall
column163: well-formed and
column164: at the time ofwhich I now write
column165: young and fresh-looking
column166: he presented an appearancethat would attract the attention of an army as he passed.  His genialdisposition made him friends
column167: and his personal courage and his presencewith his command in the thickest of the fight won for him the confidenceof troops serving under him.  No matter how hard the fight
column168: the 2d corpsalways felt that their commander was looking after them.Sedgwick was killed at Spottsylvania before I had an opportunity offorming an estimate of his qualifications as a soldier from personalobservation.  I had known him in Mexico when both of us werelieutenants
column169: and when our service gave no indication that either of uswould ever be equal to the command of a brigade. He stood very high inthe army
column170: however
column171: as an officer and a man. He was brave andconscientious.  His ambition was not great
column172: and he seemed to dreadresponsibility.  He was willing to do any amount of battling
column173: but alwayswanted some one else to direct. He declined the command of the Army ofthe Potomac once
column174: if not oftener.General Alfred H. Terry came into the army as a volunteer without amilitary education.  His way was won without political influence up toan important separate command--the expedition against Fort Fisher
column175: inJanuary
column176: 1865.  His success there was most brilliant
column177: and won for himthe rank of brigadier-general in the regular army and of major-generalof volunteers.  He is a man who makes friends of those under him by hisconsideration of their wants and their dues.  As a commander
column178: he wontheir confidence by his coolness in action and by his clearness ofperception in taking in the situation under which he was placed at anygiven time.Griffin
column179: Humphreys
column180: and Mackenzie were good corps commanders
column181: but cameinto that position so near to the close of the war as not to attractpublic attention.  All three served as such
column182: in the last campaign of thearmies of the Potomac and the James
column183: which culminated at AppomattoxCourt House
column184: on the 9th of April
column185: 1865.  The sudden collapse of therebellion monopolized attention to the exclusion of almost everythingelse.  I regarded Mackenzie as the most promising young officer in thearmy.  Graduating at West Point
column186: as he did
column187: during the second year ofthe war
column188: he had won his way up to the command of a corps before itsclose.  This he did upon his own merit and without influence.CONCLUSION.The cause of the great War of the Rebellion against the United Statuswill have to be attributed to slavery.  For some years before the warbegan it was a trite saying among some politicians that 'A state halfslave and half free cannot exist.'  All must become slave or all free
column189: or the state will go down.  I took no part myself in any such view ofthe case at the time
column190: but since the war is over
column191: reviewing the wholequestion
column192: I have come to the conclusion that the saying is quite true.Slavery was an institution that required unusual guarantees for itssecurity wherever it existed; and in a country like ours where thelarger portion of it was free territory inhabited by an intelligent andwell-to-do population
column193: the people would naturally have but littlesympathy with demands upon them for its protection.  Hence the people ofthe South were dependent upon keeping control of the general governmentto secure the perpetuation of their favorite institution.  They wereenabled to maintain this control long after the States where slaveryexisted had ceased to have the controlling power
column194: through the assistancethey received from odd men here and there throughout the NorthernStates.  They saw their power waning
column195: and this led them to encroach uponthe prerogatives and independence of the Northern States by enactingsuch laws as the Fugitive Slave Law.  By this law every Northern manwas obliged
column196: when properly summoned
column197: to turn out and help apprehendthe runaway slave of a Southern man.  Northern marshals becameslave-catchers
column198: and Northern courts had to contribute to the supportand protection of the institution.This was a degradation which the North would not permit any longer thanuntil they could get the power to expunge such laws from the statutebooks.  Prior to the time of these encroachments the great majority ofthe people of the North had no particular quarrel with slavery
column199: so longas they were not forced to have it themselves.  But they were notwilling to play the role of police for the South in the protection ofthis particular institution.In the early days of the country
column200: before we had railroads
column201: telegraphsand steamboats--in a word
column202: rapid transit of any sort--the States wereeach almost a separate nationality.  At that time the subject of slaverycaused but little or no disturbance to the public mind.  But the countrygrew
column203: rapid transit was established
column204: and trade and commerce between theStates got to be so much greater than before
column205: that the power of theNational government became more felt and recognized and
column206: therefore
column207: hadto be enlisted in the cause of this institution.It is probably well that we had the war when we did.  We are better offnow than we would have been without it
column208: and have made more rapidprogress than we otherwise should have made.  The civilized nations ofEurope have been stimulated into unusual activity
column209: so that commerce
column210: trade
column211: travel
column212: and thorough acquaintance among people of differentnationalities
column213: has become common; whereas
column214: before
column215: it was but the fewwho had ever had the privilege of going beyond the limits of their owncountry or who knew anything about other people.  Then
column216: too
column217: ourrepublican institutions were regarded as experiments up to the breakingout of the rebellion
column218: and monarchical Europe generally believed that ourrepublic was a rope of sand that would part the moment the slighteststrain was brought upon it.  Now it has shown itself capable of dealingwith one of the greatest wars that was ever made
column219: and our people haveproven themselves to be the most formidable in war of any nationality.But this war was a fearful lesson
column220: and should teach us the necessity ofavoiding wars in the future.The conduct of some of the European states during our troubles shows thelack of conscience of communities where the responsibility does not comeupon a single individual.  Seeing a nation that extended from ocean toocean
column221: embracing the better part of a continent
column222: growing as we weregrowing in population
column223: wealth and intelligence
column224: the European nationsthought it would be well to give us a check.  We might
column225: possibly
column226: aftera while threaten their peace
column227: or
column228: at least
column229: the perpetuity of theirinstitutions.  Hence
column230: England was constantly finding fault with theadministration at Washington because we were not able to keep up aneffective blockade.  She also joined
column231: at first
column232: with France and Spain insetting up an Austrian prince upon the throne in Mexico
column233: totallydisregarding any rights or claims that Mexico had of being treated as anindependent power.  It is true they trumped up grievances as a pretext
column234: but they were only pretexts which can always be found when wanted.Mexico
column235: in her various revolutions
column236: had been unable to give thatprotection to the subjects of foreign nations which she would have likedto give
column237: and some of her revolutionary leaders had forced loans fromthem.  Under pretence of protecting their citizens
column238: these nations seizedupon Mexico as a foothold for establishing a European monarchy upon ourcontinent
column239: thus threatening our peace at home.  I
column240: myself

column93: so indiscreetas to print scurrilous reflections on the government of neighboringstates
column94: and even on the conduct of our best national allies

column97: but refuse steadily
column98: as they may see by my example that such a course of conduct will not
column99: on the whole
column100: be injurious to their interests.In 1733 I sent one of my journeymen to Charleston

column107: tho' he sometimes made me remittances
column108: I could getno account from him
column109: nor any satisfactory state of our partnershipwhile he lived.  On his decease
column110: the business was continued byhis widow
column111: who
column112: being born and bred in Holland
column113: where
column114: as I have beeninform'd
column115: the knowledge of accounts makes a part of female education
column116: she not only sent me as clear a state as she could find of thetransactions past

column121: at the expiration of the term

column123: and establish her son in it.I mention this affair chiefly for the sake of recommending that branchof education for our young females

column125: in case of widowhood

column127: by preserving them from losses by imposition of crafty men
column128: and enabling them to continue
column129: perhaps
column130: a profitable mercantile house
column131: with establish'd correspondence
column132: till a son is grown up fit to undertakeand go on with it
column133: to the lasting advantage and enriching of the family.About the year 1734 there arrived among us from Ireland a youngPresbyterian preacher

column146: of our congregation

column154: tho'an elegant preacher

column162: and I question whether a single copy of them now exists.During the contest an unlucky occurrence hurt his cause exceedingly.One of our adversaries having heard him preach a sermon that wasmuch admired

column173: that his memory was suchas enabled him to retain and repeat any sermon after one reading only.On our defeat

column176: never joining it after
column177: tho' I continu'dmany years my subscription for the support of its ministers.I had begun in 1733 to study languages; I soon made myself so mucha master of the French as to be able to read the books with ease.I then undertook the Italian.  An acquaintance

column200: as those preceding languages had greatly smooth'd my way.From these circumstances

column203: having acquir'd that

column216: tho'
column217: after spending the same time

column220: however
column221: have acquired another tongue or two
column222: that
column223: being in modern use
column224: might be serviceable to them in common life.After ten years' absence from Boston

column232: in case of his death

column234: I would take home his son

column245: and that
column246: therefore
column247: the safer shouldbe chosen.Our club
column248: the Junto
column249: was found so useful
column250: and afforded such satisfactionto the members

column257: perhaps

column260: instead of it

column276: the Band

column282: in some considerable degree

column284: of which I shall give some instancesin course of time as they happened.My first promotion was my being chosen

column288: like that of the members

column292: however
column293: chosen

column296: besides the pay for the immediate service as clerk

column303: on the whole
column304: were very profitable.I therefore did not like the opposition of this new member

column307: in time
column308: great influence in the House
column309: which
column310: indeed
column311: afterwards happened.  I did not
column312: however

column315: after some time

column327: 'He that has once done you a kindness will be moreready to do you another

column330: return
column331: and continue inimical proceedings.In 1737
column332: Colonel Spotswood
column333: late governor of Virginia
column334: and thenpostmaster-general
column335: being dissatisfied with the conduct of hisdeputy at Philadelphia
column336: respecting some negligence in rendering
column337: and inexactitude of his accounts

column340: tho' the salary was small
column341: it facilitated the correspondencethat improv'd my newspaper

column343: as wellas the advertisements to be inserted

column347: to permit my papers being carried by the riders.Thus he suffer'd greatly from his neglect in due accounting; and Imention it as a lesson to those young men who may be employ'd inmanaging affairs for others
column348: that they should always render accounts
column349: and make remittances
column350: with great clearness and punctuality.The character of observing such a conduct is the most powerfulof all recommendations to new employments and increase of business.I began now to turn my thoughts a little to public affairs
column351: beginning
column352: however
column353: with small matters.  The city watch wasone of the first things that I conceiv'd to want regulation.It was managed by the constables of the respective wards in turn;the constable warned a number of housekeepers to attend him forthe night.  Those who chose never to attend paid him six shillingsa year to be excus'd
column354: which was suppos'd to be for hiring substitutes
column355: but was
column356: in reality
column357: much more than was necessary for that purpose
column358: and made the constableship a place of profit; and the constable
column359: for a little drink
column360: often got such ragamuffins about him as a watch
column361: that respectable housekeepers did not choose to mix with.Walking the rounds
column362: too
column363: was often neglected
column364: and most of the nightsspent in tippling.  I thereupon wrote a paper
column365: to be read in Junto
column366: representing these irregularities
column367: but insisting more particularlyon the inequality of this six-shilling tax of the constables
column368: respecting the circumstances of those who paid it
column369: since a poorwidow housekeeper
column370: all whose property to be guarded by the watchdid not perhaps exceed the value of fifty pounds
column371: paid as much asthe wealthiest merchant
column372: who had thousands of pounds worth of goodsin his stores.On the whole
column373: I proposed as a more effectual watch
column374: the hiringof proper men to serve constantly in that business; and as a moreequitable way of supporting the charge the levying a tax thatshould be proportion'd to the property.  This idea
column375: being approv'dby the Junto
column376: was communicated to the other clubs
column377: but as arisingin each of them; and though the plan was not immediately carriedinto execution
column378: yet
column379: by preparing the minds of people for the change
column380: it paved the way for the law obtained a few years after
column381: when the members of our clubs were grown into more influence.About this time I wrote a paper (first to be read in Junto
column382: but itwas afterward publish'd) on the different accidents and carelessnessesby which houses were set on fire
column383: with cautions against them
column384: and means proposed of avoiding them.  This was much spoken of as auseful piece

column387: of forming a company for the more ready extinguishing of fires

column389: amounting to thirty.Our articles of agreement oblig'd every member to keep always ingood order
column391: a certain number of leather buckets
column392: with strong bags and baskets (for packing and transporting of goods)

column394: in discoursing andcommunicating such ideas as occurred to us upon the subject of fires

column396: and many more desiringto be admitted than we thought convenient for one company
column398: which was accordingly done; and this went on
column399: one new company being formed after another
column400: till they became so numerousas to include most of the inhabitants who were men of property;and now
column401: at the time of my writing this
column402: tho' upward of fifty yearssince its establishment
column406: tho' the first membersare all deceas'd but myself and one
column407: who is older by a year than I am.The small fines that have been paid by members for absence at the monthlymeetings have been apply'd to the purchase of fire-engines
column410: and other useful implements for each company
column411: so that Iquestion whether there is a city in the world better provided withthe means of putting a stop to beginning conflagrations; and
column414: the city has never lost by fire morethan one or two houses at a time
column415: and the flames have often beenextinguished before the house in which they began has been half consumed.In 1739 arrived among us from Ireland the Reverend Mr. Whitefield
column416: who had made himself remarkable there as an itinerant preacher.He was at first permitted to preach in some of our churches;but the clergy
column419: and he was oblig'd to preach in the fields.  The multitudes of allsects and denominations that attended his sermons were enormous
column420: and it was matter of speculation to me
column421: who was one of the number
column422: to observe the extraordinary influence of his oratory on his hearers
column423: and how much they admir'd and respected him
column425: by assuring them that they were naturally halfbeasts and half devils.  It was wonderful to see the change soonmade in the manners of our inhabitants.  From being thoughtlessor indifferent about religion
column426: it seem'd as if all the worldwere growing religious
column427: so that one could not walk thro' the townin an evening without hearing psalms sung in different families ofevery street.And it being found inconvenient to assemble in the open air
column429: the building of a house to meet in wasno sooner propos'd
column430: and persons appointed to receive contributions
column431: but sufficient sums were soon receiv'd to procure the ground and erectthe building
column432: which was one hundred feet long and seventy broad
column433: about the size of Westminster Hall; and the work was carried onwith such spirit as to be finished in a much shorter time than couldhave been expected.  Both house and ground were vested in trustees
column434: expressly for the use of any preacher of any religious persuasionwho might desire to say something to the people at Philadelphia;the design in building not being to accommodate any particular sect
column435: but the inhabitants in general; so that even if the Mufti ofConstantinople were to send a missionary to preach Mohammedanism to us
column436: he would find a pulpit at his service.Mr. Whitefield
column438: went preaching all the way thro'the colonies to Georgia.  The settlement of that provincehad lately been begun
column440: instead of being made with hardy
column443: the only people fitfor such an enterprise
column444: it was with families of broken shop-keepersand other insolvent debtors
column445: many of indolent and idle habits
column448: being set down in the woods
column450: and unable to endure the hardships of a new settlement
column452: leaving many helpless children unprovided for.The sight of their miserable situation inspir'd the benevolent heartof Mr. Whitefield with the idea of building an Orphan House there
column453: in which they might be supported and educated.  Returning northward
column456: for his eloquence had a wonderful power over the hearts and pursesof his hearers
column457: of which I myself was an instance.I did not disapprove of the design
column459: as Georgia was thendestitute of materials and workmen
column460: and it was proposed to sendthem from Philadelphia at a great expense

column462: and brought the childrento it.  This I advis'd; but he was resolute in his first project
column464: and I therefore refus'd to contribute.I happened soon after to attend one of his sermons
column465: in the courseof which I perceived he intended to finish with a collection
column466: and I silently resolved he should get nothing from me
column467: I had in mypocket a handful of copper money
column469: and five pistoles in gold.  As he proceeded I began to soften
column470: and concluded to give the coppers.  Another stroke of his oratorymade me asham'd of that
column471: and determin'd me to give the silver;and he finish'd so admirably
column472: that I empty'd my pocket wholly intothe collector's dish
column473: gold and all.  At this sermon there was alsoone of our club
column475: being of my sentiments respecting the buildingin Georgia
column476: and suspecting a collection might be intended
column479: emptied his pockets before he came from home.Towards the conclusion of the discourse
column481: he felt a strongdesire to give
column484: to borrow some money for the purpose.  The application wasunfortunately [made] to perhaps the only man in the company who hadthe firmness not to be affected by the preacher.  His answer was
column487: I would lend to thee freely;but not now
column488: for thee seems to be out of thy right senses.'Some of Mr. Whitefield's enemies affected to suppose that he wouldapply these collections to his own private emolument; but I who wasintimately acquainted with him (being employed in printing his Sermonsand Journals
column490: never had the least suspicion of his integrity
column491: but am to this day decidedly of opinion that he was in all his conducta perfectly honest man
column492: and methinks my testimony in his favourought to have the more weight
column493: as we had no religious connection.He us'd
column495: sometimes to pray for my conversion
column496: but neverhad the satisfaction of believing that his prayers were heard.Ours was a mere civil friendship
column498: and lastedto his death.The following instance will show something of the terms on whichwe stood.  Upon one of his arrivals from England at Boston
column499: he wrote to me that he should come soon to Philadelphia
column500: but knew not where he could lodge when there
column501: as he understoodhis old friend and host
column503: was removed to Germantown.My answer was
column504: 'You know my house; if you can make shift withits scanty accommodations
column505: you will be most heartily welcome.'He reply'd
column506: that if I made that kind offer for Christ's sake
column507: I should not miss of a reward.  And I returned
column508: 'Don't let mebe mistaken; it was not for Christ's sake
column509: but for your sake.'One of our common acquaintance jocosely remark'd
column511: knowing itto be the custom of the saints
column513: to shift the burden of the obligation from off their own shoulders
column515: I had contriv'd to fix it on earth.The last time I saw Mr. Whitefield was in London
column516: when he consultedme about his Orphan House concern
column517: and his purpose of appropriatingit to the establishment of a college.He had a loud and clear voice
column518: and articulated his words andsentences so perfectly
column519: that he might be heard and understood ata great distance
column522: observ'd the most exact silence.  He preach'd one evening from the topof the Court-house steps
column523: which are in the middle of Market-street
column524: and on the west side of Second-street
column525: which crosses it at right angles.Both streets were fill'd with his hearers to a considerable distance.Being among the hindmost in Market-street
column526: I had the curiosityto learn how far he could be heard
column527: by retiring backwards downthe street towards the river; and I found his voice distinct till Icame near Front-street
column528: when some noise in that street obscur'd it.Imagining then a semi-circle
column529: of which my distance should be the radius
column530: and that it were fill'd with auditors
column531: to each of whom I allow'dtwo square feet
column532: I computed that he might well be heard by morethan thirty thousand.  This reconcil'd me to the newspaper accountsof his having preach'd to twenty-five thousand people in the fields
column533: and to the antient histories of generals haranguing whole armies
column534: of which I had sometimes doubted.By hearing him often
column535: I came to distinguish easily between sermonsnewly compos'd
column536: and those which he had often preach'd in the courseof his travels.  His delivery of the latter was so improv'd by frequentrepetitions that every accent
column539: was so perfectly well turn'd and well plac'd
column541: without being interested in the subject
column542: one could not help beingpleas'd with the discourse; a pleasure of much the same kind with thatreceiv'd from an excellent piece of musick.  This is an advantageitinerant preachers have over those who are stationary
column543: as the lattercan not well improve their delivery of a sermon by so many rehearsals.His writing and printing from time to time gave great advantageto his enemies; unguarded expressions
column546: might have been afterwards explain'dor qualifi'd by supposing others that might have accompani'd them
column547: or they might have been deny'd; but litera scripta monet.Critics attack'd his writings violently
column548: and with so much appearanceof reason as to diminish the number of his votaries and preventtheir encrease; so that I am of opinion if he had never writtenany thing

column552: as there being nothing of hiswriting on which to found a censure and give him a lower character
column553: his proselytes would be left at liberty to feign for him as greata variety of excellence as their enthusiastic admiration might wishhim to have possessed.My business was now continually augmenting
column555: my newspaper having become very profitable
column556: as beingfor a time almost the only one in this and the neighbouring provinces.I experienced
column560: it is more easy to get the second
column561: 'money itself being of a prolific nature.The partnership at Carolina having succeeded

column574: a good deal tothe precaution of having very explicitly settled

column580: and confidence in each other at the timeof the contract

column584: whichare attended often with breach of friendship and of the connection
column585: perhaps with lawsuits and other disagreeable consequences.I had
column587: abundant reason to be satisfied with my beingestablished in Pennsylvania.  There were

column639: which they presented to the companies

column125: therefore
column126: did not readily go out above

column143: these holes being made for another purpose

column152: to Dr. Fothergill
column153: who was among the best men I have known

column156: were never swept
column157: and the light dust carried away;but it was suffer'd to accumulate till wet weather reduc'd it to mud

column164: one morning
column165: a poor woman sweeping my pavement with a birch broom;she appeared very pale and feeble

column173: and sent my servant to examine it

column180: active man might have done it in half the time.And here let me remark the convenience of having but one gutterin such a narrow street
column181: running down its middle
column182: instead of two
column183: one on each side
column184: near the footway; for where all the rain thatfalls on a street runs from the sides and meets in the middle

column190: and sometimes splash it upon those who are walking.  My proposal

column192: was as follows:'For the more effectual cleaning and keeping clean the streets ofLondon and Westminster

column201: shall also carry it all away.'That the mud
column202: when rak'd up

column226: a little absurdly

column1: ISFJ	 VIII.The Saint Ceases Not to Pray.  Prayer the Way to Recover WhatIs Lost.  All Exhorted to Pray.  The Great Advantage of Prayer
column2: Even to Those Who May Have Ceased from It.1. It is not without reason that I have dwelt so long on thisportion of my life.  I see clearly that it will give no onepleasure to see anything so base; and certainly I wish those whomay read this to have me in abhorrence

column1: ISFJ	 IX.The Means Whereby Our Lord Quickened Her Soul
column2: Gave Her Light inHer Darkness
column3: and Made Her Strong in Goodness.1. My soul was now grown weary; and the miserable habits it hadcontracted would not suffer it to rest
column4: though it was desirous ofdoing so.  It came to pass one day
column5: when I went into the oratory

column7: and which hadbeen procured for a certain feast observed in the house.  It wasa representation of Christ most grievously wounded; and sodevotional

column9: when I saw it
column10: movedme--so well did it show forth that which He suffered for us.So keenly did I feel the evil return I had made for those wounds
column11: that I thought my heart was breaking.  I threw myself on theground beside it
column12: my tears flowing plenteously
column13: and implored Himto strengthen me once for all
column14: so that I might never offend Himany more.2. I had a very great devotion to the glorious Magdalene
column15: andvery frequently used to think of her conversion--especially whenI went to Communion.  As I knew for certain that our Lord wasthen within me

column21: before that picture of which I amspeaking
column22: I seem to have made greater progress; for I was nowvery distrustful of myself
column23: placing all my confidence in God.It seems to me that I said to Him then that I would not rise uptill He granted my petition.  I do certainly believe that thiswas of great service to me

column25: I contrived to picture Christ as withinme; [2] and I used to find myself the better for thinking ofthose mysteries of His life during which He was most lonely.It seemed to me that the being alone and afflicted
column26: like a personin trouble
column27: must needs permit me to come near unto Him.5. I did many simple things of this kind; and in particular Iused to find myself most at home in the prayer in the Garden

column29: and of the affliction He endured there; I wished
column30: if it had beenpossible
column31: to wipe away that painful sweat from His face; but Iremember that I never dared to form such a resolution--my sinsstood before me so grievously.  I used to remain with Him thereas long as my thoughts allowed me
column32: and I had many thoughts totorment me.  For many years
column33: nearly every night before I fellasleep
column34: when I recommended myself to God
column35: that I might sleep inpeace

column43: in whichthe understanding makes no reflections
column44: hath this property: thesoul must gain much
column45: or lose.  I mean
column46: that those who advancewithout meditation

column51: that by the help thereof they maythe more quickly recollect themselves.  It was a help to me alsoto look on fields

column53: and flowers. [3] In them I saw tracesof the Creator--I mean
column54: that the sight of these things was as abook unto me; it roused me

column59: unless I saw a thing with my eyes

column63: and looked at pictures of Him.  I waslike one who is blind
column64: or in the dark
column65: who
column66: though speaking to aperson present
column67: and feeling his presence
column68: because he knows forcertain that he is present--I mean

column1: ISFJ	 XXIX.Of Visions.  The Graces Our Lord Bestowed on the Saint.The Answers Our Lord Gave Her for Those Who Tried Her.1. I have wandered far from the subject; for I undertook togive reasons why the vision was no work of the imagination.For how can we
column2: by any efforts of ours
column3: picture to ourselves theHumanity of Christ
column4: and imagine His great beauty?  No little timeis necessary
column5: if our conception is in any way to resemble it.Certainly
column6: the imagination may be able to picture it
column7: and aperson may for a time contemplate that picture
column8: --the form and thebrightness of it
column9: --and gradually make it more perfect
column10: and so layup that image in his memory.  Who can hinder this
column11: seeing that itcould be fashioned by the understanding?  But as to the vision ofwhich I am speaking
column12: there are no means of bringing it about;only we must behold it when our Lord is pleased to present itbefore us
column13: as He wills and what He wills; and there is nopossibility of taking anything away from it
column14: or of addinganything to it; nor is there any way of effecting it
column15: whatever wemay do
column16: nor of seeing it when we like
column17: nor of abstaining fromseeing; if we try to gaze upon it--part of the vision inparticular--the vision of Christ is lost at once.2. For two years and a half God granted me this grace veryfrequently; but it is now more than three years since He hastaken away from me its continual presence
column18: through another of ahigher nature
column19: as I shall perhaps explain hereafter. [1]And though I saw Him speaking to me
column20: and though I wascontemplating His great beauty
column21: and the sweetness with whichthose words of His came forth from His divine mouth
column22: --they weresometimes uttered with severity
column23: --and though I was extremelydesirous to behold the colour of His eyes
column24: or the form of them
column25: so that I might be able to describe them
column26: yet I never attained tothe sight of them
column27: and I could do nothing for that end; on thecontrary
column28: I lost the vision altogether.  And though I see that Helooks upon me at times with great tenderness
column29: yet so strong isHis gaze
column30: that my soul cannot endure it; I fall into a trance sodeep
column31: that I lose the beautiful vision
column32: in order to have agreater fruition of it all.3. Accordingly
column33: willing or not willing
column34: the vision hasnothing to do with it.  Our Lord clearly regards nothing buthumility and confusion of face
column35: the acceptance of what He wishesto give
column36: and the praise of Himself
column37: the Giver.  This is true ofall visions without exception: we can contribute nothing towardsthem--we cannot add to them
column38: nor can we take from them; our ownefforts can neither make nor unmake them.  Our Lord would have ussee most clearly that it is no work of ours
column39: but of His DivineMajesty; we are therefore the less able to be proud of it: on thecontrary
column40: it makes us humble and afraid; for we see that
column41: as ourLord can take from us the power of seeing what we would see
column42: soalso can He take from us these mercies and His grace
column43: and we maybe lost for ever.  We must therefore walk in His fear while weare living in this our exile.4. Our Lord showed Himself to me almost always as He isafter His resurrection.  It was the same in the Host; only atthose times when I was in trouble
column44: and when it was His will tostrengthen me
column45: did He show His wounds.  Sometimes I saw Him onthe cross
column46: in the Garden
column47: crowned with thorns
column48: --but that wasrarely; sometimes also carrying His cross because of mynecessities
column49: --I may say so
column50: --or those of others; but always inHis glorified body.  Many reproaches and many vexations have Iborne while telling this--many suspicions and much persecutionalso.  So certain were they to whom I spoke that I had an evilspirit
column51: that some would have me exorcised.  I did not care muchfor this; but I felt it bitterly when I saw that my confessorswere afraid to hear me
column52: or when I knew that they were told ofanything about me.5. Notwithstanding all this
column53: I never could be sorry that Ihad had these heavenly visions; nor would I exchange even one ofthem for all the wealth and all the pleasures of the world.I always regarded them as a great mercy from our Lord; and to methey were the very greatest treasure
column54: --of this our Lord assuredme often.  I used to go to Him to complain of all thesehardships; and I came away from prayer consoled
column55: and with renewedstrength.  I did not dare to contradict those who were trying me;for I saw that it made matters worse
column56: because they looked on mydoing so as a failure in humility.  I spoke of it to myconfessor; he always consoled me greatly when he saw mein distress.6. As my visions grew in frequency

I used to see them frequently most distinctly on myleft hand; but that vision was not imaginary.  These gloriousSaints were my very good lords.7. It was to me a most painful thing to make a show ofcontempt whenever I saw our Lord in a vision; for when I saw Himbefore me

column1: ISFJ	 XXXIII.The Foundation of the Monastery Hindered.  Our Lord Consolesthe Saint.1. When the matter was in this state--so near its conclusion
column2: that on the very next day the papers were to be signed--then itwas that the Father Provincial changed his mind.  I believe thatthe change was divinely ordered--so it appeared afterwards; forwhile so many prayers were made
column3: our Lord was perfecting His workand arranging its execution in another way.  When the Provincialrefused us
column4: my confessor bade me forthwith to think no more ofit
column5: notwithstanding the great trouble and distress which our Lordknows it cost me to bring it to this state.  When the work wasgiven up and abandoned

column7: although I had until then thiscommandment of my Provincial to justify me.2. I was now very much disliked throughout the whole monastery
column8: because I wished to found another with stricter enclosure.It was said I insulted my sisters; that I could serve God amongthem as well as elsewhere
column9: for there were many among them muchbetter than I; that I did not love the house
column10: and that it wouldhave been better if I had procured greater resources for it thanfor another.  Some said I ought to be put in prison; others--butthey were not many--defended me in some degree.  I saw wellenough that they were for the most part right
column11: and now and then Imade excuses for myself; though
column12: as I could not tell them thechief reason
column13: which was the commandment of our Lord

column22: exceedingly happy andjoyful; though
column23: at the same time

column26: as if I had done anything in the mattercontrary to his will.  Our Lord also must have meant thatsuffering should not fail me there where I should feel it most;and so
column27: amid the multitude of my persecutions
column28: when
column29: as it seemedto me

column37: and I
column38: therefore

column54: and never spoke of those graces to any one.The saintly Dominican [2] was as confident as I was that the workwould be done; and as I would not speak of it

column22: taught of our Lord

column1: ISFJ	 XXXVII.The Effects of the Divine Graces in the Soul.  The InestimableGreatness of One Degree of Glory.1. It is painful to me to recount more of the graces which ourLord gave me than these already spoken of; and they are so many

column3: who has commanded me to do it
column4: [1]and you

column10: in thosegraces which God bestows on the soul

column14: so
column15: in fact
